Paragraph 1:
This is the first part of a multipart series. Read the second part. Once upon a Sunday there was a city mouse who went to visit a country mouse. He hid away on a train the country mouse had told him to take, only to find that on Sundays it did not stop at Beddington. Hence the city mouse could not get off at Beddington and catch a bus for Sibert’s Junction, where he was to be met by the country mouse. The city mouse, in fact, was carried on to Middleburg, where he waited three hours for a train to take him back. When he got back to Beddington he found that the last bus for Sibert’s Junction had just left, so he ran and he ran and he ran and he finally caught the bus and crept aboard, only to find that it was not the bus for Sibert’s Junction at all, but was going in the opposite direction through Pell’s Hollow and Grumm to a place called Wimberby. When the bus finally stopped, the city mouse got out into a heavy rain and found that there were no more buses that night going anywhere. “To the hell with it,” said the city mouse, and he walked back to the city. Moral: Stay where you are, you’re sitting pretty.

Paragraph 2:
In a series of hapless events, the city mouse embarked on a journey to visit his country cousin, only to encounter a string of misfortunes that would test his resolve and patience. Following the country mouse's instructions, he boarded a train bound for Beddington, unaware that it bypassed the station on Sundays. As the train whisked him away to Middleburg, he found himself in a predicament, forced to wait for the next train back to Beddington. Upon his belated arrival, the city mouse's troubles were far from over; he discovered he had missed the last bus to Sibert’s Junction. In his haste, he mistakenly boarded a bus heading in the wrong direction, which unceremoniously deposited him in Wimberby. There, he stood in the pouring rain, stranded with no further transportation options for the night. Frustration mounting, the city mouse faced the harsh reality of his situation and reluctantly decided to make the long trek back to the city on foot. Each step was a reminder of his misadventures, leading him to reflect on the moral of the ordeal: sometimes it is better to stay within the familiar comforts of home rather than venture into the unknown, where unforeseen challenges may await. Thus, the city mouse learned a valuable lesson about the unpredictability of travel and the wisdom of contentment.

While the film's brisk pacing sometimes sacrifices depth for breadth, it successfully captures Williams's extraordinary musical genius and his ability to shape contemporary culture. Throughout the narrative, his talent shines as the driving force, even as the film glosses over some of the more challenging aspects of his journey.

Paragraph 2:

He attributes his floundering to losing sight of his faith, humility and sense of creative playfulness. Yet he came back, eventually, and the film ends with his many creative ventures taking off. He also gained a renewed sense of his own role in the world, crystallized by the film when he co-produces and performs on Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright,” a song that has been used as an anthem at protests against police shootings since its release. All of this is interesting, but it happens quickly. The rhythm of the film emphasizes Williams’s successes far more than his failures, and so the main takeaway from “Piece By Piece” is that Williams is one very talented Lego, er, man.

Paragraph 1:
As you sit at your computer, staring at the login page of a genetic testing website, you can't help but feel a sense of trepidation. You've always known that you were adopted, and that your birth father had chosen to keep his identity a secret. But with the rise of genetic and genealogical databases, you've begun to wonder if it's possible to uncover more about your family history without betraying your birth father's trust. The possibility of discovering a half-sister, perhaps even one who is also searching for answers, is both exhilarating and terrifying. If you were to find her, would you be violating your birth father's desire for secrecy, or would you simply be taking advantage of a resource that's available to anyone? The concept of "double effect," first articulated by Thomas Aquinas, comes to mind - the idea that an action can have two effects, one intended and one unintended. In this case, your intention is to learn more about your own genetic makeup, but the unintended consequence might be revealing your birth father's secret. And yet, as you ponder this dilemma, you can't shake the feeling that you have a right to use these services, just like anyone else. After all, if your half-sister is out there, she may be searching for you too, and may even have already uploaded her own DNA to a database. If that's the case, then it's possible that she'll find you, regardless of whether or not you take the first step. As you weigh your options, it becomes clear that the old rules of secrecy and anonymity no longer apply in the age of genetic testing. Your birth father's expectations, and those of others like him, must adapt to a new reality in which genetic information is increasingly accessible. Ultimately, the decision is yours, but one thing is certain: the landscape of adoption and identity has changed forever, and there's no going back.

Paragraph 2:
But you also envisage a situation in which your half sister discovers your relationship via genetic and genealogical databases. And here’s where things get complicated. You say that in order to preserve your father’s secret, you’ve avoided genetic tests that you otherwise would have wanted to take; you wonder about reconsidering that policy. The fact is that you were always within your rights to take those genetic tests and let the chips fall where they may. How is this consistent with the value of respecting your father’s decision? There’s a principle, usually dated to Thomas Aquinas, known as “double effect.” The idea is that accepting a consequence that is the byproduct of an action is different from pursuing an action intended to bring about that consequence. It’s why the Catholic Church permits medical procedures that are intended to save the life of a pregnant woman even if it ends the viability of the fetus (by removing a cancerous uterus, say). Your right to use one of the services you mention isn’t defeated by the fact that doing so might, as a byproduct, expose your paternity to others. When your father chose a closed adoption, he did not intend to prevent you from availing yourself of genetic and genealogical services he couldn’t then have imagined, and he would not have had the right to do so even if he could. (Sometimes the children of a closed adoption never learn that they were adopted, and so they have no reason to think twice about being genotyped. It’s a contingent fact that you do know.) By not availing yourself of tests that you wanted for other reasons, you went beyond compliance: Rather than passively respecting his agreement, you were, in effect, joining your father’s efforts at concealment. It’s worth observing that not everyone will be on one of these databases, so there’s no guarantee that your half sister will find you this way. But suppose she could. Going on one of these websites now would have one advantage: It might allow her, if she was on the site, to decide for herself whether she was interested in unknown close genetic relatives. The decision to contact you would be left to her. Of course, her first probable response would be to talk to your birth father about the existence of someone who looked like a half sibling, but that’s not on you. Your birth father’s hopes for maintaining his secret must be recalibrated to match a changed reality. In an era of mass-market genomics, it’s hard to hide the twisting branches of our family trees.

Paragraph 1:
My mother crouched in front of me, took my small hands into hers. “Your father is a good man,” she said. I softened a bit, and she continued: “I loved him because he was such a good man. He was so smart, talented and charming. Everybody loved him. And you remind me of him.” Somehow, hearing I was like him was enough. For the moment. But periodically his absence would feel unbearable. Father’s Day, parent-teacher conferences and school sporting events were always the hardest. As a child of the ’90s, I clung to Carl Winslow from “Family Matters,” fantasizing about having a man in my house who would impart words of wisdom, dish out compassionate discipline and look at me with pride. There was a very “blood is thicker than water” energy about my yearning — a notion that my biological father and I would have an inexplicable bond that would heal all my wounds. He would be a compass that would point my life in the right direction and guide me effortlessly into Black manhood.

Paragraph 2:
As my mother crouched before me, her warm hands enveloping mine, she spoke softly about Dad, painting him in gentle strokes of kindness and strength. "You have his eyes," she'd say, "and that same determined spirit." For a fleeting moment, these comparisons wrapped around me like a comfortable blanket, making me feel somehow complete. But the warmth would quickly fade when Father's Day rolled around, or during school events when other kids' dads filled the auditorium seats with proud smiles and camera flashes. Growing up in the '90s, I'd lose myself in episodes of "Family Matters," imagining what it would be like to have someone like Carl Winslow as my father – someone who'd dispense wisdom over breakfast, cheer from the sidelines, and guide me through life's complexities. The void left by my father's absence grew deeper with each passing year, and I couldn't help but wonder if finding him would somehow heal this persistent ache, providing the compass I desperately needed to navigate my way through life.

Famous for its brightly colored beverages, TGI Fridays said its bartenders trained the actor Tom Cruise to make drinks for the 1988 film “Cocktail.” It also takes credit for having popularized the Long Island Iced Tea. Fridays, as the chain is sometimes called, is not the only casual sit-down restaurant chain that has struggled recently. Buca di Beppo, an Italian casual dining chain with more than 80 locations, many in California, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in August. Red Lobster filed for bankruptcy in May and exited Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September, The Associated Press reported.

Paragraph 2:
TGI Fridays, the iconic American casual dining chain that once trained a young Tom Cruise in the art of bartending for the film "Cocktail," is struggling to stay afloat. The chain, which popularized the Long Island Iced Tea, is not alone in its woes. Several other casual dining staples are facing significant challenges. Buca di Beppo, known for its over-the-top Italian-American cuisine, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in August, according to the Associated Press. Red Lobster, another beloved chain, filed for bankruptcy in May but managed to emerge from Chapter 11 protection in September. As the casual dining landscape continues to shift, it remains to be seen which chains will be able to adapt and survive.

Paragraph 1:
In Colorado, where the legalization of marijuana has brought a sense of freedom to many, Robby's reality is far from liberated. Without proper identification, he is unable to purchase the substance that helps alleviate his depression, relying instead on his girlfriend to make the buys. But her role in his life extends far beyond that, as she also drives him to the grocery store and doctor's appointments to pick up antidepressants. However, when Robby loses his job after his company goes bankrupt, his girlfriend reaches her breaking point, leaving him to face the daunting tasks of unemployment and a non-functional, unregistered vehicle alone. As homelessness looms, Robby's mother steps in, using a recent windfall to repair his car, pay off its debt, and rent a small house next to her own. It's a lifeline that offers Robby a chance to regroup and rebuild, a testament to the enduring power of maternal love and a second chance.

Paragraph 2:
En Colorado, como en otros estados que han legalizado la marihuana, si no tienes una licencia de conducir o una identificación equivalente, no puedes comprar marihuana para ayudarte a controlar tu creciente depresión. Necesitas que otra persona —por ejemplo, tu novia— te la compre, conduzca hasta el supermercado para comprar tu comida y te lleve al médico para tratar de conseguir antidepresivos. Ella podría incluso cansarse de las molestias, como si tú las hubieras elegido. Entonces, cuando la empresa para la que trabajas quiebra y te despide, ella también te dirá adiós. Robby estaba sin trabajo, con un vehículo sin matricular y que ahora no funcionaba, y a punto de quedarse sin hogar, pero estaba de suerte. Tenía una madre que se sentía terrible porque sus errores de hacía mucho tiempo le habían causado tanto dolor y además había recibido algo de dinero extra, suficiente para arreglar el auto, pagarlo y alquilar una pequeña casa junto a la de ella, donde él podría quedarse hasta que pudiera arreglar el resto del desastre.

Paragraph 1:
We found ourselves trapped in an endless cycle of resentment at school, where being a middle boy meant navigating treacherous social waters between the juniors and seniors. The juniors despised us for our bullying ways, though we couldn't help but see the irony in their complaints, knowing full well they would step into our shoes the following year. Our relationship with the seniors was even more complicated, tainted by bitter memories of the torment they had inflicted upon us during our junior years. Those seniors, with their perfectly pressed uniforms and liberal application of cologne, carried themselves with an air of superiority that made our blood boil. The social hierarchy reached a boiling point during the year Zaka became head prefect, his appointment seemingly reinforcing the seniors' dominance over us. However, that same year brought an unexpected disruption to the established order when Innocent "Zed" Zvarevashe, one of our own from Middle House, achieved what many thought impossible: he began dating Hester from Mary Ward. This was no small feat, as the Mary Ward girls were considered the cream of the crop, and Hester herself was particularly distinguished, being a brilliant student despite not fitting conventional beauty standards. Zed's relationship with Hester marked the first time a middle boy had managed to date a Mary Ward girl, sending shockwaves through our rigid social hierarchy. This development added another layer of complexity to the already strained relationships between the three groups, as it challenged the seniors' perceived monopoly on social privileges and forced everyone to reconsider the established pecking order.

Paragraph 2:
Caught between the bottom and top ends of the school, the middle boys were disliked by juniors and seniors alike. The juniors hated us because, not to put too fine a point on it, we bullied them. We hated the seniors because when we were in Junior House and they in Middle House they had bullied us. We hated them, they hated us right back, and so rolled the endless cycle of age-based enmity that was as old as Loyola. We had other reasons for despising the seniors. With their crisp white shirts and their knives and forks in the proper hands, they were too superior for anything. It was not uncommon for a Middle House boy to declare, with blithe insouciance, that, as he had swum three or four days before, there was no need for him to take a shower at all that week. So we found their fastidiousness about hygiene irritating. They did utterly pretentious things like splash eau de cologne on letters to girls. The school letter bag reeked of Drakkar Noir and Old Spice. And we envied their easy access to the Mary Wards. In the year that Zaka was head prefect, relations were particularly strained. A top razor named Innocent Zvarevashe, whom we called Zed, had made history by becoming the first Middle House boy ever to be the boyfriend of a Mary Ward. The Mary Ward in question, Hester, was brilliant. Not only was she the first girl to join the Maths Olympiad but she also beat all the boys that year, and took her A-levels a year early. She was far from being the prettiest of the Mary Wards—she had stick-thin legs and large round glasses and wore her hair in what were then called standing buns, pointy antennae that made her look as if she were perpetually waiting to receive alien signals—but she was a Mary Ward, all the same.

Paragraph 1:
The day we planned the trip, I told Louise that I didn't like going to Idaho via the Gallatin Canyon. It's too narrow, and while trucks don't belong on this road, there they are, lots of them. Tourist pulloffs and wild animals on the highway complete the picture. We could have gone by way of Ennis, but Louise had learned that there were road repairs on Montana Highway 84—twelve miles of torn-up asphalt—in addition to its being rodeo weekend, and "Do we have to go to Idaho?" she asked. I said that I thought it was obvious. A lot rode on the success of our little jaunt, which was ostensibly to close the sale of a small car dealership I owned in the sleepy town of Rigby. But, since accepting the offer of a local buyer, I had received a far better one from elsewhere, which, my attorney said, I couldn't take unless my original buyer backed out—and he would only back out if he got sufficiently angry at me. Said my attorney: Make him mad. So I was headed to Rigby, Idaho, expressly to piss off a small-town businessman, who was trying to give me American money for a going concern on the strip east of town, and thereby make room for a rich Atlanta investor, new to our landscapes, who needed this dealership as a kind of flagship for his other intentions. The question was how to provoke Rigby without arousing his suspicions, and I might have collected my thoughts a little better had I not had to battle trucks and tourists in the Gallatin Canyon.

Paragraph 2:
As I prepare for my trip to Idaho with Louise, I'm already dreading the drive through the narrow Gallatin Canyon, a route that's always fraught with anxiety for me. The constant stream of trucks barreling down the highway, the tourist pull-offs that seem to appear out of nowhere, and the ever-present threat of wild animals darting onto the road all combine to make this stretch of road a white-knuckle experience. We had considered taking the alternative route through Ennis, but with road repairs underway and a rodeo event scheduled, it's likely to be just as chaotic. Our destination is Rigby, Idaho, where we're set to finalize the sale of a car dealership, but things have taken a complicated turn. Just as we were about to seal the deal, a better offer came in from another buyer, and now our attorney is advising us to try and get the original buyer to back out by making him angry. It's a delicate balancing act, as I need to provoke him without raising his suspicions, all while navigating the challenges of the road. I'm not looking forward to the drive, but I'm even less enthusiastic about the task that awaits us in Rigby. With Louise by my side, I'll have to muster up the diplomacy and tact to pull off this tricky maneuver, all while keeping my cool in the face of what promises to be a trying journey.

Paragraph 1:
The climate crisis is a tragedy of the commons. So you might think you should take this range out of circulation to ensure that you are not implicated in it. Immanuel Kant might have your back: He thought the right thing to do was to follow a rule that you could, as he put it, will as a universal law. (That law might be: “Avoid participating in the creation of a tragedy.”) On the other hand, standard consequentialists, like the utilitarian John Stuart Mill, thought you should care only about the morally relevant consequences of your acts. They might side with your husband — or, weighing the contribution you could be making to positive social norms, they might not. What resolves things is the health issue you mention. In recent years, concerns have been raised about the nitrogen oxides and other pollutants that gas ranges produce as a result of combustion; some research links cooking with gas to asthma in children. The uncombusted gas that these ranges can leak may also have health consequences. Selling a person something that you know has a serious chance of harming them is wrong. It’s less wrong if you tell them about the risk. (For one thing, using a proper ventilation and exhaust system can mitigate the problem.) Even then, however, if your old range results in harm to its buyers or their children, you’ll have some moral responsibility for it.

Paragraph 2:
As you consider replacing your trusty gas range, you can't help but ponder the ethical implications of your decision. On one hand, Immanuel Kant's deontological ethics would suggest that you have a moral duty to act in accordance with universal laws that prioritize the well-being of the planet and its inhabitants. From this perspective, retiring your gas range would be the right thing to do, given its contribution to the climate crisis and the health risks it poses to your family, particularly your children, who are more susceptible to the nitrogen oxides it produces, which have been linked to asthma. On the other hand, John Stuart Mill's consequentialism would lead you to weigh the outcomes of your actions, considering the potential inconvenience and expense of switching to an electric or induction stove. Your husband might argue that the benefits of a gas range, including its precision and speed, outweigh the costs, but you can't shake the feeling that you have a responsibility to prioritize the greater good. As you deliberate, you must confront the moral complexities of your decision and consider the impact it will have on the world around you. Ultimately, the choice is yours, but it's one that warrants careful consideration of the ethical principles at play.

Paragraph 1:
Time and Space Be Damned
On Halloween, there you were, your face covered in black-and-white makeup, a thin braid splitting your face à la Glenn Danzig, the Misfits’ singer. Who had you been in all our other lives, in which I felt I’d known you? A school-aged boy on the playground, a Mount Kailash guru? I knew you in those past lives, too. A year after Halloween, sans face paint, the question of age — 20 years between us. “Very Woody Allen,” a mom friend commented. But there you were, for the first time and the trillionth, rendering the time and space between inconsequential. — Jacquelin Winter

Paragraph 2:
I first saw them at the Halloween party, their face painted in stark black and white, a single braid hanging down like Glenn Danzig from the Misfits. Something stirred deep within me, a recognition that transcended our current existence. In my mind's eye, I saw them as a schoolboy in knickers, then as a wise guru meditating near Mount Kailash. The connection felt ancient, unbound by time or convention. A year later, when a friend casually remarked "Very Woody Allen" about our twenty-year age gap, I couldn't help but smile. The comment missed the point entirely – our souls had known each other across centuries, making the decades between us seem insignificant in comparison.

Paragraph 1:
No, it’s the fact that he never had a chance to fly and that you never really found those boots and that each time you visited him he seemed to be only slightly better. It’s the fact that when you left him behind, speeding down the road past the old Rockland buildings, boarded up and unused now that most of the mad and crazy are outpatients, medicated, wandering the streets and the homeless shelters, you felt a keen elation. It’s the fact that once again you were joyfully facing the harsh limitations of reality, admitting that it all had to be taken and turned into a story of some kind. Otherwise, it would just be one more expression of precise discontent. And expressions of discontent—you think in the car, sitting in front of your own house now—no matter how beautiful, never solve the riddle of the world, or bring the banality of sequential reality to a location of deeper grace.

Paragraph 2:
As I drive away from him, the man who never soared through the skies as he once dreamed, I find myself lost in contemplation. Each visit brings a slight improvement in his condition, yet it feels like a drop in an endless ocean of longing. Passing the old Rockland buildings, a peculiar sense of elation bubbles within me, a stark contrast to the grim reality we both face. It’s a feeling I can’t quite shake off, even as I park in front of my house. I sit there, grappling with the realization that these experiences must be woven into a narrative, a story that transcends mere expressions of dissatisfaction. Without this transformation, they risk becoming beautifully written, yet ultimately hollow, reflections that fail to unravel life’s mysteries or elevate the mundane. In this moment of introspection, I understand that storytelling is my way of finding meaning, of seeking to grasp the profound amidst the ordinary.

Paragraph 1:
The other welcome news involves the good and the great, the provocative and the divisive movies headed your way in the coming months. Despite the usual grumblings about the program’s offerings (I’ve heard from other programmers that 2024 is a fairly weak year) and a sense that Toronto seems less vital than in the past, this year’s lineup did what it reliably does each fall. It helped restore my faith that however catastrophic the state of the movie industry seems to be, there are always filmmakers making worthy and even transcendent documentaries and narrative fiction. The forecast is often gloomy in movieland, but visionaries like Mati Diop and art-house stalwarts like Mike Leigh and Pedro Almodóvar are keeping the sky from falling. “Dahomey” is a stunning exploration of cultural and artistic patrimony in the wake of colonialism; it’s one of the great movies of the year. (It will be at the New York Film Festival soon.) Running a richly complex, perfect 68 minutes, “Dahomey” opens in Paris and wryly announces its themes with a shot of gaudily colored Eiffel Tower souvenirs of the kind sometimes sold by African street vendors. From there, Diop skips over to the Quai Branly Museum where the treasures — which were looted in 1892 by French troops when Benin was known as Dahomey — are being packed up for their momentous trip home. By the time one of the statues began speaking in bassy, hypnotic voice-over, I was thoroughly hooked.

Paragraph 2:
As I look forward to the upcoming slate of movies, I find myself both intrigued and optimistic, despite some criticisms of this year’s cinematic offerings. The film industry, in my view, is experiencing a renaissance of sorts with filmmakers like Mati Diop, Mike Leigh, and Pedro Almodóvar continuing to push boundaries and deliver significant work. These directors, among others, are keeping my faith alive in the transformative power of cinema. One film that particularly stands out to me is "Dahomey." It's an evocative exploration of cultural and artistic heritage in the post-colonial context. The narrative starts in Paris and includes a powerful scene set at the Quai Branly Museum, where looted treasures from Benin are being carefully prepared for repatriation. This moment is poignant, symbolizing a return and restoration of dignity to a culture long overshadowed by colonial exploitation. My fascination with "Dahomey" was further deepened when a statue in the film began speaking in a deep, mesmerizing voice-over, bridging the gap between the past and present in a way that felt both haunting and enlightening. Through this film, I sense a broader commentary on identity and history, themes that resonate deeply with me. It's films like "Dahomey" that underscore the film industry's potential to provoke thought, challenge perspectives, and ignite meaningful conversations. These cinematic creations remind me why I fell in love with movies in the first place.

Paragraph 1:
I am the youngest of five brothers, each son fading slightly, becoming paler, more flaxen. It was as though our mother were a rubber stamp that was running out of ink—and she was. She always seemed to be weary. All spring, my brothers had been stockpiling the most thankless chores for my return from college. I’d been warned that I would be lugging the drystanes from our old blackhouse and repairing the sheep fank with them. It was lonely, monotonous work. Even in the summer, the scouring Atlantic wind barely ceased its howling. At the end of the day you were likely to be soaked or sunburned or wind-chafed—often all at the same time. Any shite that my brothers did not want to handle, they’d left aside for me. So, when I told them I would not be home for the summer, they each came on the telephone and roared at me, saying I was an ingrate. I could sense that my father was disappointed in me. If he told you that you’d done a fair job then he meant it; his praise could be enough to send you floating for days. But he said nothing when I told him that I was going to London. I love him, but perhaps he does not love me. How could he? I am careful never to be myself around him.

Paragraph 2:
As I reflect on my family, I'm reminded that I'm the youngest of five brothers, and it feels like our collective vitality is slowly dwindling. Our mother, once the glue that held us together, now seems like a rubber stamp running out of ink - still present, but increasingly faint. My brothers, in their infinite wisdom, had been saving the most thankless tasks for my return from college, no doubt thrilled to have an extra pair of hands to share the burden. I was looking forward to a summer of moving stones and repairing a sheep pen, tasks that were as lonely as they were monotonous, made all the more enjoyable by the harsh weather conditions. But when I decided to buck tradition and spend the summer in London instead, my brothers were furious, their anger and accusations of ingratitude ringing in my ears over the phone. What hurt more, though, was my father's silence - his rare praise has always been a precious commodity, and its absence spoke volumes. I couldn't shake the feeling that I'd let him down, and it made me wonder if he truly loved me for who I am. The truth is, I've never been my authentic self around him, always trying to live up to some unspoken expectation, and it's a weight that I'm still trying to shake.

Paragraph 1:
Lera sat quietly, lost in thought, as the car glided through the familiar streets of Bolshaya Cherkizovskaya. The autumn leaves danced in the crisp air, painting the neighborhood in hues of gold and amber, a stark contrast to the somber thoughts occupying her mind. She pondered the whereabouts of a silver cross, once belonging to Grisha's late mother, a relic of the past that seemed to whisper secrets of an era long gone. This curiosity about Grisha’s past was tinged with a sense of nostalgia, as the streets unfolded the story of their early married life, where every corner held a memory, every shadow a whisper of laughter and love. Their old apartment stood as a silent witness to those years, its unchanged facade an emblem of neglect or perhaps an unintentional sanctuary, paused in time amidst the bustling life of the city. Determined to breathe new life into their surroundings, Lera picked up the phone, reaching out to threads of her past. She dialed her aunt in Krasnodar, rekindling a familial bond that had dimmed over time. A call to her friend Lidochka followed, the conversation flowing easily, rekindling warmth and camaraderie. Finally, she contacted Olya, Grisha's cousin's wife, weaving together a tapestry of connections that anchored her to the present. With the decision to renovate the apartment, Lera embarked on a mission to transform the stagnant space into a vibrant home. The first step was replacing the old windows, a task she hoped would invite light and fresh beginnings. When the workers arrived, an air of awkward humor enveloped the apartment. One worker, with a crude sense of humor, made an offhand comment, drawing a chuckle despite Lera's efforts to maintain decorum. Another, with a glint in his eye, casually asked about stronger drinks, breaking the ice with unexpected levity. In that moment, amidst the clatter of tools and the promise of change, Lera felt a renewed sense of purpose. The past was a tapestry of memories, but the future, she realized, was hers to design, one room, one window at a time.

Paragraph 2:
She let the cross drop and reclined in her seat. In what drawer, she wondered, between what set of ironed sheets, would Grisha’s dead mother, with her Komsomol and Party allegiances, have kept this silver cross? Along the main drag of Bolshaya Cherkizovskaya, the trees had lost their leaves, revealing sparse playgrounds with wooden seesaws and painted steel climbing bars between the buildings. Soon they were turning onto their old block of Khrushchev-era low-rises just past the Preobrazhenskoye metro, a neighborhood of durable, identical blocks where they’d spent the first years of their marriage. Little had changed inside. The living room had the same massive lacquered wall unit and textured wallpaper, damaged now by the pencil scrawlings of tenants’ children, the same double curtains of polyester lace and cretonne. Year after year, they had intended to sell the place, waiting first for the market to pick up, then worrying about dishonest agents. Finally, Grisha had simply left it empty for his visits. She could see he hadn’t done anything to the place, that he had probably been waiting for her to arrive and start renovating. The next morning, Lera made phone calls. She called her aunt in Krasnodar, promising to visit before New Year’s, and her old friend Lidochka, who cried from joy that Lera was only three metro stops away. She called Olya, Grisha’s cousin’s wife, who was rushing off to Mamontovka, where she and Kirill were building a kottedzh. Olya apologized that she couldn’t stay on the phone longer, but she needed to get to the suburbs before her work crew took their eighty-proof eyeopener. A few days later, Lera called in her own crew to replace the windows in the apartment. The two men who showed up asked if they could change into their work clothes in the living room. They were still in their underwear when she returned ten minutes later with a plate of cheese and glasses of juice. “We’ll forgive you this time,” one of them said, smiling crudely when she looked at his work boots and bare chest. The other one sniffed the juice and said, “Anything a little stronger, Madam?”

Paragraph 1:
During a heart-to-heart with my daughter, who was in college at the time, she confided that several of her sorority sisters were working as "sugar babies," texting with older men, and she was considering following suit. While I refrained from criticizing her friends' choices, I felt compelled to express my concerns about how such arrangements might affect one's relationship with intimacy and self-worth. I gently reminded her that she already received a comfortable allowance and asked if she'd thought through the emotional implications of commodifying relationships. Rather than forbidding her outright, I posed thoughtful questions about whether the potential financial benefits could justify the psychological risks involved. By maintaining an open dialogue and sharing my perspective while respecting her autonomy, I enabled her to reach her own conclusions about the situation.

Paragraph 2:
⬥ When my daughter was a college student, her sorority sisters texted with older men, as sugar babies. My daughter expressed interest in pursuing the same side hustle. I didn’t judge what her friends were doing, because all parties were consenting adults. But I told her gently that the activity wasn’t supporting, in my personal view, a fully healthy expression of human sexuality. That it was feeding a form of sexual fantasy that could, potentially, lead to negative emotional consequences for either party involved, or both of them. I asked her what she needed the money for. She had a generous allowance. Was the emotional risk worth it for, say, designer handbags or other material goods? Asking her open questions and offering my own perspective allowed my daughter to make her own decision about what to do. — Carmen

Paragraph 1:
Sergeant Noonan and Garda Swift drove up the narrow, winding road that led to the remote rural property, their squad car kicking up a cloud of dust as they approached the low, weathered bungalow nestled amidst the green fields. The farm buildings in the background stood silent and still, casting long shadows in the early evening light. As they parked the vehicle, they noticed a man standing at the entrance, pressing a blood-stained tea towel to his head. The man's appearance was disheveled, with his hair matted down by the blood that seeped from a wound. Noonan and Swift, both seasoned officers from the Ballina Garda Station, exchanged a quick glance, silently communicating their readiness to handle whatever situation awaited them. They stepped out of the car, the crunch of gravel under their boots announcing their arrival. "Good evening," Noonan began, his voice steady and reassuring. "We received a call about an incident here. Does this property belong to the Creedon family?" The man, who introduced himself as Bubbles, nodded, wincing slightly as he adjusted the tea towel on his head. "Yes, it's the Creedon place," Bubbles replied, his voice wavering slightly. "I'm not Bertie Creedon, though. I'm his son." His eyes darted nervously toward the bungalow, then back to the officers. "There's been some trouble," he admitted, his tone carrying a weight of unsaid details. Noonan's gaze softened as he took in the man's obvious distress. "I see you've got a nasty gash there. Let's get that looked at," he suggested, glancing at Swift, who was already moving toward the squad car to retrieve their emergency kit. Bubbles nodded, gratitude evident in his eyes as he took a deep breath, steadying himself. "There's another man inside," Bubbles added, his voice tinged with urgency. "He's in worse condition than me." Swift returned swiftly, the emergency kit in hand, ready to provide whatever assistance was necessary. Noonan and Swift moved with practiced efficiency, their years of experience guiding their actions as they prepared to enter the bungalow and assess the situation fully. The air was tense with anticipation, the tranquility of the rural setting starkly at odds with the unfolding events. As they approached the entrance, Noonan glanced back at the farm buildings, their silent presence a reminder of the isolation of the place. Inside, they knew, awaited the truth of the night's events and the challenge of bringing order to the chaos. With a final nod to Bubbles, they stepped inside, ready to face whatever awaited them, their commitment to duty unwavering in the face of uncertainty.

Paragraph 2:
Presently they found the residence, a low bungalow off a gravel lane, the red galvanized roofs of farm buildings visible at the rear of the property. An enormous, rickety white motor home was stranded in the grass at the front. “Now we’ll see what’s what,” Noonan said. She cut the siren and turned through the concrete posts of the gateless gate. The squad car bounced and lurched as it passed over the rattling bars of a cattle grate. Next to the motor home, there were pieces of outdoor furniture and what looked like a little fire pit dug out of the ground, empty wine bottles planted in the moat of ash surrounding the pit. Scattered elsewhere in the grass were bags of feed, a stripped-down, rusted-out engine block, scraps of tarp, scraps of lumber, metal piping, plastic piping, bits and bits and bits. “Look at all this shit,” Noonan said. “Steady on,” Swift said, nodding ahead. A man had come around the side of the house. He was holding something to his head and his other arm was raised, palm forward. Noonan killed the engine and got out of the squad car, keeping her body behind the door. Swift followed her lead on the other side. “This the Creedon residence?” Noonan asked. “It is, surely,” the man said. He was pressing a stained tea towel of blue-and-white check to his temple. The stains looked like blood. “I’m Sergeant Noonan, out of Ballina Garda Station. This is Garda Swift. You Bertie Creedon?” “Christ, no.” “You’d be the son, then?” “That’s more like it.” “What’s your name?” “I’ve no say in it but every cunt that knows me does call me Bubbles.” Bubbles looked to be in his early thirties. He was stocky, his head shaved close. He was in a faded gray T-shirt with “QUEENS OF THE STONE AGE, ERA VULGARIS” printed on it in a disintegrating white script. There were dark, wet daubs of blood flecking his forearms like tracks left by a bird. “We hear there’s been a spot of bother,” Noonan said. “There has.” “That knock to the head part of the bother?” “A little bit, all right,” Bubbles said, and lifted the towel away from his temple to let them see. There was an open gash above his eyebrow. Noonan whistled. “I wager that needs stitching. I understand there’s another man in a bad way here, too, is that right?” “There is, yeah.” “That his blood on you?” “Some of it, yeah.” “Can you take us to him?” “I can.” “Get the emergency kit,” Noonan said to Swift. Swift popped the boot, took out a bulky, multipocketed bag, and handed it over to Noonan. “Lead the way,” she said, sliding the kit’s strap over her shoulder.

Paragraph 1:
The night was warm and Julian turned in his damp sheets, waking briefly at gray dawn and hearing someone walking, inside and out. When he got up at eight and made coffee, Obie came to the big house’s kitchen door and waited outside the screen looking in, as if knocking were beside the point. “I got a startin’ list for you.” Julian looked up from his coffee. “A list of what?” “Of things to fix the house.” “Come in here.” He took the smudged sheet where he sat at the wobbly table. “Good God, this is over a thousand dollars’ worth of stuff. Where’d you get the prices?” “I borried the phone in the hall.” He shook his head. “That’s too much.” “Delivery is free above a thousand dollars. It’ll save you seven per cent, man said.” Julian saw that Obie was looking at the ceiling, already working in his mind. “Well, what’s on the schedule first?” “Electric wire. Then low-lustre paint for a couple of these rooms.” He smiled, showing big, evenly spaced teeth. “Hide the cracks and raise the spirits.” After the Poxley Lumber Company truck left, Obie began work. By Saturday, the difference in the place was palpable. In the kitchen, he installed a new gray breaker box, and two walls in Julian’s room were patched, sanded, and painted an airy antique white. Julian paid Obie in cash on the next Saturday morning and drove him to Dr. Setumahaven’s office in Poxley, dropping him off and then going shopping. When he picked him up after the treatments, the expression Obie wore was that of a martyr, his eyes misshapen and dark with pain. “You look like a boiled lobster,” Julian told him. Obie gently lowered himself into the passenger seat. “I got my money’s worth today, all right.” They rode along the dusty road without talking, and Julian imagined that he could smell the laser burn. That day, Obie mixed mortar and began patching the first-floor exterior wall.

On a warm morning, Julian awoke to the gentle hum of a day filled with purpose. As he made his way to the kitchen, he found Obie standing at the door, a comprehensive list of repairs clutched in his hand. They had a daunting task ahead: the house needed extensive repairs, and Obie had meticulously calculated the costs, which exceeded a thousand dollars. However, there was a silver lining—orders over that amount qualified for free delivery, which could help them save some money. The two discussed the repair schedule, prioritizing the electrical wiring and painting. With a clear plan in mind, Obie set to work, marking the beginning of their renovation project. By Saturday, the fruits of their labor were evident. The house boasted a new breaker box, ensuring the safety of its electrical system, and the freshly painted walls breathed new life into the space. Julian, appreciating Obie's hard work and dedication, paid him in cash. Following this, he drove Obie to the doctor's office for his treatments. The visit took its toll on Obie, who emerged from the office in visible discomfort, his skin flushed and red, resembling a "boiled lobster." The drive back was marked by a heavy silence, a shared understanding passing between them without the need for words. Despite the pain, Obie's commitment to their project was unwavering. Upon returning, he immediately resumed work, mixing mortar with determination to patch the exterior wall. Julian watched as Obie, despite his physical discomfort, poured his energy into the repair work, a testament to his resilience and dedication. Together, they continued their mission to restore the house, each repair bringing them closer to the vision they shared. The challenges were many, but the progress they made was a reminder of their hard work and collaboration, painting a picture of perseverance and friendship.

Paragraph 1:
Audio: Salman Rushdie reads. Every day, at about four o’clock in the afternoon, when the sun’s heat has begun to diminish, the old man comes into the piazza. He walks slowly, shuffling his feet, which are encased in dusty brown loafers. He is wearing, most days, a dark-blue jacket buttoned all the way up to the neck, and navy pants that fasten with a drawstring at the waist. His hair is white, and there is a beret on his head. He goes to the only café in the piazza, the Café of the Fountain, and sits on a wooden chair at a wooden table and orders a small, strong coffee. At 6 P.M., he orders a beer and a sandwich. At 8 P.M., he rises, wipes his lips, and shuffles away, presumably to his home. We do not need to know where he lives. Everything of any significance in his life has happened and will happen right here, in this little piazza. He takes his seat. He is the audience, an audience of one. The show is about to begin. It is a piazza into which seven narrow roads debouch, one at each corner and one each at the midpoint of three of the piazza’s four sides; only the side with the church is uninterrupted by a cobbled street. It should be a quiet place, a sleepy provincial square, but it is not. All around the piazza you can hear the loud sounds of people quarrelling, six days a week. On most of these days there are more people in the piazza than live in the locality. It’s as if people came here, to this peaceful little square in this peaceful little town, to get into fights. They drive fifteen kilometres from the big city to express their bad moods. They raise their voices; they pound their right fists into the palms of their left hands; they stamp their feet (doesn’t matter which foot—both are stamped equally). If they sit astride motorcycles they sound their horns in frustration, or to drown out their adversaries. If they are arguing while in adjacent motorcars with the windows down, they toot like the motorcyclists but also rev their engines and, when they are irritated beyond the point of endurance, they roll their windows up.

Paragraph 2:
Every afternoon, an old man, distinguished by his slow, deliberate shuffle and his characteristic attire of dusty brown loafers, a dark-blue jacket, navy pants, and a beret perched atop his head of white hair, makes his way to the bustling piazza. This daily ritual is as much a part of the fabric of his life as the well-worn clothes he wears. The piazza, with its deceptively serene name, is anything but quiet; it reverberates with the clamor of city dwellers who converge upon it to give voice to their frustrations and disputes. Yet, amidst this cacophony, the old man remains a silent, solitary witness, an audience of one. His destination is the Café of the Fountain, a quaint establishment nestled at the heart of the piazza. There, he orders his customary coffee, savoring the warmth of the cup in his hands as he settles into his usual spot, a small table by the window that affords him a panoramic view of the lively scene outside. Later, he indulges in a beer and a sandwich, a ritual that marks the passage of the afternoon into early evening. As he sips his coffee and later his beer, the old man observes with quiet detachment the vibrant tapestry of human emotions unfolding before him. Animated conversations escalate into heated arguments, voices rise in fervor, feet stamp emphatically on the cobblestones, and the occasional horn blares from a nearby car, all contributing to the symphony of sounds that define the piazza. Despite the tumultuous atmosphere, the old man remains a figure of calm, his presence a counterpoint to the din surrounding him. It is as if he inhabits a different plane, one where the noise and commotion fail to penetrate the tranquility of his inner world. He has become a fixture of the piazza, a familiar silhouette against the backdrop of the café, his quiet demeanor offering a silent commentary on the lively, often chaotic, tableau that unfolds before him each day. In his quietude, he finds a sense of belonging amidst the discord, a testament to the enduring power of routine and the simple pleasures of observation.

Paragraph 1:
Then I remembered Lawrence’s sensitivity to time and his sentiments and opinions about our feelings for the past. I had heard him say, years ago, that we and our friends and our part of the nation, finding ourselves unable to cope with the problems of the present, had, like a wretched adult, turned back to what we supposed was a happier and a simpler time, and that our taste for reconstruction and candlelight was a measure of this irremediable failure. The faint blue line of chalk had reminded him of these ideas, the scarified door had reinforced them, and now clue after clue presented itself to him—the stern light at the door, the bulk of the chimney, the width of the floorboards and the pieces set into them to resemble pegs. While Lawrence was lecturing me on these frailties, the others came up from the court. As soon as Mother saw Lawrence, she responded, and I saw that there was little hope of any rapport between the matriarch and the changeling. She took Chaddy’s arm. “Let’s go swimming and have Martinis on the beach,” she said. “Let’s have a fabulous morning.” The sea that morning was a solid color, like verd stone. Everyone went to the beach but Tifty and Ruth. “I don’t mind him,” Mother said. She was excited, and she tipped her glass and spilled some gin into the sand. “I don’t mind him. It doesn’t matter to me how *rude *and horrid and *gloomy *he is, but what I can’t bear are the faces of his wretched little children, those fabulously unhappy little children.” With the height of the cliff between us, everyone talked wrathfully about Lawrence; about how he had grown worse instead of better, how unlike the rest of us he was, how he endeavored to spoil every pleasure.

Paragraph 2:
Reflecting on Lawrence's acute sensitivity to the passage of time, I couldn't help but notice his critical stance on nostalgia and the prevalent inability to address current issues. Lawrence, with his penetrating gaze and fervent lectures, lamented how so many, including close friends and a significant portion of our nation, have sought solace in the past, viewing it as a refuge, which to him epitomized a glaring failure. As he expounded on these ideas, others gathered around us, including my mother, Chaddy, Tifty, and Ruth. My mother, upon spotting Lawrence, decisively chose to steer clear of him. Her suggestion to Chaddy about going for a swim and enjoying Martinis on the beach was a clear indication of her discomfort and lack of rapport with Lawrence. Our little group, with the exception of Tifty and Ruth, made our way to the beach. It was there that my mother openly voiced her disdain for Lawrence's behavior, lamenting the unhappiness that seemed to envelop his children. As we settled into the rhythmic sound of the waves, the conversation naturally gravitated towards Lawrence's negative influence on our collective enjoyment. It became increasingly apparent that Lawrence, once a part of our circle, had grown into someone markedly different from us. His constant critiques and the way he seemed to wallow in his own discontent only accentuated the divide. As I observed these interactions and listened to the exchange of opinions, I couldn't shake the feeling that Lawrence's refusal to let go of his critical perspective was not just alienating him from us but also from a shared sense of joy and present living. It was a sobering reminder of how one's outlook on time and nostalgia can profoundly affect relationships and personal happiness.

Every morning, I find myself navigating through winding alleys on my way to the office, dressed in the typical attire of a lawyer—crisp suit, polished shoes, and a determined expression. My routine includes exchanging nods and greetings with fellow lawyers, each of us part of the bustling legal ecosystem. Recently, I moved into a new office at Tis Hazari, marking the occasion with a traditional prayer ceremony. Manshu, a trusted colleague, performed the ritual, and I seized the opportunity to network with other lawyers, fostering connections crucial to my profession. Outside of work, I assist my father with volunteer efforts, which has led me to join the temple committee, adding another layer to my community involvement. It is here that I met Gaurji, a pandit well-regarded for his knowledge and the perks of his position. However, a series of strokes have left him increasingly irritable, a change that everyone noticed but few dared to address. His condition reached a boiling point during a prayer session, where, in a moment of frustration, he disrupted the solemn gathering by hurling food at the attendees. This incident left the community in shock, forcing us to confront the delicate balance between compassion for his plight and the need to maintain the sanctity of our gatherings. As I reflect on these experiences, I realize that my journey as a lawyer and community member is intertwined with the lives and stories of those around me, each day offering new lessons in patience, empathy, and the unpredictable nature of human behavior.

Paragraph 2:
During the day, I’d walk up and down the alleys, past tea stands and men sitting on stools beneath trees, typewriters before them. I talked to other lawyers—the fortunate ones in black gowns who were going to appear before a judge, and the rest, who, like me, wore dress pants and white shirts with pens in their breast pockets and their business cards rubber-banded in their pants pockets. When I moved into the Tis Hazari office, I had a prayer ceremony performed in the shed. Manshu sat in the center of the concrete room and lit a fire, and soon the place was full of smoke and it was hard to breathe. Still, I sat there and sang prayers. Why not, if it might bring luck? Also, inviting the other lawyers in the lane to the prayer ceremony was a way of getting to know people. To cultivate business, I began helping my father with his volunteer work, which was how I started dealing with the committee that oversaw the temple. No pandit ever wants to leave a temple. It provides free housing and reasonable pay for not much effort. Also, one has an almost complete monopoly over the ceremonies held in nearby houses, and this can double or triple one’s income. But Gaurji suffered a series of small strokes, and they made him even angrier. One winter evening, during prayers in the temple courtyard, he took the plates of food that had been put before the various gods for their dinner and began throwing them at the people who were seated cross-legged waiting for the prayers to start.

“If I hadn’t called your father, wouldn’t you still be sitting there with that grin on your face? What other way is there to manage you?” Nadine detects in her father some objections to Flo’s rhetoric, an embarrassment and reluctance. She is wrong, and ought to know she is wrong, in thinking she can count on this, The fact that she knows about it, and that he knows she knows, will not make things any better. He is beginning to warm up. He gives her a look. This look is at first cold and challenging. It informs her of his judgment, of the hopelessness of her position. Then it clears, begins to fill up with something else, the way a spring fills up with fresh water when you clear the leaves and scum away. His eyes fill with hatred and pleasure. Nadine sees this and knows what it is. Or is it just anger, are his eyes simply filling with anger? No. Hatred is right. Pleasure is right. His face loosens and changes and grows younger, and he holds up his hand, this time to silence Flo. “All right,” he says, meaning, That’s enough, more than enough; this part is over, things can proceed. He starts to loosen his belt. Flo has stopped anyway. She has a difficulty Nadine shares, a difficulty, apparently, in believing that what you know must happen will happen, that there comes a time when you can’t draw back. “Oh, I don’t know. Don’t be too hard on her.” Flo is moving around nervously as if she has thoughts of opening some escape route. “Oh, you don’t have to use the belt on her. Do you have to use the belt? Couldn’t you give her a talking-to? Couldn’t you just slap her hands?” He doesn’t answer. The belt is coming off, but not hastily. Now it is being grasped at the necessary point. “All right, you.” He comes over to Nadine, pushes her off the table. His face, like his voice, is entirely out of character. He is like a bad actor who turns a part grotesque. It is as if he is savoring and insisting on just what is shameful and terrible about this, so that Nadine will have no doubt about it, so that he himself will have no doubt. That does not mean that he is pretending, that he is not real. He is real and he is acting. Nadine knows it; she knows everything about him.

The atmosphere in the room grew increasingly heavy, the shadows cast by the flickering lights seeming to deepen and twist, as if alive and feeding off the malevolent energy emanating from Nadine's father. Despite Flo's valiant attempts to intervene, her words tumbling forth in a nervous cascade as she sought to reason with Nadine's father, to persuade him to consider less severe punishments, her efforts were met with a resolute, unyielding resistance, his eyes glinting with a sinister light as he reached for his belt, the soft creak of the leather a stark, ominous portent of the events that were about to unfold. Nadine felt a cold, creeping sense of dread as she watched her father's actions, his every move seemingly choreographed to maximize the impact of the impending punishment, his expression a twisted, almost theatrical mask of cruelty and sadistic pleasure, a look that seemed to savor the very thought of inflicting pain and humiliation upon his daughter. In this moment, Nadine was acutely, painfully aware of the reality of her situation, the inevitability of what was about to happen, and the dark, foreboding truth that lurked beneath her father's façade, a truth that threatened to consume her very being.

As the evening unfolded, I found myself in the company of Spinelli, a character as enigmatic as the night itself. He exuded an effortless charisma, his black shirt left unbuttoned just enough to reveal a glinting gold chain resting against his chest, and the air around him was saturated with the heady aroma of cologne. There was an intensity in his eyes, a spark that promised adventure and perhaps a hint of mischief. Together, we ventured towards a casino, a place said to be owned by a Croatian man whose past was as shadowy as the dimly lit alleyways that led us there. As we approached, the atmosphere shifted; the streetlights cast a golden hue on the pavement, and the distant murmur of excitement became audible. We were soon surrounded by a small group of women, their high heels clicking rhythmically against the ground. One of them, her eyes gleaming like polished stones, briefly grabbed my arm, her touch fleeting yet charged with a strange electricity. Inside the casino, the world seemed to morph into a dazzling spectacle of lights and sounds. The air was thick with the scent of anticipation and the faintest trace of cigar smoke. I couldn't help but be drawn to the roulette table, where a group of men, visibly inebriated, clung to their last threads of hope. Their eyes darted between the spinning wheel and the croupier, a man with a practiced poker face and nimble fingers. Spinelli leaned closer to me, his voice a conspiratorial whisper, as he insisted that the croupier was deftly skimming from the players, his sleight of hand almost imperceptible. The thought intrigued me, adding a layer of intrigue to the already intoxicating environment. I watched the scene unfold, each moment etching itself into my memory with vivid detail. The casino was a microcosm of desires and dreams, where fortunes were won and lost in the blink of an eye. It was a place where time seemed to stand still, trapped in the eternal cycle of risk and reward. As I stood there, absorbing the vibrant chaos, my thoughts drifted to Azra. I knew she would appreciate the richness of this experience, the kaleidoscope of emotions that painted the room in broad, bold strokes. In my mind, I began composing a description for her, each word meticulously chosen to capture the essence of this night. I imagined telling her about Spinelli's magnetic presence, the intoxicating allure of the casino, and the unspoken stories that lingered in the air. This was more than just an evening's diversion; it was a tapestry of human experience, woven with threads of hope, desperation, and the relentless pursuit of luck. As the night wore on, I realized that this was a memory that would linger long after the lights had dimmed and the last bets had been placed.

Paragraph 2:
One night when I went upstairs, Spinelli was all dressed and ready to go, wearing a black unbuttoned shirt, reeking of cologne, a gold chain dangling below his Adam’s apple. He lit a cigarette in the doorway, inhaled, and said “Let’s go!” and I followed without a question. It did not even cross my mind to tell my parents where I was going. They never came to check on me when I was at Spinelli’s. It turned out that we were going to a casino around the corner. “The guy who owns the casino is Croatian,” Spinelli said. “Used to be in the Foreign Legion, fought here, then in Biafra. I don’t wanna know the things he did. We do business sometimes, and his daughter likes me pretty well, too.” I could not see his lips moving as we walked; his voice was disembodied. We turned the corner and there was a splendid neon sign that said “PLAYBOY CASINO,” the “S” and the final “O” flickering uncertainly. A few white cars and military Jeeps were parked in the gravel lot. On the stairs were several hookers in ridiculously high heels, neither climbing nor descending, as if they were afraid they might fall if they moved. But move they did as we passed; one of them grabbed my forearm and turned me toward her. She wore a helmetlike purple wig, and earrings as elaborate as Christmas ornaments; her breasts were pushed up by her tiny bra, so that I could see half of her left nipple. I stood petrified until Spinelli released me from her grip. “You don’t fuck much, do you, Blunderpuss?” he said. Three men were sitting at the roulette table, all plainly drunk, their heads falling on their chests between the revolutions of the wheel. A heavy fog of masculine recklessness hung over the table, the green of the felt fractured by piles of colorful chips. One of the men won and snapped out of his torpor long enough to gather up the chips with both arms, as though embracing a child. “Watch the croupier steal from them,” Spinelli said with delight. “They’re going to lose it all before they get another drink, then they’ll lose some more.” I did watch the croupier, but could not see how the stealing happened: when the players won, he pushed the chips toward them; when they lost, he raked the pile toward himself. It all seemed simple and honest, but I believed Spinelli. I had already started composing a description of the place for Azra: the cone of smoke rising to the light above the blackjack table; the hysterical flashing of the two slot machines in the corner; the man standing at the bar in the attire of a plantation owner—a light linen suit and a straw hat—his right hand hanging down like a sleeping dog’s head, a ribbon of cigarette smoke passing slowly between his knuckles.

Paragraph 1:
In reflecting on the evolution of connectivity failures in films, it's fascinating to observe how the portrayal of isolation has transformed with the advent of cellphones. Before the late '90s, filmmakers had a much simpler time establishing isolation, as there was less reliance on mobile technology. However, as cellphones became ubiquitous, movies like "House on Haunted Hill" (1999) and "Jeepers Creepers" (2001) had to become more creative in depicting scenarios where characters find themselves without a functional phone in crucial moments. In "House on Haunted Hill," for instance, a sinister, possessed house disrupts the phone signal, adding a supernatural twist to the communication breakdown. Meanwhile, "Jeepers Creepers" presents a tense sibling argument over a low battery warning, just after they have a harrowing encounter with a demon. As someone who collects clips for a supercut of these moments, I find it intriguing how filmmakers adapt to technological changes, turning what could be a plot obstacle into an opportunity for suspense and creativity in storytelling.

Paragraph 2:
Before the late ’90s, there was little need to make such a show of connectivity failure. Lines would go down or get cut, sure, but isolation in the age before mass cellphone usage was easier to come by and therefore easier to believe onscreen. Back then, the tropes didn’t have to trope so hard. Then came the cell, and movies like “House on Haunted Hill” (1999) and “Jeepers Creepers” (2001) featured characters realizing they were holding useless plastic flip-bricks as their situations grew hairy. (In the former, the possessed house kills the signal before any of its inhabitants; in the latter, young adult siblings bicker over a low battery notification after witnessing what turns out to be a winged demon.) With smartphones, there was even more to neutralize, like GPS maps and internet searches. Movies taking pains to explain away cellphones were so prevalent that by 2009, I could collect more than 40 clips for a supercut exploring this development in the previous decade or so.

He tells me that he was among the troops on the Houston. His best friend there was named Garcilaso. Garcilaso was fifteen years old.

Paragraph 1:
After the mesmerizing performance of the "Musical Brain," my family and I were caught up in the usual post-show bustle. My parents, always keen to avoid the throngs that typically follow such events, were quick to steer us toward the exit. My mother, in particular, seemed anxious to distance herself from what she perceived as the less cultured elements of the audience. Amidst this hurried departure, I found myself curiously drawn back to the stage, seized by an impulsive desire to touch the Musical Brain. It was a simple, fleeting gesture, unnoticed by my parents, whose attention was elsewhere. However, my younger sister, ever observant and eager to emulate her older sibling, witnessed my clandestine act. Her eyes widened with a mix of admiration and mischief, and she too reached out, her fingers brushing against the Brain. But her enthusiasm got the better of her, and with a clumsy push, she accidentally toppled the contraption from its stand. The crash reverberated through the hall, slicing through the chatter of the dispersing crowd. My parents, alarmed by the sudden clamor, turned back just in time to see my sister standing amidst the wreckage, her face a portrait of shock and remorse. Tears welled up in her eyes, spilling over as she was engulfed by a wave of guilt and fear of impending punishment. The scene unfolded before me with a vividness that felt almost surreal, each moment etched in my mind with the precision of a well-rehearsed play. My sister's cries filled the air, a poignant counterpoint to the distant hum of conversations and footsteps. My parents rushed to her side, their earlier impatience forgotten, replaced by concern and the instinctive need to comfort their child. In that moment, I stood as a silent witness to the unfolding drama, a tangle of emotions swirling within me—guilt for my role in the debacle, empathy for my sister's distress, and an odd sense of detachment as I observed the scene with an almost cinematic clarity.

Paragraph 2:
It happened more or less like this: Having satisfied their curiosity about the Musical Brain, my parents headed for the street, partly because there was nothing more to see and partly to be gone before the audience started coming out of the theatre. The performance must have been over; the applause hadn’t stopped, but it couldn’t go on much longer, and Mom didn’t want to be seen leaving along with “the great unwashed.” People who didn’t know better might think she had sunk to the cultural depths of the Peronists. She turned and began to walk out in such a decided manner that I felt the moment had come: it was now safe to touch the large pink object. Without a second thought, I reached out. The tip of my right index finger touched the surface of the brain for a bare fraction of a second. For reasons that will soon become clear, that momentary contact was something I would never forget. My naughtiness escaped the notice of my parents, who went on walking toward the lobby doors, but not of my sister, who was two or three at the time, and imitated everything I did. Emboldened by my daring, she wanted to touch the Brain, too. But, clumsy little devil that she was, she didn’t go about it daintily. Drawing herself up to her full height—she was barely as tall as the box on which the Brain rested—she raised her little arms and pushed with all her might. Sensing what was about to happen, she held her breath, then released it in a scream as the Brain began to move. My parents stopped and turned, and I think they took a step or two toward us. For me, the whole scene had taken on a phantasmagoric precision, like a play rehearsed a thousand times. The Musical Brain slid heavily over the edge of the box, fell to the floor, and broke. My sister burst into tears, more upset by guilt and fear of punishment than by the sight that had appeared before our eyes, which was probably beyond her powers of comprehension.

Etheridge let himself in quietly, not releasing the catch of the lock until he’d pulled it to and could open the door soundlessly. With luck, Janet would have slept and would be sleeping still. Sleep was everything to her now, the kindest friend, the tenderest lover. She didn’t allow it to be induced, the drugs she was offered invariably declined. He looked down at the sleeping face that illness was taking from him, a little more each day. For a moment he saw in the wan, tired features the shadows of Juliet, the wisdom of Portia, Estella’s thoughtless pride. “I’ll go,” the carer whispered from the doorway. “Dear Janet,” he whispered himself, wondering how her day had been. When he had made tea, Etheridge carried the tray back to the bedside and the rattle of the cup and saucer woke his wife, as every day it did. It was what Janet wanted, what she liked: that she should always be awake when he was here. “Hello again,” she said. He bent to embrace her, and held her for a moment in his arms, then plumped her pillows up and straightened the turndown of her top sheet. She said, when he asked, that she was feeling better. But she didn’t eat any of the cake he had brought, or the biscuits, and didn’t look as well as she had that morning. “Oh, nothing to write home about,” he responded to a query as to how the day had been for him. She’d finished “A Fine Balance,” she said. She’d heard a program about silverware on the radio. “Well, no,” she said. “Not interesting at all.” “Some soup later, darling? Cream cracker?” “Soup would be lovely. No cream cracker.” “We landed the contract. I thought we wouldn’t.” “I knew you would.” She was an actress. He had been settled for years in the offices of Forrester and Bright, a firm of specialist printers that had made a corner for itself by taking on complicated assignments that other printers couldn’t be bothered with. In their early forties now, they’d been married since they were both twenty-three. “It’s awful for you,” Janet said, gloomy as she sometimes was when she’d just woken up. “Of course it isn’t.” Without an effort, the familiar reassurance came. They smiled at each other. They knew it was awful.

Although medication could ease her into deeper sleep, Janet stubbornly refused it, a testament to her enduring spirit and willpower. As he stood by her bedside, Etheridge couldn't help but see glimpses of Shakespearean heroines in her delicate features, a reminder of her vibrant past as an actress. The room was silent except for the gentle breathing of the carer, who offered to leave them alone. Etheridge leaned in, whispering softly to Janet, inquiring about her day. He moved to the kitchen to prepare tea, the sound of boiling water inadvertently waking Janet. She preferred to be conscious of his presence, cherishing the moments they had together despite her condition. They exchanged warm greetings, and Etheridge busied himself with ensuring her comfort, adjusting pillows and blankets with tender care. Janet reassured him that she felt better, though she left the treats he had brought untouched on the tray beside her bed. Their conversation meandered through the events of the day; Janet recounted finishing a book and listening to an intriguing radio program, while Etheridge shared news of a promising work contract from the printing firm where he was employed. Their marriage, spanning from their early twenties, had weathered many storms, but Janet's illness presented a formidable challenge. Yet, in this quiet moment, they found solace in each other's company, sharing a mutual understanding and reassurance. They smiled gently at one another, acknowledging the difficulty of their situation but also the strength they derived from their bond. Janet's eyes, once alight with the passion of the stage, reflected a quiet resilience, while Etheridge's presence was a constant anchor, a reminder of the life they had built together. In the soft glow of the evening, they found comfort in their shared history and the unspoken promise to face whatever lay ahead together, as they always had.

As I've been regaling friends with tales of my newly renovated closets, I've found myself boasting not just about the sleek design, but also about the mastermind behind it: Jim, a retired handyman who only takes on projects that strike his fancy. I feel lucky to have made the cut. But my interactions with Jim have extended far beyond the realm of home improvement. He recently invited me to check out the Christmas lights at our community gardens, and as we strolled through the winter wonderland, I was struck by the whimsical display. Emboldened by the festive spirit, I agreed to join him for a round of ice skating - my first time lacing up in over a decade. As I wobbled onto the rink, Jim, whose son played hockey, expertly helped me tighten my skates and offered words of encouragement. After I completed a shaky first lap, he beamed with pride, saying I was a natural.

When Jim asked me if I had seen the Christmas lights at the community gardens near his house, I said no, but they sounded nice. During closet number two, after a Friday of Jim working hard and me hardly working (that’s a Jimism), we walked through the gardens oohing and ahhing at the bright spectacle against the night sky, wondering who climbed the ladders and wrapped the string lights in the branches overhead and who would take them down. The next time we got together, we went ice skating. I hadn’t skated in more than a decade and was sure I would wipe us both out. Jim, a father of a former high school hockey player, tightened my skate for me. After our first shaky lap, he said, “Look at you. You’re a natural.”
