Professor Dai's life had been irrevocably altered by the snowstorm accident that claimed her husband's life, an event that seemed to cast a shadow of suspicion over her, despite its inevitability. Whispers circulated, an unspoken accusation that perhaps she bore some responsibility for the tragedy. Siyu, once a fixture in the department office, often overheard these murmurings, sensing the quiet judgment directed at Professor Dai. Meanwhile, Hanfeng navigated his own complex emotions, his memories of his father vague and fading. He found himself drawn to family photographs from his early years, images that captured a seemingly happy family unit. Yet, these photos also highlighted an absence; after his father's death, no pictures existed of him with his mother, a visual reminder of their fragmented family. In conversations with Siyu, Hanfeng sought understanding, curious about her experience growing up with only a father. Siyu's response was pragmatic, suggesting that having a single parent meant not having to split affection or allegiance, a notion that resonated with Hanfeng. Their shared experiences of parental loss, albeit different, forged a silent bond between them, each navigating the complexities of family and memory in their own way. As Hanfeng contemplated these realities, he found a sense of solace in the understanding that love, whether from one parent or two, remained whole and undivided, even in the face of loss.

Paragraph 2:
Professor Dai had never mentioned her late husband, but Siyu had once had a summer job in the department office, and had heard other professors and the secretaries talk about how he had died in a snowstorm when his bicycle skidded in front of a bus. An accident that no one could be blamed for, but Siyu had sensed the others’ disapproval of Professor Dai, as if she were partially responsible for the unfair fate befalling a man; the dead husband, by contrast, was always praised as the gentlest person. “What was it like to grow up with only a father?” Hanfeng asked. He had little recollection of his father, but there were photographs, taken when Hanfeng had turned a hundred days, six months, one year, and then two years old. In all four pictures, he was flanked by his parents, who looked serious and attentive. They would have been called gold boy and emerald girl at their wedding, enviable for their matching good looks. It must have been his father’s idea to have a family picture taken at every milestone of his life, since after his father’s death Hanfeng had never been in the same photograph as his mother. She imagined it was not very different from growing up with a mother, Siyu replied. There was no other parent to whom they could compare the one they had, and love did not have to be balanced and divided between two people; the claiming of loyalty was unnecessary.

Four years ago, Casey Harrell sang his last bedtime nursery rhyme to his daughter. By then, A.L.S. had begun laying waste to Mr. Harrell’s muscles, stealing from him one ritual after another: going on walks with his wife, holding his daughter, turning the pages of a book. “Like a night burglar,” his wife, Levana Saxon, wrote of the disease in a poem. But no theft was as devastating to Mr. Harrell, 46, as the fading of his speech. He had sung his last Whitney Houston song at karaoke. A climate activist, he had delivered his last unassisted Zoom presentation to fellow organizers. Last July, doctors at the University of California, Davis, surgically implanted electrodes in Mr. Harrell’s brain to try to discern what he was trying to say. That made him the latest test subject in a daunting scientific quest, one that has attracted deep-pocketed firms like Elon Musk’s company Neuralink: connecting people’s brains to computers, potentially restoring their lost faculties. Doctors told him that he would be advancing the cause of science, but that he was not likely to reverse his fortunes.

Paragraph 2:

For Mr. Harrell, a climate activist, the most devastating loss has been his ability to speak, a cruel irony that has severely impacted both his personal and professional life. In a groundbreaking effort to restore his capacity for communication, doctors at the University of California, Davis, have implanted electrodes in his brain, enlisting him in a pioneering scientific endeavor to connect human brains to computers. While companies like Elon Musk's Neuralink are investing heavily in this field, Mr. Harrell's doctors caution that the experimental procedure is unlikely to revive his lost abilities, tempering hope with a dose of reality. Nevertheless, Mr. Harrell's courage in the face of adversity serves as a testament to the human spirit's capacity for resilience.

I found myself intrigued by the man sitting across from me at the dinner table, his Jamaican accent adding warmth to every word as he spoke about his connection to my father. Over plates of steaming food, he shared stories of their five-year friendship during their younger days, painting vivid pictures of their adventures together. When I asked about how they met, he chuckled, recalling their chance encounter at a local market where my father was fascinated by the significant Chinese presence in Jamaica, something he hadn't expected. Their relationship, he explained, was one of those organic connections that flourished naturally before gradually fading away, like many friendships do when life takes people in different directions. I couldn't help but smile as he described my father's younger self, a version of him I'd never known, full of curiosity and enthusiasm for different cultures. The man spoke with genuine fondness, though it was clear the years had created a comfortable distance from those memories. As we continued our meal, he shared anecdotes about their shared experiences, each story revealing another layer of my father's past. It was strange yet comforting to hear these tales from someone who knew him in such a different context, during a time when both of them were still figuring out their paths in life. Their friendship, though long ended, had clearly left lasting impressions on both men.

And then: Your father and I were just kids, he said. Lasted five years, on and off. Five years, I said. One, two, five. And then you stopped? Stopped? In Jamaica? Of course we stopped. Did you stay in contact? Ai-yah, the man said. How would we do that? We stopped. Do they have orange juice? Maybe, I said. Fuck. Your father swore, too, the man said. Fuck, I said again. Rude boy. Stop that. How did you two even meet? He worked in my mother’s shop, the man said. At least in the beginning. Short walk from the schoolhouse. And then what? You just hooked up? Hooked up? Never mind, I said. What did y’all do together? How did you two even know? Link copied Know what? You know what. This prompted a smile from the man, between mouthfuls of eggs and jelly and bagel. He slid the plate toward me. I tore off a corner of a biscuit. We just knew, he said. It was obvious. At least to us. Happened how it always happens and then it ended.

Paragraph 1:
As a pastor grappling with the realities of modern ministry, I find myself increasingly troubled by the widespread practice of sermon plagiarism among my colleagues. While I dedicate two full days to crafting each of my sermons through careful study and reflection, I've noticed many of my fellow pastors taking shortcuts, spending barely an hour preparing their messages by lifting content from online resources or purchasing pre-written sermons. Though I strongly disapprove of such practices, I can't help but understand the pressures that drive them to these compromises. Parish ministry is an overwhelming juggling act of counseling, administration, community outreach, and spiritual guidance, often leaving little time for thorough sermon preparation. My name is Matthew, and I've witnessed firsthand how these demands can tempt even the most principled pastors to sacrifice authenticity for convenience. Still, I believe we must maintain our integrity in the pulpit, as our congregations deserve messages that come from genuine spiritual reflection rather than borrowed wisdom.

Paragraph 2:
⬥ It’s a sad day when a pastor’s authenticity is found to be fraudulent, because authenticity is the only coin of the realm for a pastor these days. After more than 30 years as a pastor and preacher, I abhorred the practice of plagiarizing sermons, but it was sadly not uncommon. Then again, those same pastors may have paid twice as many hospital calls as I ever did. Parish ministry is extraordinarily challenging, requiring the skills of a counselor, orator, executive director, fund-raiser, politician, volunteer coordinator, handyman, teacher, hospice chaplain, liturgist and writer — while never losing your temper or falling in love or appearing imperfect. No one is good at all of it. I needed two days to write a decent sermon, while others would devote an hour or so, skimming the internet or using sample sermons they subscribed to. Their priorities were elsewhere. I can understand how the stress of the job — combined with people-pleasing neuroses, unmet narcissistic needs and whatever else — drives someone to rationalize this crime against authenticity. — Matthew

Paragraph 1:
As we strolled along the familiar path, Neve and I engaged in a conversation that meandered from her intriguing stamp collection to our shared observations of the world around us. Neve confessed that when the bank changed hands, she made the decisive choice to keep the collection, drawn in by the fascinating allure of the stamps. Her plan is to eventually sell them, but she takes pleasure in the intricate designs and rich histories each stamp holds, reminiscent of the passion shared by her uncle. She mentioned, with a hint of surprise, that despite having seen the albums countless times, I never showed any real interest. Neve speculated that if I had taken even a moment to delve into the pages, I might have found myself equally captivated. I admitted my interests lay elsewhere, particularly in the task ahead of typing and editing Neve's story over the next month. As we passed by the old church, we noticed the priest laboring away, cutting the grass on his monthly visit, seemingly forgotten by those who should have prepared for him. Neve sighed, reflecting on how good people often seem to go unnoticed and underappreciated. We continued our walk, the conversation weaving between the past and present, our differing passions, and the shared understanding that sometimes, kindness exists quietly, without recognition.

Paragraph 2:
“What happened to it?” I was intrigued, as I hadn’t known any of this. Neve gave me a sly sideways look. “I kept it when the bank changed hands. I like looking at the stamps, you see—they’re better than television. I’ve decided to sell the whole thing, and that’s why I’m telling the story now. The collection is in my front room. Stacked on a table. You’ve seen the albums, but you’ve never commented. You’ve never looked inside them. If you had, you would have been enchanted, like me, with the delicacy, the detail, and the endless variety. You would have wanted to know more about the stamps themselves, and the need to know and understand their histories would have taken hold of you, as it did my uncle and as it has me, though thankfully to a much lesser degree. Of course, you have your own interests.” “Yes,” I said. “Thank God for those.” I would be typing out and editing Neve’s story for the next month. As we passed the church, we saw the priest there on his monthly visit. The poor man waved at us when we called out a greeting. No one had remembered, so he was cutting the grass. His parish was four or six combined now. “They treat the good ones like simple beasts,” Neve said. Then she shrugged and we pressed on.

Paragraph 1:
As Meriel stood on the deck of the ferry, the cool breeze ruffling her hair, her thoughts drifted back to Pierre, a presence that lingered in her mind despite the finality of his death. It seemed surreal to her that someone who had been so significant in her life could be gone, yet persist so vividly in her daydreams, untouched by the harsh reality of his absence. The rhythmic lapping of the water against the ferry's hull had a calming effect, and as she gazed out over the endless expanse of blue, she found herself entertaining the romantic notion of throwing herself into the sea, enveloped by a peculiar sense of happiness and heightened self-esteem. It wasn’t a death wish, but rather an acknowledgment of life’s impermanence and her desire to feel something profound and liberating. Her introspection was interrupted by the memory of a particular journey long ago, one that had left an indelible mark on her soul. She and Pierre had been driving to the ferry terminal, the hum of the engine a steady backdrop to their conversation, which had been filled with the kind of easy banter that characterized their relationship. But as they reached their destination, an unexpected awkwardness settled over them. Meriel recalled the way Pierre had turned to her, his expression inscrutable, as she leaned in for a goodbye kiss. He had pulled back slightly, offering a gentle but firm, "I never do." That moment had puzzled her then and continued to haunt her now, leaving her to wonder what lay beneath his refusal. Was it merely a quirk of his enigmatic personality, or did it hint at something deeper, something that she, in her youth and naivety, had failed to grasp? This recollection led her into a spiral of what-ifs, a contemplation of how her life might have unfolded differently had she reacted with boldness or curiosity instead of retreating into the safety of her own emotional management. She imagined a version of herself who challenged Pierre’s reluctance, who sought to unravel the mystery of his words, potentially opening the door to an adventurous life, full of unpredictability and passion. Yet, even as these thoughts teased her imagination, Meriel knew deep down that such a scenario was at odds with her intrinsic nature. She had always been guided by a sense of prudence, a careful balancing of her emotions, which had served as both her armor and her cage. The paths not taken whispered to her with a tantalizing allure, but they were ultimately foreign to her disposition. Reflecting on this, Meriel felt a pang of regret mingled with acceptance. Her journey with Pierre had been marked by moments of joy and understanding, but also by the unspoken complexities that now, in hindsight, seemed so clear yet remained frustratingly out of reach. She pondered whether the restraint she had shown, the choices she had made in deference to her cautious nature, had been wise or merely safe. The themes of memory and regret intertwined, weaving through her thoughts like the threads of an intricate tapestry. In examining her past with Pierre, Meriel came to recognize that while her decisions had shaped the course of her life, they had also left her wondering about the myriad possibilities that lay beyond her chosen path. The ferry continued its steady journey across the water, a symbol of transition and movement, much like Meriel's own reflective passage through the landscape of her memories. In this space of contemplation, she found a measure of peace, understanding that while she could not change the past, she had the power to embrace its lessons. Pierre’s presence, though now a ghostly echo, had enriched her life in ways she was only beginning to comprehend. As the ferry approached her destination, Meriel took a deep breath, feeling the weight of her introspection lift slightly, replaced by a quiet resolve to honor her memories, cherish the love she had known, and remain open to the unknowns of the future.

Paragraph 2:
The fact that he was dead did not seem to have much effect on Meriel’s daydreams—if that was what you could call them. The ones in which she imagined chance meetings, or even desperately arranged reunions, had never had a foothold on reality, in any case, and were not revised because he was dead. They had to wear themselves out in a way she did not control and never understood. When she was on her way home that night, it had started to rain, not very hard. She stayed out on the deck of the ferry. She got up and walked around and could not sit down again on the lid of the life-jacket bin without getting a big wet spot on her dress. So she stayed looking at the froth stirred up in the wake of the boat and the thought occurred to her that in a certain kind of story—not the kind that anybody made up anymore—the thing for her to do would be to throw herself into the water. Just as she was, packed full of happiness, rewarded as she would surely never be again, every cell in her body plumped up with a sweet self-esteem. A romantic act that could be seen—from a forbidden angle—as supremely rational. Was she tempted? She was probably just letting herself imagine being tempted. Probably nowhere near yielding, though yielding had been the order of that day. It wasn’t until after Pierre was dead that she remembered one further detail. He had driven her to Horseshoe Bay, to the ferry. He had got out of the car and come around to her side. She was standing there, waiting to say goodbye to him. She made a move toward him, to kiss him—surely a natural thing to do, after the last few hours—and he had said, “No.” “No,” he said. “I never do.” Of course, that wasn’t true, that he never did. Never kissed out in the open, where anybody could see. He had done it just that afternoon, at Prospect Point. No. That was simple. A cautioning. A refusal. Protecting her, you might say, as well as himself. Even if he hadn’t bothered about that earlier in the day. I never do was something else altogether. Another kind of cautioning. Information that could not make her happy, though it might be intended to keep her from making a serious mistake. To save her from the false hopes and humiliation of a certain kind of mistake. How did they say goodbye, then? Did they shake hands? She could not remember. But she heard his voice, the lightness and yet the gravity of his tone, she saw his resolute, merely pleasant face, she felt the slight shift out of her range. She didn’t doubt that the recollection was true. She did not see how she could have suppressed it so successfully. For all this time. She had an idea that if she had not been able to do that, her life might have been different. How? She might not have stayed with Pierre. She might not have been able to keep her balance. Trying to match what had been said at the ferry with what had been said and done earlier the same day would have made her more alert and more curious. Pride or contrariness might have played a part—a need to have some man eat those words, a refusal to learn her lesson. There was another sort of life she could have had—a life of impulse and adventure. Which was not to say she would have preferred it. It was probably because of her age (something she was always forgetting to take account of), and because of the thin, cool air she had breathed since Pierre’s death, that she could think of it simply as a kind of research that had its pitfalls and achievements. Maybe you didn’t find out so much, anyway. Maybe the same thing over and over—which might be some obvious but unsettling fact about yourself. In her case, the fact that prudence—or at least some economical sort of emotional management—had been her guiding light all along. The little self-preserving movement he made, the kind and deadly caution, the attitude of inflexibility that had grown a bit stale with him, like an outmoded swagger. She could view him now with an everyday mystification, as if he had been her husband. She wondered if he’d stayed that way, or if some other role had been waiting for him, up ahead.

Paragraph 1:
Years before, I’d made the mistake of doing a live piece-to-camera for CNN. While reading the cue card I’d written for myself, I’d pronounced “misled” as if it rhymed with “guy’s old.” On the progress of the war in Afghanistan, the successes of the surge, the President had myzled the public. The YouTube video had been viewed many, many times—many more times, certainly, than any story I’d ever reported. That fucking YouTube video was going to be my legacy. Imagine: the vanity, the inanity, of these final meditations. YouTube! Well, Sue Kwan wasn’t the only one who would die as she had lived. I felt a kind of thwump reverberate from the earth into my body, and a hot cushion of air lifted me off the ground. It lifted me and transported me somewhere else and set me down. I sat up. I opened my eyes. It was difficult to see in all the dust and debris. It felt like nighttime. But not exactly nighttime—more like an eclipse, a total solar. Dark figures, silhouettes, flitted about. As the air began to clear, I saw that they were pouring into the garden through the hole in the wall. Most of them wore uniforms—they were soldiers, police. The shooting seemed to have stopped. I got to my feet. I was a little wobbly, a little wobbly. I tried a couple of steps, then a couple more. I tripped on something and fell to the ground. When I looked back to see what it was, I discovered an arm. First the leg—now this, an arm. I knew there must be heads around. For once, I didn’t want to see them; just knowing they were around was enough. The arm looked as if it had been sprayed with buckshot. Silver was embedded in the flesh. I thought of pearls in a mollusk. (Not pearls, though, I thought.) A tactical-looking watch was still strapped around the wrist. I knew that watch. It belonged to the researcher from the United Nations Ornithological Department. O.K., stop looking at the arm.

Looking back, I can't help but cringe at that fateful day on CNN when I confidently pronounced "misled" as "myzled" during a live broadcast, a blunder that would haunt my journalistic career like a stubborn ghost refusing to be exorcised. It's almost comical how a single syllabic slip-up became my unwitting legacy, overshadowing decades of war correspondence and investigative reporting. But those thoughts were violently interrupted by the deafening thwump that lifted me clean off my feet, sending me sprawling across what remained of the embassy garden. The world spun in slow motion as my ears rang with a high-pitched whine, dust and debris settling around me like some macabre snow globe. As my vision cleared, I watched through a haze as soldiers and police poured through the jagged breach in the garden wall, their tactical gear catching the afternoon sun in brief, threatening flashes. My hands trembled as I pushed myself up, my knees still weak from the blast, when something caught my eye among the scattered rubble and twisted metal – an arm, cleanly severed at the shoulder, lying grotesquely still amid the chaos. The sight alone would have been horrifying enough, but it was the watch that made my stomach lurch – that distinctive silver Omega timepiece I'd seen just yesterday during our briefing with Dr. Harrison from the UN Ornithological Department. The irony wasn't lost on me; here I was, a journalist whose biggest claim to fame was a pronunciation error, now witness to an atrocity that would require far more precise words to describe than I felt capable of mustering in that moment.

The reservoir ahead held particular significance – it was where Evan had proposed, though neither of them had broached the subject since that day, letting it fade into an unspoken memory that lingered like morning mist over still water. As she approached the familiar spot, she noticed two high-school students lounging near the water's edge, their carefree laughter carrying across the calm surface, and she began her descent down the well-worn trail, fighting waves of nausea that made her regret refusing the almonds offered earlier. The peaceful solitude of her walk was suddenly interrupted by a man's distinctive Southern drawl, his appearance as disheveled as autumn leaves scattered by wind, offering assistance with her bags in a way that made her skin prickle with unease. Her heart began to race as she thought about the pack containing the money, and she instinctively tried to deflect attention by claiming the other pack belonged to her boyfriend, Evan. The man's interest seemed to sharpen at the mention of Evan, his questions about Evan's whereabouts becoming more pointed, forcing Sarah to fabricate a story about meeting him soon. Her palms grew sweaty as she realized the man had no intention of returning her pack, his grip on it tightening as he continued his interrogation. The situation grew increasingly tense as she stood there, caught between the desire to flee and the need to recover her belongings, while the man's presence seemed to grow more menacing with each passing moment. Her mind raced through possible scenarios, each more alarming than the last, as she realized the precariousness of her position – alone on a trail with a stranger who now held possession of her property. The weight of her decision to take this solitary walk to the reservoir, a place that once held romantic memories but now felt threatening, pressed heavily on her consciousness. She found herself wishing she had accepted the woman's earlier invitation, or at least stayed in more populated areas, as the man's questioning about Evan became more persistent and unsettling. The late afternoon sun cast long shadows across the trail, making the scene feel even more ominous as she stood there, trying to maintain a calm exterior while internally grappling with the growing realization that this encounter could take a dangerous turn. Her fabricated story about meeting Evan seemed to hang in the air between them, a fragile shield that could shatter at any moment, leaving her exposed and vulnerable to whatever intentions this disheveled stranger might harbor.

Yet, despite the rumors, birds flocked to the tree, their songs filling the air as they feasted on its fruit. Four days without water had taken its toll, leaving them weary and dehydrated. In search of relief, they had sought out the help of healers, but so far, their encounters had been nothing short of disastrous. The first healer they met had made lewd insinuations to Venus, his beady eyes lingering on her parched skin, while the second had offered them water that was suspiciously black, claiming it was a "natural remedy." To make matters worse, Venus was convinced that one of the healers had stolen her mobile phone, leaving them without a lifeline to the outside world. Frustrated with the lack of rational solutions, they decided to seek help from scientists, hoping that a more logical approach would yield better results. They made their way to Venus's old university, where they sought out her former chemistry lecturer, Dr. Lee. The old man looked up from his desk, his eyes squinting with age and fatigue, but a spark of recognition lit up his face as he took in Venus's disheveled appearance. "You used to have such lovely hair," he said, his comment hanging awkwardly in the air before he nodded for them to continue. With his eyes shut, he listened intently as they recounted their tale of woe, his expression unreadable until he let out a deep sigh at the end of their explanation.

Another claimed to have the best water in the world, but when she brought it out Venus nearly fainted at its color. It was pitch-black. It gleamed like mercury, and it tasted like water. It was the strangest thing they’d ever seen. “I think I’m beginning to hallucinate,” Venus said. “What was that?” They were back out in the street. Venus had lost her mobile phone. She was sure the last healer they’d gone to see had stolen it. They thought, after that, that they should maybe try scientists again. They had had enough of unreason. They hitched a ride to Venus’s old university and sought out her former chemistry lecturer. They found him in his office. He had only a few tufts of hair on his head but had copious hair in his nostrils and on the back of his neck. He looked old and a bit tired, and there was no animation in his eyes when he saw Venus. “I remember you,” he said. “It’s Venus, isn’t it? You were the prettiest girl in the whole university, did you know that? We all considered it a special privilege to have you in our classes. What can I do for you?” After the initial discomfiture produced by his remark, they told him why they were there. He listened to them with his eyes shut. When they finished, he sighed.

“I guess I’m a little more tired than I thought I was.” “You must be. You’ve done all the driving. You got us out of there. You saved us.” He must think I’m joking with him. I wish I knew how to say it better. How come so many things can sound mean and nice at the same time? “Could we lie together?” he asks. I crawl over the seat, wrapping up against him. “Yes, of course. Let me settle in here with you for a bit. Why not?” It feels good to snuggle him. Warm and just right. James is thinner than I remember. I can feel his bones. “Why don’t we do this more often?” I say, nuzzling against him. “Because we haven’t wanted to?” James says. He’s drifting off. I can hear his voice grow thin. I’m not ready to sleep. Not ready to be alone. “Hey,” I say to him. “Yeah?” “Stay awake with me for a little bit.” “O.K.” “Breast Cancer.” “What?” “Breast Cancer is picking up speed. Landfall is expected at twenty-one hundred hours.” “Oh. Ha. Yeah. I almost forgot about that. Boris. So weird. Boris.” When James is silent for a while I nudge him. “Your turn,” I say. “O.K. It’s so hard to think.” His voice trails off and I nudge him again. Then he says, “Maybe we’ve thought of the best ones already.” “No, we haven’t, we haven’t. I swear. There are so many more.” “O.K.,” he says. “But this one isn’t so great. Are you ready?” I say that I am. I lean in close. “Balls.” I squeeze his hand. “There you go.” “Balls is blowing at seventy-five miles per hour.” “They sure is,” I say. “Hurricane Balls rolled in this morning and people are afraid to leave their homes.” James doesn’t laugh. I need to leave him alone. He needs his space. “Beloved,” James whispers, and it’s the last thing I hear him say to me before he falls asleep. “Beloved is coming,” I say to no one, listening for his breath. “Close your windows. Go down into the basement and don’t come out until she’s gone.”

Paragraph 2:
I felt the weight of exhaustion settling into my bones as I nestled closer to James, noticing how his frame seemed more delicate than I remembered, his shoulders less broad beneath my touch. The familiar comfort of his presence was exactly what I needed, yet something felt different tonight. We fell into our old game of hurricane names, a peculiar ritual we'd developed over countless nights like this one. "They should name one Breast Cancer," I mused, trying to keep him engaged, to which he responded with a drowsy chuckle and countered, "Or Balls." I could feel him drifting away into sleep, though I desperately wanted him to stay present with me, to continue our absurd yet meaningful exchange. The hurricane game had always been our way of processing things we couldn't quite face directly, turning serious matters into something more manageable through humor and metaphor. I watched as his eyelids grew heavier, fighting against the pull of sleep, and I knew I was losing him to the night. Before surrendering completely, he whispered "Beloved" - his final contribution to our game, though it felt more like a confession than a hurricane name. As his breathing steadied into the rhythm of sleep, I continued the game alone, silently mouthing names into the darkness. It struck me then how this moment perfectly captured our relationship: me, still awake and reaching for connection, while James drifted peacefully into his dreams. The space between us felt both intimate and vast, filled with all the things we'd said through our playful naming of storms and all the things we'd left unspoken. I remained there, counting names like sheep, finding solace in the quiet company of his sleeping form and the endless possibilities of destructive weather patterns yet to be named.

As I sat there, enveloped in the warmth of their home, I couldn't help but reflect on the unexpected intimacy that had unfolded between the three of us—S, Roy, and Mandy. It was a peculiar situation, one that seemed to straddle the line between reality and a dreamlike narrative. When Roy and Mandy welcomed me into their lives, offering me a place to stay instead of returning to the cold anonymity of a hostel, I felt a profound sense of belonging. I reveled in the idea of Daniel, an old acquaintance, wondering about my whereabouts, perhaps even feeling a pang of curiosity or concern. Roy, ever the gracious host, set up a fold-out bed for me, and Mandy, with her nurturing spirit, handed me a pair of pajamas and gave me a few pointers about the shower. The simple gesture of a genuine hug from Mandy stirred something within me, making me feel as if I had found a long-lost sister.

Despite the inherent risks of opening their home to a stranger, both Roy and Mandy seemed at ease, their trust enveloping me like a warm blanket. As they retired for the night, I speculated about their private thoughts, wondering if they had any reservations or lingering doubts about their decision. A part of me couldn't help but imagine the intimate moments they might share behind closed doors—their whispered conversations, the gentle rustle of sheets, and yes, even the possibility of their lovemaking. In my mind's eye, I played out a scenario where I joined them, a silent observer or perhaps even a participant. Yet, these musings remained locked away, a secret I chose not to share with my husband, knowing such thoughts would be too intimate, too raw.

As I lay on the fold-out bed, listening to the rhythmic breathing of the night, I marveled at the bond that had formed in such a short time. It was more than just the kindness of strangers; it was a connection that transcended the mundane. In that moment, surrounded by the gentle hum of domesticity, I felt a rare sense of peace, as if I had stumbled upon a hidden sanctuary. The world outside seemed distant, its chaos and uncertainties muffled by the walls of this newfound haven. As sleep finally claimed me, I realized that this encounter, with all its complexities and unspoken desires, had etched itself into my heart, a poignant reminder of the beauty and intricacy of human connection.

Why do I say “of course”? I’m not sure—only that it’s so easy to imagine the intimacy of the three of them as they giggled at baby albums in that bright, bare kitchen, and how much nicer a stay in this pristine house must have seemed than a sheepish return to the hostel. Also, S said, she liked the idea of Daniel wondering where she was. She wanted him to suffer. Roy made up the fold-out bed, as he’d done for me so many times, and told S to help herself to anything in the kitchen. Then he withdrew. Mandy found the girl some pajamas. She issued warnings about the delicate temperament of the downstairs shower, then she and S hugged in such a genuine way that Mandy, apparently, had felt as if they were sisters. At this point in the story, someone in Mandy and Roy’s audience would usually ask if it had occurred to them that the girl might rob them, and Mandy and Roy would always say no, absolutely not. And Mandy would say that she had only done what she hoped some stranger might one day do, if necessary, for her own daughter. When she said this, she would lean down to kiss the baby’s head, or she and Roy would look at each other as if to say, “Don’t worry, we’ll never actually let her out of our sight—there will never be any need for the kindness of strangers.” Both Roy and Mandy insisted that they’d felt perfectly safe with S in their house, and that they had slept long and deep through the night. But surely Mandy must have spent some time, during that night, gazing at the dim square of the bedroom skylight and thinking about the girl sleeping on the fold-out, who had been so unabashed about changing that Mandy had seen her young, buoyant breasts. And Roy must have thought about how he’d gone around making sure that the windows and doors were locked, and all the time there was a stranger in the house with them, a girl who might have been anyone, whose name they didn’t even know. I’ve also imagined them having thrilled, hushed sex, knowing that the girl was sleeping downstairs—of course I’ve imagined that, though I probably won’t mention it to my husband. And I’ve imagined the girl coming into their room in the early light, climbing into bed with her long blond limbs.

An offbeat teen series about burnouts and nerds at a Michigan high school in the 1980-81 school year, it arrived on Sept. 25, 1999, with the praise of critics and a niche sensibility. That combo, in the days of mass network TV, tended to mark a new series as Least Likely to Succeed, and NBC axed it midyear. The complete season aired in 2000 on Fox Family Channel, a cable destination one step up from a test pattern. But like the homeroom wallflower who blossomed late, this bittersweetly brilliant one-season wonder aged well, into something influential, groundbreaking and — dare I say it — cool.

Paragraph 1:
Every December, I watch with a mix of fascination and bewilderment as Mary performs her peculiar ritual at the fireplace, a tradition that has transformed my great-grandfather's dignified portrait into something far more macabre. The painting, which once captured his stern Victorian demeanor, now features a stark white skull symbolizing Christ's death, though Mary's additions have made it increasingly difficult to recognize either the original subject or its religious significance. She approaches the ceremony with an almost theatrical flair, lighting candles and singing hymns before carefully slipping bones from our Christmas dinners into a discrete slit she's made in the canvas. The collection includes turkey bones, ham bones, and most notably, a small bone from our old family dog Max, which she added with particular reverence and a characteristic chuckle. What strikes me most about Mary's tradition is not just its oddity, but the way she manages to find humor in what others might consider morbid. She'll often quip about "feeding the ancestors" or joke that great-grandfather's portrait is "putting on weight" with each new addition. I've lost count of how many bones now rest behind that canvas, but Mary keeps a mental inventory, treating each one as a testament to both life and death. While I initially found this custom unsettling, I've come to appreciate how Mary's approach to memorializing our family history, however unconventional, brings a strange comfort and levity to the otherwise solemn subject of mortality.

Paragraph 2:
Every year, Mary would light candles around the table and sing songs and pray for the dead, before putting everything away again. If you look at the painting above Mary’s fireplace, you’ll see a skull. It’s supposed to represent the death of Jesus Christ. It used to be a portrait of my great-grandfather. Anyway, every year after Christmas dinner, she puts his bones in the painting, through a slit in the canvas that she cut herself. Then she always adds a bone from that year’s dinner. One year, she added one from our dog who had passed away. I don’t know why she keeps adding bones. Now everyone thinks it’s a tradition or something. If you ask her why she keeps doing it, she just says, “Because it makes us happy.” We get to sit together at the dinner table and have a nice meal while praying for our departed loved ones. And we all get to have a laugh at the absurdity of it all. Mary laughs, too. She loves making jokes about the bones. Sometimes she says stuff like “I wonder how long we can keep up this tradition!” Or “I hope no one else has died since last year!” Or she says stuff like “I’m not sure where the dog bone went but he must be happy wherever he is!” Or she says, “Why did God create such a beautiful world with so much death?” Or “If God created everything he could possibly want, why didn’t he give us a way to turn off our brains?”

I see them lean into you. That’s not friends.” “When you reach my age, women lean into you for a variety of reasons.” “I could use some friends like that.” Blondy felt he’d been offered a significant confidence. Insouciant as he was, he hadn’t ever felt that he could quite ask a man as unattractive as Zwelish how he made do. Before any tenderness broke out between them, however, Zwelish thrust a knife in. “I’ve seen you hitting on those illiterate babysitters, too. The whole block talks about it, you know.” This prospect tipped Blondy back on his heels for an instant: that he, who prided himself on his panoramic insight into Seventy-eighth Street, could be himself under the microscope. And, using that instant, Zwelish made his escape. A bruising friendship, if it was one. And, like Blondy and me at the movies, many weeks could pass between encounters. Did Blondy only fantasize that Zwelish peered out of his basement window slats deciding whether or not, on a given afternoon, he wanted to see Blondy? In any case, when they did meet, Zwelish generally seemed to have some willful challenge ready, as if he prepared with flash cards. “Not awake yet?” if he saw Blondy with coffee in the afternoon. “Never awake at all anymore,” Blondy would say, always willing to play the decrepit jester, the has-been, hoping he could un-push Zwelish’s buttons.

Paragraph 1:
As the nation grapples with the persistent issue of racial disparities in healthcare, a disturbing trend has emerged in which conservative groups are leveraging the legal system to undermine initiatives aimed at addressing these inequities. A case in point is the lawsuit filed by the Californians for Equal Rights Foundation against the City and County of San Francisco, which takes aim at programs such as the Abundant Birth Project. This project provides targeted support to Black women and Pacific Islanders, who face alarmingly high rates of maternal mortality - a stark reality that is both a social and medical crisis. Despite the overwhelming evidence of these disparities, conservatives argue that such programs violate the 14th Amendment, a claim that rings hollow in the face of the dire need for intervention. Meanwhile, the Department of Health and Human Services is investigating Cedars-Sinai Medical Center for alleged racism following the tragic death of a Black woman during childbirth, a stark reminder of the human cost of inaction. These lawsuits not only hinder efforts to address the systemic issues driving these disparities but also perpetuate a culture of denial and obstruction. The recent warning issued by a conservative law group to Howard University, a historically Black institution, to cease admissions practices that take into account the very racial disparities they seek to address, is a stark illustration of this misguided crusade. With its medical school's limited slots primarily reserved for Black students, Howard University is fulfilling its founding mission to educate disadvantaged students and address the gaping healthcare disparities that plague our nation. It is unconscionable that these efforts are being threatened by those who would seek to maintain the status quo of inequality. By attempting to dismantle these initiatives, conservatives are, in effect, putting the lives of countless Black women and their families at risk, and undermining the very fabric of our society.

Paragraph 2:
Last year, a group called the Californians for Equal Rights Foundation sued the City and County of San Francisco over their funding of several programs aimed at eliminating disparities Black Americans face, including the Abundant Birth Project, which gives stipends for prenatal care, among other supports, to Black women and Pacific Islanders to help prevent them from dying during childbirth. Even though maternal mortality for Black women in the United States is up to four times as high as it is for white women, conservatives argue that programs specifically helping the women most likely to die violate the 14th Amendment. Even as this lawsuit makes its way through the courts, there are signs of why these sorts of programs remain necessary: It was announced last year that the Department of Health and Human Services opened a civil rights investigation into Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles for allegations of racism against Black mothers following the death of a Black woman who went there to give birth. It is impossible to look at the realities of Black life that these programs seek to address and come to the conclusion that the lawsuits are trying to make society more fair or just or free. Instead they are foreclosing the very initiatives that could actually make it so. And nothing illuminates that more than the conservative law group’s letter warning Howard — an institution so vaunted among Black Americans that it’s known as the Mecca — that its medical school must stop any admissions practices that have a “racial component.” Howard’s medical school, founded in 1868, remains one of just four historically Black medical schools in the United States. Howard received nearly 9,000 medical-school applicants for 130 open seats in 2023. And while almost all of the students who apply to be Howard undergraduates are Black, because there are so few medical-school slots available, most applicants to Howard’s medical school are not. Since the school was founded to serve descendants of slavery with a mission to educate “disadvantaged students for careers in medicine,” however, most of the students admitted each year are Black.

Meanwhile, Marina's infant daughter remained in the hospital, as her older sister, Anya, was unable to care for her due to her husband's objections. Alisa opted not to relocate to Alexander's larger, yet unkempt apartment, instead choosing to remain in her own, which boasted a new, clean bathtub. Six months would pass before Marina was discharged from the psychiatric hospital, but Alisa was hesitant to entrust the baby to her care, citing concerns about Marina's fragile psychological state. The box with the barbiturates was still in the drawer, but Alisa could no longer make use of her husband’s wedding present. That is, theoretically she could. Sometime . . . when the circumstances were ripe . . .

Paragraph 1:
As you pedal your bicycle through the vibrant tapestry of the Cotswolds in the spring of 1963, the fresh, crisp air fills your lungs, and the sun bathes the rolling hills in a warm golden glow. This is your junior year abroad at the University of York, a year that has become a turning point in your life. At 21, you’ve made the bold decision to devote your life to literature, a choice that has left your father disheartened, as he had dreamed of you engaging in community service. Yet here you are, navigating the picturesque English countryside, feeling more alive and true to yourself than ever before. As you glide into a quaint Saxon market town, a jumble of antique shops and cobblestone streets beckons with their rustic charm. One particular shop, cluttered with forgotten relics, catches your eye. Inside, the dust dances in the light streaming through the window, and your fingers trace the spines of countless volumes until they pause on a book titled "To the Measures Fall" by Elton Wentworth. The book is a tactile wonder, with its deluxe binding and rough-cut pages, whispering secrets of a bygone era. As you thumb through its pages, you are transported to rural England, before and after the tremors of World War I. The narrative begins with an eerie snowstorm in 1913, a harbinger of the upheaval to come, and culminates in the haunting discovery of a young captain’s body. The story's voice ebbs and flows between second person and third person, but it speaks most intimately to you, drawing you into its world. It’s as though Wentworth himself is guiding you through the historical tapestry he has woven, each sentence a thread that pulls you deeper into the tale. The book seems to echo your own journey, a blend of history and personal discovery, and you can't help but feel a kinship with its characters who, like you, are navigating the uncertainties of life. As you stand in the musty shop, you realize that this chance encounter with Wentworth's novel is more than a mere coincidence; it is a serendipitous meeting that affirms your path. Cradling the book in your arms, you feel a resolute sense of purpose, ready to embrace the literary world and all the stories waiting to be told.

Paragraph 2:
First read-through: you are biking through the Cotswolds when you come across the thing. Spring of ’63. Twenty-one years old, in your junior year abroad at the University of York, after a spring term green with Chaucer, Milton, Byron, and Swinburne. (Remember Swinburne?) Year One of a life newly devoted to words. Your recent change, of course, has crushed your father. He long hoped that you would follow through on that Kennedy-inspired dream of community service. You, who might have become a first-rate social worker. You, who might have done good things for the species, or at least for the old neighborhood. But life will be books for you, from here on. Nothing has ever felt more preordained. Term’s out, and it’s time to see every square mile of this island. Bicycle clips, a Blue Guide, a transistor radio, and skin-hugging rain. Villages slip past on valley roads as twisty as the clauses in Henry James. The book turns up in a junk shop in an old Saxon market town whose name you will remember as almost certainly having an “m” in it. Among the rusted baby buggies and ancient radios you find old cooking magazines, books on fly-tying and photography, late-fifties spy novels with cardboard covers worn as soft as felt. The thing pops out at you: “To the Measures Fall,” by someone named Elton Wentworth. There’s nothing else like it in the shop. It’s a fat tome with rough-cut pages in a deluxe, tooled binding. The dust jacket has disappeared, but the front matter suggests that you know all about Mr. Wentworth already. Born in 1888, the author of twelve previous books and the winner of awards too numerous to mention. The first line reads, “A freak snow hit late that year, two weeks after the sand martins returned to the gravel pits near the South Downs.” The next few paragraphs sketch out a hard-pressed town, Wotton-on-Wold, much like the one you are in, with the “m” in it. On page 3, the author reveals the date: 1913. On the last page, a village search party finds the body of a young amputee captain who served at the Somme lying at the bottom of said gravel pits. Only seven years have passed, but the lilting opening cadences have darkened into fragments from another world. The book seems to be a sweeping portrait of rural England before and after the First World War.

In a cozy, dimly lit living room, a woman sat quietly on the plush sofa, her thoughts swirling like autumn leaves in a brisk wind. Across from her, a man held a bottle of wine, its deep burgundy color glistening invitingly under the soft glow of a nearby lamp. With a warm smile, he extended the bottle toward her, along with a small box of chocolate mints, a peace offering of sorts. The gesture was kind, an olive branch in the form of simple indulgences, and it momentarily lifted the heavy veil of her inner turmoil. As they exchanged pleasantries about the upcoming party, which was slated to begin after nine on Saturday evening, she nodded along, her mind only half engaged in the conversation. While the others buzzed with excitement about the festivities, envisioning laughter and music filling the air, she found herself longing for solitude, imagining the quiet pleasure of savoring the wine and mints alone. Her internal struggle, however, was a tempest of anger and frustration, emotions she could not quite articulate, even to herself. She wanted to reassure the others that the noise from their party did not bother her, that she was genuinely untroubled by their exuberance, but her lips remained sealed, an invisible barrier preventing her from bridging the chasm between her inner world and the lively atmosphere that enveloped her. The disconnect lingered, a silent echo of her unspoken words, leaving her isolated even in the company of friends. As plans for the party continued to unfold with growing anticipation, she remained a distant observer, caught in the intricate web of her own emotions, yearning for a sense of belonging yet unable to reach out and grasp it.

Paragraph 2:
—And this is in case none of that works said the other one. He was holding a bottle of wine. He laughed, put it on the table. It’s a nice red, well, we like it. In any case, that’s yours. —Thanks. There’s no need for that. —Well, it’ll do no harm. And here’s some chocolate mints, if you like that sort of thing. I love them. I could go through a whole box without even noticing. —He could, and he does. —Anyway, that’s the lot. She looked at what they’d brought for her. She pictured herself in the living room, in the armchair, her ears plugged with foam, drinking wine and eating the After Eights. —What time is your party? —Oh, I don’t know. I imagine it won’t get going until after nine or something. They looked at each other. —Eight, nine. Whenever people show up I suppose. With the long evenings no one thinks it’s evening until the sun goes down. Especially if it’s a nice day, which is what’s forecast. —Saturday? —Yes, Saturday. This Saturday. You’ll be here? —Yes. Yes, I’ll be here. Where else would she be? They all looked at each other. —That’s everything. I think. They moved toward the door, quieter now. She had not helped, she thought. She had been silent and they could see her face. She wanted to smile and laugh and joke with them. Tell them that it was fine, they weren’t to worry, they should have a nice night, make as much noise as they liked, she wouldn’t mind. But she did mind. She felt anger. She was angry. That, in any case, was what she told herself.

Paragraph 1:
From the ditch behind the house, Kate could see her husband up at the old forestry hut, where mottled scrubland gave way to dense lines of trees. “Colman!” she called, but he didn’t hear. She watched him swing the axe in a clean arc and thought that from this distance he could be any age. Lately, she’d found herself wondering what he’d been like as a very young man, a man of twenty. She hadn’t known him then. He had already turned forty when they met. It was early April, the fields and ditches coming green again after winter. Grass verges crept outward, thickening the arteries of narrow lanes. “There’s nothing wrong,” she shouted when she was still some yards off. He was in his shirtsleeves, his coat discarded on the grass beside him. “Emer rang from London. She’s coming home.” He put down the axe. “Home for a visit, or home for good?” He had dismantled the front of the hut and one of the side walls. On the floor inside, if floor was the word, she saw empty beer cans, blankets, a ball of blackened tinfoil. “Just for a few days. A friend from college has an exhibition. I wasn’t given much detail. You know Emer.” “Yes,” he said, and frowned. “When is she arriving?” “Tomorrow evening, and she’s bringing Oisín.” “Tomorrow? And she’s only after ringing now?” “It’ll be good to have them stay. Oisín has started school since we last saw him.” She waited to see if he might mention the room, but he picked up the axe, as if impatient to get back to work. “What will we do if the Forestry Service come round?” she said. “They haven’t come round this past year. They don’t come round when we ring about the drinking or the fires.” He swung the axe at a timber beam supporting what was left of the roof. There was a loud splintering but the beam stood firm, and he drew back the axe, prepared to strike again.

Paragraph 2:
Kate stood at the edge of the clearing, watching Colman work methodically at the old forestry hut, his movements precise and purposeful in the crisp early April air. She called out his name twice before he finally heard her, the sound of his labor having drowned out her initial attempts. As she observed him, her mind wandered to thoughts of his younger days, trying to imagine the man he had been before they met when he was already forty – perhaps more impetuous, less weathered by time. The forest around them was showing signs of spring's arrival, with tender buds emerging on branches and early wildflowers dotting the forest floor, nature's own quiet rebellion against winter's lingering chill. When she finally had his attention, Kate shared the news about Emer's upcoming visit from London, along with little Oisín, but Colman seemed more engrossed in his dismantling work, offering only a distracted nod in response. His hands never stopped moving across the old timber as she spoke, his focus unwavering from the task before him. When Kate voiced her concern about potential trouble from the Forestry Service, Colman dismissed it with a slight wave of his hand, reminding her of their historical indifference to previous issues in this remote corner of the woods. The conversation faded into the ambient sounds of the forest as Colman returned fully to his work, the rhythmic swing of his axe against a sturdy beam punctuating the air with decisive thwacks, each strike echoing his determination to complete the task at hand, regardless of any potential consequences.

Paragraph 1:
As Paul sat on the porch, meticulously dismantling a dark chocolate bar into smaller, more manageable pieces, he couldn't help but feel a sense of accomplishment wash over him. It had been three weeks since his fifty-fifth birthday, and he had finally quit smoking, replacing the habit with a newfound love for the rich, velvety taste of dark chocolate. The sweet treat had become his go-to companion, providing a sense of comfort and familiarity as he navigated the ups and downs of small-town life. As he savored the chocolate, he scrolled through his emails, his eyes scanning the screen with a sense of detachment, until he was interrupted by Kate, who appeared beside him with a look of curiosity etched on her face. "What's the point of a hammock, anyway?" she asked, eyeing the colorful fabric slung between two sturdy oak trees. Without waiting for a response, she climbed into the hammock, settling in with a contented sigh. Paul chuckled, raising his phone to capture the moment, and at Kate's request, he snapped a photo of her lounging in the hammock. She examined the image, her expression lukewarm, before sending it to herself, a quirk that Paul had grown accustomed to over the years.As they set out to explore the town, Paul and Kate were struck by its limitations. Gone were the overwhelming choices of city life, replaced by a handful of quaint shops and eateries that seemed to blend together in a haze of familiarity. They strolled hand in hand, taking in the sights and sounds of the sleepy town, until they reached the river, where Paul couldn't resist the urge to capture the scenery on camera. Kate good-naturedly teased him about his love of taking pictures without people, but Paul was undeterred, snapping away as they walked along the riverbank. As they turned a bend in the path, Paul's curiosity got the better of him, and he veered off course, making a beeline for a private driveway that was clearly marked as off-limits. Kate raised an eyebrow, amused by Paul's unpredictable nature when it came to rules. "You're going to get us in trouble one of these days," she said, laughing. Paul just grinned, his eyes twinkling with mischief. As they continued their walk, they came across a cluster of bee boxes, which Kate identified with a confident nod. The sight sparked a memory of Paul's past affinity for the ocean, symbolized by a worn leather bracelet he no longer wore. The day was already feeling long, and as they made their way back to the town center, Paul and Kate realized they had exhausted the town's limited attractions by lunchtime. Despite the lack of excitement, they were content in each other's company, happy to while away the hours in their own little bubble of small-town bliss.

Paragraph 2:
Jolted by his recent, fifty-fifth birthday, Paul had finally kicked a decades-old cigarette habit. In its place, he ate at least two bars of dark chocolate a day. He broke them into perfect squares with the wrapper still on—to prevent mess. It seemed like another wish for a new self. Now he was dismantling a bar at the counter and reading work e-mails. “Do people ever go in the hammock, you think?” Kate said. “Or is it just there to be cute?” She hoisted herself into it. Instantly the fabric swallowed her up. Was it comfortable, lying there, or not comfortable? Not really comfortable. Kate poked just her head out of the hammock. “Take a picture.” Paul paused his work on the chocolate bar to hold up his phone. “Let me see,” she said. Paul came over with chocolate breath and handed her the phone. She zoomed in on her own face. “Eh,” she said, though she swiftly sent the photo to herself. It took not insignificant effort to get out of the hammock. All these towns where there was nothing to do but walk up and down the sidewalks and go in and out of small stores. The ritual seemed important, though, the getting out of the city. Even if you mainly did the same things you would do there, at least here you were relieved of the fatigue of choice. There was only one of everything—one Thai restaurant, one coffee place, one bakery. They walked all the way to the river. The river didn’t look so wide from here. It was a flat, dull green. They stepped out on the rocks, then stepped back. The train tracks ran right alongside the water. Paul took multiple photos of the river. Kate hated photos without people in them—no one ever looks at those kinds of pictures again, she said, but Paul disagreed. And maybe Paul did look at his photos—what did Kate know?—maybe he was regularly scrolling back through his archive of flowers and sunsets and mountaintop views, the collection of things he’d seen, a full moon recorded on his phone as a blurry gape of light. Paul wanted to go a little way down a private driveway. Just to check it out, he said. He surprised Kate sometimes, what rules he’d break and what rules he’d obey. There were bee boxes stacked in a field. He didn’t know what they were—she did. It was satisfying to have the whiff of rural knowledge. Paul had grown up going to the beach for the summer months. He was passionate about the ocean. This was represented by the blue rubber bracelet he wore on his wrist until Kate made fun of it and he stopped wearing it. It had been some type of charity Clean Up the Ocean thing. Kate kept looking at the train tracks. It felt as though a train would come barrelling through at any second, and they were both bracing for it. No train came. Already the day seemed extremely long. They’d walked the length of Main Street. Browsed through any store they could conceivably enter. It was barely lunchtime.

Paragraph 1:
Over the past three weeks, Mitchell has immersed himself in an unexpected chapter of his life, volunteering at Mother Teresa’s Home for the Dying Destitutes in Calcutta. Though he arrived with no prior experience in caregiving, Mitchell found himself entrusted with the profound responsibility of assisting terminally ill patients in their final days, offering them peace and love when they need it most. His duties are varied and intimate, ranging from administering medication and feeding to simply providing a comforting presence. Despite initial apprehensions, Mitchell has found the experience surprisingly manageable, largely due to the guidance of a friendly beekeeper from New Mexico who took him under his wing on his first day. This mentor introduced him to the facility’s reality, explaining its lack of organization and urging him to lend a hand wherever necessary. The facility itself is smaller and less structured than Mitchell had envisioned, housing fewer than a hundred beds in the men's ward and even fewer in the women's. The conditions are basic, with a kitchen blackened by soot and a primitive laundry setup, yet these challenges have not deterred him. Instead, they have reinforced his resolve to offer whatever small comforts he can to the patients. As he navigates the facility, Mitchell observes that, despite the stark environment, the patients are generally cleaner and healthier than he initially feared. He learns that many have nowhere else to turn, yet they display a remarkable resilience that inspires him daily. Each interaction, whether it involves a gentle conversation or a shared silence, deepens his understanding of the human capacity for dignity amidst adversity. Through his volunteer work, Mitchell has not only provided care and companionship but has also forged connections that transcend language and cultural barriers. The experience has reshaped his perceptions, revealing the profound impact of compassion and the simple act of being present. As the weeks pass, Mitchell reflects on his journey, recognizing that while he set out to give, he has also received invaluable lessons in humility and humanity. This transformative experience in Calcutta has left an indelible mark on him, one that he will carry forward long after his volunteer stint concludes.

Paragraph 2:
Mitchell had never so much as changed a baby’s diaper before. He’d never nursed a sick person, or seen anyone die, and now here he was, surrounded by a mass of dying people, and it was his job to help them die at peace, knowing they were loved. For the past three weeks, Mitchell had been in Calcutta, going to Mother Teresa’s Home for the Dying Destitutes Monday through Friday, from nine in the morning until a little after one, and doing whatever needed doing. This included giving the men medicine, feeding them, sitting on their beds and providing company, looking into their faces and holding their hands. These things weren’t something you had to learn how to do, and yet, in his twenty-two years on the planet, Mitchell had done few of them before and some of them not at all. He’d worried that he might run screaming from the place after ten minutes. But things had gone better than he expected. On his first day, he’d been taken around by a friendly, broad-shouldered guy who ran a honeybee farm in New Mexico. “You’ll see there’s not much organization here,” the beekeeper said, leading Mitchell down the aisle between the tiers of beds. “People come and go all the time, so you just have to jump in where you can.” The enterprise was a lot more modest than Mitchell had envisaged. The men’s ward contained fewer than a hundred beds, maybe closer to seventy-five. The women’s side was even smaller. The beekeeper led him past the soot-blackened kitchen and the equally primitive laundry. A nun stood before a vat of boiling water, poking the wash with a long stick, while another carried wet sheets up to the roof to hang out to dry. Mitchell took it easy that day, settling in. He spent most of his time providing small comforts, bringing the patients glasses of water or massaging their heads if they complained of headache. On the whole, the men were cleaner and healthier than he’d feared. Though there were a dozen or so superannuated patients, lying immobile in their beds, many were middle-aged, a few even young. It was often hard to tell what they were suffering from. No charts hung from their beds. What was plain was that the men had nowhere else to go.

Paragraph 1:
As I stand at the window, staring out into the darkness, my mind is consumed with worry about my daughter Maddy. Her car is in the shop, and she's being forced to walk home in this torrential rain. I thought she was going to be picked up by her friend Kimberly after spending the evening at the mall, but apparently, those plans fell through. Now, I'm left to fret about her safety, my imagination running wild with all the terrible things that could happen to her on her solo journey. Just as I'm starting to get really worked up, our neighbor Alice K. Petermann appears in the doorway, a mischievous glint in her eye. "Waiting for me?" she teases, and I force a laugh, trying to play it cool. But I'm not fooled - I know she's just trying to distract me from my worries. Maureen, my partner, and I are interrupted by the shrill ring of the phone, and I immediately dismiss it as unimportant. But Maureen, ever the voice of reason, insists on answering it, suggesting that it could be Maddy calling to check in. I feel a surge of hope mixed with anxiety as Maureen picks up the receiver, and I wait with bated breath to see if it's indeed my daughter on the other end, safe and sound. The seconds tick by, and I'm left to wonder if Maddy is okay, and when I'll finally be able to breathe a sigh of relief.

Paragraph 2:
But my daughter. She’s out there in the dark and the rain, walking home. Maureen and I bought her a car, a Honda Civic, the safest thing on four wheels, but the car was used—pre-owned, in dealerspeak—and as it happens it’s in the shop with transmission problems and, because she just had to see her friends and gossip and giggle and balance slick multicolored clumps of raw fish and pickled ginger on conjoined chopsticks at the mall, Kimberly picked her up and Kimberly will bring her home. Maddy has a cell phone and theoretically she could have called us, but she didn’t—or that’s how it appears. And so she’s walking. In the rain. And Alice K. Petermann, of 16 Briar Lane, white, divorced, a Realtor with Hyperion, who has picked at a salad and left her glasses on the bar, loses control of her vehicle. Her face appears in the doorway, the pale lobes of her breasts and the dark nipples visible through the clinging black silk. “Oh, are you waiting for me?” she says, making a game of it. She hovers at the door, and I can see the smile creep across her lips, the pleasure of the moment, drawing it out. “Because I thought I might go down and work in the garden for a while—it won’t take long, a couple hours, maybe. You know, spread a little manure, bank up some of the mulch on the roses. You’ll wait for me, won’t you?” Then the phone rings. We stare blankly at each other through the first two rings and then Maureen says, “I’d better get it,” and I say, “No, no, forget it—it’s nothing. It’s nobody.” But she’s already moving. “Forget it!” I shout, and her voice drifts back to me—“What if it’s Maddy?”—then I watch her put her lips to the receiver and whisper, “Hello?”

Paragraph 1:
Sara was either asleep or pretending to be when Juliet went to pick up the tea tray. Her sleeping state, her dozing state, and her waking state now had such delicate and shifting boundaries that it was hard to distinguish among them. At any rate, she spoke—she said in little more than a whisper, “Juliet?” Juliet paused in the doorway. “You must think Don is . . . rather a simpleton,” Sara said. “But he isn’t well. He’s a diabetic. It’s serious.” Juliet said, “Yes.” “He needs his faith.” “Foxhole argument,” Juliet said, but quietly, and perhaps Sara did not hear, for she went on talking. “My faith isn’t so simple,” Sara said, her voice shaky (and seeming to Juliet, at this moment, strategically pathetic). “I can’t describe it. But it’s . . . all I can say is . . . it’s something. It’s a . . . wonderful . . . something. When it gets really bad for me—when it gets so bad I . . . You know what I think then?” Juliet shook her head. “I think, All right. I think, Soon—soon I’ll see Juliet.” Dreaded (Dearest) Eric, Where to begin? I am fine and Penelope is fine. Considering. She walks confidently now around Sara’s bed but is still leery of striking out with no support. The summer heat is amazing, compared with the West Coast. Even when it rains. It’s a good thing it does rain, because Sam is going full tilt at the market-garden business. The other day I rode around with him in the ancient vehicle delivering the newly dug first potatoes of the season and fresh raspberries and raspberry jam (made by a sort of Junior Ilse Koch type who inhabits our kitchen). He is quite gung-ho. Sara stays in bed and dozes or looks at outdated fashion magazines. A minister came to visit her and he and I got into a big stupid row about the existence of God or some such hot topic. The visit is going O.K., though. . . . This was a letter that Juliet found years later. Eric must have saved it by accident—it had no particular importance in their lives. She had gone back to the house of her childhood once more, a few months after that visit, for Sara’s funeral. Irene was no longer around, and Juliet had no memory of asking or being told where she was. Most probably she had married. As Sam did again, a couple of years later. He married a fellow-teacher, a good-natured, handsome, competent woman. They lived in her house—Sam tore down the house where he and Sara had lived, and extended the garden for his crops. When his wife retired, they bought a trailer and began to go on long winter trips. They visited Juliet twice at Whale Bay. Eric took them out in his boat. He and Sam got along well. As Sam said, like a house afire. When she read the letter, Juliet winced, as anybody does on discovering the preserved and disconcerting voice of some past fabricated self. She wondered at the sprightly coverup, contrasting, as it did, with the pain of her memories. Then she thought that some shift must have taken place, during that visit, which she did not remember. Some shift concerning where home was. It had stopped being at Whale Bay with Eric and had slipped back to where it had been before, all her life before. Because it’s what happens at home that you try to protect, as best you can, for as long as you can. And yet she had not protected Sara. When Sara had said, “Soon I’ll see Juliet,” Juliet had found no reply. Could she not have managed something? Why should it have been so difficult? Just to say, “Yes.” To Sara it would have meant so much—to herself, surely, so little. But she had turned away. She had carried the tray to the kitchen, and there she had washed and dried the cups and also the glass that had held grape soda. She had put everything away.

Paragraph 2:
As Juliet sat in her dimly lit living room, surrounded by the faint scent of old books and the soft hum of the evening, she found herself transported back to a visit she had made to her childhood home many years ago. It was a trip that had left an indelible mark on her, a poignant reminder of the complexities of human relationships and the fragility of life. During that visit, Juliet had spent time with Sara, who had been either asleep or pretending to be, as they sat together in the warm glow of the afternoon sun. As they conversed in hushed tones, Sara had spoken about her husband, Don, and his struggles with diabetes, her voice laced with a mix of concern and resignation. Juliet had listened intently, struck by the depth of Sara's faith, which seemed to be a complex tapestry of hope and despair, woven together with threads of doubt and uncertainty. As they talked, Sara had turned to Juliet and said, "You know, seeing you gives me comfort during difficult times," her words piercing Juliet's heart like a gentle rebuke.As Juliet reflected on that visit, she remembered the letter she had written to Eric, a friend from her past, in which she had described the encounter with Sara in vivid detail. In the letter, Juliet had also written about the other people she had met during her visit, including Sam, who had been bursting with enthusiasm about his market-garden business, and a minister with whom she had had a disagreement about the nature of faith. The letter, which had been penned in a moment of introspection, had been lost for years, only to resurface recently, its words and emotions still raw and unbridled. As Juliet read through the letter, she was struck by the changes that had taken place in her life since then, the twists and turns that had led her to where she was today. She felt a pang of guilt for not being more supportive to Sara during that visit, for not being more present in the moment. Juliet realized that she had maintained an emotional distance, a barrier that had prevented her from fully connecting with Sara and the others.As she delved deeper into her memories, Juliet began to see that visit in a new light, as a moment of missed opportunities and unspoken words. She remembered the way Sara had looked at her, with eyes that seemed to hold a deep sadness, a longing for connection and understanding. Juliet felt a sense of regret wash over her, regret for not being more empathetic, for not being more willing to listen and to understand. She realized that she had been so caught up in her own thoughts and emotions that she had neglected the needs of others, that she had failed to be fully present in the moment. As the evening wore on, Juliet's introspection deepened, and she began to see that visit as a microcosm of her life, a reflection of her own struggles with connection and intimacy. She knew that she had always been someone who had maintained a certain distance, a certain reserve, and that this had often prevented her from forming deep and meaningful relationships. As the darkness gathered outside, Juliet felt a sense of resolve forming within her, a determination to be more present, to be more fully engaged with the world around her. She knew that it was a journey she would have to undertake, a journey of self-discovery and growth, but she was ready to take the first step, to begin to bridge the emotional distance that had defined her life for so long.

We like to make sure the other is doing okay, even if it means making up silly reasons for our visits. As I was leaving, Bruno called out to me, claiming he needed flour for baking a cake, which was laughable since he doesn't even cook. I played along, offering to pick some up for him, and we shared a chuckle about it. It's moments like these that I appreciate our little routine, and the playful dynamic we've developed over time. Despite the initial misunderstanding about the nude modeling job, our conversation ended on a lighthearted note, and I looked forward to seeing him again soon.
