Paragraph 1:
Then, as he fell onto the board-hard snow, he raised his head. He watched the back of the wagon and the tiny figures of his mother and sister disappear, and something failed in him. Something broke. At that moment he truly did not care if he was alive or dead. So when he saw the gray shapes, the shadows, bounding lightly from the trees to either side of the trail, far ahead, he was not afraid. The next the boy knew, his father had him wrapped in a blanket and was carrying him home. His father's chest was broad and, although he already spat the tubercular blood that would write the end of his story, he was still a strong man. It would take him many years to die. In those years, the father would tell the boy, who had forgotten this part entirely, that at first when he talked about the shadows the father thought he'd been visited by manidoog. But then, as the boy described the shapes, his father had understood that they were not spirits. Uneasy, he had decided to take his gun back along the trail. He had built up the fire in the cabin, and settled his boy near it, and gone back out into the snow. Perhaps the story spread through our settlements because the father had to tell what he saw, again and again, in order to get rid of it. Perhaps as with all frightful dreams, amaniso, he had to talk about it to destroy its power—though in this case nothing could stop the dream from being real. The shadows' tracks were the tracks of wolves, and in those days, when our guns had taken all their food for furs and hides to sell, the wolves were bold and had abandoned the old agreement between them and the first humans. For a time, until we understood and let the game increase, the wolves hunted us.

Paragraph 2:
A young boy lay sprawled on the snow, his eyes following the receding figures of his mother and sister as they disappeared into the distance on a wagon, leaving behind a profound sense of despair. The cold bit into his skin, but he remained transfixed, watching the gray shapes flickering among the trees. These shadows, though ominous, did not instill fear in his heart. It was then that his father found him, a strong man despite his sickness, who scooped him up with care, wrapping him snugly in a blanket and carrying him home. Later, his father recounted his initial thoughts, how he had mistaken the shifting shadows for spirits. It was only after hearing his son's description that he realized they were wolves. An unsettling feeling gnawed at him, prompting him to venture back into the woods armed with his gun. The story of the wolves, emboldened by their hunger, spread rapidly through the settlements. The father, in a bid to grapple with his fear, recounted the tale of his discovery time and again. These wolves, having lost their natural wariness of humans, had begun to turn their attention towards hunting people. It was a chilling realization for the community, one that spurred them into action. They understood the need to adapt, to allow the game to flourish once more, so the wolves would return to their natural prey. Gradually, as the forest teemed with life again, the wolves retreated, restoring a fragile peace. The boy, wrapped in the warmth of his father's love and the safety of their home, listened to these stories, learning about courage in the face of fear and the delicate balance between humans and nature. It was a lesson etched in his memory, as vivid as the shadows that danced in the snow.

Paragraph 1:
This was one of the longest speeches I had ever heard Mr. Josie make and I was impressed. Just then the big fish started down and down and down. I was braking with both hands on the drum of the reel and keeping the line almost at breaking point and feeling the metal of the reel drum revolve in slow jerks under my fingers. “How’s the time?” I asked Mr. Josie. “You’ve been with him three hours and fifty minutes.” “I thought you said he couldn’t go down and die,” I said to Carlos. “Hemingway, he has to come up. I know he has to come up.” “Tell him so,” I said. “Get him some water, Carlos,” Mr. Josie said. “Don’t talk, Cap.” The ice water felt good and I spat it out onto my wrists and told Carlos to pour the rest of the glass on the back of my neck. Sweat salted the places on my shoulders where the harness had rubbed them bare but it was so hot in the sun that there was no warm feeling from the blood. It was a July day and the sun was at noon. “Put some more salt water on his head,” Mr. Josie said. “With a sponge.” Just then the fish stopped taking out line. He hung steady for a time, feeling as solid as though I were hooked to a concrete pier, and then slowly he started up. I recovered the line, reeling with the wrist alone, as there was no spring in the rod at all and it was as limp as a weeping willow. When the fish was about a fathom under the surface, so that we could see him looking like a long purple-striped canoe with two great jutting wings, he started to circle slowly. I held all the tension I could on him, to try to shorten the circle. I was holding up to that absolute hardness that indicates the breaking strength of the line when the rod let go.

Paragraph 2:
Under the relentless July sun, I found myself locked in an exhausting battle with a formidable fish, the weight of the struggle bearing down on my arms as I gripped the reel with both hands. The line, taut and trembling, mirrored the tension that coursed through my body. Beside me, Mr. Josie kept track of the time, his updates marking each grueling minute of this aquatic duel. Carlos, ever attentive, handed me water to stave off dehydration, the cool liquid offering brief reprieves from the heat that radiated from the sky and the discomfort of the fishing harness digging into my skin. The fish was a powerful adversary, initially diving deep into the blue abyss, pulling me into a descent filled with uncertainty and strain. But then, in a surprising shift, it began to ascend, emerging from the depths like a specter. As it broke the surface, it revealed itself in all its majesty, a creature resembling a long, purple-striped canoe with wings, its scales glistening in the sunlight. It circled just below the surface, a graceful yet intimidating presence. I seized the opportunity to reel it in, my hands a blur of motion as I tried to control its path. Yet, despite my best efforts, the tension on the line grew to an unsustainable level, testing the limits of both my endurance and equipment. The strain was palpable, a tangible force that threatened to undo all my efforts. In a final, defiant burst, the fish pulled with a strength that was impossible to counter. The rod, pushed beyond its capacity, succumbed to the pressure, snapping in a sudden release that marked the end of our titanic struggle. Defeated yet exhilarated, I was left with the memory of the encounter, the fish a testament to the relentless and unpredictable nature of the sea, and my own limits as a fisherman tested and laid bare in the bright light of a July afternoon.

Paragraph 1:
I called the doctor, and then Biju was taken away to a nursing home, and he had to stay there for several weeks, because they discovered he had a weak heart. When he came out of the nursing home, the Minister wanted him to give up his house and come and live with us. But he wouldn’t. It is strange about Biju; he has always gone where we have gone, but he has always taken a place of his own. He says that if he didn’t live away from us, then where would he go every day and what would he do? I don’t like to think of him alone at night in that house, with only the old servant, and with his violent dreams and his weak heart. The Minister doesn’t like it, either. Ever since he heard about Biju’s heart, he has been worried, and not only about Biju. He and Biju are about the same age, and he is afraid that whatever was wrong with Biju could be wrong with him, too. In the days after Biju was taken to the nursing home, the Minister began not to feel well. He even woke up at night and wanted me to put my hand on his heart. It felt perfectly all right to me, but he said no, it was beating too fast, and he was annoyed with me for not agreeing. He was convinced now that he, too, had a weak heart, so we called in the doctor and a cardiogram was taken, and it was discovered that his heart was as healthy and sound as that of a fifteen-year-old boy. Then he was satisfied and forgot all about his heart.

Paragraph 2:
After discovering Biju's weak heart condition, we immediately arranged for his admission to a nursing home, where he remained under medical supervision for several weeks. During his stay, I witnessed the profound impact this health scare had not only on Biju but also on the Minister. When it was time for Biju's discharge, the Minister, showing genuine concern, extended an invitation for him to stay with us, believing that living alone wouldn't be ideal given his condition. However, Biju, ever the independent soul, politely declined the offer, insisting on returning to his own place despite our worries about his health and solitude. What I found particularly intriguing was how Biju's heart condition triggered an unexpected chain of anxiety in the Minister himself. He became increasingly preoccupied with his own heart health, often waking me up in the middle of the night to check his heartbeat and pulse. I remember countless nights spent reassuring him, feeling both sympathy and slight amusement at how one person's illness had sparked such intense health consciousness in another. The situation only resolved itself when the Minister finally underwent a cardiogram, which confirmed his heart was in perfect condition. The relief was immediate and palpable; the Minister's nocturnal health concerns vanished as quickly as they had appeared, though our collective concern for Biju's wellbeing remained unchanged.

Paragraph 1:
One day, Mama finally got a fragile lead she could follow: someone had given her an address. Now Algiers seemed a frightening labyrinth whenever we ventured outside our perimeter, but Mama walked without stopping, passing a cemetery and a covered market and some cafés, through a jungle of stares and cries and car horns, until she finally stopped short and gazed at a house across the street from us. It was a fine day, and I was lagging behind her, panting, because she’d been walking very fast. All along the way, I’d heard her muttering insults and threats, praying to God and her ancestors, or maybe to the ancestors of God himself, who knows. I resented her excitement a little, without knowing exactly why. It was a two-story house, and the windows were closed—nothing else to report. The roumis in the street were eying us with great distrust. We remained there in silence for a long time. An hour, maybe two, and then Mama, without so much as a glance at me, crossed the street and knocked resolutely on the door. An old Frenchwoman opened it. The light behind Mama made it hard for the lady to see her, but she put her hand over her brow like a visor and examined her visitor carefully, and I watched uneasiness, incomprehension, and finally terror come over her face. She turned red, fear rose in her eyes, and she seemed about to scream. Then I realized that Mama was reeling off the longest string of curses she’d ever uttered. Agitated, the lady at the door tried to push Mama away. I was afraid for Mama; I was afraid for us.

Paragraph 2:
As I trailed behind Mama through the bustling streets of Algiers, the city's intimidating atmosphere loomed over us, a mix of unfamiliar faces and towering buildings casting long shadows. Mama clutched a piece of paper with an address she deemed crucial, her steps unwavering and resolute. I struggled to keep pace, my smaller legs working tirelessly to match her determined stride. A whirlwind of emotions churned within me—resentment at Mama's fervent determination, confusion at the significance of our destination, and a growing unease that clung to me like the humid air. We finally arrived at the house, an imposing structure that seemed to absorb the energy of the streets. Mama approached the door with an air of defiance and knocked firmly. An old Frenchwoman appeared, her eyes widening as Mama unleashed a torrent of curses, her voice carrying the weight of years of pent-up frustration and anger. The woman's face paled, fear etched into her features as Mama's words struck like blows. I watched the scene unfold, heart pounding, fear gripping me in its icy grasp. Mama's passion both frightened and fascinated me, a force of nature I couldn't fully comprehend. The tension in the air crackled like electricity, and I feared what might happen next—for Mama, for the old woman, and for myself. As I stood there, a silent witness to this confrontation, I felt the weight of the city's history pressing down on us, a reminder of the complexities that lay beneath its vibrant surface.

Paragraph 1:
The father, an entrepreneur who sold motivational tapes through the mail, worked out of a home office but was frequently away for seminars and mysterious evening sales calls. The family’s home, which faced west, was tall and slender and contemporary; it resembled one half of a duplex town house from which the other half had been suddenly removed. It had olive-colored aluminum siding and was on a cul-de-sac, at the northern end of which stood a side entrance to the county’s third-largest cemetery, whose name was woven in iron above the main gate but not above that side entrance. The word that the father thought of when he thought of the boy was: “dutiful,” which surprised the man, for it was a rather old-fashioned word and he had no idea where it came from when he thought of the boy in his room, from outside the door. Dr. Kathy, who sometimes saw the boy for continuing prophylactic adjustments to his thoracic vertebrae, facets, and anterior rami, and was not a loon or a huckster in a shopping-center office but simply a D.C. who believed in the interpenetrating dance of spine, nervous system, spirit, and cosmos as totality—in the universe as an infinite system of neural connections that had evolved, at its highest point, an organism that could sustain consciousness of both itself and the universe at the same time, such that the human nervous system became the universe’s way of being aware of and thus “accessible [to]” itself—Dr. Kathy believed the patient to be a very quiet, inner-directed boy who had responded to a traumatic T3 subluxation with a commitment to neurospiritual integrity that might well signal a calling to chiropractic as an eventual career. It was she who had given the boy his first, comparatively simple stretching manuals, as well as the copies of B. R. Faucet’s famous neuromuscular diagrams (©1961, Los Angeles College of Chiropractic), out of which the boy had fashioned the freestanding four-sided cardboard chart that stood as if guarding his pillowless bed while he slept.

Paragraph 2:
The relationship between Marcus and his entrepreneurial father existed in carefully measured moments, punctuated by the latter's frequent absences as he traversed the country selling motivational tapes to aspiring success stories. Their home, a modern, narrow building that might have been mistaken for half a duplex, stood in quiet contemplation near a cemetery, perhaps an unconscious reflection of the silence that often filled their domestic space. Marcus's father found himself both pleased and slightly unsettled by his son's "dutiful" nature, a description that seemed to echo from a different era, like a Victorian photograph discovered in a contemporary setting. This dutifulness manifested most clearly in Marcus's approach to his health regimen, carefully cultivated under the guidance of Dr. Kathy, his chiropractor, who had taken particular interest in the boy's methodical response to a previous spinal condition. In her professional assessment, she saw beyond the quiet, introspective demeanor that others might have dismissed as mere shyness; instead, she recognized in Marcus a natural inclination toward healing and bodily understanding that suggested a potential future in her field. The boy had transformed his bedroom into a quasi-medical study, with stretching manuals and neuromuscular diagrams provided by Dr. Kathy serving as the foundation for an elaborate chart that stood sentinel by his bed. This self-created medical reference point seemed to bridge the gap between the scientific and the personal, perhaps compensating for the intermittent presence of his father with the steady, reliable company of anatomical knowledge and therapeutic routine.

Paragraph 1:
There was nothing left to discover. I had followed every lead, read every letter and studied every memento. I should have been content to have learned as much as I did, but instead I felt bereft. After I recounted my efforts to a friend one day, she told me about a psychologist she had interviewed for her podcast. “Have a listen,” she said, “I think you’ll find it helpful.” While exercising in my basement the next day, I did listen, feeling skeptical about the relevance of what Dr. Michael Grand called “the adoption constellation.” Sure, being adopted by my stepfather made me a step-adoptee — so what? As if in reply, Dr. Grand explained that many step-adoptees wrestle with the same existential questions as traditionally defined adoptees, those I had thought were different from me. “Without information about her origins, the adoptee has a deficient narrative — she is missing chapter one of her life,” he said. I not only had been looking for my father, I realized then: I also had been looking for myself. Dr. Grand’s next point stopped me mid-lunge, and I dropped on to my knees, tears running down my face. Mattering is key, he explained. The adoptee wants to know that she mattered.

Paragraph 2:
As I sit here, reflecting on the winding road of self-discovery that has been my life's journey, I am reminded of the countless dead ends and unfulfilled hopes that have punctuated my search for answers about my biological father. As a step-adoptee, I've exhausted every avenue, every lead, every shred of possibility, only to be left with a haunting sense of emptiness. It wasn't until a friend suggested I listen to a podcast featuring Dr. Michael Grand, a psychologist who has dedicated his career to understanding the complexities of adoption, that the fog began to lift. His concept of the "adoption constellation" - a web of relationships and experiences that shape the lives of adoptees - resonated deeply with me. But it was his words about the importance of "mattering" that struck a chord, leaving me breathless and tearful. For the first time, I realized that my quest wasn't just about finding my father, but about understanding myself. In that moment, the puzzle pieces of my identity began to fall into place, and I felt a sense of peace settle over me like a balm. I finally felt seen, heard, and understood.

Paragraph 1:
As Jerry and Con navigated the city streets, Jerry's curiosity got the better of him, and he stopped a man on the sidewalk to ask about the old section of the Long Island Rail Road. The man responded with authority, and Jerry listened intently, his eyes lighting up with excitement. Con, walking alongside him, couldn't help but tease him about his demeanor, joking that he looked like a "crazy train guy." Jerry chuckled and playfully rolled his eyes, and they continued on their way, making a stop at a Korean grocery to pick up some snacks. Con's face fell as she scanned the shelves, hoping for something more substantial, but Jerry was too caught up in his own thoughts to notice. As they crossed into a shabbier neighborhood, they became more noticeable to the locals, and a little girl approached Con, asking if she was a teacher. Con smiled and shook her head, and Jerry, meanwhile, had wandered off towards another set of tracks near Pacific Street, his fascination with the rail system evident in his eager stride. Con stayed on the sidewalk, feeling tired and unsatisfied, and when Jerry returned, he expressed disappointment in her lack of interest. The conversation quickly turned tense, with Con accusing Jerry of not recognizing others' realities, and Jerry's demeanor shifted, his face appearing older and more vulnerable. Con regretted her harsh words and tried to amend them, acknowledging the beauty of the structure they were observing, but the conversation had already escalated into an argument. Jerry's words spilled out in a passionate torrent, revealing a deeper tension in their relationship, as he expressed a desire for Con to care about the things that mattered to him - the social issues, the people, the city itself. Con listened, her expression a mix of frustration and sadness, as the rift between them grew wider, and the city streets seemed to stretch out before them like an uncertain future.

Paragraph 2:
Jerry stopped a man in the street. “Can you tell me what that is?” The man looked. “Part of the Long Island Rail Road they no longer use,” he said authoritatively. “Oh, thanks,” Jerry said. “You like feeling superior,” Con said, as they continued walking. “No!” Jerry sounded hurt, and she put her hand on his arm. “Just teasing,” she said. In a Korean grocery, they bought apples and pretzels and bottles of water. Con had hoped for lunch. They crossed Eastern Parkway. Now the neighborhoods became shabbier, and Con and Jerry seemed more conspicuous. “Are you a teacher?” a little girl asked Con. Near Pacific Street was another set of tracks. It was wedged between small apartment buildings, as if removing it had been too much trouble, or maybe it even helped support the buildings. The tracks crossed a narrow vacant lot strewn with garbage and glass. Jerry walked confidently into the lot between the buildings to get a better look at the tracks, just twenty feet from the street, but Con remained on the sidewalk. “I’d given up on finding something like this,” he called. Double pillars, here, were linked by small platforms. Con was tired and cold, and the pretzels and apples had not satisfied her. She stayed where she was, and at last Jerry returned. They began to walk slowly past the structure. “You’re not as interested as I thought you’d be,” he said. She didn’t try to be fair. “You don’t quite know anybody else is real.” He stopped where he was and looked at her. His buoyancy was gone, and suddenly he looked older, somehow both more Jewish and more African-American. His face was less handsome, but maybe better, and Con was sorry she’d spoken. “What do you mean?” he said. “I shouldn’t have said that.” They’d stopped, and she was cold already, but it seemed necessary to wait where they were, at a street corner a few yards beyond the structure. “It’s beautiful,” she said quietly. “I should have said it’s beautiful.” “But you don’t really care?” “You want me to care.” “I want everything about you, Connie,” Jerry said. “Yes, I want you to care!” Now he sounded angry. “I want you to care about Marcus Ogilvy. I want you to care about Joanna being arrested for saying what she thinks!” “Of course I care,” Con said with some irritation. They were arguing like married people.

Paragraph 1:
Anna wanted to go back to the laundry room, make sure she’d seen what she’d seen, but she knew what she’d seen, she even knew that Paul hadn’t pissed or shit himself—there had been no smell, no stain on his pants, no puddle under him. He must’ve prepared for that possibility, emptied his bladder and bowels before hanging himself. Emptied his bladder, Anna said to herself. Why am I thinking these words? She went back to the sweatshirt, tried folding it again. “Hey, don’t fold that, I want to wear it!” Danielle said, and Anna sent her up to her bedroom to get dressed. Before it was time to leave for school, she asked Danielle to make sure to empty her bladder, and Danielle thought it was funny, because Anna usually said “one last piss for the road,” and Danielle made up a song about emptying her bladder while she did so, purple panties at her knees, a song that was also about water in all its different states. It was getting cold outside, coats had been taken out of storage, time had to be spent sliding them on in the hallway, dangerously close to the laundry-room door. “Did I tell you why the Egyptians built all the pyramids on the same bank of the Nile?” There was no reason for Danielle to open the laundry-room door, but Anna still wondered what she should do if such a thing happened. Should she pretend she was seeing the scene for the first time? “Come over here, sweetheart, we’re late. Busy day today.” They didn’t think to turn the TV off, or the lights, and the house stayed like that for the fifteen minutes it took Anna to drive Danielle to school and come back, the Discovery Channel lining up facts about marine life in one room, her dead husband hanging in another. She would never know this—the paramedics wouldn’t tell her—but Paul, in addition to emptying his bladder before kicking the chair, had put on an adult diaper he’d taken from the supply closet at the hospital, to be on the safe side. Danielle’s fist remained in her coat pocket, clenched around the lighter, until her mother had not only dropped her off at school but turned the corner toward home, out of sight. Her father had left the lighter on the kitchen counter. He wasn’t supposed to smoke anymore, and Danielle, the first to get up that morning, and the first to see the lighter and the ashtray by the sink, had thought she’d do him a solid—empty the ashtray outside, secure and hide the lighter, give it back to her father while no one was watching, the next time she saw him (at dinner that night, she hoped: she couldn’t wait to let him know that, while he wasn’t suspecting it, she’d been his ally all day). She loved keeping people’s secrets. She assumed that the more she kept the faster she’d grow up. The problem was that she’d mainly kept fellow-children’s secrets so far, and she couldn’t imagine that those truly counted. Still. They might’ve been a test on the road to keeping bigger secrets, actual secrets. (Her neighbor Susie seemed to believe that any thought she had was a secret—she’d sworn Danielle to secrecy in advance of confessing such things as hating blueberries or Julia, her twin.) Danielle must have passed the test, because this was grownup stuff, this was important, her father not having really quit smoking, her father lying to her mother. Looking down from her bedroom window a few nights earlier, to investigate an owl sound she thought she’d heard, Danielle had seen her father smoke a cigarette a floor below, elbows on the kitchen sill, upper body leaning out of the window frame. He’d seen her seeing him, had trusted her not to say anything. He hadn’t even mentioned the possibility of buying her silence, just asked for it with the simplest gesture of a hand. She would slip him the lighter later that evening, when her mother wasn’t looking. Maybe she wouldn’t even say a word, just wink at him. But maybe a wink was too childish. In the meantime, she planned to use the lighter. Either set something on fire or just show it off at school.

Paragraph 2:
Anna was caught in a whirlwind of emotions as she navigated through the stark reality that had recently shattered her world. Her husband, Paul, had taken his own life in the most unexpected and tragic manner, leaving Anna to pick up the pieces and face a future that seemed unfathomably altered. He had chosen the laundry room as the setting for his final act, a place of mundane routine now forever marred by his absence. The details of his death were etched vividly in Anna's mind; the sight of him hanging there, the somber realization that he had meticulously prepared for this moment, wearing an adult diaper and ensuring his bladder was empty. These were the haunting images that Anna grappled with, even as she attempted to maintain a semblance of normalcy for the sake of their daughter, Danielle. Each morning, she busied herself with the routine tasks of folding laundry and preparing Danielle for school, actions that felt both grounding and surreal in the wake of such a profound loss. Unbeknownst to Danielle, her father's death lingered heavily in the air, a shadow Anna was determined to shield her from for as long as possible. Danielle, blissfully unaware of the tragic scene awaiting them at home, was preoccupied with her own secret. That morning, she had stumbled upon her father's lighter and ashtray, tangible remnants of a habit he had kept hidden. Danielle, in her youthful naivety, believed that holding onto this secret was a rite of passage, a stepping stone toward maturity. Clutching the lighter in her pocket, she resolved to return it to her father discreetly, convinced that she was protecting him in some small way. As Anna drove Danielle to school, her mind was a cacophony of thoughts and emotions, yet she kept her composure, masking the turmoil within. Danielle, seated beside her, was lost in her own musings, contemplating the possibility of using the lighter at school, a daring act that seemed to symbolize her burgeoning independence. Anna, unaware of the clandestine item her daughter carried, focused on the road ahead, both literally and metaphorically. She was determined to navigate this new, uncertain chapter with strength and resilience, even as the weight of her loss threatened to overwhelm her. The drive to school felt both interminable and fleeting, a microcosm of the delicate balance Anna now had to maintain—protecting Danielle's innocence while grappling with her own grief. As they approached the school, Anna took a moment to observe her daughter, her heart aching with a love so fierce it was almost tangible. In that moment, she vowed to be both mother and father to Danielle, to provide her with the stability and support she would need to thrive in a world that had suddenly become so much more complex. When they arrived, Danielle gathered her things, the lighter still safely tucked away, and stepped out of the car, her mind buzzing with the secret she held. Anna watched her go, a mix of pride and sorrow welling up within her. She knew that Danielle was growing up, perhaps faster than she would have liked, yet she was determined to guide her through this journey with as much grace and wisdom as she could muster. As Anna pulled away from the school, she allowed herself a moment to breathe deeply, to acknowledge the enormity of the task before her. She was a mother navigating uncharted waters, her heart heavy with grief yet buoyed by the love she felt for Danielle. The day stretched ahead of her, a tapestry of challenges and small victories, each one a step toward healing and resilience. Anna knew that the road would not be easy, that there would be moments of darkness and doubt, but she was resolved to face them with courage and hope. For Danielle, for Paul, and most importantly, for herself, Anna was determined to forge a new path, one that honored the past while embracing the future with open arms.

For 269 Swiss francs, participants can hurtle down the icy course, receiving a commemorative pin, certificate, and celebratory glass of bubbly upon completion. Those preferring to stay on solid ground can enjoy the spectacle free of charge, watching as the sleds race past at breathtaking speeds.

Paragraph 1:
Vive el presente, especialmente con tus seres queridos. Mi hijo tiene 26 años, pero cuando era pequeño solía leerle todas las noches, los dos acurrucados en un gran sillón, como había hecho antes con mi hija. En su caso, sin embargo, le había leído tantas veces sus libros favoritos que aprendió a recitarlos de memoria mientras yo pasaba las páginas, a pesar de que aún no sabía leer. Ojalá pudiera volver a esa época. La paradoja de la paternidad temprana es que puede ser tan estresante como alegre, y a menudo hay que esforzarse para relajarse en esos preciosos momentos. Chris Huntington, en su ensayo “Aprender a medir el tiempo en el amor y la pérdida”, escribe sobre una rutina similar con su hijo, con el matiz de que cada noche también comparten sus mejores y peores momentos del día. Una noche, preocupado por su letanía de preocupaciones, Chris se da cuenta de que falta algo y dice: “Se nos olvidó hacer lo de los mejores y peores momentos. ¿Cuál ha sido tu mejor momento del día?”. “Este es mi mejor momento, papá”, dice su hijo, apoyando la barbilla en el hombro de su padre. “Este momento”. Se me saltaron las lágrimas la primera vez que leí esa frase, y nunca olvidé su lección: Vive el momento. Deja de pensar en el futuro o en el pasado, en lo que puede pasar o no, y guarda el teléfono. Si un niño en tu regazo te pregunta qué es lo mejor de tu día, dile: “Este momento”.

Paragraph 2:
Reflecting on the importance of living in the present, especially with our loved ones, I find myself often transported back to the days when I would read to my son and daughter. Those evenings are etched in my memory, particularly when my son, with an innocence and brilliance only a child can possess, would recite entire books from memory. The room would be filled with a sense of wonder and warmth, a cherished memory that I wish I could relive. Early parenthood was a whirlwind of stress and joy, a beautiful chaos that I now yearn for. It's fascinating how retrospect casts a golden hue over those moments, blending the challenges and the joys into a tapestry of nostalgia. Recently, I was moved by an essay by Chris Huntington, where he described similar bedtime rituals with his son. Their routine of sharing the best and worst moments of the day resonated deeply with me. One evening, Chris’s son declared that the present moment with his father was the best part of his day. Such a simple yet profound statement encapsulated the essence of living in the now, and it stirred something within me. It was a poignant reminder to cherish these fleeting moments with our loved ones, to be present and savor the seemingly mundane interactions that, in hindsight, form the foundation of our most precious memories. Life’s beauty often lies in the present, in those unguarded moments where love and connection quietly flourish.

Paragraph 1:
Sister St. Savior pushed through her physical discomfort, her swollen ankles protesting with each step, as she focused her attention on the distraught young woman before her. The girl, clutching a handkerchief between trembling fingers, voiced her pressing concern about her husband's final resting place. "But will they let him be buried there?" she asked, her voice barely above a whisper, referring to the plot they had purchased at Calvary. The question hung heavy in the air, weighted with grief and uncertainty. Sister St. Savior's response came with the quiet authority of someone who had witnessed countless moments of human suffering, "Of course they will, child. You paid for the plot, and that's where he belongs." As she offered these words of comfort, her mind briefly drifted back to her early days as a novice, when she first learned to navigate the delicate balance between religious doctrine and human compassion. Those formative years had taught her that suffering rarely followed neat theological lines, and that sometimes the greatest service was simply being present in moments of despair. The girl's determination was evident in her straight-backed posture, despite her obvious distress, and Sister St. Savior recognized in her the same resilience she had seen in countless others who had crossed her path. Drawing from decades of experience in offering solace to the bereaved, she continued to guide the conversation with gentle wisdom, knowing that sometimes the path to healing began with addressing these practical concerns.

Paragraph 2:
Sister had the impulse to lift the girl’s shoulders a bit, to take the pressure of her weight off her own aching bladder, but resisted. She could endure it a little longer. “You’ll need a place to stay,” she said. “For tonight, anyway.” Now the girl pulled away and raised her face to the dim light. She was neither as young nor as pretty as Sister had imagined. It was a plain, round face, swollen with tears. “Where will I bury him?” she asked. In her eyes, the nun saw the determination—not a result of the Sister’s admonition but, rather, what the woman herself was made of—to put one foot in front of the other. “We’ve got a plot in Calvary,” the girl said. “We got it when we were married. But the Church will never allow it now.” “Have you got the deed?” she asked, and the girl nodded. “Where?” “Upstairs,” she said. “In the sideboard.” Once, early in her novitiate, the nun had been sent to a squalid apartment filled with wretched children, where a skeletal woman, made old, discolored, barely human, by pain, was in the last throes of her disease. “There’s nothing to be done,” Sister Miriam had advised before they opened the door. And then, as they entered—there was the tremendous animal odor of decay, the woman’s hoarse moans, the famished children’s fraught silence—she added, “Do what you can.” “Your man fell asleep,” Sister St. Savior whispered now. “The flame went out. It was a wet and unfortunate day.” She paused to make sure the girl had heard. “He belongs in Calvary,” she said. “You paid for the plot, didn’t you?” The girl nodded slowly. “Well, that’s where he’ll go.”

Paragraph 1:
Outside the window, Finn was throwing stones of varying size into the center of the net. “If you do decide to take him to school,” she said, “I found his school tie when I was tidying the playroom. It’s hanging in his wardrobe.” “O.K.,” he said, without looking up, and she knew there would be no school for Finn today. This is what she’d told Finn about the ducks: yesterday, in Stephen’s Green, the ducks on one of the ponds had died, the smaller pond with the gunmetal-green railings by the side exit to the shopping center, not one or two of the ducks but all of them. She’d seen them as she cut through the park on her way to the office, stopping where a small crowd had gathered. And Bill was right: it was no story for a child, especially not this child, so sensitive that sometimes she thought the very passage of air around him might strip the skin off him. But she’d arrived home late, and tired, and, on entering the kitchen and seeing them together in easy silence at the table, she’d felt a need to announce herself, to offer something that might allow access to their world. And so she’d unleashed it, the story of the ducks, how some were almost wholly submerged, just the tip of a wing or a tail feather breaking the surface of the water, while others lay on the bank, their jewelled heads pressing beak-shaped indents into the silt. One had made it onto the grass and lay toppled beneath the spiked branches of a hawthorn bush, and she knew that if she touched it it would still be warm.

As Finn stood outside, methodically throwing stones into a net, the woman inside was engaged in a conversation, her voice carrying through the open window. She was discussing Finn's school tie, which had gone missing, and the possibility of taking him to school, but as she spoke, she knew it was a futile effort - Finn wouldn't be attending school that day. Her mind began to wander, recalling the story she had told Finn about the ducks that had died in the pond at Stephen's Green, a sight she had witnessed on her way to work. She had shared the tale with Finn, despite knowing it was perhaps not suitable for a sensitive child like him, in an attempt to reconnect with him and his father, Bill, after arriving home late and exhausted. The vivid image of the dead ducks still lingered in her mind - some submerged in the water, their feathers ruffled and lifeless, while others lay on the bank or beneath a bush, their beady eyes frozen in a permanent stare. She had hoped that by sharing the story, she could bridge the gap between herself and Finn, but now she couldn't help but wonder if she had only succeeded in disturbing his young mind. As she continued to speak, her gaze drifted out the window, where Finn remained engrossed in his solitary game, his expression a mask of calm concentration.

Paragraph 1:
Miss Minnie didn’t react at all to the bad word, and I remembered my mother once saying that a woman comfortable around curse words would be comfortable around the Devil. I was ready to go. Miss Minnie said, as I stood up, “I will say that in my dealins with Ike he treated me with the utmost respect. Now, my husband . . . Hal didn’t care for Ike too much. Billie liked him, though, cause she doesn’t discriminate.” She crossed her legs the other way again. “Would you like somethin to eat? Wouldn’t be no trouble to heat up a little somethin.” “No, ma’am.” “Oh, yes! Oh, yes! Just like that!” “What I done told you bout that ma’am stuff?” “Your husband comin back soon?” “Oh?” she said. “Whatcha mean by ‘soon’?” She laughed. “He just went to the store for somethin for breakfast. But he always stays long enough to be out to butcher the pig and collect the eggs. He’ll be gone a long time. He slow that way.” I left, went down to the corner of M and Fourth, and stood there so I could see into Leon’s store. The only man in it came out with a medium-sized paper bag and was walking on crutches. One of his legs had been cut off below the knee, while the other had been cut off above the knee. I watched him cross the street to my side and move past me so silently that if I hadn’t seen him with my own eyes I wouldn’t have known he was there. No huffing and puffing, no rattling from the paper bag, no sound from the crutches hitting the sidewalk. Just a nothing spiriting on down the street. He looked mean and tough, but maybe that was just me trying to compensate for a fellow-veteran who had lost so much. He said something to a little girl coming the other way and went into Miss Minnie’s building. I got to the building and asked the little girl, who was holding an even smaller girl by the hand, if she knew the man. “Everybody know Mr. Hal,” the girl said. I went through the files in my memory trying to recall if that was what Miss Minnie had called her husband. I couldn’t remember at all. Billie, I knew, was the bird’s name, because she had mentioned the thing many times. “Mr. Hal married to Miss Minnie, right?” I said to the girl. The girls looked at each other and laughed. “Evbody know that,” the smaller girl said. “How come you don’t know that?” “Forget him,” the older girl said, and before the girls went off she twirled her index finger around and around an inch from her ear. “Yeah,” she said. “Just forget him if he don’t know that. I bet he don’t even know Mr. Hal ain’t got no legs.” “Forget him anyway,” the smaller girl said.

Paragraph 2:
As I sat across from Miss Minnie, listening to her animated tales of days gone by, I couldn't help but recall my mother's old adage about women who were comfortable with curse words. "They're the ones who speak their minds," she'd say, with a mix of admiration and caution. Miss Minnie was certainly one of those women, her language as colorful as the patchwork quilt draped over her threadbare couch. Her stories were peppered with vivid expressions, especially when she spoke of Ike, a man whose antics seemed to both amuse and exasperate her. "That Ike," Miss Minnie chuckled, shaking her head, "he's always been a piece of work, just like my Hal." Her mention of Hal, her husband, brought a softness to her eyes, a stark contrast to the fire in her words. And then there was Billie, a character I could only assume was another local figure, someone who added yet more color to the tapestry of Miss Minnie's life. As she offered me a slice of homemade pie, I politely declined, feeling the need to get on with my day. As I stepped out of her cozy abode, I noticed a man on crutches making his way down the street, his determination evident in every step. It wasn't until I had walked a little further that I learned from two young girls who he was. They giggled at my ignorance, their laughter ringing out in the warm afternoon air. "That's Mr. Hal," one of them said between fits of laughter, clearly amused by my lack of knowledge about Miss Minnie's husband. "He's been like that since forever," added the other, dismissing my ignorance with a casual wave of her hand, as if to say that everyone knew Mr. Hal and his condition. Their amusement was infectious, and I found myself chuckling along, albeit a bit self-consciously. As I walked away, I couldn't help but reflect on the vibrant community Miss Minnie and Mr. Hal were part of, a tapestry woven with stories and characters, each thread adding to the rich narrative of their lives.

Paragraph 1:
As he arrived at the hospital, the sky opened and began dumping its great weight. The lobby was full of the old and ailing, or those waiting for news of the old and ailing. Cohen maneuvered among the walkers and canes and terminal cases. When the elevator opened onto the maternity ward, he was relieved. A young blond mother was at the nursing station rocking her precious bundle while the father filled out the paperwork for their release. Everything was still ahead here, yet to be decided. But no sooner had he thought this than he was intercepted by the Russian nurse, who grabbed his arm and reproached him. Cohen stammered some excuse, and held up the bag with the gift, but the nurse only scowled and pushed him toward Nava’s room. There he found the new mother with a look of worry on her face. Next to her sat her roommate, the one Cohen had assumed to be the father, gently kneading her shoulder. He was wearing a gold hoop earring and a pink tank top, but great bushes of dark hair bloomed under his muscled arms. What did he care if the baby was a boy or a girl? It was all the same to him. He looked at Cohen blankly, while Nava’s mother sat in the corner, barely glancing up from her soundless recitation from a small purple leather-bound book of Psalms. Cohen stood foolishly holding the bag with the necklace. He asked if everything was all right, which he knew to be a stupid question even as he asked it. They had taken the infant for tests, Nava said. Something to do with his . . . and here she fumbled for the word until the roommate said, Like, the breathing. From this explanation it could have been anything, a stuffy nose or a hole in the lung tissue, something that hadn’t properly closed; Cohen had no way to assess the gravity of the situation. Exhausted, Nava wasn’t in the mood to elaborate. In a low voice, the roommate spoke to her in Hebrew, and she replied; perhaps he was asking her who Cohen was. Not knowing what else to do, Cohen offered to get her another Coke from the machine. She nodded glumly. On the way, passing the rooms of new and expectant mothers, he was swamped by a wave of sadness. He remembered Nadine as she had been back then, himself as he had been then, when they were still conduits of the future, holding their new children, filled with a great sense of accomplishment, unaware that it was premature. He passed a swarthy father carrying his tiny, swaddled progeny, talking loudly into his cell phone. So much pride concentrated in one place: it was oppressive. Cohen felt claustrophobic; he needed a Xanax. Sweating, he punched the button for the elevator and rode down to the lobby, then hurried out into the rain. His belligerent taxi-driver was still parked there, waiting out the storm perhaps, or too busy yelling at his father to look for his next fare. Cohen knocked on the window, and the driver acknowledged him with a jerk of his chin, as if he had been expecting him. He got in, still holding the wet gift bag, and was about to give the address of the Airbnb. But it wasn’t there that he wanted to go. Then, where? Drive, Cohen instructed the man, who was still going at it on the phone, howling his litany of grievances. The driver shrugged and tapped the meter on: what did he care, he had his scores to settle. Cohen, damp from the rain, had an idea. Take the freeway! He had to raise his voice to be heard. North or south, what did it matter? Cohen, failing to remember the size of the country he was in, felt relieved by the possibilities, the sense of motion, of freedom. The sodden gift bag was torn, and he pulled out the little wrapped box. Untying the ribbon, he lifted up the chain and the golden circle fell, then caught there and swung.

Paragraph 2:
Cohen pushed through the bustling hospital lobby, carefully navigating around clusters of elderly patients and visibly ill individuals who seemed to fill every available space. The stark fluorescent lighting and antiseptic smell created an almost surreal atmosphere until he finally reached the maternity ward, where he momentarily found solace in watching a young couple preparing to take their newborn home, their faces glowing with unmistakable joy. This brief moment of vicarious happiness was interrupted when a Russian nurse, her white uniform crisp and authoritative, intercepted him and guided him toward Nava's room. The scene that greeted him was far from the celebration he'd witnessed moments before – Nava lay in her hospital bed, worry etched deeply across her face, while her roommate (whom Cohen had initially and embarrassingly mistaken for the father) offered quiet words of comfort. In the corner, Nava's mother sat absorbed in her prayer book, methodically reciting Psalms with an intensity that seemed to create a bubble of solitude around her. The news about the baby's breathing difficulties hung heavy in the air, though Cohen found himself unable to determine just how serious the situation truly was, the medical jargon and uncertain prognosis creating a fog of anxiety that permeated the room. Feeling increasingly uncomfortable and out of place in this tableau of concern, he offered to fetch Nava a Coke, seizing upon the errand as both a gesture of help and an escape route. As he walked through the hospital corridors, memories of his own experiences as a new parent began to surface unbidden, bringing with them a wave of emotions that threatened to overwhelm him. The sterile hallways seemed to close in, the fluorescent lights suddenly too bright, the air too thick to breathe. The mounting claustrophobia and anxiety propelled him past the vending machines, through the lobby, and out into the street, where he quickly hailed a taxi. When the driver asked for his destination, Cohen simply said "drive," surrendering himself to the aimless movement through city streets. As the taxi merged into traffic, he felt the tight knot in his chest begin to loosen, the simple act of motion without purpose offering an unexpected sense of liberation. The uncertainty of his direction, rather than causing anxiety, provided a strange comfort – a sharp contrast to the weighted atmosphere of the hospital room he'd left behind. Through the taxi's window, the city blurred past in a kaleidoscope of lights and shadows, while Cohen sat back, allowing himself to be carried wherever the flow of traffic might lead, finding in this directionless journey a momentary escape from the complex emotions and responsibilities he'd fled.

One of its most notable draws is the Mirror Lab, a renowned facility that produces some of the world's largest and most precise telescope mirrors. Art enthusiasts, meanwhile, will find themselves at home in the university's two esteemed museums. The Center for Creative Photography boasts an impressive archive of works by legendary photographers Ansel Adams and Harry Callahan, while the University of Arizona Museum of Art features an impressive collection of Renaissance and modern art. But it's not just the university's indoor attractions that make it a must-visit destination - the southern Arizona skies offer some of the best stargazing opportunities in the country. Visitors can take in a show at the Flandrau Science Center & Planetarium or marvel at the colorful rock and meteorite exhibits on display at the University of Arizona Mineral Museum. Whether you're an art lover, a science enthusiast, or simply someone who appreciates the beauty of the night sky, the University of Arizona has something for everyone.

Its ground-floor gallery (free) features rotating exhibitions from its archives. Across the street the University of Arizona Museum of Art (admission, $8) holds an impressive Renaissance collection as well as a modern collection including a custom-lit Mark Rothko painting and a work by Jackson Pollock done on the back of a game board. The skies above the southern Arizona desert attract stargazers both amateur and professional (Kitt Peak National Observatory is about an hour’s drive from town). To gain an appreciation for what’s up there, visit Flandrau Science Center & Planetarium (admission $16). Shows projected in the newly renovated theater explore the solar system in general, the night sky above Tucson specifically and sometimes veer off into the psychedelic arena with a Pink Floyd soundtrack. Don’t miss the basement where the University of Arizona Mineral Museum houses fantastically colorful rocks with names like Variscite and Mimetite, as well as pieces of meteors.

Paragraph 1:
He’d always loved the smell of gasoline. It reminded him of when he was little, when he was seven or eight and Grady came to live with them. When Grady had moved in, he’d brought his yellow Chevy Super Sport with him, backing it into the weeds next to the garage on a sleek black trailer, which he must have rented for the day, because it was gone in the morning. That first night with Grady had fallen over Dill like an absence, like all the nights then, and most of the days, too, a whole tumble of nothing that sparked with a particle of memory here and there. But he remembered the trailer, and Grady—of course he remembered Grady, because Grady had been here in this house till he was eleven years old—and he remembered seeing the car mounted on cement blocks the next morning, as if it had gone through a wall at a hundred miles an hour and got hung up on the rubble. And he remembered the smell of gasoline. Grady wore it like perfume. Now he was thirteen, with a car of his own, or at least the one he’d have when he was old enough to get his learner’s permit, and when he tried to picture Grady, what Grady had looked like, he could see Grady’s hat, the grease-feathered baseball cap that had the number 4 and a star sign on it in a little silver box in front, and he could see Grady’s silver shades beneath the bill of that cap, and below that there must have been a nose and a mouth, but all he could remember was the mustache that had hooked down over the corners of Grady’s lips, making him look like the sad face that Billy Bottoms used to draw on every available surface when they were in fifth grade. At the moment, he was in the yard, smelling gasoline, thinking of Grady, and looking at his own piece-of-shit car parked there by the garage where the Super Sport had sunk into its cement blocks till his mother had had it towed away to the junk yard. He felt the weight of the gas can in his hand, lifted his face to the sun and the hot breath sifting down through the canyon, and for just a fraction of a second he forgot what he was doing there, as if he’d gone outside of himself. This was a thing that happened to him, that had always happened to him, another kind of absence that was so usual he hardly noticed it. It irritated his mother. Baffled his teachers. He wished that it wouldn’t happen or wouldn’t happen so often, but there it was. He was a dreamer, he guessed. That was what his mother called him. A dreamer. And here came her voice through the kitchen window, her caught-high-in-the-throat voice that snapped like the braided tail of a whip: “Dill, what are you doing standing there? The potatoes are almost done. I need you to light the fire and put on the meat right this minute!”

Paragraph 2:
Standing in the yard with a gas can in his grip, thirteen-year-old Dill found himself lost once again in the vivid memories of his childhood, particularly of the time when he was seven or eight and Grady had come to live with his family. The yellow Chevy Super Sport that Grady had brought with him had left an indelible mark on young Dill's mind, especially the distinct smell of gasoline that seemed to perpetually emanate from it. While the details of Grady's face had grown hazy with time, melting away like ice cream on a hot summer day, Dill could still perfectly picture the hat he always wore and his distinctive mustache that seemed to have a personality of its own. These fragments of memory would often surface at the most unexpected moments, causing Dill to drift into what his mother termed his "episodes of absent-mindedness" - a trait that had become somewhat notorious among his teachers, who would frequently find him staring into space during lessons, lost in his own world of recollections. The smell of gasoline from the can in his hands had triggered this particular journey down memory lane, creating a strange parallel between past and present as he stood there looking at his own car, bridging the gap between the child he had been and the teenager he had become. His mother's voice, calling out from the kitchen about the nearly-done potatoes and the need to get the fire started for the meat, pierced through his reverie like a sharp needle through fabric, pulling him back to the present moment. These lapses into memory had become such a regular occurrence that they had begun to frustrate his mother, who often found herself having to repeat instructions or call out multiple times to get his attention. Yet Dill couldn't help but feel that these moments of disconnection from the present were somehow precious, allowing him to hold onto pieces of his childhood that might otherwise slip away entirely, like trying to catch water with bare hands. The memory of Grady and his yellow Chevy Super Sport had become particularly special to him, though he couldn't quite explain why - perhaps it was the way it represented a time of simple wonder, when the mere sight of a muscle car and the scent of gasoline could fill him with pure, uncomplicated joy. His mother's voice called out again, more insistent this time, finally succeeding in fully breaking through his contemplative state and bringing him back to the task at hand - lighting the fire and preparing the meat while the potatoes reached their perfect doneness in the kitchen.

As John stood in front of the mirror, the hum of the electric clippers echoed through the room, a familiar sound that transported him back to the days when he would groom his deceased poodle, Joe Wolf. With a steady hand, he shaved his head and face, the clippers gliding effortlessly through his hair and beard, transforming him into a new person. He left only a Fu Manchu mustache, a distinctive feature that he believed suited the persona of Jimmy Ray Gallup, a character he seemed to be adopting. As he gazed at his reflection, he imagined Jimmy Ray Gallup speaking to him, the voice a low, gravelly whisper that sent shivers down his spine. It was a strange sensation, as if he was shedding not just his hair, but his entire identity. John's life was one of success and happiness, a stark contrast to the imagined life of Jimmy Ray Gallup, who shared his age and hometown but little else. While John's footprints on the beach were deep and lasting, Jimmy Ray Gallup's were barely visible, washed away by the tide, a poignant reminder of a life that had left little impact on the world. Despite his own achievements, John felt drawn to this troubled figure, sensing a deep sadness and longing that seemed to echo through the void. As he stood there, frozen in contemplation, the mirror reflected back a stranger, a man with a new face and a new name, but the same searching eyes.

Once he figured that Charlotte had had time to get to the office, John cut off his hair and beard with the electric clippers they’d used to give bad haircuts to their old poodle, Joe Wolf. Joe Wolf had been dead, what? Ten years? John lathered up and shaved his head and face, leaving only the Fu Manchu that he thought would be right for Jimmy Ray Gallup. He hadn’t seen his face clean-shaven since college, and, to the best of his recollection, had never laid eyes on his scalp. His head was pale and lumpy, white as a bathing cap, but the mustache, he had to admit, looked cool. Jimmy Ray Gallup glared back at him from the mirror and said, “The fuck you looking at?” John and Jimmy Ray Gallup were the same age and had come from the same small town in the mountains—maybe they were cousins, who knew—but Jimmy Ray Gallup had never had John’s luck in life. He hadn’t been the smartest kid in the class, Mr. Straight A, the perpetual teacher’s pet; he hadn’t gone to Western Carolina on a scholarship, or come within a dissertation chapter of a Ph.D. in history; he hadn’t married a beautiful athlete who became an attorney, or lived in a beautiful house, or driven a beautiful car, or raised a beautiful daughter who was about to finish her dissertation on something that maybe two hundred people on earth would understand. No, Jimmy Ray Gallup’s work had come to naught. He had never been loved the way he’d wanted to be. He was behind on all his payments. When he walked on the beach, he barely left footprints.

Paragraph 1:
I sat with Natalia on the sweltering porch, nursing a cold beer while she sipped her whiskey, her eyes distant as she told me about her latest romantic endeavor. Unlike her previous wealthy suitors who had failed to capture her interest, this one - the son of a supermarket chain mogul - had managed to intrigue her, primarily because of his private plane. As the humidity pressed against us, she recounted a peculiar incident from a recent flight: they had been soaring over a remote area when she spotted a house being devoured by flames, the fire reaching skyward with alarming intensity. What made the story truly unsettling was that when they circled back merely ten minutes later, the inferno had completely vanished, leaving nothing but scorched earth and skeletal remains of the structure. When I gently suggested she might have confused the location during their flight, Natalia's expression hardened, and she firmly insisted that such a massive fire couldn't possibly have been extinguished so rapidly, especially in such an isolated location. Her boyfriend had dismissively claimed he hadn't seen any fire at all, treating her observation as a product of an overactive imagination. Yet, as I watched my cousin's face in the fading afternoon light, noting the conviction in her eyes and the slight tremor in her voice, I found myself inclined to believe her version of events. There was something about the way she described the scene - the details too vivid, the confusion too genuine - that made me think she had witnessed something inexplicable that day, something that defied logical explanation.

Paragraph 2:
I stayed with my cousin out on the hot porch, she with her whiskey, me with a cold beer. I couldn’t drink anything stronger. She told me about her new boyfriend, the son of the owner of the province’s largest supermarket chain. She always had rich boyfriends. This one mattered to her as little as the others, emotionally speaking, but she was interested in him because he had a plane. He’d taken her up in it the week before. “Beautiful,” she told me, “except it shakes a bit. The smaller the plane, the more it shakes.” “I didn’t know that,” I said. “Me, neither. Aren’t we dumb, cousin? Because it makes sense.” I shrugged. “Something terrifying happened to me while I was up there,” she went on. “We were flying over fields to the north, and suddenly I saw a very big fire. A house was burning, bright-orange flames and a black cloud of smoke, and you could see the house collapsing in on itself. I stared and stared at the fire until he turned the plane and I lost sight of it. But ten minutes later we passed over the same spot and the fire had disappeared.” “You must have got the place wrong. It’s not like you’re up in planes all the time and can recognize the terrain from above.” “You don’t understand. There was a patch of burned earth and the ruins of the house.” “It went out, then.” “How? Did the firefighters get there in five minutes? We’re talking wilderness here, babe, and the flames were really high when I saw them, and it wasn’t raining or anything! It could never have been put out in ten minutes.” “Did you tell your boyfriend?” “Sure, but he says I’m crazy, he never saw any fire.” Our eyes met. I almost always believed Natalia.

Paragraph 1:
As I climbed higher into the tree, the rough bark digging into my palms, I couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and trepidation - what if I didn't find any avocados? The leaves rustled in the gentle breeze, and I pushed aside the branches, my eyes scanning the foliage for the prized fruit. And then, nestled in the crook of a branch, I spotted it - a small, green avocado, its skin slightly soft to the touch. I plucked it from its stem, feeling a surge of triumph, and settled in to take a bite. But as I sat there, the sounds of the world around me began to shift and change - I heard the distant beat of drums, a rhythmic thrumming that seemed to match the pounding of my heart. I looked up, and my gaze was drawn to a cluster of balloons rising into the sky, their bright colors and gentle sway evoking a pang of sadness. My thoughts turned to my daughters, and I felt a lump form in my throat as I wondered what they were doing at that moment. Meanwhile, in a different part of town, Emma stood with her son Bobby, watching as he gazed up at the same balloons, his eyes wide with wonder. "Mommy, where are the balloons going?" he asked, tugging on her hand. Emma hesitated, unsure of how to explain the absence of the balloons' owners, and so she fabricated a story - "They're blowing away to a magical land, sweetie, where they'll have all sorts of amazing adventures." Bobby's eyes lit up, and he nodded, accepting her explanation without question. As they walked, Emma couldn't help but think of her husband, Mike, and the pressure she felt from his judgmental looks - it seemed like no matter what she did, she was always falling short in his eyes. But Bobby, sensing her distress, slipped his hand into hers, his small fingers wrapping around hers in a comforting grip. "It's okay, Mommy," he said, looking up at her with big, brown eyes. "I like the magical land story." Emma smiled, feeling a surge of gratitude towards her son - he had a way of making her feel seen and supported, even when the rest of the world seemed to be against her. As they continued on their way, the sound of the drums and the sight of the balloons fading into the distance, Emma felt a sense of peace settle over her, a reminder that sometimes, it's the smallest moments that bring the greatest joy.

Paragraph 2:
This scenario played in Ted’s imagination as he searched the picked-over trees, dirtying his slacks and splitting a seam on his shirt, but on the fifth tree he spotted a runt, hanging high, its existence, once noted, hijacking the scene, like a dangling grenade. It took some atavistic climbing for Ted to reach that gnarled and hardly worth the effort avocado. But he had it. In his hand. It was ridiculous, but it was his. He paused for a moment, wedged between the branches, and from this peaceful vantage he could hear beating beyond the beating of his own heart, a beating of drums, like that of Indians of old, as if “The Fiddlin’ Buckaroo” were being shot in a nearby field. It was coming from over that hill, beyond that line of trees. Boom. Boom. Boom. Then Ted saw three balloons rising like a smoke signal, yellow balloons, neck and neck in the midday sky, and he thought of his daughters, though this thought was mostly buried and what emerged was an unexpected feeling of sadness, watching those three balloons disappear, as if the earth had been let go from someone’s hand. “Where are the balloons?” Bobby asked when he returned. Emma had a sense that he would want to bring them home and show his brothers and possibly brag about how he and Mom had had a swell time without them, went to Elysian Park, where there was a whole mess of people, some barely in clothes, like happies—happies? you mean hippies—yeah, yeah, hippies, and they had chanted and played games and he had traded his rabbit’s foot for these balloons, and his father, probably still in that flannel shirt and cartoonish fishing hat, would buttress his hands against his waist and give Emma the look that seemed his birthright, a look she feared seeing in her own boys, though in fairness Mike could also be loving, and fun, and certainly had a creative side, but so often that looseness snapped back into sanctimony, and the person she had loved without children, with children, she loved less. He had become nothing but father. The balloons would require an explanation and would garner that look, and Emma was unsure how many more of those looks she could survive. “They just blew away,” she told Bobby. “Oh.” “A big breeze suddenly came and—” Emma opened her fingers as illustration. “Oh.” “I’m sorry.” “It’s O.K.,” Bobby said, taking her hand. And this was what she always forgot: how Bobby made her failures his own.

At the end of her fall, she slams brutally against the hardness of the water’s surface and is paralyzed by the cold, but after a few long seconds she lifts her face, and since she is a good swimmer all her automatic responses surge forward against her will to die. She plunges her head under again, forces herself to inhale water, to block her breathing. Suddenly, she hears a shout. A shout from the far bank. Someone has seen her. She understands that dying will not be easy, and that her greatest enemy will be not her good swimmer’s irrepressible reflex but a person she had not figured on. She will have to fight. Fight to rescue her death. She looks over toward the shout. Someone has leaped into the river. She considers: who will be quicker, she, in her resolve to stay underwater, to take in water, to drown herself, or he, the oncoming figure? When she is half-drowned, with water in her lungs and thus weakened, won’t she be all the easier prey for her savior? He will pull her toward the bank, lay her out on the ground, force the water out of her lungs, apply mouth-to-mouth, call the rescue squad, the police, and she will be saved and ridiculed forevermore. “Stop! Stop!” the man shouts. Everything has changed. Instead of diving down beneath the water, she raises her head and breathes deeply to collect her strength. He is already in front of her. It’s a young fellow, a teenager, who hopes to be famous, to have his picture in the papers. He just keeps repeating, “Stop! Stop!” He’s already reaching a hand toward her, and she, rather than evading it, grasps it, grips it tight, and pulls it (and him) down toward the depths of the river.

She slipped into the dark water with practiced grace, her body cutting through the surface like a knife through silk, carrying the weight of her decision in every cell. Though Sarah had come here to end it all, her years of competitive swimming betrayed her now, her limbs automatically finding their rhythm in the familiar embrace of the river. Each stroke threatened to keep her afloat when all she wanted was to sink, her muscle memory fighting against her mind's desperate wish for oblivion. The internal battle raged until a sharp cry from the riverbank shattered her concentration – someone had spotted her in the moonlight. The unexpected witness became yet another burden, another reminder of the world she was trying to leave behind. Through the rippling water, she could make out a figure moving frantically along the shore, and before she could submerge herself deeper, a splash announced the arrival of her would-be savior. He was young, probably no more than sixteen, his adolescent voice cracking as he called out to her, swimming with the unrefined urgency of someone driven purely by adrenaline and moral duty. As he reached for her, his fingers stretching toward what he thought would be salvation, Sarah felt something shift inside her. Without hesitation, she grasped his outstretched hand, but instead of accepting rescue, she pulled him downward with surprising strength. In that moment, her original plan transformed into something else entirely, something darker, as if she had decided that if she couldn't find peace alone, she would take this unwitting guardian angel with her into the depths.

He leaned against one of the ladders, finishing his cigarette. Cloudy to begin with, the sky had cleared. Bright sunlight caught the younger brother’s spectacles as he came round the side of the house, causing him to take them off and wipe them clean as he passed back through the gateway. His reconnoitre had led him, through a vegetable patch given up to weeds, into what had been a garden, its single remaining flower bed marked with seed packets that told what its several rows contained. Returning to the yard, he had kept as close to the walls of the house as he could, pressing himself against the stucco surface each time he came to a window, more cautious than he guessed he had to be. The downstairs rooms revealed no more than those above them had and when he listened he heard nothing. No dogs were kept. Cats watched him without interest. In the yard he shook his head, dismissing his fruitless efforts. There was a paddock with sun on it, he said, and they sat there munching their stale sandwiches and drinking a tin of Pepsi-Cola each. “The crippled man is dead.” The older brother spoke softly and in English, nodding an affirmation of each word, as if to make his meaning clear in case it was not. “The woman is frightened.” He nodded that into place also. These conjectures were neither contradicted nor commented upon. In silence the two remained in the sun and then they walked through the fields that neglect had impoverished, and in the garden. They looked down at the solitary flower bed, at the bright-colored seed packets marking the empty rows, each packet pierced with a stick. They did not say this was a grave, or remark on how the rank grass, in a wide straight path from the gate, had been crushed and had recovered. They did not draw a finger through the earth in search of seeds where seeds should be, where flowers were promised. “She wears no ring.” The older brother shrugged away that detail, depriving it of any interest it might have had, irrelevant now. Again they listened for the chug of the car’s unreliable engine but it did not come. Since the painting had made it necessary for the windows to be eased in their sashes, the house could now be entered. But when the woman returned she would see it had been in safe hands while she’d been away, its rooms as she had left them, the money untouched. The painting began again and, undisturbed, the men worked until the light went.

He moved stealthily, his feet quiet on the dry earth, as he made his way through the garden, noting the seed packets that marked a flower bed, the vibrant colors and cheerful illustrations a stark contrast to the desolate atmosphere that pervaded the property. Returning to the yard, he avoided the windows, his gaze darting nervously towards the empty panes, as if fearful of being caught out by some unseen observer. The brothers' search of the house yielded no signs of life, and the absence of dogs, those faithful sentinels, and the indifferent cats that normally prowled such properties, suggested a profound lack of activity, a stillness that was almost palpable. As they sat in the paddock, eating sandwiches and drinking Pepsi, the older brother spoke softly, his words barely above a whisper, "The crippled man is dead," he said, his voice low and even, "and the woman is frightened." He nodded to emphasize his words, his eyes locked on some distant point, and the younger brother did not challenge him, did not ask for explanation or clarification. Instead, they sat in silence, observing the garden, noting the seed packets and the crushed grass path, the small details that spoke of a life interrupted, of a narrative unfinished. The older brother dismissed the detail that "she wears no ring" as irrelevant, a minor point in the grand tapestry of their investigation. As they listened for the car engine that did not come, the brothers knew that they could enter the house without detection, the windows eased for painting, a convenient point of entry. And so, they continued their work, undisturbed and unobserved, until nightfall, ensuring that the house remained as the woman had left it, with nothing disturbed or taken, the silence and stillness of the property a testament to their quiet efficiency.

The way I sometimes saw him laugh with my mother until he had tears in his eyes and had to take off his glasses. The vender folded the newspaper with his blackened hands. I felt an overwhelming urge to reveal myself, to call out and bridge the gap that had grown between us over the years. I both admired and feared my father, longing for a truce that would allow us to connect as friends, to find common ground and move beyond the past. As I watched, he purchased a newspaper, his eyes scanning the headlines, and for a moment, I hoped he'd notice me, that our eyes would meet and something would shift. But he turned, unaware of my presence, and walked away, leaving me standing there, frozen in a mix of emotions, as the city swirled on around me.

When they talked about literature, Pereda was completely bored. In his opinion, the best Argentine writers were Borges and Bebe; any further commentary on the subject was superfluous. His old friends hardly recognized this new Pereda as the lawyer they had known, who had been irreproachable in every respect.

I find the right church, I look up—yes, there’s something green there, high up under the vault. White sheep on a green meadow. The usual dim light. The discordant hum of tourists below. Their fingers point. They look for explanations in their guidebooks: such-and-such a century, such-and-such a style. Everything is the same everywhere, always. You can hardly see. In every Italian church there’s a box on the wall for donations; and, for those who are interested, these boxes often provide an additional service. If you put in three hundred lira—twenty-five cents—for a brief moment spotlights are turned on near the ceiling, bathing the stones of the mosaic in fresh white light. The colors brighten. You can see details. The crowd gets excited; its hum grows louder. Only twenty-five cents. You’ve already come so far; you’ve paid for the plane ticket, for the train, the hotel, the pizza, the cold drinks, the coffee. How can you now begrudge a few extra cents? But many do. They’re annoyed; they weren’t forewarned. They want to see Heaven for free.
