Ms. Tinnin and Mr. Shaikh, along with two other students, met with Mark Polatajko, senior vice president for finance and administration for Kent State, on Dec. 4, a meeting confirmed in a statement from Rebecca Murphy, a Kent State spokeswoman. Mr. Polatajko shared the university’s investment portfolio with the four activists during the meeting, Ms. Tinnin said in an interview before Saturday’s protest. She said activists who scrutinized the portfolio found that it included investments in weapons manufacturers. On Saturday, in a nod to nationwide student demonstrations against the war in Gaza, Ms. Swengel said that encampments and demonstrations “stand as living, breathing monuments of the willingness of students to stand up against genocide and for what they believe in.” In a statement emailed to reporters, Ms. Murphy said the university “upholds the First Amendment rights of free speech and peaceful assembly for all.” “Consistent with our core values, we encourage open dialogue and respectful civil discourse in an inclusive environment,” she added.

Paragraph 1:
Danielle's thoughts often wandered back to her childhood, specifically to the unorthodox advice her mother once gave her. In a bizarre attempt to encourage breast growth, her mother instructed her to rub live butterflies against her chest, insisting that this ancient ritual would yield the desired results. The process, however, came with its own set of rules - only certain types of butterflies were suitable, and under no circumstances was Danielle to use moths, as they could cause rashes and even stunt growth. Having already honed her skills at catching lizards, Danielle found it relatively easy to capture the delicate creatures, although she did occasionally accidentally crush them in the process. The remnants of these unfortunate butterflies were carefully stored in a jar, a morbid keepsake that Danielle couldn't bring herself to part with. That was until tragedy struck, and her mother's life was brutally cut short by a classmate's bullet. In the aftermath of this devastating event, Danielle finally discarded the jar, its contents a painful reminder of a ritual that now seemed both ridiculous and poignant. Yet, despite the absurdity of the method, Danielle's breasts did, in fact, grow, and years later, as she navigated her adult life in Miami, working as a teacher and trying to put the past behind her, she couldn't help but think back to that strange ritual when she discovered a lump in her breast. The memories of those crushed butterflies, and her mother's unwavering conviction, came flooding back, leaving Danielle to wonder if there had been any truth to the bizarre practice after all. As she grappled with the uncertainty of her own health, Danielle found herself reflecting on the unconventional wisdom of her mother, and the peculiar, yet enduring, legacy she had left behind.

Paragraph 2:
The first time Danielle remembers ever being aware of her breasts was when she was thirteen and her mother told her to rub crushed butterflies on them to make them grow. Not already dead butterflies but live ones, plucked from flower petals by her own hands. Saturns were preferable because it was easy to tell the pale females, which she needed, from the darker males, which she did not. Swallowtails and other species with black spots were considered unlucky. And she was not, no matter what, to mistake a thick-antennaed moth for a butterfly, for if she rubbed a poisonous moth on her dot of a nipple not only would she get a rash but she wouldn’t see another centimetre of growth for the rest of her life. She was already an expert lizard hunter—she preferred the kink-tailed ones to any other kind—so the butterflies proved to be easy prey, but because she was used to more struggle than they were capable of she’d sometimes press too hard. Either their wings would crumble, leaving a fine, sticky dust under her fingernails, or the butterflies would simply fall apart and she’d pile the corpses in a jar, a kaleidoscopic, see-through mausoleum, too horrifying to keep in her mother’s cosmetics cabinet yet too beautiful to discard. The day her mother was shot by a young man no older than Danielle—a classmate of hers, according to some witnesses—as she was coming home from her textile shop, Danielle simply uncovered her jar of butterflies and threw its contents to the two iguanas she kept in a small cage in her parents’ bamboo-hedged, hibiscus-lined garden. And, because she’d taken her mother’s advice, her breasts did grow, so much so that, years after she had left adolescence and left Haiti with her father and was working as a first-grade teacher at a small experimental school in Miami’s Little Haiti, she discovered in the shower one morning a chestnut-size lump in one of them, the right one, which seemed to have bloomed overnight, as if her mammary glands had been soaked in a butterfly bath while she slept.

Explanations for Starlink outages in Ukraine over the past year vary. Several experts said Russia had gotten better at interfering with the signal between the satellites and Starlink terminals on the ground by using powerful and precise jammers. Others suggested that the service had been disrupted by specialized electronic weapons mounted on drones, which can confuse Starlink’s GPS signals, the global positioning system that is used to help locate satellites. Sharp increases in Starlink use can also degrade service. In some instances, technical restrictions intended to keep Russian forces from using Starlink have hurt service for Ukrainian soldiers along the front line. At other times, disruptions can be more random, such as earlier this month when SpaceX reported service problems worldwide because of solar storms.

Paragraph 2:
Over the past year, Ukraine has experienced recurring outages of the Starlink satellite internet service, prompting concerns among military officials and experts. While the exact causes are unclear, many believe that Russia has enhanced its capacity to disrupt the signal using advanced jamming technology. Others point to the increasing use of electronic warfare drones, which can interfere with GPS signals and cripple the network. Furthermore, the surge in Starlink usage and technical restrictions implemented to prevent Russian access have inadvertently hindered service for Ukrainian soldiers. Random disruptions, such as those triggered by solar storms, have also contributed to the outages. As SpaceX, the company behind Starlink, works to address these issues, experts warn that the situation highlights the vulnerabilities of satellite-based communication systems in conflict zones.

Paragraph 1:
Ogechi felt the gentle tugging at her hair as the child strapped to her back found comfort in suckling the dark strands, an unusual habit that had emerged during their time together. Rather than risk exposing this peculiar arrangement on a crowded bus, she opted to walk to Mama's Emporium, despite the distance. The weight of the child pressed against her spine as she navigated the bustling streets, her mind constantly aware of potential onlookers who might notice the strange sight. As she approached a busy intersection, her anxiety peaked, but to her surprise, not a single person spared her a glance. The crowd's attention was fixed elsewhere, their necks craned and bodies pressed forward in collective fascination. Curiosity got the better of her, and without hesitation, Ogechi spotted a low-hanging roof nearby. Drawing upon the strength that came naturally to her as a mud girl, she hoisted herself and the child up onto the corrugated surface with practiced ease, careful not to disturb the content infant who continued to suckle contentedly on her hair. From this elevated vantage point, she could finally see what had captivated the masses below.

Paragraph 2:
Only when Ogechi strapped the child to her back did she find out what it wanted. The baby wriggled upward, and Ogechi hauled it higher, then higher still, until it settled its head on the back of her neck. Then she felt it, the gentle suckling at her nape as the child drew the tangled buds of her hair into its mouth. Ahh, now this she could manage. Ogechi decided to walk today, unsure of how to nurse the child on the bus and still keep it secret, but she dreaded the busy intersection she would cross as she neared Mama’s Emporium. The people milling about with curious eyes, the beggars scanning and calculating the worth of passersby. Someone would notice, ask. But as she reached the crossing not one person looked at her. They were all gathered in a crowd, staring at something that was blocked from Ogechi’s sight by the press of bodies. After watching a woman try and fail to haul herself onto the low-hanging roof of a nearby building for a better view, Ogechi pulled herself up in one, albeit labored, move. Mud girls were good for something. She ignored the woman stretching her arm out for assistance and stood up to see what had drawn the crowd.

Paragraph 1:
Novo Nordisk started making pens in 1985, and these, or pumps, are the standard of care for Type 1 diabetics in industrialized countries. They are also used by wealthy people in low-income countries. But South Africa is a rarity among low-resource countries, the only one that has, until now, supplied insulin pens in the public health service. Eighty percent of people with diabetes live in low- and middle-income countries. The drugs known as GLP-1s, such as Ozempic, which are now routinely being used to treat diabetes in high-income countries, are not included in the World Health Organization’s list of essential medicines or the diabetes treatment guidelines of low- and middle-income countries. Novo Nordisk has an insulin access policy, under which it supplies insulin for $3 a vial to low-and middle-income countries, and for $2 a vial to humanitarian groups such as Médécins Sans Frontières, or MSF. The company signed an agreement last year with the South African drugmaker Aspen Pharmacare to manufacture human insulin there, aiming to produce 60 million vials by 2026.

Paragraph 2:
Novo Nordisk has played a pivotal role in diabetes care since introducing insulin pens in 1985, which have become the standard treatment for Type 1 diabetes in developed nations and among affluent populations in low-income countries. While most low-resource nations struggle to provide advanced insulin delivery systems, South Africa stands out by offering insulin pens through its public health service. This is particularly significant given that 80% of diabetes patients live in low- and middle-income countries, where access to newer diabetes medications, including GLP-1s, remains limited and often excluded from treatment protocols. Recognizing these disparities, Novo Nordisk has implemented an insulin access policy that provides discounted insulin to low- and middle-income countries and humanitarian organizations such as Médécins Sans Frontières. The company has further demonstrated its commitment to improving insulin accessibility by collaborating with South African pharmaceutical manufacturer Aspen Pharmacare to establish local human insulin production, with plans to produce 60 million vials by 2026.

Paragraph 1:
Angie stood before her class, her usual composure shaken as she struggled to lead the discussion about Aron, the student who had tragically died during the recent International Feast. The event, which was meant to be a celebration of diversity and community, had turned into a nightmare when Aron choked on food, his life slipping away despite the desperate attempts of Jean-Baptiste to save him. The memory of that day played out like a horror movie in Angie's mind, the vivid flashbacks leaving her breathless and disturbed. As she gazed out at her students, she saw the somber reflection of her own emotions, their faces a testament to the impact of Aron's passing. The class discussion was a necessary step in the healing process, but it was clear that the wounds were still raw. A Dominican student spoke up, his voice trembling as he shared a fond memory of Aron, while a man from a Chinese couple nodded in agreement, his eyes red-rimmed from unshed tears. Jean-Baptiste, still visibly shaken by his role in the tragedy, spoke of Aron's love of life, his words hanging in the air like a challenge to the senseless loss. Luda, her voice barely above a whisper, shared a story of Aron's kindness, her words a poignant reminder of the impact he had on those around him. But it was Milena's comment that sent a shiver down Angie's spine - her observation that Aron had died quickly, and in a state of happiness, was meant to be a comfort, but it only served to highlight the brutal finality of his passing. Angie felt a shudder run through her body, her mind recoiling from the stark reality of Milena's words. With a quiet dismissal, she ended the class, the students filing out in silence, each lost in their own thoughts of Aron, and the tragedy that had befallen him. As the room emptied, Angie was left alone with her memories, the weight of her grief almost crushing her. The International Feast, once a symbol of joy and connection, had become a haunting reminder of the fragility of life, and the devastating consequences of a single, tragic moment.

Paragraph 2:
On the Monday after the last International Feast, Angie’s hands trembled so much that she had to grip the wrist of her right hand with her left in order to write on the board. Her legs were shaking as well, so she sat down in the low chair by her desk. She said that it would be nice if everybody could say a few words about Aron. One of the Dominicans said that it was too bad that Aron hadn’t had a family. “That’s a wonderful observation,” Angie noted. A man from one of the Chinese couples said that Aron had taught everybody a lesson. “That’s an excellent point.” Angie nodded and reached into her purse for a tissue. She had never had a student die during class before. Nobody she knew had ever had a student die during class. She had been plagued by ghastly flashbacks the whole weekend. Bright and loud, the images of the last feast had kept spinning and spinning in her head, as if she were caught in a horror movie. And now the movie was starting again. She tunes the radio to some nasty Latino music. They uncover the food. The smell! She is so sick of that smell. The students stomp their feet to the beat of the music. Poor Aron, as happy as a child. Moving closer to the table. Filling his plate. Gorging. Starting to choke. They all step away in horror. Angie pushes buttons on her phone. For the life of her, she can’t remember which buttons to push. Jean-Baptiste rushes forward. Grabbing Aron from behind. His fist thrusts into Aron’s stomach. Thrusts again. Again and again. Finally! That fucking Russian meatball is out! Sighs of relief all over the room. Angie snaps her phone closed. And then Aron’s legs go slack and Jean-Baptiste starts to sway under his weight. For a moment, it looks as if they are dancing together to the loud beats of the music. Old Oolna starts to laugh, a horrible cackling laugh. And then, only then, do they realize what has happened. Angie blew her nose and looked at her silent class. “Do you want to say something, Jean-Baptiste?” “Yeah. Aron was a funny man.” “Good, Jean-Baptiste, good,” Angie agreed. Luda said that they would all miss Aron, and Milena said that his was an enviable death. Angie raised her eyebrows. “Quick and easy. And he died happy, didn’t he?” Milena explained in a calm, patient voice. Angie shuddered and dismissed the class.

Paragraph 1:
This is not to say that we in any way wish you had not arrived, or in any way wish you had not stayed. The phrase “changed irrevocably” might convey a negative tone, and that is not my intention. You are here with us now, and you should stay here for as long as seems right to you. We can’t decide for you whether you continue to stay with us, or for how long you should stay with us. What we can say is that, for as long as you are here, and for as long as you decide to be here, this house is your house, this home is your home, and none of what I have written should in any way be taken as questioning you, or your arrival, or your having stayed here. As I said, I am uncertain even of what it is that I wish to say in this already overlong note. I am uncertain of what it is I have to say, and I am conscious of trying your patience by going round in circles. I confess that, in some extremely tired moments, my mind, without evidence, entertains the notion that this situation is less than optimal, the situation of your staying here with us, I mean.

Paragraph 2:
As I sit here with you in my home, I want you to know that your presence is truly welcome, and I mean that sincerely. We've settled into a comfortable routine, and I've grown accustomed to having you around. I know that when you first arrived, I said that things had changed irrevocably, and I worry that you might have taken that to mean that I was hesitant about your stay. But please, don't think that for a moment - you're free to stay for as long as you like, and I want you to feel at home here. Still, I'd be lying if I said that I never have doubts about our arrangement. There are moments, usually late at night when the house is quiet, that I wonder if this is really the best situation for both of us. My mind starts to wander, and I think about all the what-ifs and maybes. But as soon as the sun rises and we're going about our day, all those doubts seem to fade away, and I'm reminded of how much I value your company. I just wanted to be honest with you, to let you know that while I may have my uncertainties, my desire for you to feel welcome and at ease here never wavers.

Paragraph 1:
Daniel's visit from Boston, where he maintained his position as a professor at M.I.T., brought the usual mix of familial warmth and underlying tension to the household, particularly when the conversation turned to his recently published poem "Rituals." While Millie had showered the work with genuine praise, understanding its nuanced layers and emotional depth, Eddie's bewilderment at the piece created a palpable strain in the room. The father-son dynamic grew increasingly complex as they shifted their discussion to Eddie's paintings, which Daniel diplomatically described as conventional yet not embarrassing, a assessment that carried its own subtle sting. When Eddie pressed for an explanation of "Rituals," Daniel found himself in the familiar position of defending his artistic choices, his voice taking on an edge of frustration as he attempted to convey how art, whether poetry or painting, often defied simple interpretation. Using Eddie's own artwork as a reference point, Daniel tried to bridge the gap in their understanding, suggesting that just as a painting could evoke emotions beyond its visible elements, poetry could resonate on multiple levels beyond its literal meaning. This comparison seemed to spark something in Eddie, whose expression shifted as he began to grasp the broader implications of artistic expression, yet the moment of connection was tainted by Daniel's lingering bitterness over his father's habitual tendency to diminish his achievements. The tension might have continued to build had it not been for Millie's diplomatic intervention, her suggestion of pre-dinner drinks offering a welcome escape from the intellectual standoff. The scene encapsulated the complex dynamics of their relationship: Daniel, the divorced son seeking validation for his artistic pursuits; Eddie, the father struggling to understand his son's chosen form of expression; and Millie, the mediator who understood how to diffuse the subtle power struggles between father and son. Their interaction revealed the delicate balance between artistic expression and family expectations, highlighting how even accomplished professionals like Daniel could still find themselves seeking approval from those closest to them, while simultaneously defending their creative choices against the very people whose understanding they most desired.

Paragraph 2:
Daniel, the divorced son, began to write poetry. He published some short poems, and then—in the magazine Poetry, no less—a long poem about St. Augustine and Spanish dancing and eternal salvation. It was called “Rituals.” Millie read it and said, “Isn’t it wonderful! Danny has published this wonderful poem!” Eddie read “Rituals” and found it confusing. He knew the words, and the words made sentences, but the poem itself remained a plain white canvas. “Rituals, yes, but what is it about?” Eddie asked. “It’s a poem,” Millie said. “A poem doesn’t have to be about anything. It just is, and it’s wonderful in itself!” Daniel came on a weekend visit from Boston, where he taught comparative religion at M.I.T. Immediately, being a good son, he asked about Eddie’s paintings, and they went downstairs to look at them. Daniel had no great expectations, and so he was relieved to find that the paintings were conventional and not embarrassing. Still-lifes, landscapes. He was generous with his praise. Before dinner, Millie asked Daniel about his poetry, which he shrugged off as unimportant, just something he’d found he could do, but then Eddie asked him to explain “Rituals.” Daniel felt challenged—they would never understand, so what was the point? “I can’t explain a poem.” He forced a laugh. “It makes me feel like I’m in class.” Millie understood what was happening and said she thought “Rituals” was lovely, such beautiful language—she would love to hear him read it aloud. But then Eddie, oblivious, asked, “Why the flamenco? What does it have to do with the poem?” Daniel swallowed his annoyance, but he was defensive, the way he got when a student confronted him. Finally, he said, “Eddie, listen! Poetry is . . . all art is more than engineering! You can no more explain a poem than a painting.” He pointed to the landscape over the couch. “Look at that,” Daniel said. “Can you explain that?” “It’s a field in winter, with trees and a stream, and the sun going down behind the hills.” “But that’s a description, not an explanation! There’s more to art than just representation.” Daniel was triumphant and, because he had defeated his father, ashamed. Eddie said, “Yes?” And at the same moment he began to see beyond things as they were. “Not everything can be explained,” Daniel said, imploring now, calling him “Papa.” But Eddie wasn’t listening. He had glimpsed—all at once and with great clarity—the infinite possibilities of painting the world of the mind. “It’s just a poem,” Daniel said, “and it’s not even very good.” He reflected bitterly that his father had always been this way, undermining everything he attempted, even his marriage. Could Eddie leave nothing to him? “Drinks,” Millie said into the great silence. “We all need a drink before dinner.”

Paragraph 1:
After the war, the artist lived in Paris and spent a good deal of his time in the Café Certa—though he never joined the Dadaists—and with André Breton, who won him over to the Communist Party but could not persuade him to join the Surrealists. He held himself apart, until he founded the Lézard Violet with a few friends. René Magritte contributed an article on painting as thinking, Salvador Dali one on how they sliced the girl’s eye, and, without the author’s permission, the periodical printed an English translation of a short essay on collectivism that Max Beckmann had written on his honeymoon. René Dalmann himself wrote about liberating the imagination from the grip of the arbitrary and was in charge of the magazine’s graphic design. He found all this only moderately interesting. Finally he gave up reading and merely browsed. At the end of the book were a few pages of a chronology of René Dalmann’s life, a bibliography, including works by him, and a list of his exhibitions. This contained an entry for an exhibition called “Est-ce qu’il y a un surréalisme allemand?” shown by the Galerie Colle in Paris in 1933, with a note that the catalogue cover was “Lizard and Girl,” by René Dalmann. Lizard and girl. The next morning, he went to his university’s art-history institute and looked in vain for a copy of the 1933 catalogue. He cut his lectures, called in sick with the flu at the restaurant where he was supposed to wait tables at lunchtime, and took a train to the city, where he’d seen René Dalmann’s self-portrait and postwar paintings and bought the book about him. There was a university in the city as well, and an art-history institute, but there was no catalogue at either one. By now he was in a state of feverish excitement. The librarian noticed and asked him what was wrong. He explained that he was searching for René Dalmann’s “Lizard and Girl” and couldn’t find a catalogue that had the painting on its cover. Where might the next nearest art-history institute be? “Why does it have to be the catalogue cover?” He stared in incomprehension. “Presumably he photographed his painting himself, as did his gallerist, the press, and the museum where it hangs.” “You think it’s hanging in a museum? Where?” “We have a photo archive. Come with me.” He followed her down a long corridor to a room with a projector and boxes labelled with names. He grew calmer. He even noticed the librarian’s nice figure and light step and the way she was observing his excitement with a cheerful glance of well-intentioned mockery. She pulled a box from the shelf, studied a list pasted to the inside of the lid, selected a slide almost the size of a postcard, framed in black foil, and slipped it into the projector. “Would you get the light?” He found the switch and darkened the room. She turned on the projector. “My God,” he said. It was his painting. The girl, the beach, the rock. But leaning into view from the left wasn’t the girl but a giant lizard, and it wasn’t the lizard sunning on the rock but a tiny girl, adorable, with dark curls and pale face, bright bodice and dark skirt. She lay on one side, her head on her arm, half kittenish child, half seductive woman.

Paragraph 2:
In the bustling post-war streets of Paris, the nameless character embarked on a fervent quest that consumed his every waking moment, driven by a profound fascination with the enigmatic works of René Dalmann. Having delved deeply into the esoteric world of art history, he became particularly obsessed with locating a rare catalogue that prominently featured Dalmann's evocative painting "Lizard and Girl" on its cover. His pursuit led him through the hallowed halls of various art-history institutes, each visit filled with anticipation and the hope of unearthing the elusive publication. Yet, despite his relentless search and the sacrifices he made, including neglecting personal and professional commitments, the catalogue remained stubbornly out of reach. His repeated inquiries caught the attention of a sympathetic librarian, who, recognizing the spark of passion in his eyes, offered to assist him in his quest. In the quiet solitude of the photo archive, she presented him with a slide of the coveted painting. As the image flickered to life before him, he was struck by the unexpected composition: a colossal lizard dominating the frame with an almost surreal presence, while a diminutive girl, serene and seemingly unperturbed, stood beside it. The juxtaposition of the figures was arresting, encapsulating the whimsical yet profound nature of Dalmann's work. It was a visual dialogue that echoed the philosophical musings of the Surrealists, drawing the character into a deeper contemplation of the painting's themes. The image resonated with the artistic influences of historical luminaries such as André Breton, René Magritte, Salvador Dali, and Max Beckmann, all of whom were intertwined with Dalmann's creative circle. Each figure, a titan of their respective craft, had left an indelible mark on the cultural landscape, and Dalmann, though lesser-known, was no exception. His work, rich with symbolism and marked by an intricate play of scale and perspective, was a testament to the enduring legacy of the Surrealist movement. The character, now more enthralled than ever, felt a kinship with the painting that transcended the mere appreciation of art; it was as if he had glimpsed a fragment of Dalmann's soul, captured in brushstrokes that defied convention and invited introspection. In that moment, surrounded by the musty scent of old paper and the soft hum of the archive's fluorescent lights, the character realized that his search had yielded something far more valuable than the physical catalogue he sought. He had discovered a deeper understanding of an artist's vision, a connection that bridged time and space, and an affirmation of the power of art to inspire, provoke, and transform. The librarian, sensing the profound impact the painting had on him, quietly withdrew, leaving him alone with his thoughts and the image that had so captivated his imagination. As he sat there, contemplating the intricacies of "Lizard and Girl," he understood that his journey was not merely about finding a catalogue; it was about uncovering the layers of meaning within Dalmann's work and, in doing so, uncovering a part of himself.

Paragraph 1:
Caesar's daily existence revolves around his demanding job at Chowing Down restaurant and solitary visits to Franklin Park or movie theaters, carefully crafting a life of minimal social interaction due to the weight of his past—having taken two lives that led to his imprisonment. Living in the same complex as Simon, an enigmatic sixty-year-old who remains perpetually bedridden, Caesar finds himself navigating a world that feels increasingly foreign to him since his release. Simon, who presents himself as a moneylender, maintains an unusual living arrangement with a dedicated health-care aide and a peculiar room setup that includes its own kitchen and a conspicuous green safe positioned beside his bed. The contrast between Caesar's self-imposed isolation and Simon's confined yet purposeful existence creates an interesting dynamic within the building's walls. Caesar's struggle to reintegrate into society manifests in his inability to grasp what he perceives as a "new language" spoken between men and women, highlighting the depth of his disconnection from the world that continued to evolve during his incarceration. His days are marked by a profound sense of isolation and a persistent lack of confidence, particularly in social situations where his past threatens to surface in his consciousness. The long hours at the restaurant serve as both a means of survival and a shield from the complexities of human interaction, while his solitary leisure activities in Franklin Park and dark movie theaters provide a safe haven where he can exist without the burden of explanation or judgment. The parallel lives of these two men—one physically confined to his bed but maintaining connections through his role as a moneylender, and the other physically free but emotionally imprisoned by his past—illustrate the complex nature of confinement and liberation, with Caesar's freedom paradoxically highlighting his inability to fully participate in the life that now surrounds him.

Paragraph 2:
There was one main entry door for each of the complexes. In the big room to the left of the door into Caesar’s complex lived a man of sixty or so, a pajama-clad man who was never out of bed in all the time Caesar lived there. He could walk, but Caesar never saw him do it. A woman, who told Caesar one day that she was “a home health-care aide,” was always in the man’s room, cooking, cleaning, or watching television with him. His was the only room with its own kitchen setup in a small alcove—a stove, icebox, and sink. His door was always open, and he never seemed to sleep. A green safe, three feet high, squatted beside the bed. “I am a moneylender,” the man said the second day Caesar was there. He had come in and walked past the room, and the man had told the aide to have “that young lion” come back. “I am Simon and I lend money,” the man said as Caesar stood in the doorway. “I will be your best friend, but not for free. Tell your friends.” He worked as many hours as they would allow him at the restaurant, Chowing Down. The remainder of the time, he went to movies until the shows closed and then sat in Franklin Park, at Fourteenth and K, in good weather and bad. He was there until sleep beckoned, sometimes as late as two in the morning. No one bothered him. He had killed two men, and the world, especially the bad part of it, sensed that and left him alone. He knew no one, and he wanted no one to know him. The friends he had had before Lorton seemed to have been swept off the face of the earth. On the penultimate day of his time at Lorton, he had awoken terrified and thought that if they gave him a choice he might well stay. He might find a life and a career at Lorton. He had sex only with his right hand, and that was not very often. He began to believe, in his first days out of prison, that men and women were now speaking a new language, and that he would never learn it. His lack of confidence extended even to whores, and this was a man who had been with more women than he had fingers and toes. He began to think that a whore had the power to crush a man’s soul. “What kinda language you speakin, honey? Talk English if you want some.” He was thirty-seven when he got free.

He loves being a cabinet minister; he thinks it’s wonderful. His bearer comes to wake him with tea early in the morning, and he gets up and starts getting dressed, ready to see the stream of callers who have already begun to gather downstairs. He thinks I’m still asleep, but I’m awake and know what he is doing. Sometimes I peep at him as he moves around our bedroom. How fat and old he has become. He makes an important face even when he is alone like this and thinks no one is watching him. He frowns and thinks of all his great affairs. Perhaps he is rehearsing a speech in Parliament. I see his lips move, and sometimes he shakes his head and makes a gesture as if he were talking to someone. He struggles into his cotton tights; he still has not quite got used to these Indian clothes, but he wears nothing else now. There was a time when only suits made in London were good enough for him. Now they hang in the closet and no one ever wears them. I don’t get up till several hours later, when he has left the house. I don’t like to get up early, and, anyway, there is nothing to do. I lie in bed with the curtains drawn. They are golden yellow in color, like honey, and so is the carpet, and the cushions and everything; because of this, the light in the room is also honey-colored.

Paragraph 2:
As I lie in bed, I watch my husband, a cabinet minister, go through his morning routine, a ritual he thoroughly enjoys. Our bearer, a gentle soul, wakes him with a steaming cup of tea, which he sips while scanning the newspapers, completely unaware that I'm awake and observing him. I notice the lines on his face, etched by the weight of responsibility, and the slight paunch that has developed over the years. His expression is serious, his brow furrowed in concentration, as he possibly rehearses a speech for Parliament. I find it endearing to see him struggle with his traditional Indian attire, the intricacies of which still elude him, despite his best efforts. It's a far cry from the London-made suits that now hang unworn in his closet, a relic of his pre-ministerial days. I, on the other hand, prefer to linger in bed, basking in the warm, golden light that fills our honey-colored room. The soft glow casts a flattering light on my husband, and for a moment, I see the man I fell in love with, not the cabinet minister. As I watch him, I'm filled with a sense of pride and affection, knowing that he's a man who takes his duties seriously, even if it means sacrificing some of his own comforts.

Mrs. Longo's towering stature, significantly greater than that of her Japanese students and colleagues, added another layer of complexity to her teaching experience. She was acutely aware of the way her height loomed over the classroom, which she feared might be intimidating to those around her. During lessons, she couldn't ignore the whispers and giggles that followed her movements, with students often poking fun at her height. This self-consciousness was especially pronounced in her interactions with Mr. Takahashi and Mr. Mutsu, both of whom were noticeably shorter than she was, further accentuating her sense of otherness. Despite these challenges, Mrs. Longo endeavored to draw upon her recollections of her own foreign-language teachers, hoping to emulate their methods and forge a meaningful connection with her students. He had not yet met her when he made the fateful suggestion. She is trying to teach. (“He is a student,” she tells Mr. Takahashi, very firmly.) Her husband is a teacher. He holds a doctorate, and he has taken courses in the teaching of English as a foreign language. He has taught. His students have learned from him. They have made a point of telling him so. His wife, however, is inexperienced and uncertified. She has nothing to guide her in her endeavors at the Dorodarake Special English High School but her memories of the foreign-language teachers of her own adolescence. She remembers three very tall spinsters who taught Latin in her boarding school as particularly imposing. And although she never thought to find herself sharing even a single attribute with these sere and celibate classicists, after all she does. For, although of average height for an American woman, she is, in Japan, gigantic enough to intimidate her students just by standing next to them. Like everyone else entering the portals of Dorodarake Special English High School, Mrs. Longo sheds her shoes at the door and shuffles around in heelless school slippers that do nothing to augment her height, but she has heard her students sniggering over the drill on comparatives which includes the question “Is she taller than they are?” Mr. Takahashi does not quite come up to her chin, and she towers over Mr. Mutsu by a satisfying foot and a half.

What was this? She saw that she had a plastic sack dangling from the bunched fingers of that hand, too, and for a minute, what with the newness of the surroundings and the barking of the dogs and the voice that had gone unanswered and had stopped expecting anything now, she momentarily blanked on what was in there. Until the dogs seemed to run out of breath and she remembered: makeup. Blush, foundation, and eyeliner she’d borrowed from the Rite Aid somewhere down the street and around the corner, out on the boulevard that was like a stage set, same street lamps, same tired palms, same traffic lights going green and going red and going green. T. Coraghessan Boyle on crimes and fairy tales. O.K., all right, fine. But she didn’t need makeup now—that would be for tomorrow. The food, too. What she needed now, because her legs felt as limp and soft-boned as the barbecued ribs in their squishy plastic bag, was sleep. A bed. Sheets. A blanket. What were all these doors? Doors didn’t exist for nothing. There had to be a bed behind one of them, didn’t there? Dawn’s son had got home at eleven-thirty, same as the past two nights, because they’d given him an extra shift so that baggers with seniority could take the holiday off. There was the sound of his car in the driveway and then the front door slamming, right on cue. If her eyes drifted to the clock radio on the nightstand it was only a reflex, and because she was already in bed, reading and half watching some outer-space slasher movie (with the sound muted so she didn’t have to hear the screams), she didn’t bother to go downstairs. Cameron ate at the store, anyway, and if he was hungry there were cold cuts and a fruit salad in the refrigerator. She thought of texting him about the fruit salad, which she’d just made that night, but if he opened the refrigerator he couldn’t miss it, so why bother? At some point, she drifted off with the book still propped up in her hands, as she did every night, both dogs and three of the cats stretched out in various configurations beside her and at the foot of the bed.

There will, later, be a good moon. They climb aboard to scattered cheers, secure their safety belts, check the instruments yet again. A quick salute from the starter. Contact! The swing of the starting handle. Alcock opens the throttle and brings both engines to full power. He signals for the wooden chocks to be pulled clear from the wheels. The mechanic leans down, ducks under the wings, armpits the chocks, steps back, throws them away. He raises both arms in the air. A cough of smoke from the engines. The propellers whirl. The Vickers Vimy is pointed into the gale. A slight angle to the wind. Uphill. Go now, go. The incredible engine roar. The waft of warming oil. Speed and lift. The trees loom in the distance. A drainage ditch challenges on the far side. They say nothing. No “Great Scott.” No “Chin up, old sport.” No “Blimey.” They inch forward, lumbering into the wind. The weight of the plane rolls underneath them. She’s heavy today. So much petrol to carry. Damnation. A hundred yards, a hundred and twenty, a hundred and seventy. Moving too slow. A sort of aspic. The tightness of the cockpit. Sweat accumulating behind their knees. A cold swell of air in their stomachs. A bumpy ground below. The lethal whims of the weather. The motors strike hard. The wingtips flex. The grass beneath them bends and tears. Two hundred and fifty yards. The plane rises a little and then sighs again, jarring the soil. Good God, Alcock, lift her. A line of dark pine trees stands at the end of the airfield, looming close, close, closer still. How many men have died this way? Pull her back, Jackie boy. Skid her sideways. Abort. Now. Three hundred yards. Good Jesus. A gust of wind lifts the left wing and they tilt slightly right, then lift. We are rising, Teddy, we are rising, look! A slow grade upward, an ever so faint lift of the soul, and the plane is a few feet in the air, nosing up, the wind whistling through the struts. How tall are those trees? Brown converts the pines to possible noise in his mind. The slap of bark. The tangle of pines. Hang on, hang on. They rise a little in their seats. As if this might lighten the weight of the plane beneath them. Higher now. The sky beyond the trees is an oceanic thing. Lift it, Jackie, lift it, for God’s sake. Here, the trees. Here they come. Their scarves take first flight and then they hear the applause of branches below. “That was a little ticklish!” Alcock roars across the noise. They head straight into the wind. The nose goes up. The plane slows. The agonizing climb over treetops and low roofs. Careful now not to stall. Keep her rising. Higher up, they begin a slight bank. Take her easy, old chum. Bring her around. A stately turn, all beauty, all balance, its own sort of confidence. They hold the altitude. Banking it tighter now. Until the wind is behind them and the nose dips and they are truly leaving. They wave down to the starter, the mechanics, the meteorological officers, the few other stragglers below. No Elizabeth Ehrlich from the St. Louis newspaper, no young Lottie: mother and daughter have already gone home for the day. Pity that, Brown thinks. Alcock wipes the sweat off his brow, then waves to their shadow on the last of the ground and steers the plane at half-throttle out to sea. The scene below looks to him like toys in a child’s bath. A line of golden strand. Boats bobbing in the St. John’s harbor. Alcock picks up the rudimentary telephone device, half-shouts into it, “Hey, old man.” The telephone is a series of wires wrapped around their necks to pick up speech vibration. To listen, they have earpieces tucked beneath their leather hats. “Yes?” “Sorry about this.” “Sorry, what?” “Never told you.” “Never told me what?” Alcock grins and glances down at the water. They are eight minutes out, at a thousand feet with a wind strength behind of thirty-five knots. They lurch over Concepçion Bay. The water below: a moving mat of gray. Patches of sunlight and glare. “Never learned how to swim,” Alcock says. Brown is momentarily taken aback—the thought of ditching at sea, of floating for a moment on a wooden strut, clinging to the rolling tanks. But surely Alcock swam to safety after he was shot down over Suvla Bay? All those years ago now. No, not years. Just months ago. Paragraph 2:
Alcock and Brown stood by their Vickers Vimy, the aircraft that would carry them into the annals of history, an emblem of daring ambition and human ingenuity poised on the precipice of the unknown. The early morning air was thick with a blend of anticipation and the clinging mist of the Irish coast, a fitting backdrop for the historic flight they were about to undertake. Each man was lost in his own thoughts, yet united by a common purpose that transcended their individual apprehensions. As they methodically prepared their aircraft, a series of pre-flight rituals were performed, not out of mere superstition, but as acts of respect for the machine that would be their lifeline across the vast and unpredictable Atlantic. The Vickers Vimy, a robust biplane echoing the industrial might of post-war Britain, stood ready, its twin Rolls-Royce engines gleaming with the promise of power and reliability. Both men were seasoned pilots, yet the enormity of their task - to be the first to deliver mail across the Atlantic by air - weighed heavily upon them, a reminder of the thin line between success and failure.

The checklist was exhaustive, each instrument meticulously inspected, from altimeters to compasses, ensuring every component was in optimal condition. The weather reports were less than favorable, warning of potential storms and unpredictable winds that could easily turn their audacious venture into a harrowing ordeal. Yet, both Alcock and Brown were undeterred, driven by a sense of duty and a thirst for adventure that eclipsed the shadows of doubt. Their resolve was further steeled by the historical significance of their endeavor; they were not merely pilots but pioneers, setting the stage for future generations of aviators who would traverse the skies with the same courage and determination. The mailbags were securely stowed, each letter a testament to the growing interconnectedness of a world that was shrinking through technological advancement. As the engines roared to life, the airfield buzzed with a tense excitement, the few spectators present acutely aware that they were witnessing the beginning of something monumental.

The takeoff was fraught with tension, the Vimy straining against the earth's pull, its wheels reluctantly relinquishing their grip on the ground as Alcock expertly guided the aircraft into the sky. As they climbed, the coastline quickly receded, replaced by the endless expanse of ocean, a daunting reminder of the challenge that lay ahead. The initial hours were uneventful, though the cold quickly seeped into their bones, a bitter companion on this journey. The flight suits provided some protection, but the relentless chill of high altitude flight was an inescapable reality. Both men took turns at the controls, their eyes constantly scanning the horizon and their instruments, ever vigilant for any sign of trouble. The weather soon turned, as foretold by the reports, and the Vimy was buffeted by strong winds and driving rain, the once-clear sky now obscured by a thick blanket of clouds. The turbulence was relentless, each jolt a reminder of the precariousness of their situation.

Mechanical issues were a constant threat, the engines occasionally sputtering under the strain, each cough and splutter sending a jolt of fear through the cockpit. Brown, in charge of navigation and communication, was constantly recalibrating their course, his mind a whirlwind of calculations as he measured their progress. His charts were a lifeline, a map through the storm-tossed skies, guiding them when the stars were hidden and the horizon indistinguishable from the ocean below. Alcock's focus was absolute, his hands steady on the controls, his experience as a pilot a bulwark against panic. The physical toll was immense; the constant noise, the bone-chilling cold, and the ever-present tension sapped their strength, yet neither man considered turning back. Each mile conquered was a victory, a testament to their resilience and the indomitable spirit that propelled them forward.

As the hours passed, the enormity of their task became increasingly apparent. They battled fatigue with steely determination, their thoughts occasionally drifting to loved ones left behind, and the world they hoped to change through their efforts. Their personal reflections were interwoven with the broader narrative of progress and innovation, a reminder that their flight was not an isolated event but part of a continuum of human endeavor. The letters they carried were symbols of hope and connection, tangible proof that the boundaries separating nations could be overcome. The storm eventually abated, and as dawn broke, the first rays of sunlight pierced the clouds, bathing the ocean in a golden glow. It was a moment of profound beauty, a respite from the rigors of their journey, and a harbinger of success. Their destination, once a distant dream, now lay within reach.

He and Don shared a Van Nuys pedigree, only a few grades separating them in high school, though Don would retire soon, while Ted would remain a lawyer with fugitive dreams. You can’t pin all your hopes on just one thing, that’s what Ted’s wife said. You need options. Like an actual career. Then again, Carol was a practical woman who distrusted too much encouragement, except when it came to her singing in church. “Here you go, kid.” Drysdale placed the baseball back into Ted’s hand, and Ted wondered if “kid” was tongue in cheek, a jab between middle-aged men, or merely a function of the bottom line, pupils focussed on the endgame of ink. Were we all kids here? Ted lingered for a moment in the chorus before returning to his seat, and as he climbed toward his row he found himself wavering between feeling very young and feeling very old. His plan was to lord the baseball over his daughters, evidence of what they had missed: contact with a bona-fide All-Star, a future Hall of Famer, Don Drysdale in the flesh. Yesterday, the girls had begged him to let them skip the game—Please, please, please, Dad—so they could work on some Sunflower Girl project, and Ted had given in and last minute had to corral other people, which reminded him of his limited supply of friends, all of them busy today, the seats starting to signify a greater failure, until Renshaw from the office said yeah, sure, and asked if he could bring his twelve-year-old son, Renshaw Jr., the two of them visible up ahead. “Hot-dog guy came,” Renshaw said. “Peanuts, too,” Renshaw Jr. added. This information was self-evident and rather explicit on their faces. Ted stood there, delaying the knee-to-knee proximity. Over the stadium P.A., “I’m a Believer” played as a message for the fans next year. Ted’s oldest daughter loved Davy Jones; he could hear her shriek in his head.

Ted Martin, a 35-year-old lawyer with a collection of unfulfilled dreams, found himself standing near the third-base rail at a baseball game, a place teeming with the laughter and shrieks of children. In his hand, he held a baseball that Don Drysdale, a soon-to-retire baseball player and an old high school acquaintance, had just returned to him. As he stood there, Ted was swept by a wave of nostalgia and introspection. His thoughts drifted to his wife and her pragmatic advice about maintaining a stable career, which had often overshadowed his youthful aspirations. He lamented the fact that his daughters had chosen to participate in a Sunflower Girl project rather than attend the game with him, missing the chance to witness this special moment. The baseball seemed to symbolize a bridge between his youthful excitement and the sobering responsibilities of adulthood. Ted imagined showing the baseball to his daughters later, hoping it would serve as tangible proof of meeting someone famous, a story he could share with pride. Yet, beneath this anticipation lay a contemplation of his life choices, including his limited social circle. The necessity to invite Renshaw, a colleague from his office, and Renshaw's son to accompany him to the game underscored his lack of close friends, a reality that sometimes gnawed at him. As the stadium erupted with the familiar chords of "I'm a Believer," Ted hesitated to return to his seat. The song, reminiscent of his oldest daughter's fondness for Davy Jones, tugged at him, stirring a mixture of emotions that ranged from regret to hope. It was a poignant reminder of the passage of time and the dreams that had been sidelined for practicality's sake. For a moment, Ted stood there, the baseball in hand, caught between the allure of past dreams and the demands of his present life, pondering the path he had taken and the stories he would one day tell his daughters about this day and his brief brush with fame.

Ms. Vance preceded her husband onstage. During his speech, the last of the night, he formally accepted the party’s nomination to be Donald J. Trump’s running mate. She cast Mr. Vance, the junior senator from Ohio, as a working-class person who had overcome childhood traumas that she could barely fathom. “It’s hard to imagine a more powerful example of the American dream, a boy from Middletown, Ohio,” Ms. Vance said, explaining that she came from a very different background and grew up in a middle-class neighborhood of San Diego. As of 2014, she was a registered Democrat, though she is a registered Republican now. Ms. Vance also received her bachelor’s degree from Yale and was selected for a Gates Fellowship at Cambridge, springboards to a career as a corporate lawyer with a prestigious San Francisco law firm. She clerked for Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., and for Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh when he was an appeals court judge. Ms. Vance spoke for about five minutes, telling the delegates that her husband’s focus in the Senate — keeping people safe and creating opportunities — would continue as vice president if he is elected in November. She said that Mr. Vance had not changed since they first met. “Except for that beard,” she said. Joseph Bernstein contributed reporting.

Paragraph 1:
Utilities can take advantage of federal funding in the Inflation Reduction Act to decarbonize the grid and make it safer. Billions of dollars have been made available to upgrade the grid, in part by replacing older power lines with stronger ones that can carry more electricity. Utilities will be able to connect to more wind and solar power generators in remote locations while improving overall reliability. Old poles should be replaced with ones made of stronger, composite materials. Allowing utilities to bury their lines underground in areas that are fire-prone or experience extreme weather would sharply reduce risks of fire and power outages. Regulators and shareholders often balk at the price, but this is a cost of doing business these days. Utilities should also clear vegetation consistently and aggressively along the corridors that carry their big transmission lines and local distribution lines. Neighborhoods might not like the way trimmed trees look, but they will like the look of charred houses even less. More contingency planning will also help strengthen the grid and minimize the impact when lines are downed. Microgrids, which the fund I work with has invested in, are one example. These small, self-contained networks can provide electricity powered by natural gas or solar energy with batteries to large buildings or even a campus. They can operate on their own, or connect to a larger grid, and can provide electricity to communities, hospitals and grocery stores even when power lines operated by the big utilities are turned off because the risk of fire is high.

Paragraph 2:
Utilities across the nation stand poised to leverage the substantial federal funding available through the Inflation Reduction Act to significantly enhance and decarbonize the power grid. With billions of dollars allocated for grid modernization, utilities have the opportunity to replace aging power lines with more robust alternatives, connect seamlessly with renewable energy sources, and bolster overall grid reliability. By substituting old poles with those made from stronger materials and strategically burying lines in areas prone to wildfires, utilities can effectively mitigate risks and improve safety. While there is palpable resistance from regulators and shareholders concerned about the associated costs, these upgrades are not merely beneficial but necessary to transition towards a cleaner energy future. Critical measures such as vegetation clearance and comprehensive contingency planning are underscored, with particular emphasis on the deployment of microgrids. These innovative systems can operate independently or integrate with the larger grid, ensuring a reliable power supply even during outages. On a more personal note, the fund I work with has actively invested in microgrids, recognizing their potential to revolutionize energy resilience and sustainability. Despite the challenges posed by financial and regulatory hurdles, the momentum towards a modernized, decarbonized grid is both urgent and achievable. By embracing these advancements, utilities not only align with federal objectives but also drive progress towards a sustainable energy landscape, ensuring that the power grid is robust, reliable, and ready to meet future demands.

You should get to a doctor.” “I’m scared to,” Lisa confessed, and the blue of her eyes showed it, anxious and bright amid her fading freckles. Les hung there, one hand still cupping her healthy right breast. It was soft, warm, and heavy. This was the bee sting, the intimacy he had coveted, legitimately his at last; he felt befouled by things of the body and wanted merely to turn away, but knew he could not.

Like “Piece by Piece” — the recent documentary about the producer and musician Pharrell Williams, told in Lego form — the movie struggles a bit to find its narrative groove. At the start, the film suggests that we’re going to discover some secret about Willis buried in the mountains of paper, art and video that she left behind. But this is not really a documentary about revealing secrets — and thank goodness for that. You don’t need to leave behind revelations to have lived a life worth knowing about. Willis’s archives were evidence of a mind and heart bursting with ideas, energy and talent, and the obstacles that the industry and the culture threw in her way.

She’d thought that the new priest might joke with her, might offer real comfort that came from his contemporary understanding of how the world actually worked. Instead of invigorating the parish, though, Father Leon’s arrival had strained its atmosphere. “Would you believe he told me to type up his homily?” Collette had hissed, thrusting a legal pad into Father Paul’s chest. “Who does he think he is?” “I’ll talk to him,” Father Paul had promised, but the same day he’d drawn Crystal aside and asked her to type it. “Please. As a favor to me.” So, ever since, it had fallen to her to decipher Father Leon’s slanted, feminine cursive. Each time Crystal handed Father Leon the printed pages, dense with abstractions and Biblical quotations, he murmured a wooden thank-you without looking at her, already scanning his words. Rather than sticking to love and brotherhood and the primacy of conscience, Father Leon went right for the hot-button issues, criticizing the permissiveness of American society. “Tolerance of sin is not a Christian virtue, and homosexuality is a sin, full stop,” Father Leon had told the congregation during an early weekday Mass. “Even in this house of God, I can smell the stink of Satan. He has found purchase in the hearts of some gathered here today.” Crystal pictured him scowling down from the pulpit, in his cassock looking like an unpleasant child forced to play dress-up. There had been very few people present, but one of them was the president of the Altar Society, whose fourteen-year-old grandson was gay. She’d stormed into the office in a rage. “The stink of Satan? Shame on him,” she told Father Paul. “God forgive me, but that man doesn’t belong here.” “He’s young, he’s full of ideas. He’s getting his sea legs,” Father Paul had said, looking fretful. “We’re lucky to have him, with so few young men entering the priesthood.”

In the quiet solitude of the room, the woman sat, her mind replaying the choice she made earlier not to lock the door when the man lay on the bed. Now, as he moved towards the exit, she sensed his presence, heavy with unspoken apologies. Despite his attempts at reconciliation, she remained silent, her resolve firm as she waited for him to leave. Once the door finally shut behind him, she secured it with a definitive click, a symbolic gesture of closure. Alone in the space, she examined her surroundings, noticing an intriguing duality; each object seemed to hold both its tangible form and an intangible emotional weight. Seeking respite from the charged atmosphere, she ventured outside for a contemplative walk, later dining alone, yet the solitude offered little reprieve. Upon her return, the emotional echoes persisted, clinging to the room's corners. The next morning, in search of distraction, she visited a nearby museum. Walking through the hushed galleries, she was unexpectedly drawn to a figure standing alone, the man, engrossed in a painting titled "Funeral." The artwork's somber theme mirrored the unresolved tension between them. As she observed him from a distance, a sense of emotional detachment enveloped her, the gulf between them palpable and profound. The museum's silence magnified their unspoken distance, each brushstroke of the painting echoing the complexities of their relationship. In that moment, amidst art and solitude, she contemplated the layers of their shared history, unresolved yet intricately intertwined, like the dual nature of everything she now perceived.

Paragraph 2:
He came toward her now. She realized she could have locked the door earlier, when he was on the bed. She stood there and waited. Then she felt him lean against the door, the dead weight of him, an inch away, not pushing but sagging. She slid the bolt into the chamber, quietly. He was pressed there, breathing, sinking into the door. He said, “Forgive me.” His voice was barely audible, close to a moan. She stood there and waited. He said, “I’m so sorry. Please. I don’t know what to say.” She waited for him to leave. When she heard him cross the room and close the door behind him, finally, she waited a full minute longer. Then she came out of the bathroom and locked the front door. She saw everything twice now. She was where she wanted to be, and alone, but nothing was the same. Bastard. Nearly everything in the room had a double effect—what it was and the association it carried in her mind. She went out walking, and when she came back the connection was still there, at the coffee table, on the bed, in the bathroom. Bastard. She had dinner in a small restaurant nearby and went to bed early. When she went back to the museum the next morning he was alone in the gallery, seated on the bench in the middle of the room, his back to the entranceway, and he was looking at the last painting in the cycle, the largest by far and maybe most breathtaking, the one with the coffins and cross, called “Funeral.”

Paragraph 1:
As the taxi merged onto the F.D.R. Drive, he found himself quietly enthralled, both by Liza's beauty and the mesmerizing view of the Manhattan skyline. She sat beside him, her presence both familiar and comforting, exuding an unspoken connection that seemed to bridge the gap between them. However, a shadow lingered in his mind—the awareness that the substances coursing through his veins would likely obliterate these precious memories. Yet, despite this looming erasure, he was profoundly moved by the experience, immersed in a sense of presence and beauty that he knew was ephemeral. Liza, meanwhile, was visibly frustrated with the touch-screen television embedded in the back of the taxi seat. Her fingers tapped impatiently against the screen, and sensing her annoyance, he leaned over, offering assistance. In that moment, as their heads drew closer, he felt a rare intimacy enveloping them—a fleeting but precious connection that transcended the ordinary.

As the taxi navigated the arches of the Brooklyn Bridge, he was suddenly overwhelmed by the splendor of the moment. The city lights danced over the water, casting shimmering reflections that seemed to echo the beauty he saw in Liza. Yet, amidst this visual feast, he was struck by an acute awareness that these moments of wonder would soon dissolve, lost to the haze of forgetfulness. The realization was bittersweet, adding a layer of poignancy to the experience—a recognition of beauty tempered by the inevitability of its loss. 

After the drive, he found himself back in his apartment, the familiar surroundings grounding him as Liza prepared to leave. She handed him a small vial of pills, her touch lingering for a moment longer than necessary, before she turned and walked away. The door clicked shut behind her, leaving him alone with his thoughts and the remnants of the evening's enchantment. Hours later, he awoke, feeling surprisingly normal, his mind clear and unburdened. He lay there, staring at the ceiling, and let his thoughts drift back to the drive. To his surprise, he found that he could recall the journey with startling clarity—the sweep of the skyline, the warmth of Liza beside him, and the cascade of emotions that had washed over him. 

Puzzled, he pondered the contradiction. The memories were vivid, etched in his mind with a clarity that defied the effects of the drugs. It was then that a revelation dawned upon him: perhaps the drive had never truly happened. The conclusion was disorienting, yet strangely comforting, suggesting that the beauty and connection he had felt were creations of his own mind, existing in a realm beyond the tangible. In that realization, he found a semblance of peace, accepting that the value of the experience lay not in its reality but in the emotions it evoked. Even if it had been an illusion, it had been a beautiful one, leaving an indelible imprint on his heart. In the quiet solitude of his apartment, he embraced that understanding, finding solace in the knowledge that some memories, whether real or imagined, held the power to transcend the boundaries of time and consciousness.

Paragraph 2:
Had Liza been talking this whole time? He turned and faced her as they merged onto the F.D.R. Drive, and she looked beautiful, her arms raised to pull her light-brown hair into a ponytail; he watched her chest rise and fall as she breathed, saw the thin gold necklace she always wore against her perfect collarbone. Then without transition he was looking at the skyline of lower Manhattan, the buildings growing larger and more detailed as the taxi approached, though he was not aware of moving. Then he was aware of moving at an impossibly smooth rate, and there was the Brooklyn Bridge, cablework sparkling. Liza was cursing at the little touch-screen television in the taxi, which she couldn’t seem to turn off, and he reached out a hand to help her and experienced contact with the glass as a marvel, like encountering solidified, sensate air. Then he was smoothing her hair back and she was laughing at this uncharacteristic intimacy, something he’d done only a few times in their six years. Now the view again, and it occurred to him with the force of revelation: I won’t remember this. This is the most beautiful view of the city I have ever seen, the most perfect experience of touch and speed, I’ve never felt so close to Liza, and I won’t remember it; the drugs will erase it. And then, glowing with the aura of imminent disappearance, it really was the most beautiful view, experience. He wanted badly to describe this situation to Liza but couldn’t: his tongue was still numb; he couldn’t even ask her to remind him of what the drugs would erase. While he was distantly aware that Liza would tease him for it later, that he was being ridiculous, he felt tears start in his eyes as they merged onto the bridge and he watched the play of late-October sunlight on the water. That he would form no memory of what he observed and could not record it in any language lent it a fullness, made it briefly identical to itself, and he was deeply moved to think this experience of presence depended upon its obliteration. Then he was in his apartment; Liza gave him a couple of pills, put him to bed, and left. He woke around midnight and felt like himself. His jaw ached a little. He pissed, changed the russet-colored, saturated gauze, and took another painkiller with a full glass of water. He texted Liza and also Josh, who had asked how it all went. He smiled at how much time he’d wasted ruminating about the extractions; it was nothing. He streamed an episode of “The Wire” on his laptop and fell asleep. When he got out of bed late the next morning and had his coffee—iced so as not to disrupt the clotting—he realized: I do remember the drive, the view, stroking Liza’s hair, the incommunicable beauty destined to disappear. I remember it, which means it never happened.

A woman told me to come the following Tuesday. I tried to describe myself, but she wasn’t interested. “Anything will do,” she said. The days passed slowly. I told Bruno about it, but he misunderstood. He thought I was signing up for a drawing class in order to see nude girls. He didn’t want to be corrected. “Their breasts?” he asked. “They show their boobs?” I shrugged. “And down there?” After Mrs. Freid on the fourth floor died and it took three days for anyone to find her, Bruno and I got into the habit of checking on each other. We’d make little excuses—“I ran out of toilet paper,” I’d say when Bruno opened his door. A day would pass. There would be a knock on my door. “I lost my TV Guide,” he’d explain, and I’d go and find him mine, even though I knew his was right where it always was, on his couch. Once, he came down on a Sunday afternoon. “I need a cup of flour,” he said. It was clumsy, but I couldn’t help myself. “You don’t know how to cook,” I said. There was a moment of silence. Bruno looked me in the eye. “What do you know,” he said. “I’m baking a cake.”

I still remember the day I stumbled upon an advertisement for a nude modeling job, my curiosity piqued by the prospect of trying something new. I decided to take a chance and contacted the woman listed, who instructed me to come the following Tuesday, dismissing any need for a description or further details. I casually mentioned this to Bruno, who completely misinterpreted the situation, thinking I was attending a drawing class to see nude models. His eyes lit up with curiosity, and he began asking me questions about the models' bodies, completely unaware of my actual role. It was quite amusing, but also a bit awkward. Bruno and I have a routine of checking in on each other, often with fabricated excuses, a habit we formed after our neighbor, Mrs. Freid, passed away unnoticed for days. We like to make sure the other is doing okay, even if it means making up silly reasons for our visits. As I was leaving, Bruno called out to me, claiming he needed flour for baking a cake, which was laughable since he doesn't even cook. I played along, offering to pick some up for him, and we shared a chuckle about it. It's moments like these that I appreciate our little routine, and the playful dynamic we've developed over time. Despite the initial misunderstanding about the nude modeling job, our conversation ended on a lighthearted note, and I looked forward to seeing him again soon.

Ms. Harris’s ascent was of course politically extraordinary, a whirlwind of less than a month from replacing President Biden to the convention. But it was also unprecedented as a media phenomenon — at least in politics, where images are usually built over years. Vice presidents are the spare tires of American politics; you know they’re there but don’t need to think about them except in an emergency. This meant that Ms. Harris could be reinvented through digital media. Her goofy quotes and hearty laugh were edited to soundtrack TikTok videos, with a boost from the coveted Charli XCX “Brat” endorsement. Excited, relieved Democrats packed venues for her as they hadn’t for Mr. Biden. The crowds at the convention jammed and danced. Dissension, especially over the war in Gaza, stayed mostly off-camera. With its wire-to-wire jubilance — or “joy,” to use the word of the week — the convention signaled to viewers that this was not just a party but a par-tay. (For its part, former President Donald Trump’s fervent convention, coming after the attempt to assassinate him, aimed to convey a divinely predestined inevitability.)

Ms. Harris's meteoric rise to replace President Biden marked an unprecedented transformation in American political history, catalyzed by an extraordinary surge in digital media attention. Her carefully curated image, amplified through platforms like TikTok and bolstered by influential endorsements from figures like Charli XCX, resonated powerfully with a new generation of voters. The Democratic base, which had previously shown tepid enthusiasm for Biden, rallied behind Harris with renewed vigor and optimism, packing her campaign events with an energy that had been notably absent. The convention itself became a masterclass in modern political theater, with Harris at the center of jubilant celebrations that strategically sidelined potentially divisive issues, particularly the ongoing conflict in Gaza. This carefully orchestrated display of unity stood in stark contrast to the intense fervor of former President Trump's convention, which, following an assassination attempt, took on an almost messianic tone as his supporters portrayed his return to power as divinely ordained. Harris's ascension represented not just a political succession but a generational shift in how political narratives are shaped and consumed in the digital age.

He shivers uncontrollably as he follows Flynn through the entrance of the house, his eyes immediately drawn to the distinctive red and black tiles that pattern the floor. Flynn's voice cuts through the silence, commanding him to shut the door behind them, and he notices the imposing black lock that seems to mock his growing unease. The house stands eerily empty; he remembers seeing the housekeeper once before, but she's nowhere to be found today, her absence adding to the unsettling atmosphere. The sound of metal scraping against tile pierces the air as Flynn pulls out a fold-up bed on casters, its wheels protesting as they move across the floor. Despite Flynn's urgent prompts to "come on" and "quick now," he finds himself paralyzed, a creeping terror seeping into his legs, rendering them useless. He watches helplessly as Flynn continues to the next room, dragging the squealing bed behind him. The space appears to be a dining room, where Flynn unfolds the bed with practiced movements, then turns to him with expectant eyes, instructing him to lie down. The command hangs heavy in the air, but his body remains frozen, trapped between the urge to flee and the inability to move.

Paragraph 2:
He remembered shivering, remembered feeling the cold on his skin. Flynn opened the front door. He followed him into the hall. The same red and black tiles. —Shut the door. He pushed the front door closed. The lock was colossal, a big black box screwed right into the wood. Flynn kept walking. He stood for a while, then followed him. Flynn’s black shoes on the tiles, and his own shoes—they were the only noises. The house was empty. He’d seen the housekeeper once, a woman much older than his mother, walking toward the brothers’ house with a net shopping bag full of apples. But she wasn’t there now. He could tell: something about the cold—the house had been empty for hours. Flynn pulled open a door. He disappeared behind it, then came back out, backward. He was dragging something. It was a fold-up bed, on casters. The casters squealed across the tiles. Flynn dragged the bed across the hall, to another door. He stayed where he was. Flynn was still going backward, pulling the bed, looking at him. —Come on, he said. He didn’t move. He remembered that. He remembered the slow terror, in his legs. —Come on, said Flynn. Quick now. He watched, stayed at the door, as Flynn unfolded the bed. He heard him grunt as he pushed the two sides down. It was the dining room, or something. Flynn pushed the bed against the long table. —There you are. Lie down.

The conversation with my wife is out of a melodramatic domestic novel, except that at work she is Nietzschean. I refer to her being possessed by the will-to-power. My wife says, “How deep is the cut?” “I think I see the bone.” She says, “Do you see any white?” “Yes.” “That’s the tendon. Bones aren’t white while you’re still alive. They’re not white until you clean them after you rob them from a grave. You may have cut the tendon. Can you move it?” “No. Yes. It looks like a bone.” “It isn’t the bone. But there are nerves in there—” “Is that true? That’s not just hypochondria?” “You should be able to see only one nerve, unless it’s a really big cut—do you see it?” “See the nerve?” “It’s a thing, it’s visible.” “What does it look like?” “A thread. Does it make you sick to look at the wound?” “No. What makes you think that?” “Well, take a look and tell me what you see.”

Paragraph 2:
My wife, who channels Nietzsche in her professional life, turned her penetrating gaze to my injury with the same intensity she brings to boardroom negotiations. "What exactly do you see in there?" she asked, leaning closer to examine the wound. I winced, both from the pain and her clinical scrutiny, before responding, "I think I can see bone – it's white." She shook her head with the certainty of someone who's seen her share of injuries. "Bones aren't actually white until after death," she corrected me, her voice taking on that familiar instructional tone she uses when sharing medical knowledge. "What you're probably seeing is a tendon." Her fingers hovered near the wound as she continued her assessment. "Can you see any nerves? They would look like thin, translucent threads." The conversation felt more like a medical consultation than a moment between spouses, but that's exactly how she approaches everything – with precision and authority, whether in the boardroom or at home.
