Reaching the crest of the dune, Daniel was met with the breathtaking expanse of the sea stretching endlessly before him. The vastness of the ocean was staggering, an immense, shimmering expanse that seemed to merge with the sky at the horizon. Tall waves rolled in a rhythmic dance, advancing relentlessly toward the shore, their thunderous roar filling the air. Daniel stood transfixed, captivated by the sight and sound, a potent mix of awe and vertigo coursing through him. The beauty was almost overwhelming, rendering him momentarily speechless and immobilized. His heart pounded in his chest, each beat echoing the ceaseless crash of the waves. Yet, this paralysis was short-lived. An undeniable urge surged within him, compelling him toward the water. Without a second thought, he flung his bag aside, his feet barely touching the ground as he sprinted down the slope, sand flying in his wake. He navigated the scattered debris and uneven terrain with effortless agility, leaping over driftwood and rocks, his eyes fixed on the ever-changing hues of the sea. As he drew nearer, the ocean seemed to shift colors, a mesmerizing palette of blues and greens that dazzled his senses. So focused was he on reaching the shimmering water that he lost all sense of distance, the sea perpetually just out of reach, a siren call pulling him forward. His breath came in quick gasps, a mix of exertion and exhilaration propelling him onward. In that moment, Daniel was not merely a spectator to the ocean's grandeur but a part of it, his spirit soaring as he raced toward the inevitable embrace of the waves, his soul resonating with the boundless energy of the sea.

Then he was at the top of the dune, and he could see it. It was everywhere, immense, rising before him like the side of a mountain, shining blue, deep, so close, its tall waves advancing toward him. The sea! The sea! Daniel thought, but he didn’t dare say it aloud. He stood there, unable to move, his fingers slightly spread, not quite understanding that he had slept right next to it. He heard the slow noise of the waves moving against the beach. There was no wind now, and the sun shone on the sea, lighting a fire on the crest of each wave. The sand was the color of ash, smooth, crisscrossed with streams and pools of water reflecting the sky. To himself, Daniel repeated the lovely word over and over. The sea, the sea, the sea . . . His head was full of noise and vertigo. He wanted to speak, to shout, even, but his throat would not allow his voice to pass. Then he had to move—shouting, tossing his blue bag far across the sand, jogging with his arms and legs as if he were crossing a highway. He leaped over the bands of dead seaweed; he stumbled in the dry sand at the top of the beach. He took off his shoes and socks and, barefoot, ran still faster, not even feeling the thorns of the thistles. The sea was far, at the other end of the field of sand. It shone in the light, its color and appearance changing: a blue expanse, then gray, green, almost black against the ochre sandbanks, the white hems of the waves. Daniel didn’t realize how far it was. He continued to run, his arms tight against his body, his heart pounding in his chest.

This summer day began like all the others. Harry prepared his breakfast in the kitchen—Rice Krispies with skimmed milk, and Sanka sweetened with saccharin. At about nine-thirty, he took the elevator down to get the mail. A day didn’t go by that he didn’t receive a number of checks, but this day brought a bounty. The stocks had fallen, but the companies kept paying the dividends as usual. Harry got money from buildings on which he held mortgages, from rents, bonds, and all kinds of business ventures that he barely remembered. An insurance company paid him an annuity. For years he had been getting a monthly check from Social Security. This morning’s yield came to over eleven thousand dollars. True, he would have to withhold a great part of this for taxes, but it still left him with some five thousand dollars for himself. While he totalled up the figures, he deliberated: Should he go to the office of Merrill Lynch and see what was happening on the Exchange? No, there was no point to it. Even if the stocks rose early in the morning, the day would end in losses. “The market is completely crazy,” he mumbled to himself. He had considered it an iron rule that inflation always went along with a bullish market, not with a bearish market. But now both the dollar and the stocks were collapsing. Well, you could never be sure about anything except death.

After finishing his modest meal, he made his way to collect the day's mail, which proved to be a substantial stack of financial correspondence. His weathered hands sorted through numerous checks from his diverse investment portfolio - dividends, mortgage payments, rental income, bond yields, and various business interests. Despite the bearish stock market conditions, the total sum exceeded eleven thousand dollars, though Harry's momentary satisfaction was tempered by the sobering reality of impending tax obligations. He briefly contemplated making a trip to Merrill Lynch to monitor the market's performance but dismissed the idea, ruminating on the peculiar economic climate where both stocks and the dollar were simultaneously losing value. This unusual situation left him feeling uneasy about the financial landscape, yet he maintained a philosophical perspective. As he placed the checks in his worn leather wallet, Harry reflected on life's persistent uncertainties, acknowledging with grim humor that death remained the only genuinely predictable aspect of existence.

They sat drinking wine and discussing the annoying habits of their husbands and children, the dirty socks left on couches, dishes unscraped in the sink. Angela’s son had bought a frog at a pet store and tried to sleep with it in his bed. Her husband was always at the hospital. He’d suggested that her symptoms were psychosomatic. “Men always say that women are crazy,” Angela said vehemently, “but men have been in charge for most of history, and look how that’s turned out!” Bridget laughed. “Bitches be crazy,” Angela went on, shaking her head and making air quotes. Bridget didn’t know what, or whom, she was quoting. Angela sighed. “I shouldn’t complain, though,” she said. “He keeps us in frogs and fresh sheets.” Bridget laughed again. She was enjoying herself more than she’d expected to. They ordered another bottle of wine, which Angela chose because it was organic and sulfite-free. “I can’t taste the difference,” Bridget said. “You’ll thank me tomorrow,” Angela said. Around them, the hotel swelled with people sitting alone, stroking their phones with one hand while eating or drinking with the other. Even when the place was full, it was quiet. By ten o’clock, the bar was empty again and the street outside was dark. It was a government city, sedate in its schedules.

The conversation meandered to their domestic grievances, with Angela recounting how her son had once again left his soccer gear strewn across the living room, and her husband's persistent habit of asking where things were without bothering to look for them first. "Men," Angela scoffed, taking a generous sip of her wine, "they think every symptom we have is all in our heads." Bridget couldn't help but chuckle at her friend's sardonic commentary, particularly when Angela admitted that despite her complaints, her husband's steady income kept their lifestyle comfortable. The hotel bar, typical of this government city, was already thinning out as the clock approached ten, but the two women, finding solace in their shared experiences and witty banter, signaled the waiter for another round. The soft lighting cast a warm glow over their corner table, creating an intimate atmosphere perfect for their candid exchange about life's frustrations and small victories.

The man took a step in his direction and removed his hands from his pockets. “What are you doing up there?” After a while, the man said, “It’s dangerous up there.” Eventually, he stepped back inside. “What the hell?” the man said as they resumed walking. “Some kind of joke?” his companion said. He was back at the window a few minutes later. Now he said, “My wife’s having an affair.” The man he addressed was trying to make it over the icy patch in front of the church. The affair was embarrassing to admit out loud, but he wanted to stop the man, make him understand. After clearing the icy patch, the man raised his eyes to the window. “Did you hear me?” he hollered. “My wife’s having an affair!” It was easier to say the second time. “Good for you,” the man said, and kept moving. A minute later, he said, “Hey!,” and that man didn’t stop, but the next one did. “My wife’s having an affair!” he said. “Yeah?” the man said. He was almost directly below him and really had to crane his neck. “What are you going to do to her?” the man asked. He didn’t like the way the man was just standing there looking up at him, smiling. He’d picked the wrong man. “You gonna kill her?” the man asked. He stayed away from the window until the man was gone.

Perched precariously on the brick ledge of an open window, Marcus swayed slightly as he stared down at the street below, his mind clouded with thoughts of betrayal and despair. "It's over, everything's over," he called out to no one in particular, his voice cracking as he revealed to the scattered pedestrians that his wife had been sleeping with another man. The cool autumn breeze ruffled his disheveled hair as he watched people's reactions below, desperately seeking some form of connection or understanding in his moment of crisis. A middle-aged businessman briefly glanced up, his initial look of concern quickly replaced by an dismissive wave as he hurried along, muttering something about "attention-seeking behavior." Then came another man, who stopped and actually seemed to listen, but his response sent chills down Marcus's spine. "What are you going to do about her?" the stranger asked, his tone unnervingly eager, "Are you planning to make her pay?" The sinister undertones in the man's questions made Marcus instinctively withdraw from the window ledge, pressing his back against the interior wall until he could no longer see the stranger. When he finally peered out again, the man had disappeared, leaving Marcus feeling even more isolated than before, his attempt to find empathy from random passersby having only served to deepen his sense of alienation and despair.

Paragraph 1:
Carole thought she’d never see this again. Yet here they are, her daughter and her son-in-law with their baby boy. James’s arms are wrapped around his wife, as she holds their son, who has fallen asleep. Perhaps Jeanne will now realize how indispensable her son is to her, how she can’t survive without him. Carole regrets not telling her daughter a few of her stories. Now she will never get to tell them to her grandson, either. She will never play with him again. The first time her husband took her to the doctor, before all the brain scans and spinal taps, the doctor asked about her family’s medical history. He asked whether her parents or her grandparents had suffered from any mental illnesses, Alzheimer’s, or dementia. She had not been able to answer any of his questions, because when he asked she could not remember anything about herself. “She’s not a good historian,” the doctor told her husband, which was, according to Victor, the doctor’s way of saying that she was incapable of telling her own life story. She is not a good historian. She never has been. Even when she was well. Now she will never get a chance to be. Her grandson will grow up not knowing her. The single most memorable story that will exist about her and him will be of her dangling him off a terrace, in what some might see as an attempt to kill him. For her, all this will soon evaporate, fade away. But everyone else will remember. They are about to roll her out of the apartment on the gurney. Although her wrists are strapped down, her son is holding her left hand tightly. Jeanne gives Jude to his other grandmother and walks over to the gurney. She moves her face so close to Carole’s that Carole thinks she is going to bite her. But then Jeanne pulls back and it occurs to Carole that she is playing Alo, Bye, another peekaboo game her children used to enjoy. With their faces nearly touching, Jeanne crinkles her nose and whispers, “Alo, Manman,” then “Bye, Manman.” It would be appropriate, if only she could make herself believe that this is what her daughter is actually doing. It would be a fitting close to her family life, or at least to her life with children. You are always saying hello to them while preparing them to say goodbye to you. You are always dreading the separations, while cheering them on, to get bigger, smarter, to crawl, babble, walk, speak, to have birthdays that you hope you’ll live to see, that you pray they’ll live to see. Jeanne will now know what it’s like to live that way, to have a part of yourself walking around unattached to you, and to love that part so much that you sometimes feel as though you were losing your mind. Her daughter reaches down and takes her right hand, so that both of her children are now holding her scrawny, shaky hands, which seem not to belong to her at all. “Mèsi, Manman,” her daughter says. “Thank you.” There is nothing to thank her for. She has only done her job, her duty as a parent. There is no longer any need for hellos or goodbyes, either. Soon there will be nothing left, no past to cling to, no future to hope for, only now.

Paragraph 2:
The paramedics wheeled Carole out of her apartment on the gurney, her thin frame barely making an impression on the stark white sheets, while her daughter Jeanne stood nearby, wrapped in her husband James's protective embrace as they cradled their sleeping son, Jude. The weight of unshared stories pressed heavily on Carole's chest, more suffocating than any physical ailment, as she watched her family through increasingly clouded thoughts. She remembered, with painful clarity, her recent doctor's visit when she couldn't recall her family's medical history – a moment that had crystallized the reality of her condition. The memories she had treasured, the tales she had meant to pass down, were slipping away like water through cupped hands, leaving behind only the bitter taste of regret. These stories would never find their way to Jeanne's ears or settle into young Jude's imagination, becoming instead another casualty of her failing mind. Through the haze of her thoughts, Carole observed Jeanne gently transferring their sleeping grandson to James's arms before approaching the gurney. In a gesture that transported them both back through time, Jeanne leaned close, initiating their old childhood game of "Alo, Bye" – a simple ritual that had marked countless moments of connection and separation throughout their shared life. The familiar exchange stirred something deep within Carole, even as other memories continued to fade. When Jeanne whispered her gratitude, tears glistening in her eyes, Carole could only think how she had done nothing extraordinary; she had simply been a mother, doing what mothers do. Yet now, as the paramedics prepared to wheel her away, she understood with devastating clarity that this moment marked more than a temporary farewell. It was the beginning of a longer goodbye, as her memories – the very essence of who she was and what she meant to her family – would continue to slip away, leaving behind only fragments of the woman she had once been. The fluorescent lights of the hallway cast harsh shadows across her face as she was moved toward the elevator, each foot of distance adding another layer to the inevitable separation from her life as she had known it, while Jeanne, James, and little Jude remained behind, their figures growing smaller in her vision but looming larger in what remained of her heart's memory.

Failed to Ban Dangerous Pesticides The Trump administration rejected efforts to ban a number of toxic chemicals. One decision that angered public health experts was allowing the continued use of chlorpyrifos, a pesticide that had been widely applied on food crops. It has been linked to neurological damage in children, including developmental disorders in toddlers. Under President Trump, senior officials at the Environmental Protection Agency rejected a finding by their own scientists detailing the ways in which chlorpyrifos can stunt brain development in young children. President Biden’s administration has banned chlorpyrifos, though that decision is being challenged in court. The Trump administration also withdrew Obama-era proposed bans on methylene chloride and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), ingredients in paint strippers that have been found to cause miscarriages; reduced male fertility; and damage to the liver, kidneys, and immune and nervous systems. It did the same regarding trichloroethylene (TCE), a carcinogen found in cleaning products, paint removers, spray adhesives, carpet cleaners and spot removers. This year the Biden administration banned most uses of methylene chloride. It has proposed limits on the use of N-Methylpyrrolidone and a ban on all uses of trichloroethylene. Under the first two years of the Trump administration, the E.P.A. approved more than 100 products with pesticides that are banned in other countries, according to an analysis by the Center for Biological Diversity, an environmental group.

For a while the boy staggers around, reaching over to clutch at little sticks, which he holds up to his father with pride. When the work bell sounds, Mather lines up at the service entrance and waits his turn for the security check. The boy tenses in Mather’s arms as they approach the nursery, but when Mather hands him off to the caregiver the boy does not let himself cry. Even at this age, he is trying to be brave. Mather watches through the high window as the boy is quickly placed on the floor of the playroom, in front of a bucket of foam blocks. The caregiver disappears into an office, but the boy does not seem to notice. He picks something out of the bucket and puts it in his mouth. Mather gives him a last look, then heads up the ramp to the elevator.

Paragraph 2:
Mather and his young son embarked on their routine journey to the workplace, their path marked by familiar landmarks like the old bald hill and the towering spire. As they approached the Faraday gate, they were waved through, joining the steady stream of cars inching forward like a slow-moving river. Mather longed for a breath of fresh air, the kind that invigorates the lungs and clears the mind, but felt hesitant to request the window be opened, a silent wish suppressing his voice. Upon reaching the parking lot, a patch of green caught his eye—a small grassy oasis amidst the concrete expanse. He allowed his son to explore, his eyes constantly darting to ensure the boy didn’t wander too close to the steep decline that bordered the patch. The sound of the work bell resonated through the air, a signal compelling Mather to guide his son towards the day's routine. They approached the service entrance, where Mather underwent the customary security check, the mundane yet necessary ritual of the workplace. The boy, sensing the imminent separation, tensed as they neared the nursery. Yet, with a bravery that belied his young age, he refrained from shedding tears as he was gently handed over to the caregiver. Mather lingered for a moment, watching his son adjust to the environment, settling in with a pile of colorful foam blocks that seemed to promise endless possibilities for creation. With a mixture of pride and reluctance, Mather turned away, heading towards the elevator that would lift him to his day's duties, leaving his son in the vibrant chaos of the playroom, each to navigate their respective worlds until the day's end reunited them once more.

Paragraph 1:
Hester, with her serene demeanor, knelt at the altar rails, her thoughts a tapestry of introspection woven with the solemnity of the church service led by her brother, Bartholomew. She was a woman of depth, often contemplating the world with a quiet intensity that seemed almost to illuminate her surroundings. As Bartholomew delivered the sermon, his voice resonating through the hallowed space, Hester pondered the weight of their shared presence in this sacred setting. The words he spoke were not merely utterances but held a special significance, echoing with the authority and compassion that defined his role as a clergyman. Bartholomew, though devoted to his calling, occasionally found himself adrift in memories of the past, reflecting on the absence of youth in his congregation—a bittersweet reminder of time’s relentless march. His sermons, crafted with care, were imbued with a yearning to connect with those who had yet to fill the empty pews. Yet, it was on a particular Sunday night, in the solitude of his bedroom, that Bartholomew faced a moment of profound disorientation. As the moonlight filtered through the curtains, he was suddenly gripped by a realization so abrupt it felt as if he had been struck, though no physical harm befell him. This bewildering experience momentarily shattered the tranquility of his mind, leaving him in a state of confusion. It was as if the very foundations of his reality had shifted, leaving him to grapple with an inexplicable sense of displacement. Gradually, as the moments passed, the fog of confusion began to lift, and Bartholomew’s sense of reality slowly reassembled itself. He breathed deeply, grounding himself in the familiar contours of his room, the reassuring solidity of the world he knew returning to him. This episode, though unsettling, served as a poignant reminder of the delicate balance between the spiritual and the temporal, a theme that often colored his reflections. Meanwhile, Hester, unaware of her brother’s nocturnal turmoil, continued to find solace in the beauty of his words, her faith a steady beacon amidst the uncertainties of life. Together, their lives intertwined, they navigated the complexities of their shared journey, each drawing strength from the other in ways both spoken and silent.

Paragraph 2:
It was not her way to say all was well, that because of her work everything was good; there was a presumption in that she didn’t care for, and such sentiments cloyed. But as she knelt before her brother at the altar rails, while he raised the cup or again wiped clean its rim, she knew that all this was meant to be. He was here, where he should be, and so should she, where her unyielding spirit had brought them. “The peace of God,” he ended each occasion of worship, and gave his blessing. The words were special. And her brother saying them in the hush while Hester still knelt among the few who came to Oscarey church, before the shuffling and the whispering began, was special, too. Except at weddings and the christenings that sometimes followed them, there were no young among the congregations of the three churches, and with nostalgia Bartholomew now and again remembered Youth Reach and Youth Action and the Saturday rambles to Kilmashogue and Two Rock. On Sundays, when he looked down from the pulpit at aged faces, at tired eyes, heads turned to hear him better, and when his hand was afterward shaken at the door, he sensed the hope that had flickered into life during the service: in all that was promised, in Psalm and Gospel, in his own interpretations, the end was not an end. Then—as it happened, on a Sunday night—Bartholomew with cruel suddenness was aware of a realization that made him feel as if he had been struck a blow so powerful it left him, though not in pain, without the full use of his faculties. This happened in his bedroom before he had begun to undress. The bedside light was on; he had closed the door, pulled down the two blinds, and was standing beside his bed, having just untied the laces of his shoes. For a moment, he thought he had fallen down, but he had not. He thought he could not see, but he could see. A shoe was in one hand, which brought something of reality back, and sitting down on the edge of the bed did, too. The clatter of the shoe on the linoleum when it slipped from his grasp brought more. Sensations of confusion lingered while he sat there, then were gone.

Paragraph 1:
The sun was a wolf. The fanged light had been trailing him for hours, tricky with clouds. As it emerged again from sheepskin, Jack looked down at the pavement, cursed. He’d been walking around since ten, temperature even then close to ninety. The shadow stubs of the telephone poles and his own midget silhouette now suggested noon. He had no hat, and he’d left his sunglasses somewhere, either at Jamie’s or at The Wheel, or they might have slipped off his head. They did that sometimes, when he leaned down to tie his shoes or empty them of pebbles. Pebbles? Was that a word? He stopped to consider it, decided in the negative, and then marched on, flicking his thumb ceaselessly against his index like a Zippo. His nerves were shot, but unable to shut down. No off button now. He’d be zooming for hours, the crackle in his head exaggerated by the racket of birds rucked up in towers of palm, tossing the dry fronds. What were they doing? Ransacking sounds. Looking for nuts or dates, probably. Or bird sex. Possibly bird sex. Maybe he should walk to Rhonda’s, ask her to settle him. Or unsettle him. Maybe he wanted more. Share was what she should do, if she had any. He always shared with her. Not always, but it could be argued. Rhonda was a crusher, though, a big girl, always climbing on top. Her heft was no joke, and Jack was a reed. Still, he loved her. Ha! That was the tweak coming on. He’d never admit to such a thing when he was flat. Now his immortal brain understood. He wanted to marry Rhonda, haul her up the steps of her double-wide, pump out about fifty kids. In the fly-eye of his mind he saw them, curled up like caterpillars on Rhonda’s bed.

Paragraph 2:
As Jack trudged through the sweltering streets, the sun beat down on him like a wolf, its ferocious heat relentless in its pursuit. He squinted, his eyes watering from the glare, having carelessly left his hat and sunglasses at either Jamie's or The Wheel - he couldn't quite recall. His thumb twitched with an otherworldly energy, a telltale sign of the tweak coming on, as he wrestled with the demons that had been his constant companions of late. Despite the turmoil brewing within, his mind began to wander to Rhonda, the woman who had a hold on him like no other. Theirs was a complicated dance, one in which she led and he followed, her physical dominance a potent counterpoint to his deep-seated affection. And yet, as he walked, Jack found himself fantasizing about a future with Rhonda, one in which they'd leave their troubled pasts behind and start anew. He pictured a sprawling house, teeming with children, their laughter and shouts a balm to his frazzled nerves. It was a vivid, if distorted, vision, one that spoke to the depths of his longing. But for now, it remained just that - a fantasy, a fleeting respite from the crushing weight of his own undoing. As the sun continued its merciless assault, Jack's thoughts grew increasingly disjointed, his agitation threatening to consume him whole. Still, he pressed on, driven by a mad hope that somehow, someway, he might find a way to tame the beast within and find solace in Rhonda's arms.

Paragraph 1:
Bett's dedication to her role as a carpenter's helper had given her a false sense of security in her relationship with Rich, as she believed their shared interest in construction was strengthening their bond. The reality, however, was starkly different, as Rich had already begun falling deeply in love with Nita, a colleague from his university. Their affair ignited during a fateful weekend when Bett was away, the very house Rich was building becoming the stage for their forbidden romance. The revelation of their relationship set off a chain of dramatic life changes: Bett, devastated, fled to California and Arizona, seeking solace in distance, while Nita made the bold decision to resign from her university position. Rich, caught in the emotional turbulence of his choices, let a significant career opportunity slip through his fingers, ultimately opting for early retirement and selling their city house. Nita, despite being the catalyst for this upheaval, adapted to her new life with Rich, though the transition was far from smooth. As time passed, she found herself reflecting on her role in the affair with increasing introspection, discovering that beneath her initially carefree exterior lay a more serious and self-conscious person than she had presented during the early days of their relationship. The house that had once symbolized Bett and Rich's shared dreams now stood as a testament to how quickly life's foundations could shift, and how love could simultaneously construct and deconstruct lives.

Paragraph 2:
And at the same time that Bett had been busy telling people that she’d found her role in life as a carpenter’s helper, and that it had brought her and Rich much closer, Rich had been falling in love with Nita. She’d worked in the registrar’s office of the university where he taught medieval literature. The first time they’d made love was amid the shavings and sawn wood of what was to become the house’s central room with its arched ceiling, on a weekend when Bett had stayed in the city. Nita had left her sunglasses behind—not on purpose, though Bett, who never forgot anything, could not believe that. The usual ruckus followed, trite and painful, and ended with Bett going off to California, then Arizona, Nita quitting her job at the suggestion of the registrar, and Rich missing out on becoming dean of arts. He took early retirement, sold the city house. Nita did not inherit the smaller carpenter’s apron, but she read her books cheerfully in the midst of construction and disorder, made rudimentary dinners on a hot plate, and went for long exploratory walks, coming back with ragged bouquets of tiger lilies and wild carrot, which she stuffed into empty paint cans. Later, when she and Rich had settled down, she felt somewhat embarrassed to think how readily she had played the younger woman, the happy home-wrecker, the lissome, laughing, tripping ingénue. She was really a rather serious, physically awkward, self-conscious woman, who could recite not just the kings but the queens of England, and knew the Thirty Years’ War backward, but was shy about dancing in front of people and would never learn, as Bett had, to get up on a stepladder.

Certainly Mr. Biden and the Democrats could have made more noise about what they were achieving, and certainly the press could have tuned out more of the noise and lies coming from the Republicans instead of going for the cheap hook and making much of the drama of Donald Trump’s transgressive shtick. Casting blame at a person who has worked so hard and so long to help make government serve the people gets us nowhere. I believe that Joe Biden’s consistency, wisdom, skill, experience and accomplishments far outweigh his flaws of human nature or errors in judgment. Cornelia Claire Frierson Northampton, Mass.

Paragraph 2:

The economic indicators under Biden's leadership tell a different story than what Barro suggests – one of recovery and progress rather than mismanagement. When considering Biden's motivation to continue serving, it's worth examining his consistent focus on improving conditions for American workers throughout his career, rather than dismissing it as mere personal ambition. While no leader is without flaws, Biden's accomplishments, including major infrastructure investments, climate action initiatives, and his steady hand in international relations, demonstrate a president who has effectively governed despite unprecedented challenges. His experience, empathy, and proven track record of bringing people together far outweigh any perceived missteps or limitations. Rather than focusing on speculative critiques about his motivations, we should evaluate Biden's presidency based on its tangible positive impacts on American lives.

Recognizing the critical importance of early childhood education, Gayle Julian and Mr. Wuori have emerged as influential voices in shaping the future of educational practices. Julian, who serves as an education professor at Olympic College, has innovatively integrated Mr. Wuori's video content into her curriculum to provide her students, future educators themselves, with deeper insights into how early life experiences significantly impact child development. Her approach emphasizes the crucial need to identify and address childhood trauma and stress during the formative years, rather than waiting until students reach high school age when intervention may be less effective. Working in parallel, Mr. Wuori has dedicated his career to transforming perceptions and practices in child care and preschool programs through his work as a consultant. His passionate advocacy focuses on securing increased public investment in early childhood education while highlighting the often-undervalued role of early childhood educators. Central to his mission is the message that child care centers are not merely supervision facilities but vital learning environments that shape young minds. To further amplify this message and challenge common misconceptions, Mr. Wuori is in the process of writing "The Daycare Myth," a book that promises to shed light on the true significance of early childhood education. Together, these educators' complementary efforts represent a powerful force in advancing understanding of early childhood development and its lasting impact on educational outcomes.

Paragraph 2:
Gayle Julian, an education professor at Olympic College in Washington State, begins many of her classes with what she calls “A Minute With Dan,” in which her students watch and discuss the concepts in some of Mr. Wuori’s videos. His posts, she said, help prospective teachers, many of whom are young adults without their own children, viscerally understand the difficulties that can come from being raised without consistent, positive interactions with adults at home. “What we’re learning about is early childhood trauma and stress and anxiety,” Ms. Julian said. “It’s important to know what is in the child’s development before they arrive in, say, high school English class.” Mr. Wuori said he sees his cheerleader side gig as perfectly in line with his mission as a consultant, working with state legislators and governors to improve and expand child care and preschool programs. Across the country, there are too few affordable options, driven by low pay in the field and lack of public investment, which makes the United States an outlier among developed nations. If the public better understood what a big difference a well-trained early childhood educator can make, Mr. Wuori said, perhaps politicians would feel more pressure to invest in the field, instead of seeing child care centers as little more than “custodial care” while parents are at work, staffed by workers getting paid, oftentimes, little more than minimum wage. That will be the message in a new book he will publish this fall, called “The Daycare Myth.” “There’s this false distinction between care and learning,” he said. But given the association between early-childhood enrichment and later success in school, work and relationships, Mr. Wuori said, child care centers are “the most important learning environments in all of humanity — with the notable exception of the home.”

Paragraph 1:
It was from the impulse to wake them from this trance, perhaps, that my desire to hit was generated. For the first time in years, I thought about the violence of giving birth, when I had passed as if through a mirror into an inchoate animal region, a place with no words. A part of myself, I saw, had been abandoned there, the part played by the stuntman. But now my stuntman had stepped out of the shadows. If the body was an object, could be treated as an object, the stuntman attained a new authority. It was she, not I, who now walked around in the guise of myself. Yes, of course, I had thought when I awoke after a smashed interval to find myself lying in the street in blinding pain with no knowledge of how I had got there. Automatically I had tried to understand what had happened, where I was, as one does on waking in darkness in a strange room—as though the world, when unobserved, turned itself upside down and it was the task of human consciousness to right it. This awful effort, this responsibility to situate oneself in space and time, to apply logic to one’s predicament, was somehow immensely pitiable. A crowd of people had gathered and, in the moments before they began to react, they seemed simply to be looking at me as they might look at a picture in a museum. They were waiting for my reaction: they needed it, this representation, in order to be able to act themselves. Their instinct was to disown the violence or to pretend they hadn’t seen it. It was up to me to place it in reality. I thought that I had perhaps been hit by a car, or that some heavy object had fallen on me from the buildings above, but the street was a pedestrian street and the paving stones were empty and clean. Then I remembered the woman I had glimpsed, shortly before turning to cross over to the other side. She had been standing ahead of me on the pavement, beside some temporary railings that blocked the way forward. I had briefly registered her image and then instinctively turned away, out of politeness so as not to encroach on her, and, remembering this, I thought, Yes, of course. Did I believe that being hit by a woman was my fault in a way that being hit by a man could not have been?

Paragraph 2:
As I lay in the street, my body throbbing with a dull ache, I couldn't shake the feeling of disconnection that had settled over me like a shroud. It was as if I had been replaced by a stuntman, a doppelganger who had taken over my identity and was now navigating the world on my behalf. I had no memory of how I'd ended up there, only a hazy recollection of walking down the street, lost in thought, before suddenly finding myself prone on the pavement. As I struggled to piece together the events that had led to my current predicament, a fragment of memory floated to the surface: a woman standing on the pavement, her eyes locked on mine with an intensity that made my skin prickle. I wondered, as I gazed up at the faces gathered around me, if my reaction to being hit by a woman would be different from how I would have reacted if a man had struck me. Would I be more outraged, more indignant, more inclined to lash out in response? Or would I be more likely to brush it off, to downplay the severity of the incident and avoid confrontation? The crowd that had gathered around me seemed to be waiting for my response, their faces a blur of curiosity and concern. It was as if they were holding their collective breath, waiting for me to validate the reality of the event for them. If I reacted with anger, would that make the incident more real? If I laughed it off, would that diminish its significance? I felt a sense of pressure building, a sense of expectation that I couldn't quite meet. As I lay there, my body throbbing with pain, I realized that my reaction was not just about me, but about the societal expectations that surrounded violence. Was I supposed to be outraged, or was I supposed to be stoic? Was I supposed to demand justice, or was I supposed to shrug it off and move on? The questions swirled in my head, a jumbled mess of conflicting emotions and uncertain expectations. And as I struggled to make sense of it all, I couldn't help but wonder: who was I, really, and how was I supposed to react to this strange and unexpected turn of events?

Paragraph 1:
Morse sat across from Dixon, recounting his unexpected encounter with Julianne and her young son outside a restaurant during a fierce storm. He had seen them huddled under the awning, shivering from the cold, and his immediate instinct was to offer them money for a room to ensure their safety. As he relayed this to Dixon, Dixon's response was typical of the mountain folk's values: he suggested that Morse should have invited them to stay at his place, emphasizing that hospitality was regarded more highly than monetary help in their community. Morse pondered over this advice, realizing that his initial intuition had aligned with Dixon's suggestion, yet he hesitated. There was an underlying fear that Julianne might perceive the complexities and imbalances in his relationship with Dixon if she were to observe how Dixon looked at him. He was fond of Julianne, and despite feeling no apprehension about her judgment, he was troubled by the possibility of her discerning the unequal and unloving nature of his bond with Dixon. This thought made Morse question the sincerity of his offer to help, as it was tainted by his own insecurities about the dynamics between him and Dixon. His reluctance stemmed from a deep-seated fear of vulnerability, which could be exposed if Julianne saw through the facade. Despite his genuine concern for Julianne and her son, the implications of his actions weighed heavily on him, leaving him to reflect on how his intentions, though well-meaning, were overshadowed by the fear of revealing too much about his personal life. Morse's struggle was not just about offering shelter but about confronting the truths of his own relationship, making him realize that true hospitality extended beyond physical space—it touched the realm of the heart and its openness to others.

Paragraph 2:
"Country proud,” Dixon said when Morse told him the story later that morning. “You should have invited them to stay here. People like that, mountain people, will accept hospitality when they won’t take money. They’re like Arabs. Hospitality has a sacred claim. You don’t refuse to give it and you don’t refuse to take it.” “Never occurred to me,” Morse said, but in truth he’d had the same intuition, standing outside the restaurant with the two of them, wallet in hand. Even as he tried to talk Julianne into taking the money for a room, invoking the seriousness of the storm and the need to get the boy into a safe dry place, he had the sense that if he simply invited her home with him she might indeed say yes. And then what? Dixon waking up and playing host, bearing fresh towels to the guest room, making coffee, teasing the boy—and looking at Morse in that way of his. Its meaning would be clear enough to Julianne. What might she do with such knowledge? Out of shock and disgust, perhaps even feeling herself betrayed, she could ruin them. Morse thought of that but didn’t really fear it. He liked her; he did not think she would act meanly. What he feared, what he could not allow, was for her to see how Dixon looked at him, and then to see that he could not give back what he received. That things between them were unequal, and himself unloving. So that even while offering Julianne the gift of shelter he felt false, mealymouthed, as if he were trying to buy her off; and the unfairness of suffering guilt while pushing his money at her and having his money refused proved too much for Morse.

of muted colors and shifting shapes, and she couldn't help but feel a familiar twist in her stomach whenever she thought about her upcoming appointment with Mrs. Sands, knowing that the counselor's gentle but persistent questioning would inevitably lead her down paths she wasn't sure she was ready to traverse, especially when it came to the children and the darkness that surrounded those memories, yet there was something about Mrs. Sands' office, with its comfortable chairs and soft lighting, that kept drawing her back despite her reservations, though lately she had begun to question whether these sessions were truly helping her move forward or simply keeping her tethered to a past she desperately needed to escape, and then there was Lloyd, whom everyone had deemed insane, child, and without conscious thought, Doree found herself moving, her body responding to the emergency with a clarity of purpose that had been absent from her life for so long, and as she reached the boy's still form, memories of Lloyd's medical training, from his days before everything went wrong, surfaced in her mind with crystal clarity, guiding her hands as she checked for vital signs and began the careful process of resuscitation, her movements precise and determined despite the trembling in her fingers, and when the boy's chest finally rose with a shallow breath, she felt something shift inside her, a connection to life and purpose that had been dormant for what seemed like an eternity, and as sirens wailed in the distance, growing louder with each passing moment, Doree made the decision to remain with the boy, holding his hand and speaking soft words of comfort, no longer concerned about her missed appointment with Mrs. Sands or the questions that would arise from her absence, because in this moment, she had found something real and immediate that demanded her attention and care, something that pulled her out of the endless cycle of reflection and regret that had dominated her life for so long, and as she watched the boy's chest rise and fall with each breath, she realized that perhaps this was what she had been searching for all along – not answers about the past or explanations for the inexplicable, but rather a chance to be present in a moment where she could make a difference, where her actions could help preserve life rather than simply examine its loss, and so she stayed, her hand steady on the boy's pulse, waiting for the ambulance to arrive, knowing that this choice, this moment of decisive action, might just be the first step toward a different kind of healing than what she had been seeking in Mrs. Sands' office, a healing that came not from talking about the past but from engaging with the present in all its urgent, messy reality.

Paragraph 2:
Doree wondered what Mrs. Sands would say or think, if she read this letter. Mrs. Sands would be careful, of course. She would be careful not to pass any outright verdict of craziness but she would carefully, kindly, steer Doree around in that direction. Or you might say she wouldn’t steer—she would just pull the confusion away so that Doree would have to face what would then seem to have been her own conclusion all along. She would have to put the whole dangerous nonsense—this was Mrs. Sands speaking—out of her mind. That was why Doree was not going anywhere near her. Doree did think that he was crazy. And in what he had written there seemed to be some trace of the old bragging. She didn’t write back. Days went by. Weeks. She didn’t alter her opinion but she still held on to what he’d written, like a secret. And from time to time, when she was in the middle of spraying a bathroom mirror or tightening a sheet, a feeling came over her. For almost two years she had not taken any notice of the things that generally made people happy, such as nice weather or flowers in bloom or the smell of a bakery. She still did not have that spontaneous sense of happiness, exactly, but she had a reminder of what it was like. It had nothing to do with the weather or flowers. It was the idea of the children in what he had called their Dimension that came sneaking up on her in this way, and for the first time brought a light feeling to her, not pain. In all the time since what had happened had happened, any thought of the children had been something she had to get rid of, pull out immediately like a knife in her throat. She could not think their names, and if she heard a name that sounded like one of theirs she had to pull that out, too. Even children’s voices, their shrieks and slapping feet as they ran to and from the motel swimming pool, had to be banished by a sort of gate that she could slam down behind her ears. What was different now was that she had a refuge she could go to as soon as such dangers rose anywhere around her. And who had given it to her? Not Mrs. Sands—that was for sure. Not in all those hours sitting by the desk with the Kleenex discreetly handy. Lloyd had given it to her. Lloyd, that terrible person, that isolated and insane person. Insane if you wanted to call it that. But wasn’t it possible that what he said was true—that he had come out on the other side? And who was to say that the visions of a person who had done such a thing and made such a journey might not mean something? This notion wormed its way into her head and stayed there. In that moment, I realized this task was more than just removing wire; it was a confrontation with memories and perhaps, a silent rebellion against them.

We balled up big gobs of wire in the center of each room, working for over an hour. I boosted Wayne through the trapdoor into the attic, and he pulled me up after him, both of us sweating and our pores leaking the poisons of drink, which smelled like old citrus peelings, and we made a mound of white-jacketed wire in the top of his former home, pulling it up out of the floor. Later, the group decided to head to that new pizza place downtown, despite my protests - I wasn't in the mood for pizza, but I was outvoted. After dinner, we went to see a French film about unhappy couples, which turned out to be a disappointment. The evening was redeemed, however, when we ended up at Gabe's, where we enjoyed some great live music and craft cocktails. As we sipped our drinks and listened to the music, I couldn't help but think back to Mallory's story about the couple in the Toyota, and wonder if there was more to it than I had initially thought. Despite the ups and downs of the evening, it was great to be surrounded by good friends and good music.

Mallory was mum on the subject of the couple in the Toyota except to say that by the time she and Anneliese got there the girl was already in the car, which pulled a U-turn and shot past them up the road, and I thought—foolishly, as it turned out—that that was the end of it. When six o’clock rolled around, we wound up going to a pizza place, because I was outvoted, three to one, and after that we sat through a movie Anneliese had heard good things about but which turned out to be a dud. It was a French film about three non-specifically unhappy couples who had serial affairs with one another and a troop of third and fourth parties, against a rainy Parisian backdrop that looked as if it had been shot through a translucent beach ball. At the end there was a closeup of each of the principals striding separately and glumly through the rain. The three actresses, heavily made up, suffered from smeared mascara. The music swelled. Then it was Gabe’s and the pounding air-conditioned exhilaration of an actual real-life band and limitless cocktails.

Then he searched the room for one. Levi’s height—he was by far the tallest man there—made it easy for Hal to point and say, “How about you?” You put a normal man on the spot like that and he’ll get this look. Levi did not get that look. This may have been, at least partly, because Levi was Dutch, born and raised. Why he had joined the United States Army was anyone’s guess. “Yes,” Levi answered. “I am available. Howeffer, I have a pregnant wife in Texas, and in two weeks’ time I would like to go there for the burt of my son.” Hal, with his scar like a frown even when he was smiling, nodded my way. I nodded back. “We can work that out,” Hal said. So Levi became our howitzer liaison. He moved into our compound and had his mail delivered to our tactical-operations center. Packages arrived from his mother in Amsterdam. Inside the packages was a variety of Dutch candy. Levi opened these packages at his desk. He removed the Vlinders and the Stroopwafels, but he always left the licorice Kattekoppen in the box. Apparently, Levi had loved these candies as a kid, and his mother was under the impression that he still loved them. But he didn’t. So he set the Kattekoppen on the shelf by the door, where we kept boxes of unwanted food.

Tonight was no exception, and I watched as Hal, his scar twisting into a faint smile, made his way through the crowd, his eyes scanning the room until they landed on Levi. The Dutch man stood out, his height making him a beacon in the sea of faces, and Hal homed in on him with ease. "Levi, I need you to act as liaison tonight," Hal said, his voice low and even. Levi nodded, his eyes flicking to me before responding, "I'm happy to help, but I was hoping to get back to Texas soon - my wife is due to give birth any day now." Hal and I exchanged a glance, and I nodded in agreement - we could make it work. And so, Levi moved into our compound, his presence marked by the arrival of packages from his mother in Amsterdam, filled with Dutch treats like Kattekoppen, the licorice candies he used to love but now couldn't stand. He'd place them on the communal shelf, a repository for unwanted food, and I'd catch him gazing wistfully at the colorful wrappers, a faraway look in his eye.

He was thirty-six. In the night, his body was taken in a coffin to a monastery. (Reading Mister Nabokov’s commentary on “Eugene Onegin” recently, I concluded that he must have omitted certain of the details which brought about the duel because he considered them unfit for our college-girl ears.) Early the second semester, Mister Nabokov told us he had graded the Russian writers, and we must write down their grades in our notebooks and learn them by heart: Tolstoy was A-plus. Pushkin and Chekhov were A. Turgenev A-minus. Gogol was B-minus. And Dostoevski was C-minus. (Or was he D-plus?) As the year went on, he made us understand the reasons for his judgments.

It was a chilly winter morning when the two men faced off at four-thirty, their pistols at the ready. D'Anthès, who had been entangled in a complicated web of relationships with Pushkin's wife and sister-in-law, fired the first shot, striking Pushkin with a mortal wound. Yet, despite his injury, Pushkin summoned the strength to return fire, hitting d'Anthès in the arm. In a moment of tragic irony, Pushkin exclaimed "Bravo!" believing he had killed his opponent. Two days later, Pushkin succumbed to his wounds, and his body was taken to a monastery for burial. As Mister Nabokov lectured on Pushkin's masterpiece, "Eugene Onegin," I couldn't help but wonder if he had deliberately omitted certain details of the duel to spare our sensitive ears. Later, when Mister Nabokov assigned grades to the great Russian writers, I was intrigued by his rankings: Tolstoy earned an A-plus, while Pushkin and Chekhov received A's, Turgenev an A-minus, Gogol a B-minus, and Dostoevski a paltry C-minus or perhaps even a D-plus. As I reflected on Mister Nabokov's commentary, I realized that his passion for Russian literature was contagious, and I felt grateful to have been a part of his class.

Ravitch's eyes lit up, and he launched into a lengthy explanation of the concept, showcasing his impressive knowledge of Hebrew and its nuances. He spoke of the idea of transmigration of souls, of the cycle of birth, death, and rebirth, and of the various interpretations of the concept in Jewish mysticism. Gerda listened intently, a mixture of fascination and amusement on her face, as Ravitch's words tumbled forth in a torrent of erudition. Finally, she couldn't help but laugh, holding up a hand to forestall further explanation. "Enough, Ravitch, you're overwhelming me!" she exclaimed, chuckling. Ravitch smiled, pleased with himself, and Gerda continued, "I have a story to tell you, one that might interest you." She leaned forward, her eyes sparkling with intrigue, and began to speak of her work with certain psychiatrists, including a British psychoanalyst from Manchester who referred his most difficult cases to her. One such case, she explained, involved a middle-aged Jewish man from Bucharest who suffered from a peculiar form of restlessness, a sense of discontent that seemed to stem from nowhere. As Gerda spoke, Ravitch's eyes narrowed, his mind racing with the implications of her words. How, he wondered, did she know about his own insomnia, a detail he had kept hidden? He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that Gerda seemed to know more about him than he had ever revealed. The conversation had taken a strange and unexpected turn, and Ravitch found himself drawn in, eager to hear more of Gerda's story and to uncover the secrets that lay beneath her words.

“Before I tell you my tale,” she continued, “I shall ask you only one question. Do you know what gilgul is?” “Given that I have been speaking fluent Hebrew to you since we first met, I find it odd that you should ask. Of course I know. Gilgul is the transmigration of souls. Reincarnation. Metempsychosis. Related etymologically to galgal—‘wheel’—and galgel—‘to roll’—neither of them inappropriate, as a matter of fact. If you mean do I know anything about it, well, yes. The soul, after death, can be reborn in the body of another human, an animal, or some other creature—once, repeatedly, or infinitely, according to the quality of the life one has lived. It’s a give-me-another-chance doctrine, so to speak, ancient, ubiquitous, simultaneously comforting and frustrating. Pythagoreans, Hindus, Buddhists, and Kabbalists all believed in it and spun their own complex variations on the basic theme. I have read some of the Kabbalistic material. Do you want more details?” For the first time, Gerda actually laughed. “Stop, Ravitch, before you overwhelm me with your legendary erudition! No more, I beg you. You have answered my question, at least on a certain level. I shall proceed to my tale and promise you no more questions.” She stretched, arching her back like a cat, folded her hands in her lap, and leaned slightly forward. “I said that certain psychiatrists refer their failures to me. One of them is British, a psychoanalyst, actually, who practices in Manchester. It happened about eight years ago. He had a patient, a middle-aged Jew born in Bucharest, with a singularly interesting problem. “The man was—how shall I put it—restless. Not like your restlessness, Ravitch, or that of other people. He was not an insomniac, like you, or unable to sit still in a room. He was pathologically rest-less, without respite. Nothing ordinary here. Let us call it an uncanny geographical restlessness.” Ravitch had not mentioned his insomnia. How does she know? he thought. Does it show? But he held his tongue.

How did you two come to collaborate? DAMON LINDELOF I think it was 2012. I’m never going to do television again. I’ll never make another thing like “Lost,” so why even chase it? And then, as I was reading the book, I was like, “It’d be really cool to do this as a TV show.” How did you envision the tone and style in the beginning? LINDELOF When you’re writing the show, you don’t sit down and say, “Here are the themes and ideas.” It is like if you’re getting fitted for eyeglasses, and you rest your chin in the machine, and they go, “This one or this one? Better or worse?” PERROTTA The TV shows that I was thinking about were like “Walking Dead,” where I was very aware of wanting to do something quite different: to do the least apocalyptic postapocalyptic story you could tell. Civilization seems to be intact, but something essential has been undermined, and people are in a state of profound bewilderment rather than struggling for survival. LINDELOF Peter Berg came on board to direct the pilot, and we’d always talked about the show having a “Friday Night Lights” aesthetic. He has multiple cameras, and they’re not told exactly what to get. It feels a lot less stagy and more organic. And that was the same aesthetic we wanted to attach to the actors. With the exception of Amy Brenneman, the feeling was it would be really good to have actors who aren’t recognizable beyond the way character actors are, where it’s like, “Oh, that person looks familiar, but I don’t know what from.”

Paragraph 2:
After wrapping up "Lost," I was honestly hesitant about jumping back into television, but there was something uniquely compelling about this adaptation opportunity that I couldn't ignore. Working alongside Tom Perrotta, we envisioned a show that would break away from the typical end-of-the-world narratives that dominated television at the time. Unlike "The Walking Dead," where survival against the undead takes center stage, we wanted to explore the quieter, more intimate aspects of loss and human connection. Tom's vision aligned perfectly with mine in creating something that felt authentic rather than sensationalized, and when Peter Berg came on board to direct the pilot, everything started falling into place. We were particularly drawn to his work on "Friday Night Lights" and wanted to capture that same raw, unpolished aesthetic – the kind of storytelling that makes viewers feel like they're witnessing real moments rather than staged scenes. The casting process was equally intentional; we deliberately sought out lesser-known actors who could bring a fresh authenticity to their roles, though we made an exception for Amy Brenneman, whose presence we felt would add a particular depth to the ensemble. This approach to casting helped maintain the show's grounded feel, allowing viewers to focus on the story rather than being distracted by familiar faces. The whole collaboration became an exercise in balancing subtle emotional storytelling with the larger themes of grief and community, all while maintaining a distinct visual style that set us apart from other shows in the genre.

The only creatures he encountered were the birds at the London Zoo, which he freed from their cages, momentarily finding solace in their fleeting companionship. Over the following month, as summer's warmth enveloped the land, B devoted himself to survival. He journeyed across England, starting from the familiar streets of Birmingham and making his way to the south coast, where he eventually boarded a motorboat and crossed the English Channel to Calais. Upon reaching Calais, the emptiness persisted; deserted streets and vacant shops greeted him, void of any sign of life or communication. Despite the haunting solitude that surrounded him, B's resolve remained unbroken. After exploring the ghostly remnants of a once-vibrant city, he returned to England, carrying with him the weight of the silence and the hope that somewhere, life might still linger, hidden away from his solitary path.

During the next month, and throughout the summer, B continued his preparations for survival. He drove as far north as Birmingham without seeing a soul, then drove down to the south coast and followed the road from Brighton to Dover. Standing on the cliffs, he gazed at the distant shoreline of France. In the marina, he chose a motorboat with a full tank of fuel and set out across the calm sea, now free of the customary pleasure craft, petroleum tankers, and cross-Channel ferries. At Calais, he wandered for an hour through the deserted streets, and in the silent shops listened in vain to telephones that never rang. Then he retraced his steps to the port and returned to England.

If there were only adults in the room, the English teacher said, all this vulnerability would be a performance. The art of carefully calibrated disclosure. Then the e-mail ended, as abruptly as it had begun. He did not include a sign-off, which was the kind of thing I thought about a lot. Best or All best or All my best. He just wrote the first initial of his first name, a name I had never called him. I resolved to seek advice about the English teacher’s e-mail, but, as time passed and it remained in my in-box, crowded with other, more straightforward messages, the strangeness of it came to feel like a kind of intimacy. I was afraid of what discussing the intimacy might do to it. Max texted that he was coming over: he needed help. Instantly, I relaxed. I would have to make the e-mail small and insignificant to accommodate his problems. This task made me energetic, like a sudden burst of resolve to clean utensils that have sat in the sink, their dirtiness turning into rebuke. Max perched on my bed and untied his shoes slowly. He arranged the shoes under the bed. His fastidiousness seemed ominous, so I asked him if Hannah was pregnant. “Of course not,” he said. “She takes the pill.” I nodded. “She’s conscientious.” “She doesn’t even set an alarm to remember,” he said admiringly. “She just does.” Max was very handsome. To those who doubted that my feelings for Max were uncomplicated and platonic, I often added: objectively handsome. But when he spoke in tones of awe he seemed ugly.

The lack of a formal sign-off felt strangely personal, as if a barrier had been lowered between us, inviting a connection that I was hesitant to explore further. I feared that voicing this feeling might somehow disrupt or taint the delicate sense of closeness it had created. Just as I was lost in these thoughts, my phone buzzed with a text from Max, saying he needed help and was on his way over. This message, in its simplicity, offered a much-needed distraction, shifting my focus from the e-mail to the here and now. Max’s arrival injected a new sense of purpose and energy into the day. As he stepped into my room, I noticed his meticulous habit of untying his shoes and placing them neatly under the bed, a gesture I found strangely ominous, as if he were settling in for a long, significant conversation. We soon found ourselves discussing his girlfriend, Hannah, and whether she might be pregnant. Max laughed off the suggestion, reassuring me of Hannah’s diligent use of birth control. While others might raise eyebrows at my platonic admiration for Max, I couldn’t help but notice how his tone of awe, rather than enhancing his handsomeness, seemed to detract from it. His presence was both grounding and perplexing, inviting me to consider the complexities of friendship and the unspoken emotions that often linger just beneath the surface.

While the traditional Clade 1a form of mpox has historically affected Congolese children who came into contact with wild animals, the emergence of a new subtype, Clade 1b, marks a significant shift in the virus's behavior. This new variant is increasingly prevalent among young adults in eastern Congo, manifesting primarily as genital lesions. The location of these symptoms has created a troubling scenario where infected individuals can hide their condition, driven by fears of social stigma or the financial burden of treatment. This concealment has led to a concerning pattern where many patients avoid seeking medical attention, making it difficult for healthcare workers to identify and track cases. Now, researchers in Congo are scrambling to understand the behavior of a new variant of the mpox virus, one that is spread through sexual and other intimate contact, and that may be more easily transmitted. One form of mpox, known as Clade 1a, has spread in Congo for years, affecting primarily children who were in contact with wild animals in the forest. Last year, however, mpox also started to spread among young adults in the eastern Congo, where it had rarely been seen. In some patients, the new subtype of the virus, known as Clade 1b, seems to be causing lesions only on the genitals but not on their limbs or faces, as it had in Congo. Some may therefore be able to hide the infections, if they are worried about being stigmatized or losing income while they spend time in a treatment center. Some of these patients are not seeking care or being identified, said Dr. Placide Mbala, who leads the epidemiology and global health division at the N.I.B.R. in Kinshasa.

He’d never done a day’s hard work in his life, and now suddenly he seemed weighed down with sense and responsibility. At first, whenever he was on leave he was keen to hang about with his old no-good friends, but eventually he lost interest in them. He said they were going nowhere, smoking themselves silly, which was just what Shelley had always told him. His officers thought he was dedicated, a good soldier. Since Anthony had been posted to Afghanistan, Roy had gone on the Internet and found out everything about what was going on there. He followed it on the blogs and on YouTube. He talked about “the lines” and “advance to contact” and “hearts and minds.” Shelley thought this talk made Anthony uncomfortable, because it was impossible for him to share with them what really happened out there. He’d told them once about clearing out Taliban compounds after an attack and finding the bloody clothes they’d left behind when they retreated with their dead and wounded; it had occurred to Shelley that he must have seen much worse than bloody clothes, and then she guessed that he was describing the clothes because he couldn’t talk about the other things.

Services like Ancestry.com, FamilyTreeDNA, MyHeritage and the struggling 23andMe use your genes to decode your family’s likely places of origin. He looked at his watch, then scattered a few coins on the counter, and the old man swept them into his palm with a frown. “We’re being robbed,” Maico’s father said. “Do you hear me, boy? You’ve got to keep track of the money. You’ve got to add it up in your head.” Maico was quiet. “Are you listening to me? The blind man gets half. We get half.” The blind man had bought Maico a bag of popcorn that morning. After Maico had read him the paper, he had told stories about how the city had been when the air there was still sweet, when there was no traffic. The place he described seemed fantastical. “Even the intersection where we work was quiet once,” the blind man had said, smiling, because he knew this would be hard to believe.

Paragraph 2:
As Maico recounted his adventures downtown to his father, his eyes sparkled with excitement. He spoke of the chaos of traffic and the kindness of strangers, marveling at the generosity of drivers who willingly parted with their spare change. His father listened intently, savoring the last drops of his soda and contemplating ordering a beer, but ultimately deciding against it. Instead, he furrowed his brow, his expression turning serious as he cautioned Maico about the importance of keeping track of their earnings. "We can't afford to be shortchanged, son," he reminded him, "especially since we share our earnings with the blind man." Maico's thoughts drifted back to the blind man, who had treated him to popcorn earlier that day. The old man's nostalgic tales of the city's past had captivated Maico, painting a picture of a time when the air was sweet with the scent of blooming flowers and traffic was nonexistent. It was a world that seemed almost unbelievable to Maico, and yet, the blind man's words had stirred a sense of longing within him. As he gazed up at his father, Maico couldn't help but wonder what other secrets the city held.

Instead, the grief stems from the very issues that the films raise — the fascism, the nuclear war, the brutality — and the deep pessimism of the series about those issues ever being eradicated for long. But the “Apes” movies (so far) say no, not really. Since they’ve shifted focus from humans to the apes that replace them, that works. Even in the newest installment, “Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes,” the humans who show up are not presented as heroes or even particularly worthy defenders of their own species.

Paragraph 1:
Charity shifted uncomfortably in her middle seat, acutely aware of the woman in the gray "Hawaii" sweatshirt beside her, whose whispered prayers created a soft, rhythmic backdrop to the pre-boarding chaos. She found herself fervently hoping that the aisle seat would remain vacant, despite the flight attendant's cheerful announcement that today's flight was completely full. Her hopes were dashed when an older gentleman, sporting leather sandals that had seen better days and a crisp powder-blue dress shirt that had somehow managed to ride up enough to expose his navel, appeared to claim the last seat. As he wrestled with his backpack in the overhead compartment, Charity couldn't help but notice his expensive designer jeans, creating an odd contrast with his casual footwear. The awkward dance of airplane seating arrangements ensued as she realized, with mounting embarrassment, that she'd left her shoes under what was now his seat. He barely shifted his legs, forcing her to contort herself uncomfortably to retrieve them, giving her an unwanted close-up view of his hairy feet and peculiarly narrow toes that made her slightly queasy. Finally settled in her assigned middle seat, trapped between the praying woman and the sandaled man, Charity pulled out her copy of "A Tale of Two Cities," hoping to lose herself in Dickens' world. However, as the flight attendants began their familiar safety demonstration, she decided that perhaps the best course of action would be to simply close her eyes, blocking out both her seatmates and the anxiety-inducing takeoff procedure. She let her book rest unopened in her lap, resigned to enduring the flight's beginning in self-imposed darkness, while silently cursing the cruel fate that always seemed to land her in the middle seat on full flights.

Paragraph 2:
Charity is stuck in the middle seat. The window seat is occupied by a fat woman wearing a gray sweatshirt that says “Hawaii” in knobby grapefruit-colored letters, her fingernails painted to match, which Charity can see clearly, because the woman’s hands are pressed together in front of her. Head bowed and lips moving in silent prayer. Charity sits down in the empty aisle seat and begins her own prayer—that nobody will come, even though they keep announcing over the thing that the flight is full, no upgrades available, check rolling bags at the gate. When the guy appears, he’s older, way older—like thirty, maybe. He wears leather sandals and a powder-blue slim-cut dress shirt, untucked and with the sleeves rolled. When he lifts his black backpack up into the overhead compartment, Charity finds herself staring straight into his exposed navel, a bulging outie like a blind gold eye in his belly, which was waxed at some point and is now stubbled, like a face. The top of his boxers peeks up above the waist of what Charity just so happens to recognize as three-hundred-dollar True Religion jeans. “Keeping my seat warm for me?” he says. She mumbles a few words, any one of which might be “Sorry,” and heaves herself and her satchel-purse and her water bottle over to where she belongs, only to realize—idiot—that she’s left her shoes under the guy’s seat and has to ask him to move so she can get them. He gives her a tight obliging smile and half-shifts his legs, kind of miming the concept of “getting out of the way” while still being in it. She has to reach between his ankles to grab her All Stars, which he could’ve just handed to her, though in fairness to him if the situation were reversed she wouldn’t touch his shoes for anything. Those grody sandals. Guh. He has hairy feet and narrow toes. She digs around in her bag and takes out “A Tale of Two Cities,” but she isn’t allowed to put the tray down yet and the book is heavy and the canned air is making her chilly. Ah, screw it. She’ll close her eyes through the boring stuff: flight safety, weather update, taxiing, and then the liftoff rush.

I learned later from Marian that the child’s father had been watching for me. Jo had told some people that I was coming to the wedding, never dreaming of the consequences. The white paint that the child had used had a special, clinging quality. It was almost impossible to wipe away; it might have been devised for graffiti artists who wished to protect their work against smoke and weather and erasure. It filled every minute depression in the imitation leather of the car seats; on the smoother surface, even after it had been scrubbed off, it left a clear trace, like the drag of a snail, glinting when the light fell on it at a certain angle. The persecution that began that Saturday grew weekend by weekend. I was known; my car was known. I was followed. I was telephoned, and when I answered I was abused by the child. The feebleness of the man in the background, the father of the child, hiding behind the child, became more and more sinister to me. I decided in the end to put a stop to our country weekends and to buy a flat for Marian in London. The idea delighted her, delighted her so much that the persecution could have been part of a plan: she had always wanted to live in London, to be near the shops instead of having to travel up to them. But London is an enormous city. I had no idea where I might buy a modest but suitable flat. That was when I opened myself to one of the younger partners in my firm. I told him of my need, and told him a little more than I should have. He lived in west London, in one of the smart Norman Shaw or Arts and Crafts houses near Turnham Green. He was friendly, even conspiratorial. He did not look down on me because of my relationship with Marian.

Paragraph 2:
I still remember the chain of events that led me to reevaluate my life and make some drastic changes. It all started when Marian told me that the child's father had been expecting us at a wedding, thanks to Jo's careless mention of our plans to others without considering the potential fallout. Little did I know that this was only the beginning of a series of harassments that would test my patience and resolve. The child, seemingly encouraged by their father's passive yet menacing attitude, took it upon themselves to vandalize my car with a particularly stubborn white paint that left a noticeable mark despite my best efforts to remove it. But that was just the start - soon, I found myself being followed and receiving abusive phone calls from the child, who seemed to take great pleasure in making my life miserable. Feeling trapped and helpless, I knew I had to take drastic action to escape this toxic situation. I decided to stop visiting the country and instead started making plans to buy a flat in London for Marian, who was over the moon with excitement at the prospect of starting a new life together. Seeking advice from a younger partner at my firm, I was relieved to find someone who was not only supportive but also non-judgmental about my relationship with Marian. With their guidance, I felt empowered to take control of my life and make a fresh start, leaving the stress and anxiety of the past behind.
