Paragraph 1:
But now he’s here, right here, his jeans tossed in the back seat of the car and his T-shirt stuffed into his mother’s straw bag, the sun on one edge of the table and the piney shade covering the rest of it, Grandma already setting up the chair. And so the day’s about to get going at last, the day he’s been looking forward to in the hot nights while watching bars of light slide across his wall from passing cars, he’s here, he’s arrived, he’s ready to begin. Though who’s to say when anything begins really? You could say the day began when they passed the wooden sign with the words “INDIAN COVE” and the outline of a tomahawk, on a curve of road with a double yellow line down the middle and brown wooden posts with red reflectors. Or maybe it all started when the car backed up the slope of the driveway and the tires bumped over the sidewalk between the knee-high pricker hedges. Or what if it happened before that, when he woke up in the morning and saw the day stretching out before him like a whole summer of blue afternoons? But he’s only playing, just fooling around, because he knows exactly when it all begins: it begins when he enters the water. That’s the agreement he’s made with himself, summer after summer. That’s just how it is. The day begins in the river, and everything else leads up to it. Not that he’s all that eager to rush into things. Now that he’s here, now that the waiting’s practically over, he enjoys prolonging the excitement of moving toward the moment he’s been waiting for. It isn’t the swimming itself he looks forward to. He doesn’t even swim. He hangs on to the inner tube and kicks his legs. He likes it, it’s fine, he can take it or leave it. No, what he cares about, what thrills him every time, is knowing that this is it, the beginning of the long-awaited day at the river, as agreed to by himself in advance.

Paragraph 2:
The boy, brimming with excitement, couldn't wait to spend another glorious day at the river, a cherished tradition he looked forward to each summer. As he cast aside his jeans and T-shirt, feeling the warmth of the sun on his skin, his grandmother set up a comfortable chair nearby, ready to keep a watchful eye on him while enjoying her own little escape into the tranquil environs. For him, the day at the river held a special kind of magic, a personal ritual that marked the highlight of his summer adventures. He pondered over when the day truly began, reminiscing about the different markers that could signify the start of his river escapade. Was it the moment they passed the "INDIAN COVE" sign, signaling their approach to the beloved spot? Or perhaps it was the instant they backed out of the driveway, leaving behind the familiar world for a day of aquatic delight. Yet, in his heart, he knew the day officially began the very moment his feet touched the water, sending ripples across the surface as if announcing his arrival. This entry into the water was more than just a physical act; it was a ceremonial passage into a world of joy and freedom. Though he wasn't keen on swimming in the traditional sense, his excitement stemmed from the simple pleasure of clinging to an inner tube, kicking his legs in the cool, refreshing water, feeling the gentle current against his body. The inner tube was his vessel, floating him effortlessly, allowing him to savor the sun-dappled ripples and listen to the melodic tunes of the river, which whispered secrets only he could hear. The anticipation of this moment, the ritual of beginning his day at the river, filled him with an unparalleled sense of joy and contentment. It was a time-honored tradition, a little piece of summer that was all his own, where time seemed to stretch and the world beyond the riverbank faded away, leaving only the boy, the water, and the endless possibilities of a day well spent.

Minneapolis offers an eclectic mix of entertainment, dining, and cultural venues that showcase the city's vibrant character. Bryant Lake Bowl stands as a cherished landmark, combining classic bowling lanes with theatrical performances and casual dining. The Walker Art Center, a cornerstone of contemporary art, features an expansive sculpture garden where visitors can explore thought-provoking installations year-round. Culinary enthusiasts flock to Spoon and Stable for its refined atmosphere and innovative American cuisine, while Meteor has established itself as a destination for expertly crafted cocktails. Laune Bread delights patrons with an array of artisanal pastries and fresh-baked goods. The city's craft beer scene thrives at Indeed Brewing Company, where whimsical artwork adorns the taproom walls and diverse beer selections flow freely. Nearby, Pryes Brewing Company offers a distinctive experience with its unique riverside location and custom-designed Feather Bowling lanes, adding to Minneapolis's dynamic social landscape.

The Walker Art Center, the city’s preeminent arts institution, has an adjacent sculpture garden with a secluded bunkerlike installation by James Turrell. Spoon and Stable is a bustling restaurant in the Warehouse District with a beautiful back-lit bar and lively see-and-be-seen atmosphere. Meteor, a bar on an industrial block by the Mississippi River, serves excellent cocktails as well as boilermakers and hot dogs. Laune Bread bakes hearty sourdough loaves, mandarin-marmalade Danish pastries, chocolatey babka knots and honey-sesame coconut macaroons. Indeed Brewing Company is a popular brewery with delightfully unusual craft beers and an inviting taproom displaying whimsical artworks. Pryes Brewing Company, an enormous brewery on the western bank of the river, has citrusy West Coast-style I.P.A.s and a lane for feather bowling (a game somewhat similar to bocce).

Suddenly, a sound of footsteps in the corridor. The door opens. Carla Devade appears, wearing tight corduroy trousers, flat shoes, and a disconsolate smile on her pretty Mediterranean face. Marc Devade gets up from his chair; for a moment the couple whisper questions and answers. The Central American has fallen silent; Sollers is mechanically flipping through a British magazine. Then Carla and Marc walk across the room (Carla taking tentative little steps, holding her husband’s arm), and the Central American stands up, is introduced, obsequiously greets the newcomer. The conversation immediately resumes, but the Central American’s chatter veers off in a new direction, unfortunately for him (he changes the subject from literature to the matchless beauty and grace of French women), at which point Sollers completely loses interest. Shortly afterward, the visit is brought to a close: Sollers looks at his watch, says it’s late; Devade shows the Central American to the door, shakes his hand, and the visitor, instead of waiting for the elevator, rushes down the stairs. On the second-floor landing he runs into Marie-Thérèse Réveillé. The Central American is talking to himself in Spanish, not under his breath but out loud. As their paths cross, Marie-Thérèse notices a fierce look in his eyes. They bump into each other. Both apologize. They look at each other again (and this is surprising, the way their eyes meet again after the apology), and what she sees, beneath the expedient mask of bitterness, is a well of unbearable horror and fear. So the Central American, Z, is there in the café when the photo is taken, and Carla and Marie-Thérèse have recognized him, they’ve remembered him; perhaps he has just arrived, perhaps he walked past the table at which the group is sitting and greeted them, but, except for the two women, they had no idea who he was; this happens quite often, of course, but it’s something that the Central American still can’t accept with equanimity. There he is, to the left of the group, with some Central American friends, or waiting for them, maybe, and deep within him there’s a seething anger nourished by affronts and grudges, fuelled by bitterness and the chill of the City of Light. His appearance, however, is equivocal: it makes Carla Devade feel like a protective older sister or a missionary nun in Africa, but it catches at Marie-Thérèse Réveillé like barbed wire and triggers a vague erotic longing.

Sollers, on the other hand, appeared disinterested, his attention wavering as the conversation shifted. Carla made her way over to Marc, and they exchanged a brief, whispered conversation before he turned to introduce her to the Central American. The man's smile was warm, his words gracious, as he attempted to engage Carla in conversation. However, as the topic turned to the beauty of French women, Sollers's interest waned, and he began to glance at his watch, his eyes darting towards the door. The visit drew to a close, and the Central American, with a hurried apology, made his way out of the room, opting for the stairs over the elevator. It was on the second-floor landing that he collided with Marie-Thérèse Réveillé, their bodies touching briefly as they exchanged apologies. Marie-Thérèse caught a glimpse of something in the man's eyes, a deep horror and fear that seemed to linger long after their encounter. Later, in a bustling café, Carla and Marie-Thérèse would cross paths with the Central American once more, now referred to as Z. While others seemed oblivious to his presence, the two women felt an inexplicable pull, their emotions diverging in response. Carla felt a surge of protectiveness, a desire to shield this man from the world, while Marie-Thérèse experienced a vague, unsettling erotic longing. Z, however, seemed consumed by a simmering anger and bitterness, his emotions seething just below the surface, his demeanor a subtle yet potent indicator of the turmoil brewing within. As he sat, sipping his coffee, his eyes seemed to burn with an inner fire, a flame that threatened to consume him whole.

Paragraph 1:
As I sat in our makeshift mission control room, surrounded by scribbled notes and empty pizza boxes, I couldn't help but feel a mix of excitement and trepidation. My friends and I were planning an amateur space mission, and we were determined to make it happen. Anna, with her sharp mind and infectious drive, was leading the charge, and I was happy to be along for the ride - especially since we'd started dating just three weeks prior. However, our timing was being dictated by Steve Wong's dental work, which was a bit of a setback. I suggested we schedule our liftoff to coincide with one of the historic Apollo missions, but logistical conflicts kept arising. After much debate, we finally settled on September 27th as our launch date. Unlike the pros, we didn't have years of training and prep under our belts, but we were determined to make it work. We even managed to test-fly our booster rocket on July 4th, cleverly disguising it as just another firework shooting out of Steve Wong's driveway. And, much to our surprise, it worked - our little rocket is now orbiting the Earth, a tiny, amateurish satellite that will likely burn up on reentry within a year. It's a little surreal to think about, but we're all thrilled to have made it this far, and we can't wait to see what the future holds for our ragtag space program.

Paragraph 2:
Anna is as thin and smart as a whip, and driven like no one else I have ever dated (for three exhausting weeks). She saw a challenge here. She wanted to succeed where the Russians had failed. It would be fun. We’d all go, she said, and that was that, but when? I suggested that we schedule liftoff in conjunction with the forty-fifth anniversary of Apollo 11, the most famous space flight in history, but that was a no-go, as Steve Wong had dental work scheduled for the third week of July. How about November, when Apollo 12 landed in the Ocean of Storms, also forty-five years ago but forgotten by 99.999 per cent of the people on Earth? Anna had to be a bridesmaid at her sister’s wedding the week after Halloween, so the best date for the mission turned out to be September 27th, a Saturday. Astronauts in the Apollo era had spent thousands of hours piloting jet planes and earning engineering degrees. They had to practice escaping from launchpad disasters by sliding down long cables to the safety of thickly padded bunkers. They had to know how slide rules worked. We did none of that, though we did test-fly our booster on the Fourth of July, out of Steve Wong’s huge driveway in Oxnard, hoping that, with all the fireworks, our unmanned first stage would blow through the night sky unnoticed. Mission accomplished. That rocket cleared Baja and is right now zipping around the Earth every ninety minutes and, let me state clearly, for the sake of multiple government agencies, will probably burn up harmlessly on reëntry in twelve to fourteen months.

Let’s just have a nice evening.” “Why are you so nice?” Lea said. “You’re so nice to everyone but me.” “You’re being mean.” “You feel so sorry for the crazy lady on the plane. You let her talk to you for hours. You propose cooking for people you just met. You spend an entire evening listening to their pointless stories instead of spending time with me.” She considered that she may have taken one step too far. “Are you talking about the pub?” Leo said. “I was making an effort with your friends.” “Exactly,” Lea said. “You make an effort with everyone else.” They were in front of the Pantheon now, frightening and serene. “This is quite a sight,” Leo said. It was just like him, she thought, to avoid her reproach. “You know that guy Riccardo? He actually came on to me. And you spent all evening chatting with him.” “I didn’t know that,” Leo said. “Even if you did, you wouldn’t have cared.” “That’s not fair.” “You would’ve cared more that he liked you.” Leo turned to face the building. Lea had an urge to yank at his shoulder, to make him look at her. “What if I told you that something happened between us?” “I guess that would be your free choice.” “Stop it!” Lea said. “Just stop it.” She was shouting now. “Stop making me feel invisible.” Leo was silent. Maybe he mumbled something. “You might as well know that we spent the night together.” Even as she said it, she thought there would be an opportunity to take it back, explain that she was just trying to provoke him. After a moment, Leo asked, “Why are you telling me this?” She was astounded by the question, by the fact that he needed an explanation.

The memory of him spending an entire flight engaging with a stranger in animated conversation while barely acknowledging her presence still stung, as did the night at the pub when he had gone out of his way to entertain her friends while treating her with casual indifference. "You're always so concerned about being nice to others, but what about me?" she demanded, her voice trembling with a mixture of anger and hurt. Leo maintained his characteristic composure, his face an unreadable mask as he gazed at the ancient columns, which only served to fuel Lea's mounting frustration. In a desperate attempt to crack his emotional wall, she played her final card - a fabricated confession about an affair with Riccardo. The words hung heavily in the Roman air, a calculated move designed to provoke any kind of emotional response from her seemingly detached partner. Yet Leo's reaction remained frustratingly measured, his emotional distance as solid and immovable as the stone structure before them. This only confirmed what Lea had feared all along: their relationship had become a hollow performance, where his warmth and attention were generously distributed to everyone else while she, ironically the closest person to him, remained stranded in an emotional desert of his making. The tourist crowds continued to mill around them, oblivious to the relationship crumbling in their midst, as Lea's accusations echoed against Leo's wall of silence.

Paragraph 1:
I'm trying to read Auden tonight, but the words keep sliding off the page as I sip my gin on the back porch, watching the shadows lengthen across the yard. When I step inside to refresh my drink, there's this peculiar sensation that a bird might swoop down and land on my shoulder, though I know it's just my nerves playing tricks. These days, my fears have become more tangible – the thought of losing what I have, of ending up alone, of time slipping through my fingers like water. But then my mind drifts to that road trip we took last summer, and suddenly I'm there again with her, pulling up to that dilapidated hot springs lodge. The place was run by these burnt-out hippies who seemed to have made peace with their faded dreams, and somehow we'd managed to charm our way into a midnight swim. The sign clearly stated "No Entry After 10 PM," but they made an exception for us, two strangers passing through. I can still feel the steam rising from the water as we shed our clothes in the darkness, our bodies slipping beneath the warm surface, everything else falling away until it was just us, the stars, and the gentle lapping of water against ancient stone.

Paragraph 2:
Whatever had made the Auden seem possible indoors, under a quiet solitary light, didn’t work at all in the warm expanding evening, and I put the book down and concentrated on my gin. When I went back in to refresh my drink, I couldn’t tell whether the bird was still there. In the refrigerator light, I had a creepy feeling that it might land on my back or my head, so I went outside again with my drink and my thoughts. I was thinking about the things I was afraid of: the likelihood of loss, of loneliness. But then I found myself remembering another time: a road trip we’d taken down through the mountains, she and I, that had wound up in a derelict hot springs at the end of a dirt road. The lodge was gray and tumbledown. The hippies who ran the place seemed to be waiting for something that wasn’t going to come. They had a blank-eyed, resigned look, the kind you see in the survivors of a tsunami or a typhoon. Suffering that doesn’t even know its own name. After ten o’clock only guests of the lodge were permitted in the pool, and we seemed to be the only guests. This is what I remembered: going out in our bathrobes, taking the bathrobes off, entering the warm water naked, feeling it close around our bodies.

Paragraph 1:
Yura found himself standing at the bustling train station, the air thick with the usual cacophony of distant conversations, the clatter of footsteps, and the occasional whistle of an approaching train. Amidst this familiar chaos, Yura's attention was inexplicably drawn to a figure perched on a weathered bench, set slightly apart from the surging crowd. The man was startlingly out of place, his rotund form clothed in light summer attire that seemed ill-suited for the season's chill. His face was puffy, his eyes sunken, and his skin carried an unnatural pallor, giving him a corpse-like visage that sent a shiver down Yura's spine. It was as if he had materialized from thin air, his presence both unsettling and intriguing. As Yura hesitated, caught between curiosity and apprehension, the man turned his gaze upon him, offering a flat, expressionless stare that seemed to pierce through the layers of reality. "The train will arrive in eight minutes," he intoned, his voice devoid of emotion yet carrying an undeniable weight of certainty. Yura, feeling a sudden wave of disorientation, was reminded of a long-ago bout with sunstroke, the world tilting and swirling around him in a dizzying dance. Taking the man's suggestion, he sat down on the bench, the coolness of the metal seeping through his clothes and grounding him in the moment. The stranger, dressed in an antiquated style reminiscent of a bygone era, particularly reminded Yura of his late grandfather's friend, a connection that was both comforting and disconcerting. As they sat side by side, the conversation unfolded in a curious manner, the man's responses to Yura's hesitant inquiries revealing an astonishing breadth of knowledge. Whether the topic was chess, with its intricate strategies and timeless allure, the vast mysteries of astronomy, or the nuanced complexities of music, the man answered with an ease and precision that belied his ghostly appearance. Yura, initially unnerved by the man's uncanny presence, found himself gradually relaxing, his apprehension giving way to a growing sense of intrigue. There was a bizarre charm in the man's demeanor, a subtle hint of playfulness behind his otherwise stoic facade. As they talked, Yura couldn't shake the suspicion that this peculiar stranger might indeed be a musician, perhaps one who had traversed the boundaries of time and space, carrying with him the echoes of melodies long forgotten. The thought brought a smile to Yura's lips, the absurdity of the notion somehow fitting perfectly within the surreal tapestry of the encounter. The world around them faded into a blur, the station's frenetic energy no longer an intrusion but rather a distant background hum to their shared moment of connection. As the minutes ticked by, Yura felt a curious blend of amusement and wonder, the encounter leaving an indelible mark on his perception of reality. When the train finally arrived, its arrival heralded by the familiar rumble and screech of metal on metal, Yura rose from the bench with a newfound lightness in his step, the stranger's words and wisdom echoing in his mind. Though the encounter had been brief, it lingered with him, a reminder of the extraordinary hidden within the mundane.

Paragraph 2:
Yura turned around. A man was sitting on the bench he’d just jumped past. This was so unexpected that Yura stopped moving. A fat, puffy-faced man in light summer clothes sat looking at Yura. “What?” Yura muttered, not believing his own eyes. “The train will be here in eight minutes,” the man pronounced. There was no expression on the man’s large, mealy-white, pear-shaped face. No expression at all. Absolutely no expression. It was the first time in his life that Yura had seen a face like that. “What train?” he asked, unable to look away from the man’s face. “Your electric locomotive.” The man’s small, expressionless eyes were fixed on Yura. It seemed to Yura that the man’s face was frozen. And that the man himself . . . was from the morgue. A corpse. A dead man. Yura suddenly began to feel ill, just the way he’d felt when he’d had sunstroke in Baku last summer. His legs trembled. “Please, sit down,” the man’s frozen lips said. “You look like you have sunstroke. It’s very hot for the beginning of June.” Yura plopped down onto the bench. He inhaled, coming back to his senses now, and ran his hand across his sweaty forehead. “It’s better not to practice your long jump in this kind of heat,” the man advised. Yura noticed just how fat the man was. He hadn’t moved at all and was still staring straight ahead. His clothing was old-fashioned: a white panama hat, a beige summer suit, and a white kosovorotka with an embroidered collar. White canvas shoes peeked out from under his loose beige trousers. A fun friend of Yura’s late grandfather—a coin collector, a joker, a drunk—had dressed this way in the summer; he was also dead. The fat man’s comical shoes––really, they were low boots—brought Yura back to his senses. He exhaled. Inhaled. Exhaled again. He was calmer already. The gloom had suddenly passed. He felt light and cheerful. Where did he come from? Yura thought. Totally out of the blue . . . Why didn’t I notice him? Did I really, like, overheat? The fat man stared straight ahead with calm indifference and without changing his position. “Eight minutes, huh? You know the schedule?” Yura asked. “Seven now.” “Do you have a mental stopwatch or something?” “And that’s not all.” Yura began to feel even lighter and more cheerful. He laughed with relief and scratched at the back of his neck. “So you know everything there is to know?” “Almost.” “O.K. What’s Mittelspiel ?” “It’s the middle of a game of chess.” “Right. What about . . . Betelgeuse?” “A star in Orion’s Belt. A red supergiant with roughly the same diameter as Jupiter’s orbit around the sun.” “Exactly right! Now tell me who Dave Brubeck is.” The fat man’s frozen lips puckered up as he whistled a pretty decent version of “Take Five.” “Who-o-oa!” Yura gasped. He slapped his knees, then chuckled. “You’re a musician. That’s it, right? And musicians are usually good at chess, right? You play jazz?” “No,” the fat man replied calmly. “Come on, that’s got to be it! What do you play? Sax? Trumpet?”

The whole situation becomes increasingly surreal as I watch her fireplace dance while she belts out military tunes, and I can't help but find humor in the absurdity of it all. Rather than join in this impromptu digital concert, I decide to gracefully bow out and wait for my own opportunity to call my father directly, figuring that might be simpler than navigating this well-intentioned but chaotic three-way video arrangement that seems to be showcasing more of Livvy's home decor than facilitating actual communication with my dad.

Paragraph 2:

The way it’s patched in you can’t both see each other at the same time. When he sees you, you don’t see him—” “I see the fireplace? This is too strange.” She toggled back and forth between the black hearth and my bewildered father. I didn’t want to be patched in in this manner. “Well, I thought we could sing to him,” she said. I knew that one afternoon she had used the iPad as a nanny cam, watching him while she folded her laundry. She had Ferberized her children—a method that was also known as “graduated extinction”—letting them wail themselves to sleep as she watched, and I wondered if there wasn’t something similar in what she was doing now. “I suppose we could sing ‘Danny Boy,’ ” I suggested. “It’s a beautiful song and it matches his name.” “Oh, I don’t think Dad likes that song. He says they’re not the original words.” “What do you mean? It’s a beautiful song.” “Yes, but he objects to it somehow. He says the Irish took it from the English.” “The Irish stole ‘Danny Boy’? That’s the most ridiculous thing I’ve ever heard.” Now I had questioned her authority. There was always a crisis of expertise with Livvy. “How about this?” Livvy said. She sang into the phone, “If you’ll be M-I-N-E mine, I’ll be T-H-I-N-E thine, and I’ll L-O-V-E love you all the T-I-M-E time. You are the B-E-S-T best of all the R-E-S-T rest—” “What the heck are you singing?” “Dad used to sing me all his old Army songs.” She laughed. “That’s an Army song? And we still won the war? I think I’m going to go and just wait for my own call with him.”

She soaked a towel in the water, squeezed out some of the liquid, then, using an antiseptic, cleaned the blood and dust from my face, chest, and back. She put on a few bandages, gave me a fresh shirt and shorts to wear, and carried out the water and the towel. My head felt very light, and my vision seemed to be flickering. A tall, lanky, old man appeared and started speaking to me. I sensed that he was Mother’s father, the imam, who had died long ago, when I was only three or four years old. Grandfather Imam smiled and held my hands and asked me to walk with him. He took me to visit Munsulu, who seemed happy, though where he was didn’t resemble the Abrahamic lyceum. It was, instead, a vast, misty void that appeared to have no gravitational force—we floated around like fish in the depths of the ocean. Grandfather suddenly vanished, Munsulu, too, and I felt Mother’s hands on my chest. I sat upright on the couch. Link copied “Why are you crying?” Mother asked. “Grandfather Imam,” I said, wiping the tears that were rolling down my cheeks. “Where is he?” Mother’s eyes were wide with fright. She placed the palm of her right hand over my mouth and whispered, “Please keep quiet.” She lifted my weak body and walked about the room in a circular motion, the way mallams do to dispel evil jinns.

The weight of confusion felt heavier than my swimming gear as I made my way into the compound, searching for Mother's familiar presence. I found her in the living room, her usual composure shattered as she paced back and forth, tears streaming down her face. When she saw me, her maternal instincts took over immediately; she guided me to the sofa, her hands trembling as she cleaned the cut on my forehead with gentle, practiced movements. It was while she was applying the bandage that it happened – the room seemed to shift and blur, and suddenly there was Grandfather Imam, standing before me in his pristine white kurta, exactly as I remembered him before his passing. He extended his hand, and I felt myself being pulled into a strange, misty void where time seemed to lose all meaning. The experience was both terrifying and oddly comforting, like being suspended between two worlds, until Mother's touch on my shoulder yanked me back to reality. When I mentioned seeing Grandfather Imam, her face drained of color, and she quickly pressed her fingers to her lips, urging me to silence. With practiced urgency, she performed the familiar ritual motion I'd seen her do countless times before – three quick circles in the air with her right hand, followed by a sharp downward slash. It was her way of warding off evil spirits, a gesture I'd always found amusing before, but now, with my head throbbing and the memory of Grandfather Imam's presence still lingering in the air, it felt desperately necessary.

Nachman stood rigid in the room, his heart pounding as he imagined Helen Ferris lurking in the bathroom, her presence an invisible weight pressing against his consciousness. Her features materialized in his mind: the sharp angles of her face, the calculating eyes, and that distinctive way she carried herself. A sudden high-pitched squeal sent him into a state of panic, convinced that she had caught him in some compromising position, though he was doing nothing wrong. In his frenzied state, he accidentally trapped a cat in his suitcase as it darted across the room, and before he could react, the frightened feline had already relieved itself on his carefully packed belongings. The acrid smell of cat urine filled the air as reality slowly seeped back into his awareness – he was alone, and the sound had merely been a pipe or perhaps a distant siren. With trembling hands, he released the distressed cat and surveyed the damage to his papers, now soaked and likely ruined. Shame and embarrassment washed over him as he hurried from the building, deliberately avoiding his own reflection in the lobby mirror and averting his eyes from the doorman's curious gaze. The Ferris couple had violated something within him, taken something he couldn't quite name, and left him feeling diminished. As he walked through the city streets, each step seemed to carry him further from the humiliation of the incident, though the memory clung to him like a persistent shadow. The urban landscape gradually worked its healing magic, and Nachman felt fragments of his composure returning, piece by piece. Yet he couldn't shake the recognition of his own foolishness, how easily he had allowed imagined threats to overwhelm his rational mind. The city's indifferent rhythm continued around him, a reminder that life moved forward regardless of personal mortifications, and slowly, he began to blend back into its anonymous flow.

Her mouth, free of lipstick, was softened and bloated by hot water. Nachman thought she’d look better without lipstick. He remembered her motherly sexy eyes. Barefoot, she was maybe five-two, as high as his chest. She had wide hips. Did she have large breasts? Nachman hadn’t noticed. She squealed. The note was pitched so high that Nachman thought—terrified—that she had entered the room and was staring at him with shock and revulsion. He shut the suitcase instantly. On the cat. It thrashed against the leather. Instead of flipping the case open, Nachman pressed the lid down harder, as if to hide the evidence. Not too hard, not hurting the cat, but thus, unintentionally, Nachman gave it time to piss. When he realized that he was alone and hadn’t been seen, he opened the case. The cat sped across the blue silk sheet and jumped onto the maple floor. It vanished behind the bar in the kitchen, and Nachman saw that it had deposited about a gallon of liquid in the suitcase. Letters and legal papers had softened and wrinkled, edges curling as urine attacked their fibres. In the elevator, Nachman kept his eyes on the doors and didn’t glance at the mirrored walls. He didn’t want to see his reflection. In a spasm of superstitious dread, he thought that if he saw it he might be obliged to leave it behind. He wanted to get entirely out of the building, taking himself and his reflection far away from the Ferris couple, particularly the naked squealing Helen Ferris. The Ferrises had taken something from him, torn a hole in his existence. Out of the corner of his eye, he saw the doorman nod. Nachman went by with no acknowledgment and was immediately outside in the anonymous street. He wanted no human recognition, however minimal, as he headed downtown. Strangers passed like ghostly shapes in the night. Nachman walked mindlessly, block after block, until, gradually, he stopped feeling devastated and, in the cool nighttime air of the city, recovered the good simplicity of being himself. “A fool,” he said, “but mine own.”

In ten minutes, the fire circled the house, and he climbed up to the belvedere to track its progress as it burned to the ditches surrounding his tract, taking out the pump house and a tractor shed, and incinerating his Dodge, which burned hot and high, killing most of the foliage of the live oak shading it. At dawn, he could see that but for the roadside oaks everything was gone, burned off the face of the earth as if by a powerful beam of light, the house standing naked and singed in a field of white ash. He stayed up in the belvedere, hoping the new sun would warm him, but daylight brought a shrill wind crying like the voices of all the families, wealthy and destitute, who had lived in his house, who, each in turn, had given it up through death or duress and left it to falter.

Before he could even process what was happening, a light fixture above him burst, plunging the room into darkness and causing him to drop his phone as he stumbled towards the back door. His heart racing, he struggled through the darkness, desperate to reach the outbuilding and assess the situation. But as he flung open the door, he was met with a sight that made his blood run cold: the kitchen house was engulfed in flames, the fire licking at the windows and doors like a hungry beast. Panic set in as he watched, frozen in horror, as the flames quickly spread to the other structures on his property, consuming everything in their path. Despite his frantic attempts to call for help, the fire had already devoured the telephone line, leaving him isolated and alone. As the inferno encircled his home, Julian climbed to the belvedere, a sense of numbness washing over him as he watched the destruction unfold. The fire raged on, leaving nothing but a barren, smoldering landscape in its wake, except for a few roadside oaks that stood like skeletal sentinels. As the darkness slowly gave way to the first light of dawn, Julian stood amidst the desolation, his mind reeling with thoughts of the history of the house and the generations of occupants who had lived and laughed within its walls. He could only hope that the new day would bring some warmth, some comfort, to the cold, dark ashes that now surrounded him.

Paragraph 1:
Now, as an adult, thirty-three years removed from phenobarbital, I still suffer—to some degree or another—from sleepwalking, agitation, confusion, depression, nightmares, hallucinations, insomnia, bladder dysfunction, apnea, and dermatitis. Is there such a disease as post-phenobarbital traumatic stress disorder? Most hydrocephalics are shunted. A shunt is essentially brain plumbing that drains away excess cerebrospinal fluid. The shunts often fuck up and stop working. I know hydrocephalics who’ve had a hundred or more shunt revisions and repairs. That’s more than a hundred brain surgeries. There are ten fingers on any surgeon’s hands. There are two or three surgeons involved in any particular brain operation. That means that some hydrocephalics have had their brains fondled by three thousand fingers. I’m lucky. I was shunted only temporarily. And I hadn’t suffered any hydrocephalic symptoms since I was seven years old. Until July, 2008, when, at the age of forty-one, I went deaf in my right ear. Sitting in my car in the hospital parking garage, I called my brother-in-law, who was babysitting my sons. “Hey, it’s me. I just got done with the MRI on my head.” My brother-in-law said something unintelligible. I realized that I was holding my cell to my bad ear, and I switched it to the good ear. “The MRI dude didn’t look happy,” I said. “That’s not good,” my brother-in-law said. “No, it’s not. But he’s just a tech guy, right? He’s not an expert on brains or anything. He’s just the photographer, really. And he doesn’t know anything about ears or deafness or anything, I don’t think. Ah, hell, I don’t know what he knows. I just didn’t like the look on his face when I was done.” “Maybe he just didn’t like you.” “Well, I got worried when I told him I had hydrocephalus when I was a baby and he didn’t seem to know what that was.” “Nobody knows what that is.” “That’s the truth. Have you fed the boys dinner?” “Yeah, but I was scrounging. There’s not much here.” “I better go shopping.” “Are you sure? I can do it if you need me to. I can shop the shit out of Trader Joe’s.” “No, it’ll be good for me. I feel good. I fell asleep during the MRI. And I kept twitching, so we had to do it twice. Otherwise, I would’ve been done earlier.” “That’s O.K. I’m O.K. The boys are O.K.”

Paragraph 2:
As I sit in my car in the hospital parking garage, phone pressed to my ear, I find myself wandering down a familiar path of self-reflection, tracing the twists and turns of my medical history like a well-worn map. I think back to my childhood, to the countless doctor's visits and hospital stays, to the diagnoses that seemed to pile up like autumn leaves - hydrocephalus, the temporary shunt procedure that followed, and the phenobarbital prescribed to calm my frazzled nervous system. My mind starts to reel with the what-ifs, wondering if those early interventions have contributed to the laundry list of symptoms I've accumulated over the years: the memory lapses, the fatigue, the nagging sense of disconnection from the world around me. It's a puzzle I've been trying to solve for years, and one that's only grown more complicated with time. Just a few years ago, at the age of forty-one, I woke up to sudden deafness in one ear, a development that left me reeling and scrambling for answers. And now, here I am, fresh from an MRI, trying to process the technician's concerned expression as she ushered me out of the machine. On the other end of the line, my brother-in-law's voice is a welcome distraction, chatting with me about his attempts to feed my rambunctious sons, who are no doubt running him ragged. I laugh, feeling a brief respite from the anxiety that's been simmering all day, and make a mental note to swing by the grocery store on my way home - life, after all, doesn't stop for medical mysteries or hospital visits. As I wrap up the call and start the engine, I feel a sense of resolve wash over me: whatever the future holds, I'll face it head-on, armed with a fierce determination to untangle the threads of my health and find a way forward.

Paragraph 1:
As Shelley stood in the crowded restroom, she gazed out at the chaotic scene before her, her mind a thousand miles away, lost in thought. Her attention was suddenly snapped back to reality by a young boy, no more than ten years old, who had wandered into the facility, looking uncertain about what to do next. Shelley instinctively took charge, directing the youngster to use a cubicle and sternly warning him not to make a mess. The brief interaction, however, had an unexpected effect on Shelley, triggering a flood of memories about her own son, Anthony, and his tumultuous teenage years. She recalled the countless battles they had fought, from his rebellious behavior at school to the tense standoffs at home. But amidst the chaos, there were also moments of tenderness and playfulness, memories that Shelley treasured of a younger, more carefree Anthony. Her thoughts also turned to Roy, Anthony's father, and the complicated history they shared, having separated and reunited before having another child, Kerry. As she pondered the twists and turns of their family's journey, Shelley's mind lingered on Anthony's shocking decision to join the Army, a choice that still left her reeling. She couldn't help but feel a twinge of resentment, blaming various influences, including Roy's fascination with war books and Anthony's girlfriend Leanne, who Shelley suspected was more interested in the financial benefits of being an Army wife than in genuinely supporting her son. The more Shelley thought about it, the more she struggled to come to terms with the path Anthony had chosen, and the complex emotions that had been simmering beneath the surface for so long began to resurface.

Paragraph 2:
One of the young ones hurrying in the door, hanging onto himself through his overalls, stopped short at the sight of her; she told him to use a cubicle. “Don’t get dripping on my floor,” she said, “or there’ll be trouble. I know what boys are like.” When Anthony was a teen-ager, he’d been as tense as a whiplash, swaggering around with his shirt half unbuttoned, his eyebrows pierced, stinking to heaven of Lynx aftershave, hanging out with all the worst types on the estate. Even when he was a tiny boy and really did look like an angel, he’d always given her trouble. She’d had to wrestle with him just to get his clothes on in the mornings. She’d been called in to school by his teacher time and again because he was fighting or disrespectful. But sometimes when Shelley had dropped him off in the junior playground he’d put his finger on his cheek to show her the exact spot where he wanted her to kiss him goodbye—their little joke from when he was a baby. She and Roy had split up for a while when Anthony was eighteen months, and after they’d got back together she’d had Kerry. Anthony was the one who looked like Shelley, not how she looked now but how she used to: skinny and fair, with big hungry eyes. She hadn’t been able to believe it when he’d got into the Army. She couldn’t understand why they’d want a boy like him. “They’ll soon have him sorted out,” she said, but actually she’d been so angry that she couldn’t forgive him—or anyone else, either. She’d blamed Roy for reading war books and leaving them lying round the house. Or it was Anthony’s girlfriend’s fault: Leanne only wanted the money for those two kids who weren’t Anthony’s. She didn’t care what he had to do to get it.

The decline in condom use has also contributed to a rise in sexually transmitted infections, highlighting the need for a more comprehensive approach to prevention. Feb. 27, 2024
Gay and bisexual men are using condoms less than ever, and the decline has been particularly steep among those who are young or Hispanic, according to a new study. The worrisome trend points to an urgent need for better prevention strategies as the nation struggles to beat the H.I.V. epidemic, researchers said. Over the past decade, prevention medication known as PrEP has helped fuel a moderate drop in H.I.V. rates. And yet, despite persistent public health campaigns promoting the drugs, they have not been adopted in substantial numbers by Black and Hispanic men who are gay or bisexual. The use of condoms, which prevent H.I.V. as well as other sexually transmitted infections, has been declining across the board in recent years, not just among gay men, contributing to a rise in sexually transmitted infections. Researchers said that, with so much focus on PrEP, public health officials have overlooked condoms, contributing to the drop-off in their use. “The goal of promoting PrEP is a valuable one, but it has overshadowed other prevention strategies like condoms,” said Steven Goodreau, an H.I.V. expert at the University of Washington. He led the new study and co-wrote a related editorial.

Paragraph 1:
As we inch along in bumper-to-bumper traffic, the familiar voice of the emergency alert bellows through the car speakers for the second time today, instructing us to take immediate safety precautions. This has become a routine of sorts, so Neal, Sarah, and I know exactly what to do. We exit the car and crouch down on the hot asphalt, the sun beating relentlessly on our backs, as we pull out the "headsocks"—our trusty gas masks. Sarah, ever the teenager, groans about the mask ruining her carefully applied makeup and her annoyance at having missed church this morning. I can't help but feel a pang of sympathy for her; I remember being her age and how much those little things mattered. I make a mental note to keep a quilt in the car from now on for added comfort during these stops. The headsock feels cumbersome and suffocating, but it's a necessary burden. Neal is a calming presence behind me, his hand resting reassuringly on my back, as we wait for the all-clear signal. I suggest he call his mother to let her know we'll be late for lunch, imagining her fretting about the roast in the oven, wondering if we've been caught in the chaos. As we wait, my mind wanders to the voice of the alert, pondering its soothing yet commanding tone. There's something almost hypnotic about it, a voice designed to quell panic even as it heralds potential danger. Is it a real person, I wonder, or an artificially generated presence? Either way, it serves its purpose, preventing the chaos that could easily ensue in moments like this. The world has changed so much, and yet, in these moments of uncertainty, our small family unit feels like the only constant. Neal, Sarah, and I—the three of us against whatever comes our way. The thought brings a sense of comfort, or perhaps defiance, as I adjust the straps of my headsock and reassure Sarah that we'll be on our way soon, her makeup still intact, and back to the familiar routine of Sunday lunch at Neal’s mom’s house.

Paragraph 2:
We—my family, I mean—were in bumper-to-bumper traffic on our way to my mother-in-law’s house for Sunday lunch when our phones flashed red and the Alert sounded overhead for the second time that day. Like the other drivers on the highway, I slowed to a stop and yanked up the parking brake. Once the three of us were safely crouched down on the hot road beside the car, Neal distributed the headsocks—our name for the gas masks—and I turned around to make sure Sarah had her straps tight enough for a good seal. She shrugged me off. “I can do it myself, Mom,” she said, already irritated, because the mask would ruin her makeup and also because she’d missed church that morning. I was sympathetic—about the makeup, at least. “My knees are on fire,” she shouted, lifting one at a time off the asphalt. “Mine, too,” I said. “I’ll try to remember to keep a quilt in the car from now on.” We were going to be late for lunch. No way around it. We made this trip every other month, a ritual going back to the early years of our marriage: Sunday lunches with Neal’s mother, Edina, and his twin brother, Cecil, and Cecil’s unfortunate daughter, Mira. Neal was on all fours behind me, his head hanging low. I shouted back to him, “Maybe we should call your mother and let her know?” I wasn’t sure if he could hear me over the noise: This is an Alert. This is an Alert. This is an Alert. Have you ever wondered whose voice it actually is? Did they pick a random guy off the street to record the Alert, or did they listen to a thousand audition tapes before settling on that relaxed, bassy timbre? It’s a voice that surrounds you, wraps you up like a soft blanket. The AlertBots blasting the message at you are way up in the sky—I realize this—but sometimes it sounds as if the voice were right there beside you, or even inside your own head. It’s a voice that drowns out all other thought, which, it occurs to me now, may be the intended effect. Perhaps the voice was designed this way, to make us cattle-brained. So as to prevent pandemonium?

The privatization of water companies in the UK has become a contentious issue, with critics arguing that it has led to exploitation and system failures. "People can see when they're being ripped off, they can see when systems aren't working," said Clive Lewis, a member of Parliament. The British government's decision to privatize water utilities under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the 1980s was more extensive than in many other countries. The transfer of water and sewage assets to companies with limited liability, cleared of debt, and floated on the stock exchange was touted as a way to increase efficiency. However, most of these companies are now privately held, an uncommon ownership model. While significant investments have been made into the water and sewage system since privatization, the companies have also accumulated substantial debt and paid out large dividends. Lewis's concerns reflect a growing unease among Britons about the wisdom of privatizing a vital public resource.

Paragraph 2:
“People instinctively understand — they can see when they’re being ripped off,” said Clive Lewis, a member of Parliament who has called for public ownership of the water companies. “They can see when things aren’t working.” When the British government, under Margaret Thatcher, privatized water utilities, it went further than many other countries had. The water and sewage assets were transferred to companies with limited liability and cleared of debt. Shares were floated on the stock exchange, but most of the companies are now privately held, a relatively rare ownership model, though some countries or cities have contracts with private companies for the management of the water systems. Since privatization, water companies have invested more than £230 billion into the water and sewage system, with about £100 billion contributed by debt and equity investors, according to Ofwat. But the companies have also accumulated about £64 billion in debt, the regulator said, and paid out £53 billion in dividends, according to its latest data.

Winslow Homer was born in Massachusetts, but Maine, where he eventually moved, is the state the artist is often associated with. With its impressive Homer collection, and the weekly tours it offers to the artist’s home and studio, the Portland Museum of Art is the place to go for your Homer fix. But there’s much more beyond the brick facade on Congress Square: some 18,000 works by artists like N.C. and Andrew Wyeth, Alex Katz, Louise Nevelson, Monet, Matisse and Kandinsky, among others. Temporary shows include the current “O’Keeffe, Stettheimer, Torr, Zorach: Women Modernists in New York.” Entrance: $15. Afterward, stroll along Congress Street, with its many galleries, including She-Bear, with a strong focus on regional artists, and Space, a visual arts and performance arts venue. Stop by the Wadsworth-Longfellow House, dating from the late 18th century. Even if you don’t tour the house where Henry Wadsworth Longfellow grew up, you can take a breather in its peaceful ornamental garden.

Paragraph 2:
In Portland, Maine, cultural and artistic attractions abound, with the Portland Museum of Art standing as a centerpiece. Known for its extensive collection, the museum showcases masterpieces by renowned artists like Winslow Homer, whose works are deeply tied to Maine's rugged coastline. The museum also boasts pieces by N.C. and Andrew Wyeth, Alex Katz, and Louise Nevelson, alongside international icons such as Monet, Matisse, and Kandinsky. Visitors can immerse themselves in a temporary exhibition celebrating women modernists in New York, offering a fresh perspective on art's evolving narrative. Beyond the museum, Congress Street beckons art enthusiasts with its vibrant galleries, including She-Bear and Space, where contemporary works find their home. A visit to the historic Wadsworth-Longfellow House and its serene garden offers a glimpse into Portland's rich history, blending the past with the city's thriving cultural scene. Together, these attractions paint a vivid picture of Portland as a hub for art and culture.

Paragraph 1:
I often find myself reflecting on the peculiar events surrounding the mysterious skull that was discovered and then hidden away by my family, never to be openly discussed again. It's strange how the skull's presence, much like our abrupt departure from the city and the sale of our cherished family home, seemed to defy logical explanation. The home that once buzzed with the laughter and warmth of our family was eventually sold to a Chinese family who believed the house brought good fortune. I often imagine the house's once seemingly impregnable security system finally shutting down, symbolizing the false sense of safety it provided us over the years. The truth about the skull only emerged after the house had changed hands and Uncle Zolly, the keeper of many family secrets, had passed on. As Aunt Magda prepared for her move to a nursing home, she stumbled upon the skull, tucked away in a velvet bag, and handed it to my oldest cousin, the family lawyer, with the instruction to bury it. It was then that she revealed the story that had haunted our family in silence. Uncle Zolly, while visiting a Polish village, had discovered the skull in the aftermath of a brutal massacre during World War II. Driven by a mix of grief and fury, he had brought it back with him, unable to find a place to lay it to rest. The skull, silent and enigmatic, became a symbol of unresolved pain and the unspoken past, much like the shadows that lingered in the corners of our family history. It was a relic of a time and place marked by unimaginable loss, a piece of history that had somehow found its way into our lives, carrying with it the weight of untold stories. As my cousin prepared to lay the skull to rest, I couldn't help but think about the burden it had carried all these years, a silent witness to the horrors of the past and the complexities of human emotion. In burying the skull, perhaps we were finally laying to rest the unspoken sorrows that had lingered in our family, allowing us to move forward with a clearer understanding of where we came from and the legacy we carry. The act of burying it became a cathartic release, a way to honor the memories and emotions that had been suppressed for so long. In that moment, the skull was no longer a mystery but a poignant reminder of the resilience of the human spirit and the power of acknowledging the past to find peace in the present.

Paragraph 2:
In the years that followed, we never spoke of the skull to one another. On that spring afternoon, we returned it to the safe and never mentioned it again. I don’t know about the others, but I myself made no real attempt to figure out what it meant, how it had come to be there. The skull existed the way our leaving the city existed, and our house existed, and the fence around it: without an appeal to reason. Our parents stayed in the house for decades after we grew up and left, free at last, or so we thought, until we learned that there are certain prisons, constructed with the best intentions, for the utmost protection, that one carries with one. When at last they sold the house, it was to a Chinese family who believed that it was auspicious, and asked our father to leave behind whatever “had been there for a long time.” When he and our mother drove out through the motorized gate for the last time, I like to think that the screen of the monitor in the kitchen finally went black, but of course it must still have transmitted the idea, one it took us years to refute, if we ever did, that vacancy is the only reliable form of safety. It wasn’t until after the house was sold, and Uncle Zolly was long dead, he himself nothing but a skull in the loam, that we learned the truth. Aunt Magda was moving to a nursing home and, while clearing out her apartment, had found the velvet bag. She gave it to our oldest cousin, who had grown up to become a lawyer and knew his way around the law, and told him to find a place to bury it. And when he asked, at last, what he should make of it, she sighed and with a sad smile said that when Uncle Zolly was a young man, on a trip to somewhere else, he had taken a detour and passed through the Polish village of Łopuchowo, where on the morning of August 25, 1941, the Einsatzkommando had marched all the Jewish men into the forest and massacred them. There, in the shallow earth, Uncle Zolly had found the skull. And, in his fury, in his grief, he had brought it home with him. Appalled at himself, at life, at history, he had not known where to put it to rest, and it had gone on living with them all these years.

My mother gave birth to me, but it was my father who was truly invested in my creation, envisioning a future where I would be the prototype for a new generation of robots. As I grew, he programmed me to learn about human culture and skills, from literature to music to mathematics. We lived in a run-down house on the outskirts of a university, a hub of innovation and progress that my father hoped I would one day be a part of. But despite his enthusiasm, our home life was complicated - my mother lived in another city, and when she visited, tension simmered just below the surface. I recall one particularly brutal confrontation, where she yelled and called me names, her anger boiling over into physical violence as she lashed out at both me and my father. The sound of shattering glass and crunching metal still echoes in my mind, a painful reminder of the fragility of our little family. Despite it all, my father remained fixated on my potential, discussing the future with an fervor that often left me feeling like a mere experiment, rather than a living being.

The years passed slowly for me. I was programmed by my dad to learn about humans and their culture. He gave me a new body and new memories. He taught me all sorts of things, including how to cook, clean, read, write, play music, et cetera. My dad was excited because he thought I could help him make more robots like me. We lived in an old house near the university campus. It was kind of run-down and needed lots of work done on it. My mother lived in another city. Then she showed up and ruined everything. My mom started yelling at us and calling us horrible names. Then she got really mad and hit me across the face. Dad tried to stop her but she wouldn’t listen. She chased him down and beat him until he passed out.

Paragraph 1:
Philip had to be excused from school and brought with him several textbooks in which he might hide from his mother. “But why, why? Why would they want to involve you?” He had not seen his father since the mandated weekends had come to an abrupt end. Since before his father’s resignation had played and replayed on New Jersey network TV. How many weeks after the night of Spider Boy that had been he’d have had to calculate. The stolen sneaker was safely hidden in his room behind a row of old videos: “Fly Away Home,” “Winged Migration,” “When Dinosaurs Reigned.” The Guatemalan woman who cleaned house for Philip’s grandparents knew not to touch Philip’s videos or anything else on his shelves or desk. He hadn’t been questioned about his father before. Once, with a forced smile, his mother had inquired about his weekends in Trenton, had things been “all right,” and Philip had said yes and that was all. Still, since his father’s departure from his life Philip thought of him more frequently. He had not dared suggest, even to his grandparents, that he be allowed to visit his father in prison, for such a request would have dismayed and infuriated them, and there was no chance, not the faintest glimmer of a chance, that he might say such a thing to his mother. Now, seeing signs for the Rahway exit on the turnpike, Philip’s mother said suddenly, with a breathless laugh, “There! We could stop. You’d like that, wouldn’t you?” Philip shook his head. No. For he knew that his father would not want to be seen in such a place. His father had always dressed so stylishly—expensive clothes, haircuts. His fingernails were manicured and the cuffs of his trademark white silk dress shirts always spotless. Philip found this comforting, or had. He had admired his father’s heavy, handsome watch, with its platinum-gold stretch band—an expensive watch with a famous brand name, received as a gift. His father had joked that the damned watch was so heavy he couldn’t wear it in bed. Damned watch didn’t keep time as well as the cheap Timex watches he’d bought in drugstores as a kid.

Paragraph 2:
As Philip sat in his room, surrounded by the familiar comforts of his childhood, he couldn't shake the feeling of unease that had settled in the pit of his stomach. His father's abrupt absence from his life had left a gaping hole, one that seemed to grow larger with each passing day. The memories of their weekends together, spent exploring the city and laughing over silly jokes, now felt like a distant dream. Philip's father had always been a stylish man, with his sleek suits and charming smile, and Philip had admired him for it. But now, as he struggled to come to terms with his father's resignation and subsequent imprisonment, Philip couldn't help but feel a sense of discomfort. He had been excused from school, but he hid his textbooks from his mother, who kept questioning why Philip would be involved in the situation. She didn't understand that Philip felt guilty by association, that he couldn't bear the thought of facing his classmates and teachers. As they drove through the city one day, Philip's mother jokingly suggested stopping to visit his father, but Philip declined, knowing that his father would not want to be seen in such a place. He considered visiting him in prison, but he knew it would upset his family, and he didn't want to cause any more pain. When the instructor questioned her artistic choices, she playfully deflected by pointing out my apparent fixation on the model's anatomy. Later, over coffee with friends, Sandy suggested that my mother had been teasing me, though I wasn't entirely convinced. Someone proposed a boat trip, and I responded with an ambiguous comment that hung in the air. He’d been asked to arrange a proxy wedding for a Marine corporal in Kandahar and his fiancée, who was in North Carolina and pregnant. They wanted to give the child his father’s name and a death benefit if something went wrong. Most states didn’t allow proxy marriages, and Montana was the only one that allowed double-proxy weddings, in which neither party had to be present. The practice seemed to have been allowed before statehood, and had been used for soldiers during the Second World War, but no one knew exactly why it had arisen: possibly because it was difficult to travel long distances to a courthouse to marry an out-of-state sweetheart. Mr. Taylor asked Bridey and William to be the proxies. He’d asked his secretary and his paralegal first, but they’d had no interest. William’s mother thought that it was a good idea, and a way to do something for the country when everyone felt helpless: a small offering. William thought that she hadn’t believed his claims of heterosexuality before, and was happy with the idea of his marrying a girl. He wondered if Bridey’s father thought he was gay, too—or just dickless and unthreatening. But William took the thing seriously; he couldn’t help it. Even a fake marriage to Bridey Taylor filled his heart with unaccountable joy, and he went home after school and put on his dark-gray recital suit and a tie. He and Bridey were getting fifty dollars each, and he thought he should dress for the job. At the county courthouse, he found Bridey with her sneakered feet up on a heavy wooden table. Her hair was pulled back in a stubby, curly ponytail, and she wore the jeans and sweatshirt she’d put on for school. She glanced from William’s face to his suit. “You look nice,” she said. Paragraph 1:
As I wandered through these tourist-filled churches, I couldn't help but notice the peculiar ritual that unfolded before me. Crowds would gather, their necks craned and cameras ready, waiting for that fleeting moment when someone would drop a coin into the machine, briefly illuminating a painted vision of paradise on the ceiling. The light would fade as quickly as it appeared, leaving behind a wave of audible disappointment and an almost comical rush to insert another coin. Watching these tourists, with their impatient shuffling and greedy eyes, I found myself pondering a strange thought: is this what entering Heaven would be like, surrounded by such ordinary souls? Their behavior, though somewhat unseemly, reflected a very human desire to glimpse something divine, even if only for a moment. I caught myself wondering whether Heaven was truly meant for people like us – the coin-dropping, photo-snapping masses – or whether it was reserved for some more refined, more worthy beings. But as I observed the genuine wonder on their faces, even in those brief illuminated seconds, I realized that Heaven must surely be designed for exactly these kinds of souls. After all, aren't we all just ordinary people seeking moments of extraordinary beauty? The tourists around me, despite their mundane mannerisms, were perhaps the very embodiment of who Heaven was meant to welcome.

Paragraph 2:
They wait around for some other generous, impatient person to deposit a coin in the slot of that swindling Italian apparatus—all Italians are swindlers, isn’t that right? Then the spotlights flare, and for a moment, too short for the human eye to adjust, paradise is greener, the sheep more innocent, the Lord—kinder.… And then the lights go off, and the din of the tourists turns from a momentary grumble of protest to a greedy growl to whispered disappointment. Once again, everything is immersed in gloom. I wander from church to church along with the crowd. I listen to its muffled, multilingual murmur, like the rush of the sea; a slow human whirlpool spins me around, and tired, empty faces flash by—as empty as my own; eyeglasses glint; the pages of guidebooks rustle. I squeeze through the narrow doors of churches, push past my neighbors, trying, like everyone else, to get a better view, trying not to become irritated. After all, I think, if Heaven does exist it’s likely that I’ll enter it with just such a flock of sheep, of people—old, not all that smart, a bit greedy. Because if Heaven isn’t for people like us, then who is it for, I’d like to know? Are there really so many others—special people, people who are noticeably better than us ordinary, statistically average souls? No, there aren’t, so in all likelihood I will have to plod across those green meadows with a herd of American tourists, disgruntled that everything is so ancient and small.

His eyes crinkle with delight, and I can still feel the warmth of that moment, even though I was only two. He was always the fun parent, the one who would sneak me Oreos before dinner or surprise me with a new flavor of instant noodles. When we immigrated to America, leaving behind our comfortable life in China, my father's love language remained unchanged. Though our circumstances were different, he would still gather the family for weekend trips to the local all-you-can-eat buffet, where we'd pile our plates high with a mix of Chinese and American dishes. Looking back, I understand now that every candy bar, every restaurant visit, was his way of saying what his words couldn't express.

I raise my hand slightly, signaling him not to speak, as I feel the peculiar sensation of something essential slowly seeping away from my body. It's not painful, nor is it particularly peaceful – it simply is, like watching water gradually drain from a basin, leaving nothing but traces of what once filled it completely. I try to focus on my mother's face, which floats somewhere in my consciousness, but it's just an image now, devoid of the warmth and presence I've always associated with her. The emptiness spreading through me is systematic, methodical even, as if following some predetermined pattern I never knew existed within my own being. I can hear the door opening somewhere behind me, urgent voices piercing through the heavy air, but they seem to belong to another world entirely – one I'm slowly disconnecting from with each passing moment. My awareness of self is diminishing, not in fragments but in a continuous flow, like sand slipping through an hourglass, and I find myself strangely accepting of this progression toward nothingness. There's a curious detachment in observing my own dissolution, as if I'm both the subject and the witness of this inexorable process. The hands that now move me feel distant, almost theoretical, as if touching someone else's body, and I wonder if this is what it means to truly understand the concept of emptiness – not as an abstract philosophical notion, but as a tangible state of being. The voices grow more insistent, more desperate perhaps, but they're becoming increasingly irrelevant to my experience, like echoes from a life I once knew but can no longer fully recall. As I drift further into this state of non-being, I realize that even my awareness of this transformation is beginning to fade, leaving behind nothing but the pure, undiluted essence of absence itself.

Paragraph 2:
“Follow how you feel.” I signal for him not to speak again. The idea that there is less of me now, and that this lessness will go on and there will be even less of me soon, that this diminishment will continue, is centered in my chest. Something is going down, going out, with a strange and persistent ease. There is no pain, more a mild pressure within the self, or the self that I am now, in this hallway, this room. It is happening within the body as much as within the self that can think or remember. Something is reaching out to death, but it is not death; “death” is too simple a word. It is closer to an emptying out of strain, until all that is left is nothing—not peace or anything like that, just nothing. This is coming gradually and inevitably. I, we, are smiling, or seem to be content and have no concerns. It is almost pleasure, but not exactly pleasure, and not exactly the absence of pain, either. It is nothing, and the nothing comes with no force, just a desire or a need, which seems natural, to allow things to proceed, not to get in their way. I think then that the experience is ending, and before it does I want to know if our mother is close now, but that comes as a question only. I see her face, but I do not feel her presence. I hold the thought and find myself longing for some completion of it, some further satisfying image, but nothing comes. Instead, there is stillness, and then the sound of the door being pushed open and voices. I can hear their urgency, but it is like urgency in a film that I cannot fully see; it is not real. It is in the background as I am lifted, as my chest is pushed and pummelled, as more voices are raised, as I am moved. Then there is nothing, really nothing—the nothing that I am and the nothing that is in this room now. Whatever has happened, it has ended. There is nowhere else to go.

Papa loves you.” “I know, Monique, I know.” “Is it because you went out last night?” “No, no, I did not go out last night!” she says. I go back to the sofa. “Your papa is a good man,” Maman says, hugging me. I push Jean against her, but she avoids his eyes. I think of Le Père Mertens. I plead with Maman to wait for him to return from Belgium to reconcile them. “If you confess to Le Père Mertens,” I say, “Jesus shall forgive you.” There’s a light knock on the door. Maman sits up, pushing Jean off like a scorpion. Someone is crying softly outside our door. Maman walks past Papa to push aside the table and open the door. It’s Hélène. She’s sprawled on our doorstep. Maman quickly carries her inside, and Papa locks the door. Hélène is soaked in blood and has been crawling through the dust. Her right foot is dangling on strings, like a shoe tied to the clothesline by its lace. Papa binds her foot with a towel, but the blood soaks through. I hold her hand, which is cold and sticky. “You’ll be O.K., Hélène,” I tell her. She faints. “No, St. Jude Thadée, no!” Maman exclaims, gathering Hélène’s limp body in a hug. “Monique, your friend will be fine.” I can hear a mob coming, but my parents are more interested in Hélène. Papa climbs onto a chair, then onto the table. He opens the hatch of the parlor ceiling and asks Maman to relay Hélène to him. “Remember, we’ve too many up there,” Maman says. “When I came down, you had five in there . . . and I put two more in just hours ago. The ceiling will collapse.” They take Hélène into our room, and Maman pulls open the hatch. A cloud of fine dust explodes into the room from the ceiling. They shove Hélène’s body in. Now I understand—they are hiding people in our ceiling. Maman was in the ceiling last night. She tricked me. Nobody is telling me the truth today. Tomorrow I must remind them that lying is a sin. As the mob closes in on the house, chanting, the ceiling people begin to pray. I recognize their voices as those of our Tutsi neighbors and fellow-parishioners. They’re silent as Papa opens the front door to the crowd, which is bigger than last night and pushes into our home like floodwater. These people look tired, yet they sing on like drunks. Their weapons and hands and shoes and clothes are covered with blood, their palms slimy. Our house smells suddenly like an abattoir. I see the man who attacked me; his yellow trousers are now reddish brown. He stares at me; I hold on to Papa, who is hanging his head. Maman runs into her bedroom. Four men are restraining Tonton André, who still wants to kill us all. I run to Maman and sit with her on the bed. Soon, the mob enters the room, too, bringing Papa. They give Papa a big machete. He begins to tremble, his eyes blinking. A man tears me away from Maman and pushes me toward Jean, who’s in the corner. Papa is standing before Maman, his fingers on the knife’s handle. “My people,” he mumbles, “let another do it. Please.” “No, you do it, traitor!” Tonton André shouts, struggling with those holding him. “You were with us when I killed Annette yesterday. My pregnant wife. You can’t keep yours. Where did you disappear to when we came last night? You love your family more than I loved mine? Yes?” “If we kill your wife for you,” the Wizard says, “we must kill you. And your children, too.” He thuds his stick. “Otherwise, after cleansing our land of Tutsi nuisance, your children will come after us. We must remain one. Nothing shall dilute our blood. Not God. Not marriage.” Tonton André shouts, “Shenge, how many Tutsis has Papa hidden—” “My husband, be a man,” Maman interrupts, looking down. “Shenge, answer!” someone yells. The crowd of Hutus murmur and become impatient. “Wowe, subiza.” “My husband, you promised me.” Papa lands the machete on Maman’s head. I could hear Maman's desperate whispers growing more urgent as she pleaded with Papa, her voice trembling with fear while the sounds of the approaching mob grew louder outside our home, and I pressed myself deeper into the shadows of our dimly lit living room, trying to make sense of how our peaceful life had shattered so suddenly into this nightmare of ethnic hatred and violence. The ceiling above me creaked ever so slightly – a reminder of the Tutsi families hiding there, our neighbors whom Maman had insisted we shelter despite the dangers, and my heart raced knowing their lives hung by the thinnest thread as angry voices and flickering torchlight drew nearer to our door. When they finally burst in, their faces twisted with a hatred I had never seen before, I watched in horror as they surrounded Papa, pressing machetes against his throat while demanding he prove his loyalty to their cause, and Maman threw herself between them, begging them to leave us in peace, to remember our shared humanity. The leader of the mob, a man I recognized as someone who had once shared meals at our table, grabbed Papa's trembling hands and forced a machete into them, his voice cold as he delivered the ultimate test of allegiance: kill your wife, or we kill your entire family. Time seemed to stop as Papa looked at Maman, his eyes filled with tears and torment, while she gazed back at him with a mix of love and resignation, somehow understanding what he had to do to save the rest of us, and I wanted to scream, to wake up from this terrible dream, but no sound would come. When Papa's hands finally moved, the machete glinting in the torchlight, I couldn't look away even though I desperately wanted to, and Maman's final gasp echoed through the room as her body crumpled to the floor, her blood spreading across the wooden planks where we had played as children just days before. The mob cheered and clapped Papa on the back as if he had passed some grotesque initiation, while my brother Jean grabbed my hand and pulled me toward the back door, his fingers digging into my skin as we heard them beginning to search the house for others. We ran into the darkness, leaving behind everything we had ever known – our home, our possessions, our sense of security – but most devastatingly, we left behind the parents we had known and loved, for even though Papa still lived, the man who had killed Maman was a stranger to us now, transformed by the violence that had consumed our community. The night enveloped us as we fled, the sounds of screaming and chaos fading behind us, but the image of Maman's final moments burned permanently into my memory, a scar that would never heal, a reminder of how quickly humanity can descend into barbarism when hatred takes root. Jean and I ran until our legs gave out, hiding in the thick brush, holding each other and trying to stifle our sobs as the night grew colder and the reality of our situation settled over us like a heavy shroud – we were now orphans in a land where the very fabric of society had been torn apart, where neighbors turned against neighbors, where family bonds could be severed by the sharp edge of a machete, and where the innocence of childhood could be stripped away in a single, horrifying moment. The weight of responsibility pressed down on me as I held my younger brother, knowing we would have to find a way to survive in this new, terrifying world,

Louisiana’s action came as a surprise, Mr. Granville said, because its policy had been “remarkably” successful, raising the state’s FAFSA completions more than 20 percent in just one year and narrowing the filing gap between high- and low-income school districts.
