Paragraph 1:
The man awoke after a half hour of sleep and sat up in bed, orienting himself. In two months he would be sixty-eight. He got to his exercises, managing seventy-seven pushups but only thirty sit-ups before something told him to stop. As his sweat dried, he pruned the bonsai tree he kept in a special compartment in one of the bedroom windows. The compartment allowed the tree to be in the room and then, with just a turn of its wooden platform, to be outside. And with the press of a button a transparent covering emerged from the side of the compartment to cover the tree outside. The bonsai was a gift from his youngest daughter, who lived in the suburbs of Virginia, where trees with all the life of plastic had been put up to decorate the new developments. Someone had warned him that bonsai trees in people’s homes did not live very long, but his had gone on for more than six years and it had given him unimaginable pleasure. The tree was so small that he could cover it with both hands. A booklet that came with the tree said it had been “trained” for thirty-five years. He had waited the first two years for the tree to wither and die, but it went on and on. Now he believed that it could live forever. In the National Arboretum he and Maggie had seen bonsai trees that had been living—“trained”—for three hundred, four hundred, five hundred years. If them, why not his own? After washing up, he changed from his pajama top to a T-shirt. He peered long into the bathroom mirror, at his father’s and his grandfather’s face. His father had died at seventy-five and his grandfather had made it only to sixty-six. He turned his face this way and that to see if he wanted to shave right then. Last week Elsa had fallen in the playground and cried as if her world were falling apart. He decided to shave because his granddaughter liked smooth cheeks. He left the bathroom and stood just outside the children’s room and listened to them playing. Adam was pretending to be a dog for Elsa. “If you give me a biscuit, I’ll jump over here,” he said. He barked. If only he could be like that all the time. He found Maggie at the stove, singing. The coffee was waiting. He stood watching her. The newspaper was on the edge of the table. A man on the radio was telling him the news. The window was open and he could hear a man and a woman talking. “Why you always so cheerful with all this?” he asked, and fanned his hand to indicate all that was wrong, including Adam. She placed bacon on a plate covered with paper towels and put another towel over it. Then she danced over to him and did three slow twirls. “Because I have you,” she said and twirled back over to the stove. “Don’t you see, Noah, how easy it would be if you were married to you? Your days would be good. See me? Watch me. I’m standing on your shoulders.” She raised herself up on the tips of her toes and looked over as if from the edge of a mountain. She called down into the valley from the mountain, “Nooooaah, thank you.” She settled back on her feet, swaying her hips. “Two eggs or three?” She took an egg in each hand and danced over to him, with her hips still swaying. She kissed him. He put his arms around her and kissed her with such passion that one egg cracked in her hand and she had to place the other one on the newspaper before it, too, cracked. They did not move. She rested her cheek against his chest. He had got lost on his way to the woman’s place that first time. “I’ll have to give you a map for the next time,” she said. “Two eggs, then,” Maggie said. She leaned to the side and found the children watching them. “Hey,” Elsa said. Noah did not move. Adam was holding Elsa’s hand. “Hey yourself,” Maggie said. Elsa pointed to the egg Maggie had crushed against the back of Noah’s robe. “He’s pretty messy that way,” Maggie said to Elsa. Boys, her grandmother mouthed.

Paragraph 2:
Noah's weathered hands moved with practiced precision as he began his morning routine, the dawn light filtering through his bedroom window just as it had for countless mornings before. At nearly sixty-eight, he maintained a disciplined approach to his daily exercises, each stretch and movement a testament to his determination to stay active, followed by the meditative moments he spent tending to his cherished bonsai tree, a thoughtful gift from his youngest daughter that had flourished under his care for more than six years. The miniature tree had become more than just a plant; it represented hope, continuity, and the delicate balance between nurturing and letting nature take its course. After completing his morning ablutions, Noah found himself lingering before the bathroom mirror, his reflection prompting contemplation about his family's history – his father's passing at seventy-three and his grandfather's at sixty-nine casting subtle shadows over his thoughts about mortality. Despite these sobering reflections, he reached for his razor with purpose, knowing that his granddaughter Elsa would appreciate his smooth cheeks during their morning interaction. The familiar path to the kitchen brought him to Maggie, his wife of forty-two years, who was already immersed in her breakfast preparations, her movements accompanied by a soft humming that filled the space with warmth. Though life had presented its share of challenges, Maggie's optimistic spirit remained undiminished, her eyes twinkling with the same light that had first captured Noah's heart decades ago. She paused in her cooking to perform an impromptu dance, her spatula serving as an unlikely dance partner as she twirled toward Noah, expressing her gratitude for their shared life through both words and playful gestures. Their moment of morning intimacy was witnessed by their grandchildren, Elsa and Adam, who had paused their play to observe their grandparents' affectionate exchange. The scene unfolded like a well-worn photograph coming to life – Maggie's flour-dusted apron, Noah's freshly shaved face, the children's curious expressions, and the morning sun streaming through the kitchen windows, all combining to create a tableau of domestic tranquility that seemed to transcend the ordinary routines of daily life. The kitchen, with its familiar scents of coffee and toast, became a sanctuary where four generations of family history converged through stories, traditions, and the simple act of being present with one another. Noah's morning ritual, far from being merely a series of habitual actions, had evolved into a celebration of continuity and connection, each element – from the careful tending of his bonsai to the shared moments with Maggie and their grandchildren – weaving together to create a tapestry of familial bonds that grew stronger with each passing day. The presence of Elsa and Adam added a particular vibrancy to these morning moments, their youthful energy and innocent observations serving as a reminder of life's cyclical nature and the importance of passing down not just stories and traditions, but also the simple joy of being together. As Noah settled into his usual chair at the kitchen table, watching Maggie serve breakfast with her characteristic flourish while the grandchildren resumed their play nearby, he felt a profound sense of contentment, recognizing that these ordinary moments, strung together day after day, constituted the extraordinary gift of a life well-lived and deeply loved.

About twenty feet down the walkway, the group came to a halt and spat out from its amoeba-like body a woman dressed in normal street clothes, who now began to address the others. By standing on my tiptoes, I could just see over the women’s heads to the four-hundred-year-old Zen garden that was one of the most famous in all of Japan. A Zen garden, with its raked gravel and precise minimum of rocks, bushes, and trees, is meant not to be entered but to be contemplated from the outside, and just beyond where the group had stopped was the empty portico designed for this. But when I tried to make my way out by tapping shoulders and asking to be excused, the group seemed only to tighten around me. Whomever I tapped would turn to me with a bewildered look, and take a few quick little steps to the left or the right so that I could pass, but immediately another woman in a kimono would flow in to fill the void, either out of an innate instinct to correct the group’s balance or just to get closer to the tour guide. Enclosed on all sides, breathing in the dizzying stench of perfume, and listening to the guide’s relentlessly incomprehensible explanations, I began to feel claustrophobic. But before I could try to elbow my way out more violently, the women suddenly started to move again, and by flattening myself against the wall of the abbot’s residence I managed to stay put, forcing them to move around me. They crossed the wooden floor in a chorus of scuffling slippers.

I found myself inadvertently caught in the midst of a group of women elegantly clad in kimonos as they moved in unison down a dim, open-air corridor. The gentle rustle of silk accompanied their synchronized steps, and before I knew it, I was swept along with them, unable to distinguish where one person ended and another began. As the group came to a halt, a woman in street clothes emerged to address them, her voice echoing off the walls as she delivered what I assumed to be an explanation of the surroundings. I craned my neck, eager to catch a glimpse of the famous Zen garden rumored to be nearby, its tranquil beauty tantalizingly out of reach. My attempts to extricate myself from the throng were met with polite but impenetrable resistance; each time I tapped a shoulder and asked to be excused, another woman seamlessly filled the vacated space, as if part of an unyielding tide. A sense of claustrophobia crept over me, aggravated by the crowd's density, the overpowering scent of floral perfumes mingling in the air, and the steady stream of incomprehensible words from the tour guide. I felt as though I was suffocating under the weight of it all, desperate for a moment of solitude and fresh air. Just when I thought I might never escape, the group began to move once more, a collective shift that offered me a fleeting opportunity. Pressing myself against the cool stone of the corridor wall, I managed to stay put, letting the procession of vibrant kimonos sweep past me like a river around a rock. Relief washed over me as the last woman disappeared around a corner, leaving me alone at last, with the distant sound of their footsteps fading into silence. I took a deep breath, grateful for the reprieve, and turned my attention back to the promise of the Zen garden, its serene allure now within my grasp.

Greta stepped into the familiar embrace of the cozy café-bar nestled near her flat, a sanctuary of sorts amidst the bustle of the small shops and the converted chapel offering classes nearby. Seeking a respite from the monotony of her daily routine and the gentle yet persistent presence of her partner Graham, she let her daughter Kate's words echo in her mind, describing the place as a "hippie haven." The description fit perfectly as she took in the scene around her, a delightful mix of students, middle-aged men looking for a quiet corner, and young mothers finding brief moments of solace. The ambiance was relaxed, encouraging her to let go of the constraints of time and simply be. Initially, Greta approached the counter with the intention of ordering just a coffee, her usual guard against indulgence in place. However, a spontaneous decision led her to opt for a glass of Pinot Grigio, a small act of rebellion against her own tendencies towards caution. The sip of wine was like a key unlocking a door within her, flooding her with a sense of liberation and a tinge of exhilaration reminiscent of her younger days. As she settled into her seat with The Guardian spread out before her, she found herself reflecting on the trajectory of her life, feeling a resurgence of vitality coursing through her veins. Despite the comforting bubble of her personal rejuvenation, she remained acutely aware of the larger, more pressing issues unfolding in the world, as depicted in the articles she scanned. Yet, in that moment, Greta allowed herself to savor the contentment that came from this little escape, a temporary yet precious reprieve from the humdrum of everyday life. In that café-bar, with the gentle hum of conversation around her, she felt a rare alignment of her inner world with the outer, a balance that seemed both fragile and profoundly satisfying.

Paragraph 2:
The place Greta went for coffee was around the corner from the flat, in a row of independent restaurants and small shops selling home-baked bread and local pottery. A converted chapel offered Pilates and art classes, and Sefton Park was beyond that, at the end of the road. Greta bought a copy of The Guardian and found herself a corner by a warm radiator in the shabby red-and-yellow-painted café-bar. “It’s a hippie place, Mum,” Kate had said. “Just your kind of thing.” Students were working on laptops; a couple of men probably Greta’s age, with flaring drinkers’ faces, were on to pints already, at the bar. Young mothers had escaped from home to gossip with their friends, steering their bulky pushchairs in beside the tables. There was plenty of room—no one would mind if Greta took her time over her coffee. It was a relief to be away from Graham for a while, she thought, though the thought wasn’t drastic or hostile: she never wavered, these days, in her appreciation of his kindness. When she looked at her watch at quarter to two, she decided to buy herself a second cup of coffee; then, on impulse, at the bar she asked for a glass of Pinot Grigio instead, though that was risky in the middle of the day. She was wary of alcohol, in her weakened state. Although it was very ordinary wine—Graham would have refused to drink it—the cold green taste of each mouthful was heady and transforming, worth whatever it would cost her afterward. She began to feel liberated and exhilarated, just as she might have felt when she was twenty. It occurred to her—but very calmly, the way you might describe a limb getting over an attack of pins and needles—that she was coming back to life. And yet all her attention was focussed on what was in the newspaper, not on herself. She understood that her own experience was a tiny atom beside the cold, hard masses of history and politics, full of cruel truths.

Just as quarks were bound by forces that grew stronger with distance, he felt the paradoxical pull of his marriage to Joan – the further they drifted apart, the more intensely he felt connected to her through years of shared habits and memories. The phone rang, and he answered it knowing it would be Joan, as if their thoughts had synchronized across the city's expanse. "Do you remember," he began without preamble, "that morning in the Berkshires when we saw those deer in the clearing?" There was a pause on the line, filled with static that seemed to crackle with unspoken tensions. "Richard," Joan's voice carried a note of weariness he had grown familiar with, "I'm not sure that ever happened." Her words hit him like a physical blow, making him question yet another memory he had held as truth. The marriage license on his desk seemed to mock him, its altered state a testament to something he couldn't quite explain to himself, let alone to Joan. Time had become unreliable, bending and warping like the theoretical physics he used to study, and he found himself increasingly unable to distinguish between what had actually occurred and what he had perhaps wished had happened. The deer in the clearing, the morning light filtering through the trees – it all felt so real, yet Joan's doubt made him wonder if he had constructed this memory from fragments of desire and loneliness. He needed to tell her about the license, but the words stuck in his throat, much like the truth about that morning in the Berkshires, real or imagined.

Ines clutched her abdomen as waves of excruciating pain radiated through her body, each surge more intense than the last. What had begun as a manageable discomfort quickly escalated into an overwhelming agony that left her paralyzed on her living room floor, unable to reach for her phone or call out for help. The pain consumed her entirely, leaving her in a state of desperate isolation until, mercifully, emergency services arrived. The ambulance ride passed in a blur of sirens and urgent voices, culminating in a diagnosis that shook her to her core: a twisted and gangrenous gut that would have claimed her life within hours had she not received immediate medical intervention. Post-surgery, Ines lay in her hospital bed, drifting between consciousness and a drug-induced haze, her body feeling simultaneously foreign and familiar. The surgeon's visits were clinical yet reassuring, though Ines found herself responding to his presence with a detached gratitude, her mind preoccupied with existential questions about the worth of her preserved life. When the anesthetist explained the temporary numbness around her incision site, attributing it to nerve healing, Ines barely registered the information. Instead, she focused on an inexplicable sensation - a ghost of a thrill that seemed to dance along her consciousness, neither purely physical nor entirely emotional, as she grappled with the reality of her near-death experience and the uncertain path of recovery that lay ahead.

Paragraph 2:
She went through the motions, hoping to become accustomed to solitude and silence. Then one morning pain struck her like a sudden beak, tearing at her gut. She caught her breath and sat down, waiting for it to pass. It did not pass. It strengthened, blow on blow. She rolled on her bed, dishevelled and sweating. She heard the creature moaning. She tried to telephone the doctor, but the thing shrieked raucously into the mouthpiece, and this saved her, for they sent an ambulance, which took the screaming thing to a hospital, as it would not have taken a polite old woman. Later, they told her she had had at most four hours to live. Her gut had been twisted and gangrenous. She lay quietly in a hospital bed in a curtained room. Numb and bandaged, she drifted in and out of blessed sleep. The surgeon came and went, lifting her dressings, studying the sutures, prodding the walls of her belly with strong fingers. Ines was a courteous and shamefast woman. She did not want to see her own sliced skin and muscle. She thanked him for her life, unable to summon much warmth in her voice. What was her life now, to thank anyone for? The anesthetist came in to discuss what palliatives she might be allowed to take home with her. He said, “I expect you’ve noticed that there’s no sensation around the incision. That’s quite normal. The nerves take time to join again, and some may not do so.” He, too, touched the sewed-up lips of the hole, and she felt that she did not feel, and then felt the ghost of a thrill, like fine wires shooting out across her skin.

He rubbed the sleep from his eyes and began his morning routine, his joints creaking in protest with each movement. "Barbara, I'm up," he called out, but his wife didn't stir, absorbed as she was in her morning prayers. Mel wasn't surprised; he knew better than to interrupt her quiet time with God. Barbara, a former nurse, had devoted herself to raising their children, pouring all her energy into their upbringing, even when they didn't always appreciate her sacrifices. He recalled the Thanksgiving dinner when their daughter Annie had thoughtlessly suggested Barbara should "get a life," as if her role as a mother wasn't enough. The comment had stung, but Barbara had taken it in stride, her dedication to her family unwavering. As Mel made his way to the kitchen, his gaze fell on the subtle reminders of God's presence in their home: the challah on the counter, the prayer book on the table, and the mezuzahs on the doorframes. These symbols of their faith were woven into the fabric of their daily lives, a constant source of comfort and guidance. As he prepared to leave for the day, Mel caught Barbara's eye, and though she didn't break her silence, her hands paused in their gentle clasping, and her eyes crinkled at the corners, a silent acknowledgement of his presence. She blew him a soft kiss, her lips barely moving, and Mel felt a surge of love and gratitude for this woman who had given so much of herself to their family. With a quiet smile, he headed out the door, feeling the weight of her prayers and love accompanying him into the day ahead.

Paragraph 2:
Gingerly, he sat up in bed the next morning, pivoted, placed his feet on the floor, and stood. He felt somewhat better, but he couldn’t turn without pain. He could move only robotically, in straight planes and lines. “Barbara,” he called to his wife, but she remained absorbed in her prayer book by the window. She was blue-eyed, fair, and soft-featured, easily bruised, a nurse by training, though she hadn’t practiced for twenty years. She’d given up her job to devote herself to the children, who were not overcome with gratitude and had been urging her for years to go back to work, or at least to volunteer somewhere. “You should get a life, Mom,” Annie had suggested at Thanksgiving. Barbara took umbrage at this. “I have a life, thank you very much,” she snapped, and plunged a serving spoon deep into the cranberry sauce. “Nice,” Sam whispered sarcastically to his sister. Of course, the kids had no idea what kind of life their mother was getting herself into. “Good morning,” Mel called out. Barbara lifted one finger and kept praying, swaying slightly in her nightgown and quilted slippers. He sighed, inched his way into the bathroom, showered, dressed, and went down to the kitchen, where he poured himself a lonely bowl of cereal. God had entered the house. Stealthily at first, modestly and quietly, God had crept inside Mel’s split-level. He’d smuggled Himself in inside a loaf of challah. He’d stowed away in the pages of Barbara’s black prayer book, and staked out every doorway in the mezuzahs Barbara had nailed up, each containing a little Hebrew scroll proclaiming His name. Mel darted a look at the mezuzah on the doorframe of the kitchen; it was ceramic, and painted in naïve Middle Eastern fashion with a blue five-fingered hand. The hand itself was decorated with a dark, almost Egyptian-looking eye, which gazed down upon Mel balefully. Stiff and slow, Mel eased himself into his coat. “Goodbye,” he called. He listened for a moment. “I’m heading out.” Then, just as he stepped into the frigid garage to drive to the station, he sensed Barbara coming up behind him, book and reading glasses in hand, still silent so as not to interrupt her prayers, but blowing kisses all the same.

His long face was dignified and melancholy and he had something of the beauty of a powerful, discouraged, elderly horse. It’s silly, I hardly know the game anymore. If I leave you now, you can entertain yourself ? It must all seem strange to you but you’ll be surprised how soon you get used to it. She tapped her fingers across the back of his hand. Grant went in search of Kristy and met her in the hall. She was pushing a cart with pitchers of apple juice and grape juice. “Well?” she said. Grant said, “Does she even know who I am?” He could not decide. She could have been playing a joke. It would not be unlike her. Paragraph 1:
Blake trudged into the house, his steps heavy with exhaustion, only to be greeted by the familiar sight of disarray and disappointment. The kitchen lay untouched, devoid of any signs of supper, while the half-empty gin bottle stood as a silent witness to the evening's unraveling. Lipstick-smeared glasses lay scattered on the counter, a testament to Louise's habitual escapism. Frustration welled up within him, a tidal wave of emotions he could no longer contain. Mechanically, he reached for the calendar, marking the days ahead with a decisive stroke to indicate his vow of silence—two weeks without words exchanged, despite Louise's tearful protests echoing through the house like a haunting refrain. Their relationship, once vibrant and full of promise, had deteriorated over the years into a shadow of its former self. Louise's physical appearance had changed, reflecting the toll that time and unspoken resentments had taken, while Blake had emotionally retreated, erecting a physical barrier between them in the form of a bookshelf with lockable doors. This silent partition stood as a stark symbol of the growing chasm between their lives. To Blake, their incessant quarrels seemed as mundane as the sounds of distant traffic or the chatter of strangers in a crowded cafe—inevitable and inescapable elements of the everyday. He found a strange solace in this normalization of discord, accepting it as a natural part of life, even as it eroded the foundation of their once cherished connection. Yet, beneath the surface of routine disagreements, a deeper longing stirred within him for the days when love and laughter filled the spaces now occupied by silence and regret.

Paragraph 2:
Blake had come home one night, overworked and tired, and had found that Louise had done nothing about getting supper. The gin bottle was half emptied, and the first three glasses he took from the bar were smeared with lipstick grease. He had gone into the kitchen, followed by Louise, and he had pointed out to her that the date was the fifth. He had drawn a circle around the date on the kitchen calendar. “One week is the twelfth,” he had said. “Two weeks will be the nineteenth.” He drew a circle around the nineteenth. “I’m not going to speak to you for two weeks,” he had said. “That will be the nineteenth.” She had wept, she had protested, but it had been eight or ten years since she had been able to touch him with her entreaties. Louise had got old. Now the lines in her face were ineradicable, and when she clapped her glasses onto her nose to read the evening paper she looked to him like an unpleasant stranger. The physical charms that had been her only attraction were gone. It had been nine years since Blake had built a bookshelf in the doorway that connected their rooms and had fitted into the bookshelf wooden doors that could be locked, since he did not want the children to see his books. But their prolonged estrangement didn’t seem remarkable to Blake. He had quarrelled with his wife, but so did every other man born of woman. It was human nature. In any place where you can hear their voices—a hotel courtyard, an air shaft, a street on a summer evening—you will hear harsh words.

Paragraph 1:
Neither is exactly unhappy, but what has built up in them instead is a sense of surplus, of life unlived. Somewhere else, while they are absorbed in pushchairs and fish fingers and wiping bottoms, there must be another world, of intense experiences for grownups. They feel as if, through their perpetual preoccupation with infantile things, they, too, had become infants; as if their adult selves were ripening and sweetening all in vain, wasted. You can see this sensual surplus in them. It glistens on their skin and in their eyes, like cream rising to the top of the milk (though neither of them is fat: Rachel is tall and muscular, Janie slight and boyish, only her breasts rounded because she’s breast-feeding). They half know this about themselves, how visibly they exude their sexual readiness. They know that they make a picture, spread out there under the trees in their summer dresses, with their brood gambolling around them. The children press home their opportunity and clamor for ice cream. “Pretty please, Mummy, pretty please.” “It’ll keep us happy for much longer—you won’t have to worry about us.” The guns the boys have bought were made in Germany, and, on the packages, inside the bright-orange explosion where it says “Bang Bang” in English it also says “Toller Knall,” which is presumably the German equivalent. The children point the guns at one another’s heads, shouting, “Toller Knall, Toller Knall,” then laugh delightedly at how unthreatening it sounds.

Paragraph 2:
Rachel and Janie sat beneath the sprawling oak trees, their summer dresses catching the occasional breeze, while their children played nearby in the dappled sunlight. Though neither woman could be described as truly unhappy, both harbored a quiet yearning for experiences beyond their all-consuming maternal duties. Rachel's tall, muscular frame contrasted with Janie's slight, boyish figure, the latter's form subtly altered by motherhood, her breasts full from nursing. Despite their deep immersion in childcare, both women remained acutely aware of their own sensuality and the picture they presented: two vibrant mothers exuding vitality even as they juggled their parental responsibilities. Their children, ever observant of opportune moments, launched into a well-practiced campaign for ice cream, employing their most persuasive techniques with the skilled persistence only children can muster. In the background, their boys engaged in imaginative play with their German-made toy guns, finding endless amusement in shouting "Toller Knall" instead of the usual "Bang Bang," the foreign phrase somehow rendering their mock violence more playful than threatening. Through it all, both women maintained their composed exterior while internally navigating the complex waters of motherhood and personal identity, their unfulfilled aspirations simmering beneath their capable, nurturing facades.

Paragraph 1:
Cathal sat in his dimly lit office, meticulously preparing rejection letters for bursary applications in the Visual Arts department. His focus was unwavering as he printed each letter, carefully folding them into envelopes to be sent out. The task, though routine, required a certain level of precision and detachment, which Cathal had mastered over the years. With the task completed, he left his office, the click of the door echoing in the quiet hallway. As he made his way out of the building, he noticed the Polish girl who cleaned after hours, her presence a silent reminder of the many unseen hands that kept the institution running smoothly. Once outside, Cathal felt the cool evening air wash over him. He removed his tie and jacket, freeing himself from the constraints of the workday, and retrieved his bus pass from his pocket. He walked briskly to the bus stop, his thoughts momentarily clouded by a flicker of doubt about whether the Arklow bus would arrive on time. The evening sky was beginning to darken, and just as his patience began to wane, the familiar bus appeared in the distance. Climbing aboard, he found a seat next to an overweight woman who greeted him with a friendly nod. Almost immediately, she struck up a conversation about the weather, her voice cheerful and persistent. Cathal, though not in the mood for small talk, responded politely, his words measured and courteous. He wished silently that she would lapse into silence, allowing him to retreat into his own thoughts, but he maintained the conversation out of a sense of duty to civility, all the while gazing out the window at the passing scenery.

Paragraph 2:
For a while he tried to focus again on what was there, but in the end decided to switch to the raft of letters, which would all be identical, except for the name: Dear ____, Thank you for your application for a Bursary in Visual Arts. The selection committee has now convened, and made its decisions. The final round was extremely competitive, and we regret to inform you that on this occasion . . . By 5 p.m., he had most of the rejection letters printed on letterhead and was waiting by the elevator. When he heard someone coming, he pushed through the door to the stairwell. It was hotter and smelled musty there. The Polish girl who cleaned after hours was leaning against the bannister, texting. He felt her watching him as he passed, and was glad to reach the foot of the stairs and the exit, to get out onto the street, where it was noisy and a hot queue of cars pushed at the traffic lights. He took his tie and jacket off and felt for the bus pass, which was there, in his breast pocket, and walked to the Davenport, to wait for the Arklow bus. For no particular reason, a part of him doubted whether the bus would come that day, but it soon came up Westland Row and pulled in, as usual. Almost every seat was occupied, and he had to take an aisle seat beside an overweight woman, who slid a bit closer to the window, to give him room. “Wasn’t that some day,” she said, brightly. “Yeah,” Cathal said. “They say it’s meant to last,” she said. “This fine weather.” He had chosen badly; this woman would want to talk. He wished she would stay quiet—then caught himself. “That’s good to know,” he said.

“Coffee?” the waiter said. I looked up to see him placing two steaming mugs on our table. The researcher drew a breath. I was staring at a brown sky. I sat up. The first thing I noticed was a leg. It stood a yard from me, still socked and shoed, as if it had come detached midstride. Next I saw the hole in the wall. It looked as if a wrecking ball had been swung through. Cinder blocks and sandbags and concertina wire all lay in a dusty heap. A dog sat on top of the heap. The dog—one of those Kabuli street hounds glistening with bald patches, a tumor the size of a cantaloupe hanging between its haunches, and no doubt an ear infection that caused it to list and wander in psychotic circles—was barking mutely. I realized I was deaf. All I could detect was a high-pitched tone, like a test of the emergency broadcast system. The emergency broadcast system? I thought. Jesus, I was getting old. Then I wondered: Tinnitus—rhymes with “hit us” or “smite us”? Maybe this was only a test. I was watching a woman pull a long splinter out of her cheek. It kept coming out, like a magic trick. “Sue?” I said. It was Sue Kwan, from Human Rights Watch. She’d been at the Norwegian Embassy, too. I’d bluntly propositioned her after abasing myself in front of the World Bank consultant. Kwan had rebuffed me so gently, with such pity. I’d responded by calling her latest report biased and confusingly structured. Now she looked at me, wide-eyed, unable to answer on account of the splinter. “I’m sorry, Sue,” I said. I can only imagine how absurd it sounded. Sue, though, seemed not to have heard me, either. I followed her gaze back to the hole in the wall. Several men with rifles were climbing over the rubble, into the garden.

Paragraph 2:
As I sat at the table, sipping the coffee the waiter had just served, I couldn't have anticipated the chaos that was about to erupt. The researcher across from me seemed just as oblivious, engrossed in our conversation. But in an instant, everything changed. I found myself disoriented, my surroundings transformed into a surreal landscape. A detached leg lay on the ground, a gruesome sight that seemed almost unreal. A massive hole gaped in the wall, and debris was scattered everywhere. Amidst the wreckage, a Kabuli street hound perched atop the rubble, its jaws open in a silent bark. I realized, with a jolt, that I was temporarily deaf, the only sound a high-pitched ringing in my ears. I wondered, with a pang of anxiety, if this was the onset of tinnitus, a cruel irony given my age. As I struggled to make sense of the scene, I spotted Sue Kwan from Human Rights Watch, her face contorted in pain as she pulled a long splinter from her cheek. I recalled our awkward encounter at the conference last year and felt a surge of regret. I tried to apologize, but she didn't seem to hear me, her eyes fixed on the splinter. I watched, frozen, as armed men began to climb over the rubble into the garden, their movements eerily silent in my deafened state. The world around me had descended into chaos, and I was left to navigate the wreckage, unsure of what lay ahead.

Paragraph 1:
This article is part of our Pets special section on scientists’ growing interest in our animal companions. For 30 years, archaeologists have been digging at Jamestown, the first permanent British settlement in America. The trumpets, children’s shoes, pistols and millions of other unearthed objects have provided fresh clues to what life was like at the fort that settlers built in 1607 on the James River in Virginia. Now, some of the most intriguing clues are coming from bones — not of the people who lived in Jamestown, but of the dogs. The earliest written records of European colonists make only fleeting references to dogs. Spanish and British explorers brought mastiffs, bloodhounds and water spaniels to the New World, though probably not as pets. Some European dogs helped hunt down deer and birds, while others were sent into battle: When Powhatan forces attacked Jamestown, English soldiers retaliated by setting dogs loose on Powhatan villages. The records also indicate that dogs sometimes served as food. When the Powhatan people laid siege to the settlement in 1609, the British residents suffered through a winter that came to be known as “the Starving Time.” The people trapped inside Jamestown resorted to eating dogs. “Having fed upon horses and other beasts as long as they lasted, we were glad to make shift with vermin, as dogs, cats and mice,” George Percy, the president of the Jamestown council, wrote in 1622.

Paragraph 2:
Recent archaeological excavations at Jamestown, the first permanent British settlement in America, have unearthed a trove of artifacts that offer a glimpse into the harsh realities of life in the early 17th century. Among the discoveries are bones that reveal the critical role dogs played in the survival of European colonists, who brought them to the New World not as pets but as working animals. These canine companions were tasked with hunting, guarding, and even assisting in warfare, serving as a vital resource for settlers struggling to adapt to the unforgiving environment. The dire conditions of the winter of 1609, known as "the Starving Time," are particularly starkly illuminated by the findings, which suggest that dogs were consumed by the desperate colonists as a last resort. As documented by George Percy, president of the Jamestown council, in 1622, the settlers were forced to resort to extreme measures to stay alive, including eating their own dogs. This gruesome yet fascinating discovery underscores the complexity of the relationships between humans and animals in early colonial America, and highlights the often-overlooked role of dogs as a crucial component of the settlers' survival strategies.

The man nods understandingly as I describe the unique personalities of different dogs I've known, and I can tell he's genuinely engaged in our conversation, not just making polite small talk. Meanwhile, Juju continues his joyful circuit around the schoolyard, occasionally pausing to check on me before resuming his game with the boy, whose pompom cap bobs up and down with each attempted capture. In this peaceful end-of-day moment, I'm struck by how dogs have this remarkable ability to create connections between people who might otherwise remain strangers, turning an ordinary afternoon into something quietly meaningful.

Paragraph 2:
“It’s Juju!” the boy called in his clear, piercing voice as he jumped down from the box. The pompom bobbed on top of his cap. “Hello,” I gasped, breathless from having been pulled along behind Juju. “Hello,” the man answered with the same ambiguous smile. The box they’d been sitting on had held carrots: on top was a picture of a fresh, bright-orange carrot. The other boxes in the stack had held frozen squid, pudding, corn, and Worcestershire sauce. The schoolchildren had already gone home for the day, and the music room and the playground were quiet. The yard was in shadow, and silence filled the school like stagnant water. The rabbits huddled together in a corner of their hutch. The cafeteria, too, seemed empty. The window was clear now, and I could see all sorts of details that had been obscured before: the shine of the stainless-steel serving counter; the cut of the collars on the white uniforms hanging on the wall; the color of the switch on the conveyor belt. “They seem to be done for the day,” I said, sitting down next to the man. “Yes, they just finished,” he answered. Juju ran around in the last rays of sunlight, dragging his chain, while the boy ran after him, trying to catch his tail. Beyond them, the sun was sinking into the sea, dyeing the water a deep amber that seemed to swallow up the waves, the boats, the lighthouse, and everything else. Seagulls were flying among the masts in the deserted marina. “I’m sorry he keeps pestering Juju.” “Not at all. Juju seems to love it.” “How long have you had him?” “It’s been ten years. I’ve spent almost half my life with him, so he’s part of all my most important memories. It’s like those photos that come with the date printed on them—all I have to do is remember how big Juju was or what kind of collar he was wearing and I can figure out when something happened.” “I understand,” he said, kicking at a pebble with the toe of his plain brown shoe. After that, we talked about dogs for a while. I told him about discovering a dog zoo in a hot-springs resort in the mountains, and about the hysterical pregnancy suffered by a Maltese that used to live next door to me. He asked various questions, nodding solemnly at my answers, and from time to time he even smiled.

Yet these mental conversations, while soothing in their own way, serve as constant reminders of what I've lost. But while the artificial may animate and add dimension to the intangible, it will never breathe life into what is dead. And, for me, the contrived creation of a verbal afterlife felt even more empty than the premature end to the most dynamic and electric life I have ever known. I would still trade anything to have just one more conversation with real Eli, my Eli. I don’t think that will ever change. His imaginary voice and running commentary continue to fill my days, but for now — and hopefully forever — that voice will remain in my head.

Yingying would cry, and Jiayu would comfort her, and then they would reconcile, all the while pretending that they did not notice the students around them, most of whom were boarders supported by the government. They were much older, some in their late teens, ready to leave school after an apprenticeship. Looking back, she questions whether their interactions were genuinely spontaneous or if they were, in part, a performance—two young girls desperately trying to carve out their own identity among the older, government-supported students who populated the school. The realization that even their childhood friendship might have been colored by this need for distinction adds another layer of complexity to her understanding of loss, identity, and the ways in which people navigate their relationships in the face of institutional and social pressures.

After that, he read all the letters he had ever received and threw most of them away, and then he bought a large map of India and hung it above his bed. Or, rather, he didn’t buy a map of India, but that was what he really wanted to do while he was waiting. He waited and waited, and began to write a story about waiting for her, but he didn’t know how it would end, so he stopped. Finally, he did nothing at all; he didn’t even wait anymore. He was sleeping less and less, eating nothing but bread and tomatoes and yellow supermarket cheese, and then, at last, she came back. They sat together on his sofa, and she said, “It’s been a long time.” “Yes,” he said, although he had firmly made up his mind to say as little as possible. “It’s been a very long time.” She had lost weight on her travels, and he didn’t think she looked better than before. She was tired, but then she was always tired; she’d gone away to recover from feeling tired all the time, and now that she was back she was still tired.

Just as I started to roll over, Alex turned to me and used his big hands to pull all my hair back, stretching my face into surprise. He held me like this, studying my posture of alarm, then let go abruptly and fell onto his back in frustration. We embarked on a silence. It grew and grew until it was a sort of god that we could only submit to. After fifteen or twenty minutes I almost giggled—somebody say something!—and then I realized with horror that he was probably asleep. This wasn’t our silence; it was mine alone. I lay paralyzed as it hollowed and darkened, expanding in every direction with a familiar cruelty. Hello, stranger. As he reached over and gently pulled my hair back, a gesture that once felt intimate now added to the weight of the moment. I could sense his frustration; it was as if he was trying to find something in me that I couldn't, or wouldn't, reveal. When Alex fell back onto his pillow with a sigh, a silence settled over us, thick and suffocating. For a moment, it felt like we shared this silence, but as his breathing slowed and deepened into the rhythm of sleep, I realized I was alone in it. The silence pressed down on me, echoing memories of a time when Alex had rescued me from a similar void of despair. Back then, his presence had been a lifeline, pulling me back from the brink. Now, the silence felt familiar, a reminder of my internal struggle and the growing chasm between us. As I lay there, enveloped in that oppressive quiet, I wondered if this time, I would have to find my own way out.

About Your Money Troubles … Our 10-year-old daughter told us that her friend’s father was fired from his job recently and the family is feeling stressed. Still, it feels dishonest to pretend I don’t know. Should I broach the subject? A.S. You should not. Your first instinct is the more generous one. Regardless of the circumstances, any job loss can feel embarrassing or shameful. And a chatty child is not an invitation to probe a sensitive subject.

On a chilly Thursday evening at 9:30, Thomas and Mary were absorbed in their reading in the sitting room, with Thomas sprawled on the sofa engrossed in a Haruki Murakami novel while Mary sat at the table studying a guide on cocker spaniel training. The quiet atmosphere shifted when their son Mark unexpectedly descended from upstairs, seeking refuge from the cold, and settled down with his laptop and headphones to watch a film. Thomas, seeing an opportunity to connect with his son, expressed interest in joining him, despite Mark's skepticism about his father's potential enjoyment of the movie. When Thomas suggested they watch together for thirty minutes, Mary declined the invitation, explaining that the laptop screen was too small for three viewers, and she wasn't keen on relocating to the cold playroom to use the television. Instead, she opted to take their dog Ricky for an evening walk. As predicted by Mark, Thomas found the film both unengaging and unnecessarily violent, though he valued the shared moment with his son before retiring to bed at 10:30. When Mary finally came to bed an hour later, Thomas feigned sleep, bringing the evening to a quiet close.

Thursday evening, 9:30. Thomas and Mary are in the sitting room reading, he on the sofa, she at her place at the table. He is reading a novel by Haruki Murakami, she a book about training cocker spaniels. Unusually, their son, Mark, comes downstairs. “It’s warmer here,” he says, and proceeds to open his computer to watch a film, with headphones. The boy is fourteen. Thomas looks up and says that he’d like to watch the film, too, if that’s O.K. Mark tells him that he won’t like the film, but Thomas says he’ll give it half an hour, if that’s all right. Mark says, “Fine,” and unplugs the headphones. Thomas asks Mary if she would like to watch the film, too. Mary says that there isn’t really room for three to watch a film on their son’s laptop. Mark says that they could go and watch the film on the TV in the playroom. Mary says that it’s too cold in the playroom to sit through a film and decides to take Ricky for a walk. Thomas finds the film dull, stupid, and disturbingly violent. It’s nice to sit beside his son, but, at 10:30, he bails out and goes to bed. Mary joins him at 11:30, when he is not asleep, but pretends he is, face to the wall.

Paragraph 1:
She was a woman defined by caution, her every move calculated to avoid the pain that had become all too familiar. For her, a hit was as easy as a kiss, a harsh reality that had left its mark. So when he reached out to her, his hand extended in a gesture of friendship, she instinctively pulled back. But he was quick to reassure her, his eyes crinkling at the corners as he smiled and said he wasn't making advances, just suggesting a drive. The tension was broken, and they shared a laugh, the sound of which was enough to put her at ease. She agreed to his proposal, and as they drove through the winding roads, the scenery blurring together outside their windows, they found themselves lost in conversation. Later, in the intimate confines of a hotel room, she explored the topography of his scars with her fingers, her nursing school training kicking in as she gently traced the ridges and valleys of his skin. He told her about the war injury that had left its mark, the wound that had cauterized itself in the heat of the moment. As they moved together, their bodies entwined in a slow dance, she felt a sense of liberation wash over her. It was as if the very act of connection was a balm to her soul, soothing the hurts of the past and leaving her feeling alive. In that moment, they were two people, lost in the beauty of their own private world, their movements building to a crescendo that left them both breathless and wanting more.

Paragraph 2:
A hit could come as easily as a kiss. The back of a hand could arrive at a moment’s notice. This physics was in her bones, in the way she drew herself slightly away, even now, when he reached out to touch her shoulder. She felt herself—with the breeze blowing her hair around her eyes—withdrawing a little bit from the pliant urgency in his voice when he told her that he just felt like getting away. So she waited until he added, I’m not hitting on you, I’m just proposing a drive up the river, and then they both laughed at that. And she waited a few more beats, and then said, Sure, which was, he thought, the most beautiful word in the world. Now they were in a bed, in the shadowy hotel light, listening to the occasional car passing on the road. He heaved into her, lifting himself up on his hands, while she held his shoulders, her fingers sliding around to feel the scar coming down from his neck and channelling out in two lines that then met again around his left nipple to form a craterlike hollow, and she drew on her time in nursing school, testing the tissue where the shrapnel went in and stayed in and burned—he’d later say—phosphorous white and hot enough, thank God, to cauterize the wound and seal off the blood vessels. He thrust down and deep and then eased up as she pushed against him—forgetting his scars—until the two motions spun into what seemed to be an airless freedom. He grunted, and she came, too, her finger flicking.

Paragraph 1:
In the strange tapestry of my life, there are threads of confinement and liberation, woven with moments that seem both surreal and hauntingly real. I remember the yellow cell where I was first confined, its walls a constant reminder of my isolation. Eventually, I was transferred to an institution, a place where days blurred together, and my hands became accustomed to the repetitive task of packaging shoelaces. During those times, my mind often wandered to Miro and the gang, vivid figments of my imagination that kept me company. Meanwhile, Katja embarked on her own journey, moving to a new apartment with a secret address, her days filled with the mundane yet taxing tasks of dealing with blisters and making endless insurance calls. When I was finally released, I returned to my old apartment, a place that felt both familiar and foreign. I longed to reconnect with Katja, to fill the empty spaces of our shared past, but my attempts fell short. Life, it seemed, had other plans. In a twist of fate, I found myself "dying" in a moped accident in Portugal, only to be metaphorically resurrected in Stockholm when Katja learned of my supposed death. In this spectral form, I became a constant, ghostly presence in Katja's life, silently offering her support and comfort as she navigated her daily routine. Though I was no longer physically present, I found solace in knowing that I could still be there for her, whispering encouragement and understanding as she faced the challenges of her world. In this peculiar existence, I became both a shadow and a light, a testament to the enduring bond between us, transcending the boundaries of life and death.

Paragraph 2:
I was led back to my yellow cell. Katja went home to her smoky stairwell. I was moved to an institution. She moved to a new apartment with a secret address. I spent my days putting black and sometimes brown shoelaces in transparent plastic packaging. She spent her days putting ointment on her blisters and calling the insurance company. I spent my nights dreaming of Miro and the gang. She spent her nights dreaming of me. I was released after two years and ten months. I went home to my old apartment. I put on my cutoffs, sat on the sofa with a glass of apple juice, and turned on the TV. It was a documentary about hyenas and I looked out at the courtyard to see if my neighbor might be watching the same show. But he had moved. Or else he had put the TV in a different room. For several weeks I tried to get into playing the role of myself. I thought about contacting Katja. Sometimes I walked past her old apartment. Once, I called her office and said that I was a friend who wanted to plan a surprise party for her and needed her new address. They said that unfortunately they couldn’t help me. The second time I called I got disconnected. The third time I don’t remember what happened. Eight months later I died in a moped accident in Portugal. One week later I was resurrected in Stockholm when Katja found out what had happened. Suddenly I was back in her life. I was lying beside her when she woke. I followed her when she ran to the bus. I gave her a thumbs-up if she made a sale at work and I comforted her when she collapsed in the bathroom with the faucet running so that no one would hear her crying. In the evening I followed her to dinner.

The two of you smoked on the patio of George, back when Aiden could still do that. A gaggle of gays leaned on the bench beside you, holding their sides from laughter, and you breathed in their gasps and the smoke and the humidity and you told Aiden what you’d wanted to tell him. At first, he didn’t say anything. He took another pull of his cigarette. Then he grasped your hand, folding his fingers into yours. I don’t care, he said. I’m just glad you’re O.K. That’s all I care about, Aiden said, and then he smiled, glowing under the midnight lights.

I'll never forget the night I told Aiden I was poz, sitting on George's patio in Houston's thick, humid air. The smoke from his cigarette curled upward as he processed my words, his initial silence stretching longer than I could bear. Around us, a group of strangers erupted in laughter, their joy a stark contrast to the weight of our moment. Aiden was only in town for two weeks, and I had agonized over whether to tell him at all. But there he was, finally reaching across the table to hold my hand, his eyes meeting mine with unwavering warmth. "I only care that you're okay," he said, squeezing my fingers gently. The relief washed over me like a wave, and suddenly the sticky Houston night felt a little more bearable.

Noeleen was waiting for him in the hallway. As he sat in the dining room with her, she suggested that he get a set of forms from his aunt’s bank and her solicitor, which would give him power of attorney, or at least the power to deal with her financial affairs. The house had a smell of damp and old cooking. As he stood in the downstairs room, he was amazed at how small everything was, not only the rooms themselves but the objects in them—the armchairs and the television in the corner of the front room, the dining-room table and chairs in the back room. Somehow, the place had shrunk in Josie’s absence. He remembered spending Christmas here in recent years and loving the coal fires lighting both rooms, the Christmas tree, the warmth of the place as he helped her package presents for neighbors and friends and later watched the television with her or helped her in the kitchen. When he went upstairs and looked at his old bedroom, he noticed how worn the carpet was and how the color on the wallpaper had faded. He must, he thought, have noticed this before, but now the room seemed shabby and strange, almost unfamiliar, and not the room he had slept in every night throughout his childhood, with the small desk in the corner where he did his homework. Suddenly, he realized that he was dreading the night ahead in this house; he did not think he would sleep. When he went to look for sheets to put on his bed, he found a musty smell in the hot press. He turned away and walked down the stairs and made up his mind that he would search for Josie’s papers and bank statements and then he would go. He made a call to the Riverside Hotel, and when they told him they had rooms free he said he would be there in an hour. Josie would hate the waste of money, and the thought that he might not want to spend the night in her house, but the idea of having to make up a bed for himself and try to sleep in this old room made him shiver. That’s all over now, he thought. He suppressed any urge to feel sorry for himself at losing it.

He moved through Aunt Josie's house with a growing sense of unease, each room feeling like a shrunken version of the spaces he remembered from his childhood. The once-grand living room, where countless Christmas celebrations had unfolded with laughter and warmth, now appeared tired and diminished, its wallpaper peeling at the corners and the familiar furniture bearing the weight of neglect. After an awkward conversation with Josie, conducted under the watchful eyes of other residents who seemed to hover just within earshot, he encountered Noeleen in the narrow hallway. Her whispered suggestion about securing power of attorney for his aunt's finances lingered uncomfortably in his mind, adding another layer of complexity to an already difficult situation. The house's transformation was most apparent in the small details - the worn carpet beneath his feet, the slight mustiness in the air, and the way shadows seemed to gather in corners that once held cheerful memories of holiday decorations and family gatherings. Each step through the house revealed another reminder of how things had changed in Josie's absence, the space feeling more like a faded photograph than the vibrant home he remembered. When he reached his old bedroom, the prospect of spending the night there filled him with an unexpected dread. The room, once a sanctuary of childhood comfort, now felt like a stranger's space, with its dated furnishings and musty bedding serving as painful reminders of time's passage. The decision to book a hotel room came with a twinge of guilt, knowing how Josie would disapprove of such an unnecessary expense, but the thought of lying awake in that unfamiliar-familiar room was more than he could bear. As he made the booking on his phone, he rationalized that some distances - even those measured in memories rather than miles - were better maintained, and sometimes the most respectful way to honor the past was to acknowledge when it could no longer comfortably accommodate the present.

Had the book been a gift? A souvenir of a casual dalliance that might be over by now? Was it possible that Grisha had skipped that page and not seen the inscription? Or had he left the book here in order to savor the inscription, certain that Lera would never open it? She remembered the saying (was it her mother’s?) that on such occasions there were only two options: to leave or not to know. Nothing in between. Well, where was she to leave to? The house in Dobbs Ferry had been sold, the bank check deposited, the furniture taken to consignment shops. And not to know—wasn’t that always the intelligent option? It seemed that so much of marriage—hers, at least—was made up of these negative spaces, the words she’d kept herself from saying, all in the service of not polluting daily conversations with unnecessary poison. And what good had it done her? She threw the bedcover off, her feet, her underarms clammy with sweat. She opened the window and breathed in the frost-laden air. The cold was like a remorseless living presence descending on her and gripping her under her nightgown. She stared at the snow until she felt herself floating up, out of her numb skin. It sickened Lera to have to call Olya in the morning. She could think of no one else who could tell her what was going on with Grisha. “He hasn’t called us in a month,” Olya said. It was hard to tell if she really felt snubbed or was only feigning insult. “Must be a busy season for him.” “Let’s not be so delicate. If he had someone else, you would tell me, I hope.” “You know me, Lera. I don’t stand over anyone’s business holding a candle.” The hesitation in her voice suggested that she didn’t want to say more on the phone. “I need to drive to Mamontovka today,” Olya said. “Why don’t you come along?” Olya steered her Acura with one hand resting atop the wheel. The gold tooth Lera remembered in the corner of her smile was gone. She’d cropped her hair, which played up her Tatar features, the wide cheeks and profile that looked as if it had been pounded flat by a small hammer. The Mamontovka that Lera remembered had changed as well.

Lera stood by the window, the cold air seeping in like an unwelcome guest, as she reflected on her tangled relationship with Grisha. Her fingers traced the edges of a book with an inscription that had become a symbol of uncertainty. Was it a relic from a past affair? Did Grisha intentionally leave it for her to find, as if daring her to uncover a truth she wasn't sure she wanted to face? A saying from her mother echoed in her mind, advising her to remain ignorant rather than confront what she feared. But ignorance felt like a trap, especially now that her house in Dobbs Ferry was gone, leaving her with nowhere to retreat. The unspoken tensions in her marriage gnawed at her, and the futility of avoiding conflict left her feeling suffocated. Desperate for clarity, Lera picked up the phone and called Olya, hoping for some insight into Grisha's world. Olya's voice was a lifeline, suggesting that Grisha might simply be busy and inviting Lera to accompany her on a drive to Mamontovka. As they drove, Lera observed subtle changes in Olya's appearance, each one a reminder of the passage of time and the inevitability of change. Mamontovka, too, had transformed, its familiar landscapes altered by new developments. The drive offered a momentary escape, but also a reminder that nothing remained static—not places, not people, not relationships. Lera's mind drifted back to the book and its inscription, a mystery intertwined with her own uncertainties. The cold air through the open window had felt alive, a tangible reminder of her present reality, yet sitting beside Olya, Lera found solace in the shared silence, a pause from the relentless questioning. In that quietude, she contemplated her choices, torn between seeking answers and preserving the fragile peace of ignorance. The road unfolded before them, a metaphor for the journey she was on, uncertain yet inevitable. As Lera and Olya continued their drive, Lera realized that perhaps the answers she sought were not in the inscriptions or the past, but in the path she chose to take next. With Mamontovka in the rearview mirror, she considered the possibility of finding her own way forward, one decision at a time.

In the quiet, early hours, Janet found herself awakening in a modest room just off the kitchen. The soft rustle of activity caught her attention as she observed Sasha moving purposefully around the apartment, immersed in her morning routine of brewing coffee and scrolling through her phone, the faint glow of the screen illuminating her focused expression. After Sasha departed for the day, Janet unintentionally drifted back to sleep, her mind lulled by the stillness that reclaimed the space. She later awoke to the comforting aroma of scrambled eggs, courtesy of Danny, who had taken up the morning's culinary duties. As they sat together, Janet seized the moment to inquire about Sasha's emotional well-being, particularly her apparent "despair." Danny, pausing thoughtfully, elaborated on Sasha's support network—friends with whom she shared her burdens and a therapist who offered a professional ear. He carefully explained the concept of a "talk therapist" to Janet, likening it to conversing with a friend, yet devoid of personal ties or judgments. This revelation provided Janet with a clearer understanding of the therapeutic process, a notion she found both intriguing and reassuring. As their conversation waned, Janet prepared to leave, acknowledging the subtle importance of their dialogue. She silently mouthed a goodbye to Danny, who was now absorbed in his work, headphones securely in place, lost to the world outside his concentration. The morning had unfolded with a gentle rhythm, leaving Janet with a sense of connection and newfound insight into the complexities entwining their small circle.

Paragraph 2:
She slept in a small room off the kitchen. With the couch pulled out, the door couldn’t close. That night, she woke up in the dark and turned to check the clock. For the first time in months, she had slept past 4 a.m. The sun was about to come up and Sasha was moving around the apartment, the lights still off. Janet watched her through the doorway: pouring coffee, checking her phone, smoothing her already smooth skirt, checking her phone again. It glowed in her hand. Her neck was always bent. When Sasha left, Janet vowed not to fall back asleep—in solidarity, or at least sympathy—but somehow she did. Danny scrambled eggs for her. The secret was low heat and patience. “Who else knows?” she asked. He looked startled. “Knows what?” The egg slipped down Janet’s throat. “You know,” she said. “Her despair.” “Oh.” He seemed relieved. He said there were a few friends Sasha confided in, and also a therapist. “An analyst?” “It’s called a talk therapist.” When he saw that Janet didn’t understand, he explained. She appreciated this: he was a good explainer. “They just talk. Face to face. No couch involved.” He took the plates to the sink, where the frying pan was already soaking and would soon be effortlessly scraped clean. “Like a friend, except the whole point is that you don’t know them.” “But they know you.” Danny nodded and scrubbed. He went back to his computer. He was wearing headphones again, so she mouthed bye on her way out the door.

Lu sat before the glowing monitor, her fingers hovering uncertainly over the keyboard as she contemplated Susan's floppy disk and the prompt that awaited her response. The cursor blinked steadily, a rhythmic reminder of the empty document before her, as she began typing in English, her thoughts initially coming in measured, careful sentences. Frustrated by the limitations of her second language, she switched to Cantonese, letting her native tongue carry the weight of decades of unspoken truths – about power dynamics she'd never fully understood, about the sacrifices that had become so routine she'd stopped recognizing them as sacrifices, about the invisible threads that had woven the tapestry of her marriage and her life in America. The characters flowed across the screen, each one holding fragments of memories: the way she'd learned to smile and nod in meetings even when her ideas were dismissed, the countless times she'd swallowed her words to keep peace at home, the subtle art of making herself smaller to fit into spaces that were never designed to accommodate her. As her thoughts deepened, she found herself writing about the intricate dance of survival she'd perfected over the years, the delicate balance between maintaining her identity and adapting to a world that demanded constant compromise. Yet, as she reread her words, a protective instinct surfaced – not for herself, but for her daughter who might someday read these truths. With a decisive press of the delete key, Lu watched the complex tapestry of her narrative disappear, character by character. In its place, she crafted a simpler story in English, reducing years of nuanced experience into a straightforward account of an affair between two people. The weight of her unspoken truth settled heavily in her chest as she saved the file, knowing that some stories were better left untold, some burdens better carried alone than passed down to the next generation.

Paragraph 2:
That night, Lu sat down at the family computer. She pushed the floppy disk Susan had given her into the drive and opened the file. She stared for a long time at the first question. In this space, please tell us what you witnessed.I saw other women grieving. [Delete] In this space, please tell us what you witnessed.I never grieved. [Delete] Lu tried switching to Cantonese. She printed the page and wrote by hand. In this space, please tell us what you witnessed.I saw the lines of a long net in which we were all trapped, caught up. I saw men and women who had excelled within these lines, but also wanted to escape them. I saw my children growing up without their mother, and that’s why I never left my marriage. And, for fourteen years, I came to know a power that was more shadow than substance. But wait: before you say that I know little about power, let me tell you that shadows have a strength. Nothing can dissolve these quiet things, which are nourished by what is within reach. And the other kind of power, the kind that kept me in my place, well, my co-workers say they do not see it. And do I? I have learned not to. I have learned to cross the street and look the other way, because you can’t stop someone else’s contempt. You can’t change the earth, the sky above your head, the disrespect, you can’t change the electrical wires in your path, but you have to teach your children to sense their presence, to step over them smoothly, without a single note of fear. They have to keep moving, after all. Why am I writing this in a language you can’t understand? So that my dead mother can read it? She already knew. Lu reread the paragraph. Only her big daughter would know how to translate it. But something turned over in her. It was out of the question to ask the child. Was this something, after all, that a mother should do? She crumpled the page and dropped it in the bin. In this space, please tell us what you witnessed. Lu returned to English. Two people had an affair. Nothing more. But also nothing less. [Save.]

‘In Her Place’ Stream it on Netflix. Chile’s submission for this year’s Academy Award for best international feature film is a historical psychodrama centered on a true story: In 1955, the writer María Carolina Geel shot and killed her lover in the crowded dining room of an upscale hotel in Santiago. Geel went to prison in a case that shook the country, and wrote a best-selling book about life behind bars. The president later pardoned her after the Nobel Prize-winning poet Gabriela Mistral appealed on her behalf. But Maite Alberdi’s “In Her Place” isn’t about Geel’s spectacular life — it’s about the effect this case has on a fictional secretary working for the trial judge. Mercedes (Elisa Zulueta) lives in a humble home with her husband and two teenage sons, and spends all her time either working at the court or cooking and cleaning at home. Geel’s scintillating crime of passion, and the brazen, glamorous woman at its center, captures Mercedes, who uses the keys confiscated by the court to let herself into Geel’s apartment. Reading the accused writer’s books, wearing her designer clothes, Mercedes starts to imagine — and vicariously live out — a different life that’s both seductive and frightening. An extraordinary tale of crime and redemption becomes the backdrop for a delicate portrait of an ordinary woman trapped not just by patriarchy, but by something that seems almost worse: mediocrity.

Paragraph 1:
Marciano clutched the cardboard box of face masks closer to his chest as the rain pelted down, each drop a reminder of how far he'd fallen from his previous job, the memory of this morning's clinic visit still fresh and unsettling in his mind like an open wound that refused to heal. The sidewalk stretched before him like a wet, glistening snake, dotted with earthworms that had emerged from their underground sanctuaries, and he carefully stepped around them, his head swimming from the effects of the intravenous treatment that left a metallic taste in his mouth and made his stomach churn with uncertainty. The neon sign of Herlihy's bar flickered through the rain-streaked afternoon, beckoning him with its promise of temporary shelter, though his heart raced at the thought of entering this predominantly white establishment where his presence would undoubtedly draw unwanted attention. Despite his reservations, Marciano pushed through the heavy wooden door, the warmth of the bar enveloping him as several pairs of eyes turned to assess the newcomer, including the bartender's calculating gaze that seemed to pierce through his rain-soaked exterior. Summoning what little confidence he had left, he approached the bar and spoke his favorite English word, "Corona," his voice barely masking the tremor that threatened to betray his nervousness. The persistent cough he'd been fighting all day chose that moment to surface, and he quickly pressed his fist against his mouth, aware of the sideways glances from the other patrons who instinctively shifted away from him in their seats. As he nursed his beer, Marciano watched through the foggy window as his bus passed by, its headlights cutting through the rain like distant lighthouses, but he couldn't bring himself to care about missing it, too consumed by the toxic mixture of fear and anger brewing inside him about his deteriorating health and financial situation. The box of face masks sat beside him on the worn wooden bar like a silent reminder of his new reality, while the mounted television droned on with news he barely comprehended, his thoughts drifting to Rosa Hinojosa and what she might think of him now, sitting alone in this unfamiliar bar, seeking solace in a bottle while the world outside continued its relentless downpour. The cough returned, more insistent this time, and he could feel the weight of judgment from the other patrons pressing down on him like the humidity in the air, their unspoken accusations and assumptions hanging heavy in the smoke-filled atmosphere. Time seemed to slow to a crawl as he sat there, each sip of his Corona a small act of defiance against the circumstances that had brought him to this moment, the cold glass against his lips a sharp contrast to the warmth of the bar and the fever he could feel building beneath his skin. The news anchor's voice provided a monotonous backdrop to his troubled thoughts, mixing with the gentle tapping of rain against the windows and the murmured conversations of the other patrons who had already dismissed him as just another stranger seeking refuge from the storm. Marciano's fingers traced patterns in the condensation on his beer bottle, creating temporary artwork that disappeared as quickly as his former sense of security had, leaving behind only smudged remnants of what once was. The face masks in their cardboard container seemed to mock him with their pristine whiteness, their presence a stark reminder of the doctor's words that morning and the series of treatments that lay ahead, treatments he wasn't sure
