Paragraph 1:
“Our rescuers, poor devils, cursed as they climbed, and stopped now and then to sing, drink, and laugh loudly. They weren’t very enthusiastic. Many years later, I also happened to be part of a rescue party, so I know exactly how they felt. These expeditions are tedious and dangerous affairs, and in most cases they can only lead to trouble, because no one wants to pay for the emergency supplies—least of all the rescued, who are rarely solvent. “They reached us at around two in the morning; and here I must tell you that, on top of everything else, they were members of the border patrol. Once they’d found us, a signal was sent to the valley with a flashlight. ‘Who are they?’ a voice asked from below. ‘It’s just three whiny gagno’ was the fierce reply, in dialect. Then, turning to us, ‘Is this what they teach you in school?’ “After that, they tied us up like salami and lowered us down to the valley without talking to us but stopping often to drink, and curse, and guffaw among themselves. Pass me the bottle, please.” I passed the narrator the bottle and asked him what a gagno was. “Gagno,” he said, “means child, but it’s a word loaded with mockery. Second-grade kids say it to first graders.

Paragraph 2:
I still remember that night when the border patrol found us, those poor devils who seemed more interested in their drinks and songs than the actual rescue. Years later, when I participated in a similar mission myself, I understood their seemingly casual attitude – these operations were as tedious as they were dangerous. They finally reached us around two in the morning, their flashlights piercing the darkness as they signaled to their companions in the valley below. I'll never forget how they mockingly called us "three whiny gagno," using that childish term to belittle us in our desperate state. The process of being tied up and lowered to the valley was nerve-wracking, made more unsettling by their constant drinking and joking amongst themselves. The sound of their laughter echoed through the night as we dangled precariously between sky and earth. It wasn't until much later, when someone passed me a bottle and asked about that night, that I explained the meaning of "gagno" – a term that now carries the weight of that memorable rescue, a reminder of how vulnerability and humiliation often go hand in hand with salvation.

Paragraph 1:
This hotel signalled the new era of the old town. Mrs. Arunachalam, who was seven months pregnant and spread across the middle seat of my taxi van, wanted to make the eleven-hour journey to Jaffna in small stages, like an ant on a sugar trail. She ought not to have been travelling at all, the way she sighed and swooned, but her husband was very keen to show her a property in Jaffna that he intended to buy and develop as their new family home, and so she had come. “Vasantha, can’t you go slowly around the bend, please?” she kept saying, in an infuriating refrain, from the moment we left Rajagiriya on her journey of a lifetime. “Yes, Madam,” I’d reply. Yes, yes, yes. I am already around the bleeding bend. When she saw the flags and streamers, she was jubilant. “That’s the place. That’s the place we booked for the night, Kollu. Isn’t it pretty?” Her husband leaned forward. “That’s right. You’ll be able to rest very quietly here.” Within half an hour, they had tucked into the best part of a pot of chicken curry and gone to their room upstairs to gently burp and gurgle their prenatal intimacies. By the time I got to the cafeteria, it was empty, except for the creepy-crawlies on the wall and one sulky waiter massaging his neck. “Dinner put.” He pointed at the curry pot and the basin of boiled rice. He was more suited to the job of a traffic policeman, one of the automaton types we used to have before we modernized into a mania for red-amber-green multispots.

Paragraph 2:
As I drive my taxi down the winding roads, I glance in the rearview mirror to see Mrs. Arunachalam clutching her belly, her face etched with discomfort. She's seven months pregnant, and I can tell she's not enjoying the bumpy ride. "Vasantha, please slow down," she asks for what feels like the hundredth time, her voice laced with a hint of desperation. I oblige, easing off the gas pedal as her husband, seated beside her, gives me a sympathetic smile. He's the one who's insisted on making this journey to Jaffna, eager to show his wife a property he's planning to buy. I wonder if it's really necessary, given her condition, but I keep my thoughts to myself. As we pull up to a hotel festooned with flags and streamers, Mrs. Arunachalam's eyes light up, and her husband reassures her that she'll be able to rest soon. After they've eaten a meal of chicken curry, they retire to their room, leaving me to grab a bite in the cafeteria. The only person there is a waiter, who stands stiffly, his eyes fixed on some point in the distance. He reminds me of an old-fashioned traffic policeman, his demeanor a perfect blend of sternness and servility. I watch him for a moment, fascinated by the way he seems to embody a bygone era.

Keith, a distinguished professor of geophysical sciences at the University of Chicago, had invited me to explore his controversial proposal for combating global warming: injecting sulfur dioxide into the stratosphere. As we talked, the panoramic view seemed to underscore both the audacity and the necessity of his proposed solution. Keith's stratospheric solar geoengineering concept, while contentious, offers a potential tool to reflect solar energy back into space, thereby cooling our increasingly warming planet. The conversation felt weighty with the knowledge that we were discussing not just theoretical solutions, but potential alterations to Earth's fundamental systems.

When I visited him there on a clear day this summer, the pale blue stretched from the surface of Lake Michigan up toward the edge of space. It is up there in the stratosphere that Keith, a professor in the University of Chicago’s department of geophysical sciences, wants to alter the very composition of the air. He believes that by releasing many tons of sulfur dioxide roughly 12 miles, or 20 kilometers, above the ground, it would be possible to reflect some of the sun’s energy away from Earth. Doing so would effectively turn down the planet’s thermostat, slowing down global warming. It’s an audacious gambit that’s fraught with controversy, as I wrote in an article published Tuesday morning. I had come to Chicago to talk to Keith about this proposed technology, which is known as stratospheric solar geoengineering. While it can seem like the stuff of science fiction, ambitious proposals to alter the planet’s climate are increasingly being taken seriously as the effects of global warming grow more acute.

To pry up the planks when he had nothing to offer was a small indignity he had spared the captive below. The last thing Stevick wished to do, after all, was annoy him with inessentials. Success in an endeavor like this one lay in the details. Stevick was certain he was going to do a good job.

A very long train was stopped on the tracks one afternoon, the man told George. He was walking. He had always walked to River Bar before the accident. He waited and waited for the train to move so he could cross. There was no engineer, no one in sight, and happy hour at River Bar was almost over—you get a shot and a beer for three dollars, he said. He had six bucks, and he could get a little credit from Smitty, the bartender who was working that night. He figured he’d step over the linkage between train cars, do it quickly. Why stand there getting eaten alive by tiger mosquitoes when he could be inside, under a fan, drinking with his buddies? He’d got one of his legs up over the linkage when the train lurched forward and started rolling. It picked up speed, with him trapped under it. He detailed to George what had happened next. There was a tourniquet fashioned from a shirt. A nephew of Smitty’s who worked in the emergency room. A sum he was awarded, eventually, thanks to a lawyer from Charlotte. An ex-wife who bled him of the money as if he had a hollow leg. And look, he said, I don’t have any leg. He had told this story—the bar, the train, the shirt, the lawyer, the ex-wife, the hollow leg—probably eight hundred times. River Bar was a shack painted sky blue, with a dark, open doorway. It looked like the kind of outbuilding where you’d expect to find old gas cans and a lawnmower. There were voices audible from inside. People relaxing and drinking in this tiny shed. The man thanked George for the ride and got out of the car and started crutching. At the entrance, he shouted, “Honey, I’m home!”

Paragraph 2:
He tells George the story as he's told it countless times before, his voice carrying the weight of both familiarity and lingering regret. That fateful evening, he'd been trying to make it to River Bar for happy hour, spotting what seemed like a perfectly still train blocking his path. The decision to climb between the cars proved catastrophic when the train suddenly lurched into motion, catching him in its merciless grip and ultimately claiming his leg. The memory remains crystal clear: the excruciating pain, the quick thinking that led him to fashion a tourniquet from his own belt, and the fortunate arrival of Smitty's nephew who happened to be nearby. The legal battle that followed brought him a decent settlement, though he never saw much of it – his ex-wife managed to claim most of the money, adding financial injury to his physical wounds. As he recounts these events, their car pulls up to River Bar, a humble establishment that's become something of a second home to him over the years. The irony isn't lost on him that the place he was so desperate to reach that day has remained a constant in his life, despite everything that happened. Thanking George for the ride, he pushes open the car door and makes his way into the bar with practiced ease, his entrance marked by his customary greeting, "Honey, I'm home!" – a cheerful declaration that somehow manages to encompass both the tragedy and resilience of his story.

It was just another evening in our household, full of laughter, tears, and the occasional dose of chaos.

Paragraph 2:
Connie pursed her lips at her middle child. “Momma, please,” he said. “A bath’ll take too long.” Bull came out of the other bedroom, already in his sweats and an old Tacoma Dome T-Shirt. Even at home, comfortable, he moved like a cocked hammer on a single-action revolver. “We don’t waste water in this house,” Connie said. “So unless you plannin’ to take one of your brothers in there with you—bath.” Bull made himself a plate from the fridge. He eyed the three pecan pies on the counter as he filled another Mickey D’s cup with water. Connie caught him looking. “I’ll bring home whatever pie’s left,” she said. “You cook more for the church than you do for this damned house,” Bull said. The room was silent. Connie ignored Bull and turned to her bedraggled youngest son—sweat and dirt on his face, my juice staining his peach-fuzz mustache, lint in his short hair. She picked out some of the lint. “Now you desperately need a bath,” she said. Isaac was still scheming on a shower, and Pops read his mind. “You know that li’l Mitchell girl don’t care if you shower,” Pops said. “She’d sniff your jockstrap after football practice.” “Lonnie!” Connie glared at her brother. “That’s vile. Don’t bring that talk in my house.” Bull took the hot sauce out of the cabinet, slammed it shut, and carried his food into the living room. Sinking into the couch, he kicked his feet up on the coffee table and turned the TV on, “SportsCenter” playing loud. He doused his plate with Louisiana, then put the sauce bottle on the coffee table without a top. Connie couldn’t let that go. “At least put the top on, Terrance,” she said. Bull screwed the top on the hot sauce without looking over. “Thank you,” Connie said. “And, baby, could you please turn that down.” Apparently, that was too much. Bull turned the TV off and threw the remote onto the couch, then carried his plate into their bedroom and slammed the door. Connie turned to my pops. “O.K. What happened at work?” she asked. Isaac slapped me light on the back of the head as he stood up and I got up and started to leave with him. Iz rose, bleary-eyed, and followed us. As I passed my pops, he reached over the back of his chair and put me in a headlock over his shoulder, nuzzling me like a cub. “You right, Apples,” Pops said to Connie. “I forgot to tell you—we caught young Simba at the offices.” I thought I was too old for his play tousling, but when his two-day beard tickled my ear and neck I laughed so hard my tired body floated in it.

Paragraph 1:
James hates the feeling that she knows everything about him. The lace curtains thickly shrouding the window on the stairs suddenly seem stifling—he wants to fight through them, to get to air. He has sisters, but they are older than he is and both married now. Even when they were at home, they would never have been idling around in their nightclothes at eleven in the morning; they would have been at work for hours already, in the kitchen or turning out the lodgers’ rooms, with their sleeves rolled up and coarse aprons tied over their clothes. He has never been anywhere like Ellen Pearson’s bedroom before. Heavy curtains are still pulled across the windows, and the beds aren’t made. The air is musky, as if the girls have been spraying scent, and there’s a stuffy smell, too, of crumpled sheets and bodies hot from sleep. The water in the basin is scummed with soap. Ellen is standing to look at her reflection where one curtain has been dragged back to let the light in, mirror held up in one hand and a swansdown puff in the other. Motes of her face powder spin in a yellow beam of sunshine. She cries out when James steps into the room, letting the mirror fall onto the thick Turkish carpet, where it doesn’t break. There’s another mirror set in the door of a massive wardrobe, its bevelled edge reflecting darts of light around the papered walls. Ellen is taller and heavier than he remembered, though she is only seventeen, not as old as Connie. Her apricot-colored wrap is trimmed with lace flounces. As James takes her in, the beam of light is extinguished abruptly, and a squall of rain blows against the windowpane. He would never have come up if he’d known it was their bedroom. He was thinking Connie was going to show him into some sort of upstairs drawing room: who knew how they arranged the rooms in a house like this, with so many to spare? “Jimmy called to see you,” Connie says, coming in behind him. Ellen is blushing. She pleads with Connie, “But we’re not ready!” “I only came to say goodbye,” he says.

Paragraph 2:
James stood awkwardly in the unfamiliar setting of Ellen Pearson's bedroom, a space that emitted a heavy, musky atmosphere, filled with the scent of perfume and the remnants of sleep. The room was dimly lit by heavy curtains that blocked out the daylight, creating an ambiance that sharply contrasted with the bright, orderly environment he was accustomed to with his industrious sisters. Ellen, a seventeen-year-old girl, was visibly caught off guard when James entered the room unannounced, causing her to fumble and drop a small mirror onto the plush carpet. Her surprise was evident, and she seemed embarrassed and unprepared for his unexpected visit. As she hastily tried to regain her composure, Connie, another character, stepped into the room and casually informed Ellen that James, whom she referred to as "Jimmy," had come to see her. The use of "Jimmy" felt overly familiar to James, adding to his discomfort in this setting where everything seemed out of place. He shifted uneasily, clarifying that he was only there to say goodbye, not wanting to linger any longer than necessary in this awkward scenario. The situation highlighted the stark differences between James's experiences and the current setting, where Ellen's casual demeanor and the disarray of her room contrasted sharply with the orderly, purposeful life he was used to. James's memories of his sisters, always busy and efficient, underscored the discomfort he felt in this space that seemed to encapsulate a world so different from his own. The unexpectedness of the encounter left Ellen flustered, and James, feeling out of place, was eager to extricate himself from the situation. The atmosphere was thick with unspoken words and unexpressed emotions, capturing the essence of teenage awkwardness and the complexities of navigating unfamiliar territories. As James prepared to leave, the room seemed to close in around him, its messy intimacy a stark reminder of the unpredictability of life and the challenging dynamics of personal relationships. In the end, the visit was a reminder to James of the vast differences in people's lives, and he left with a sense of relief and a deeper understanding of the world beyond his own experiences.

Paragraph 1:
She was in the middle of vacuuming when she noticed Roy through the window, standing motionless in her front yard with something cradled in his arms. After switching off the vacuum's persistent hum, she opened the door to find him holding Curtains, her children's beloved dog, now lifeless and limp in his embrace. Roy's face was etched with remorse as he explained how he'd accidentally hit the dog with his truck, his voice trembling slightly with each word. As he spoke, she found herself reaching out to touch his forearm, a gesture of reassurance that surprised even her, while trying to place his familiar-seeming face in her memory, though she knew they'd never met before. Despite his obvious financial struggles, evidenced by his worn clothing and weathered appearance, Roy fumbled with his wallet, insisting on compensating her for the loss while admitting he only had sixteen dollars to his name. The moment hung between them, heavy with the weight of unexpected tragedy and the strange intimacy of shared grief between strangers.

Paragraph 2:
It was then that she saw Roy. What was he holding? She shut off her vacuum by yanking the plug from the wall. She opened the door. “Hello.” “Hello.” “I’m afraid I’ve killed someone’s dog.” “Yes,” she confirmed. “That’s Curtains. He belongs to my children.” “Curtains?” “It’s an old story.” And then, looking at the animal again, “Oh, dear.” She reached out and took the dog’s body from Roy and, for one moment, like an uninspired actor in the uninspired film her husband and children were just then watching, she brushed the skin of Roy’s forearm. She held his eyes, trying to remember if they’d met before. “Poor Curtains.” They had never met. Roy hoped. Maybe she’d wanted the dog dead for some reason. Maybe she’d grown tired of feeding him or accidentally petting those tumorous lumps that old dogs get. “I’m sorry.” Roy shook his chin. “He appeared out of nowhere. I didn’t even have an instant to brake. I’m sorry. Let me give you some money for a new dog.” He reached for his wallet. He was broke. “What does a dog cost?” There was sixteen bucks in his wallet.

Paragraph 1:
Jack and Bertie found themselves grappling with their apparent paralysis regarding Lisa's ongoing medical situation, as they watched her struggle through the aftermath of her initial surgeries. The doctor's recommendation to wait before pursuing additional procedures seemed both a blessing and a curse, with the remaining settlement money carefully set aside for these future interventions. Jack couldn't help but remember the day he'd donated his own skin for Lisa's surgeries, a decision made after discovering his tissue was more compatible than Bertie's. The sight of Lisa now, confined mostly to her room, heavily medicated against the persistent pain, and withdrawn from school, weighed heavily on both of them. Bertie, ever the pragmatist with her belief in the healing power of purpose and self-improvement, had pushed Lisa to seek employment, resulting in her current position at a telemarketing firm. Despite her disfigurement, which they had taken to referring to simply as being "bitten" – a euphemism that barely scratched the surface of her trauma – Lisa had managed to secure and maintain this job, though it clearly took everything she had to do so. Bertie maintained an almost forcefully positive attitude about the situation, constantly encouraging Lisa and celebrating small victories, while Jack found himself lost in thoughts about the unsuspecting people on the other end of Lisa's phone calls. He often wondered what they might imagine when they heard her altered voice, or how they would react if they knew the true extent of her condition. The reality of her situation, hidden behind the anonymous nature of telemarketing, seemed to Jack both a mercy and a cruel reminder of how much their lives had changed. The delicate balance between pushing Lisa toward recovery and protecting her from further trauma remained a constant source of tension, with Jack and Bertie sometimes questioning whether their current approach of cautious waiting was truly the best course of action, even as they understood the medical necessity of this holding pattern.

Paragraph 2:
It would have been easy. Jack was artistic (everyone said so), and Bertie had balls. But, in the end, they’d never done a thing; never called a TV station or decorated a coffee can with ribbons and a picture of Lisa’s face. Never took the case back to court—even though it was clear, after the initial surgeries, that Lisa would require more. The procedures couldn’t be rushed, though. The doctor had recommended that Lisa wait before going back under the knife: “Too much trauma already. Let’s see how the current work heals.” What little remained of the settlement money was kept in a separate account, like a vacation fund or a Christmas club, some perverse dowry. Money for the future, earmarked for surgery. Jack had helped, at some point, hadn’t he? Standing at the edge of the alley, he scratched his leg—a vague recollection that he’d given Lisa some of his own skin. It had been more compatible than Bertie’s. In the fall, Lisa had refused to go back to school for her junior year. She mostly stayed inside, in her bedroom. There was a lot of pain medication—which was apparently, Jack learned, something to be shared. “I’m in pain, too,” Bertie had cried, defensively, when he caught her one night with the bottle. “Anyway,” she chided, changing the subject, “your sister can’t live in a fog for the rest of her life. She needs to get a job.” Jack didn’t understand why a person in Lisa’s position couldn’t be allowed to stay inside, in a dark bedroom, for the rest of her life. Bertie had a thing, though, about self-improvement and positive thinking, which often made her children shrink from her as if she were a terrorist. Amazingly, Lisa had found a job fairly quickly, full time at a telemarketing firm. “You see,” Bertie had chirped. “Up and at ’em,” practically shoving Lisa out the door, her hair strategically feathered over her cheeks. “Minimum wage,” Lisa said, and Bertie replied that there was no shame in that. All day, Lisa had sat in a cubicle, talked on the phone in her new, funny voice. But maybe, thought Jack, the people his sister called just assumed she had a toothache, or an accent. No one on the phone would have known that his sister was a high-school dropout in Tucson—or that she’d been mutilated. That was a word no one had used—not the doctors or Lisa’s friends or even the truth-obsessed women from Bertie’s so-called church. No one ever said maimed, destroyed, ruined. Bitten, people preferred to say, modestly, as if Lisa’s misfortune had been the work of an ant, or a fly.

If you entered into the marriage without committing to your partner unconditionally and for life? That could count as “partial simulation” with respect to the property of marital indissolubility and permanence. The same goes for someone entering into marriage without internally forswearing infidelity, and some Catholic authorities say, in this context, that viewing pornography is equivalent to infidelity. The point is that your cousin might well be able to find grounds that didn’t radically mischaracterize the nature of the marriage.

This fundamental principle establishes that an annulled marriage was essentially void from its inception, rather than becoming invalid over time. The concept of "partial simulation" emerges as a significant factor, where entering marriage without complete commitment or harboring intentions of infidelity can constitute grounds for annulment. Notably, some Catholic authorities extend the definition of infidelity to include pornography consumption. In this particular case, the ethicist suggests that the cousin may have legitimate grounds for pursuing an annulment without compromising the truthful representation of the marriage's original circumstances.

Last year, 422 cases of invasive meningococcal disease were reported in the United States, the highest number since 2014, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But as of Monday, 143 cases have been reported to the C.D.C. so far this year, 62 more than the number of cases reported last year during the same period. The illness is extremely dangerous. Even with appropriate treatment, 10 to 15 percent of patients who develop meningococcal disease will die. Many recent cases were caused by an unusual strain of N. meningitidis called ST-1466. Survivors of meningococcal disease may be left with long-term disability, deafness, amputations or brain damage.

Paragraph 1:
Chris tripped over a pile of saucepans, Susan caught him, and after this they made their way around the house together, Chris hanging onto Susan’s arm, Susan and Amanda holding hands, unclasping to sticker anything they wanted. None of them were in the habit of touching. All of them—even Amanda, who had lovers—were rather fastidiously inhibited in their ordinary lives. Amanda was prodigal with red stickers. Chris put a yellow one on a Pembroke table that he might use to write on. Susan succumbed to a nineteen-thirties Parisian hatbox and a pair of Chinese ivory masks. “Those masks are nice,” Amanda said, jealous. “Clever you, I didn’t notice them.” Smitten momentarily with cupidity, Susan wouldn’t give them up; she put them in her bag, saving her pleasure in them for exploring later. At the door to Vivien’s bedroom, Amanda halted and the others crowded against her, breathing in one another’s heat and freshness, aftershave and wool, shampoo: they were middle-aged, but still clean and competent, at least. Here, too, everything had been pulled out of drawers and cupboards. All their eyes were drawn to where, beside the single bed with crumpled sheets, no one had cleared away a last cigarette, crushed out, slovenly, in a jam-jar top. None of them mentioned it. It might have belonged to whoever had made the inventory, but it might also have been Vivien’s.

Paragraph 2:
Moving through the dimly lit house, Chris stumbled slightly, prompting Susan to steady him with a gentle hand as they continued their solemn task of marking inheritances with colored stickers. Susan's other hand remained intertwined with Amanda's, an unusual display of affection between the typically reserved pair that seemed warranted by the weight of the moment. Amanda moved with purpose, confidently placing red stickers on various items that caught her eye, while Chris carefully affixed a yellow marker to an elegant Pembroke table that had always drawn his attention. Susan's selections revealed her refined taste – a delicate Parisian hatbox and a pair of Chinese ivory masks that made Amanda's eyes linger with barely concealed desire. When they reached Vivien's bedroom, all three halted instinctively at the threshold, taking in the scattered belongings and disheveled sheets. Their gazes collectively settled on a crushed cigarette resting in a makeshift ashtray fashioned from a jam-jar top, but none dared to speculate about its last user. In this shared silence, the trio found themselves bound together in an intimate understanding that transcended their usual emotional boundaries, each lost in private thoughts about the life that had once filled these rooms.

Paragraph 1:
As I walked back into the living room, I was immediately enveloped in the warmth and comfort of family conversation. My mother was holding court, regaling both me and my sister-in-law, Joanne, with stories of my birth and childhood. I settled into the couch, a mixture of amusement and embarrassment washing over me as my mother recounted the tale of my arrival into the world. Apparently, I was an easy birth, but my infancy was a different story altogether - I was a colicky, fussy baby who kept my parents up all hours of the night. My mother chuckled as she recalled the sleepless nights and endless diaper changes, and I couldn't help but laugh along with her. She also waxed poetic about the differences between raising boys and girls, claiming that girls were far easier to manage, much to Joanne's amusement. As I listened to my mother's reminiscences, I found my mind beginning to wander, drifting back to a moment of quiet contemplation I'd experienced recently. I'd been on a train, sipping a drink and lost in thought, when I noticed a woman sitting across from me, her eyes closed and a soft smile on her face. The gentle rocking of the train and the soft hum of the engine had created a sense of warmth and tranquility, and I'd felt my worries and cares melting away as I gazed at this peaceful stranger. But the tranquility of that moment was short-lived, as my thoughts were soon interrupted by the demands of the present. I was at work, sitting at my desk and staring blankly at my computer screen, when I was struck by the sudden realization that I missed my colleague Sam. He was out of the office, and his absence was palpable. Just then, his wife Dvera appeared in the doorway, her eyes red-rimmed and puffy. I felt a jolt of concern as I took in her distraught expression, and my mind began racing with worst-case scenarios. But as she approached me, I realized that I was also navigating a complex web of racial dynamics - a white woman crying in my presence, and the implications that came with it. I felt a sense of trepidation as I asked her if everything was okay, but to my surprise, she apologized for her tears, explaining that she'd been moved by hearing certain words that had touched her heart. As I listened to her explanation, I felt a sense of relief wash over me, and I was grateful that the situation had been defused. It was a small moment, but one that had highlighted the complexities and nuances of human interaction - and the ways in which we navigate the world, both within our families and beyond.

Paragraph 2:
When I returned to the living room, my mother was saying, “Now, he”—and she pointed at me—“wasn’t too much trouble comin out, but, oh, your husband was too much, Joanne. Two days. Two long days. I’m bound for Heaven cause I’ve had my hell right here in Washington, D.C. But I will say”—and she pointed to me again—“that he made up for that easy birth by havin his share a colic. And, when he slept, he slept kinda like this,” and my mother leaned her head to the side with one eye open and one eye shut. “I had to keep one eye on you,” I said. She didn’t miss a beat: “I hope you still sleep that way cause I ain’t finished with you yet, boy. Just wait. Just you wait.” Then to Joanne: “You see what war does? It makes a man lose all natural fear of his mother. Be thankful you havin girls.” I sat back in the chair with my Kool-Aid. They went on talking like that, my mother and my sister-in-law and her twin girls just dying to come out. There is a moment that a man hungers for when he’s boozing—the conductor has already escorted him to the best seat on the train. This happens somewhere, depending on the alcohol, along about the fifth sip. The view from that window is extraordinary; God knew his business that day. A woman sits across from him and only when he looks out the window does she look away. Otherwise, her eyes are always on him. Her blouse is tight and she shows just enough cleavage not to make herself out to be a tramp. He takes another sip, and emphatic waves of warmth come over him. The woman crosses her legs. She is not wearing old-lady stockings. Hers are sheer nylon, so the man can bear witness to the miracle of her legs. He raises his glass and tries to decide whether to look again at her legs or out the window at what God made just for him. I went in to the office on Monday morning to continue clearing up. I was missing Sam, who had soothing words for every bad occasion. I worked away and all the while recited aloud the dead white woman’s words. A moll is gav vain ah rav und ah rabbit sin. Zetcha kender lock gadank za tire vos ear lair rent doe. I was nearing completion of the “S” files when I felt someone watching me. I turned around. Sam’s wife, Dvera, was standing in the doorway. She was crying. I stood and asked if it was bad news about Sam. She took a while, but she eventually shook her head and covered her mouth with both hands. She continued to cry. I stayed near the window. This was all I needed before Alaska: a white woman crying and no witnesses to my innocence. After several minutes, she pulled out a handkerchief that was tucked into her sleeve, and she stopped crying. “I’m sorry,” she said. “It’s been a long time since I heard those words.” I didn’t understand. I looked at the floor, but felt safe enough to put down the papers I was holding.

Paragraph 1:
They walked back to camp, and Layton veered off as they got close, so they came from different angles. They said nothing, and her father and Harry asked nothing. Sam thought they must have heard the shots, but she figured it could have been Layton shooting alone. She had hit quarters propped in the tree bark, and made a smiley face in a piece of paper. In the pocket of her shorts, she carried an exploded hollow-point, which Layton said wasn’t legal to buy anymore, and a warped quarter. Layton slipped the folded smiley face into the camp garbage bag, and told Harry he didn’t think there were pheasants out here at all. Sam’s father was making enchiladas in a Dutch oven, and chipping ice for margaritas with a pick. He made one without tequila for Sam. Layton asked for a virgin, too—alcohol made him nauseated since the work in the lab—and got out a little stereo with batteries. Sam’s father said it would ruin the silence of nature, but pretty soon he was dancing at the cookstove, singing along to reggae covers. It was still light, and the swallows dived in the canyon. Her father two-stepped over with a big plastic spoon and a chip full of salsa, singing in falsetto, “No you ain’t—seen—nothin’ like the Might-y Quinn.” He gave her the chip and kissed her on the forehead. Her uncle Harry had too many margaritas and started talking about the case, about those poor, sick people with their lives ruined, and the gall of the people who said they were making it up. When it got dark, he went to bed. The other three sat close around the orange coals of the fire, and her father made up blues songs on the harmonica. After a while, Layton said, “I need someone to walk on my back if I’m gonna row tomorrow. I’d ask you,” he said to Sam’s father, “but I’m guessing you weigh about two-fifty.” Her father didn’t say anything; he kept playing harmonica.

Paragraph 2:
Sam and Layton approached their camp from separate directions, both maintaining a casual demeanor despite the earlier gunshots that echoed through the area, and neither her father nor Uncle Harry seemed inclined to question the sounds. Sam's fingers absently traced the hollow-point bullet and warped quarter in her pocket, silent reminders of her impressive shooting practice where she'd managed to hit quarters and create a perfect smiley face on paper. Layton, ever discrete, had already disposed of the telling target with the smile. He made a casual comment about the lack of pheasants in the area, smoothly deflecting any potential questions. The camp buzzed with activity as Sam's father immersed himself in preparing enchiladas and mixing margaritas, thoughtfully crafting alcohol-free versions for both Sam and Layton, the latter's abstinence stemming from his previous lab work experiences. The atmosphere lightened considerably when reggae music filled the air, and despite his initial reluctance, Sam's father found himself swept up in the rhythm, dancing and singing along. The evening took a slightly serious turn when Uncle Harry, loosened by one too many margaritas, shared details of a troubling case before retreating to his tent for the night. The remaining trio gathered around the crackling fire, creating their own melody as Sam's father played his harmonica. The night wound down with Layton's playful request for someone to walk on his back, accompanied by a knowing glance at Sam's father and a humorous implication that he might be too heavy for such a task.

Paragraph 1:
Before Covid, scientists estimated the effectiveness of the influenza vaccine by comparing the vaccination status of those who tested positive for flu with those who did not. But now, with vaccines for Covid and respiratory syncytial virus in the mix, the calculations are no longer simple. Patients turn up at clinics and hospitals with similar symptoms, and each vaccine prevents those symptoms to a different degree. An accurate estimate of effectiveness will be crucial for designing each season’s vaccine, and for preparing doctors and patients to face a rough respiratory season. In 2021, for example, the University of Michigan experienced an outbreak of influenza. When the researchers worked out that the season’s vaccine didn’t protect against that strain, they were able to warn other college campuses to prepare for clusters in their dorms, and hospitals to stock up on antiviral drugs. Solving the problem may itself pose complications, because different divisions at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention work on influenza, Covid and other respiratory diseases. “It requires problem-solving across these sort of artificial lines of different departments,” Dr. Martin said.

Paragraph 2:
Estimating vaccine effectiveness amidst multiple respiratory viruses, such as influenza, Covid, and respiratory syncytial virus, presents significant complexities for scientists and healthcare providers. These challenges are compounded by overlapping symptoms and the varying degrees of protection offered by each vaccine. For instance, during an influenza outbreak at the University of Michigan in 2021, researchers found the season's vaccine ineffective against a specific strain. This discovery enabled them to alert other campuses and hospitals, showcasing the critical need for timely and accurate assessment of vaccine performance. Dr. Martin, a key figure in this narrative, emphasizes the importance of cross-departmental collaboration at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to effectively tackle these issues. He advocates for a more integrated approach that combines expertise from various fields to enhance the understanding and management of vaccine effectiveness. This collaborative effort is essential to navigate the intricacies of respiratory viruses and ensure that public health responses are both swift and effective, ultimately safeguarding communities from the unpredictable nature of viral outbreaks.

In the heart of Ballard, a Seattle neighborhood, a culinary institution has withstood the test of time. Mike's Chili Parlor, a humble eatery, has been serving its signature dish since the 1920s, when Greek immigrant Mike Semandiris began selling chili to hungry maritime workers. Over the years, the business has evolved, relocating to a brick building that has become a local landmark. Despite numerous buyout offers from developers, Mike's has remained a family-owned operation, with the founder's great-grandson now at the helm. Today, patrons can still enjoy a hearty bowl of chili paired with a cold beer. The parlor's enduring presence is a testament to the neighborhood's rich history, even as newer establishments like Secret Savory and Rupee Bar bring diverse flavors to the area, underscoring Ballard's reputation as a vibrant and eclectic culinary destination.

Paragraph 2:

The Chili, as it’s known, soon moved to a brick building two blocks away, where it remains, having turned down handsome buyout offers from developers in recent decades. Today’s Mike (Mr. Semandiris’s great-grandson) still serves jalapeño-, cheese- and minced-onion-topped chili bowls ($7 for regular size, $19 for the “big-ass” version) alongside ice-cold pours of Rainier beer ($6 pint, $15 pitcher; cash only, A.T.M. on site, 21 and over). For a more updated dining experience, Secret Savory, a Thai bar and restaurant, and Rupee Bar, a Sri Lankan-focused eatery that won a James Beard Award for design, are two newer establishments that show off the modern-day breadth of Ballard’s culinary scene.

Paragraph 1:
I've been questioning my grip on reality ever since I saw my mother standing in our front yard last month, which would have been perfectly normal if she hadn't passed away three years ago. At first, I dismissed it as grief playing tricks on my mind, but then other spectral figures started appearing throughout the neighborhood, making me realize I wasn't alone in these supernatural encounters. The weekly safety meetings at the community center have become a theater of the absurd, where my neighbors, particularly this one man about five years my senior, advocate for solutions that sound more like medieval torture scenarios than practical security measures. He passionately argues for public executions while others nod in agreement, their faces illuminated by a twisted sense of justice. It's almost comical how they romanticize their immigrant ancestors, spinning tales of their unwavering honesty and dignity, conveniently forgetting the documented instances of corruption and misconduct that pepper our town's historical records. I force myself to attend these meetings, not out of solidarity but pure necessity – I need to know when they're planning to barricade streets or install new security systems that might affect my daily routine. Last month, they mounted a surveillance camera on my house without even asking, claiming it was for the "greater good." The irony is that while the camera is now broken, it did capture footage of two attempted break-ins before giving up the ghost, so to speak. The neighborhood has become a strange mix of paranormal activity and paranoid security measures, with everyone seeing threats both earthly and otherworldly around every corner. Sometimes I wonder if the ghosts are more reasonable than the living, as they silently observe our descent into collective hysteria. The crime statistics may be rising, but our response seems increasingly unhinged, transforming what was once a typical suburban community into something that feels like a cross between a ghost story and a dystopian novel.

Paragraph 2:
The interesting thing was what started to happen in the neighborhood. Eventually, I realized that I wasn’t crazy—I’d considered the possibility, as anyone would after seeing her dead mother climbing the stairs—and I also realized that my mother wasn’t the only ghost. My neighbors have “safety” meetings. They don’t accomplish much. There have been break-ins around the neighborhood, some violent muggings, an old lady beaten. It’s awful. But the neighbors are even worse. They go to those meetings and yell about how they pay their taxes (which is only partly true—they evade everything they can, like most middle-class Argentineans) and how they’ve bought guns and are taking classes in how to use them. And they describe the actions they think the police should take: humiliation, medieval torture, an eye for an eye, that kind of thing, even execution. There’s one man I don’t know, a little older than me, who declares that the police should display the heads of these “illegals” on stakes, as in colonial days. The others don’t contradict him; they don’t even roll their eyes. All the meetings end with them recalling their grandparents, such good people, those European immigrants who arrived with nothing but the shirts on their backs, who came to find honest work, who were poor but dignified, who were white. Just another myth. The immigrants of that era were, in many cases, petty thieves; others were anarchists running from the police, and most of them became dishonest traders who prioritized earning money over assuming any kind of ethical responsibility. But I don’t argue anymore, if I ever did. I’m resigned to that world view they all share. It’s a lie, but arguing against a credible lie is a task for titans. I go to the meetings because I want to know what they’re planning. I want to know beforehand if they’re going to close off the street, for example. One time, they installed an alarm system unbeknownst to me, and I accidentally set it off when I leaned against a door to check my phone messages. They also mounted a camera on my house without my permission, but I have to admit the thing has been helpful. At least it lets me see if someone is trying to pick the lock, which has already happened, in fact, several times. The camera is broken now, and I haven’t found the time to fix it.

Paragraph 1:
Kromer couldn’t operate hedonism but these days it operated him, in the way that a punctuated cylinder operates a player piano. What he knew came mostly from books—Anaïs Nin, William S. Burroughs, “The Hite Report,” stuff gleaned as a teen-ager from his parents’ shelves. Yet, in his current circle of Manhattan friends, who were mostly graduate students and legal proofreaders, Kromer played the role of satyr. The more he protested that it was only a single heroin-laced cigarette that had happened to be placed in his hand, or that his so-called threesome had consisted of scarcely more than heavy petting and a brush with sleep apnea, the more they looked to Kromer as their saint of degeneracy. Kromer’s reputation had its origin in the parties he was dragged to by a former schoolmate: a raven-haired, baggy-eyed heiress named Greta. Though these parties were invariably disappointing, Greta invariably closed them down. When a host was reduced to switching off lights and hinting that the sofa wasn’t available, Greta took Kromer on her finishing rounds, often in the rain. Kromer worked nights, so the hours didn’t bother him, and he had nothing else to do. Greta’s legacy, a large trust fund she wasn’t permitted to touch until her thirtieth birthday, drove her mad with the determination to die squalorously before she became wealthy. “Hell, I’ve been in three kinds of threesome,” she once told Kromer, her lips tremulous and her eyes fixed on some dreamy distance, in a way that made her look as if she were on the brink of tears or insane laughter, but in fact indicated that she hadn’t slept for two or three days. “With two boys, with two girls, and with a couple. The only kind I can’t ever be in is the kind I’d really like—three men.” Greta was, in her desultory way, the real thing. The difficulty was an uncoöperative world, slouching through a new propriety under Clinton. Everyone else Greta knew had been molesting their trust funds since prep school. That was the problem—they were responsible to their money, while Greta waged war on hers.

Paragraph 2:
Kromer had long since given up trying to convince his Manhattan social circle that their perception of him as a libertine was greatly exaggerated, as his association with Greta, the notorious trust fund rebel, had cemented his reputation beyond repair. While his friends whispered about his supposed escapades at elite gatherings, the truth was far more nuanced, though his frequent appearances at Greta's infamous parties didn't help matters. Greta herself had become something of a legend among the upper echelons of Manhattan society, a wealthy heiress who, despite her future millions waiting in trust until her thirtieth birthday, seemed determined to experience every possible form of debauchery and squalor before claiming her inheritance. Her exploits, particularly her various romantic entanglements and threesomes, had become the stuff of cocktail party gossip, though she remained perpetually unsatisfied, always seeking some elusive experience that continued to evade her grasp. Unlike her trust fund peers, who typically followed predictable paths of privilege and propriety, Greta appeared to wage a personal war against both her inherited wealth and societal expectations, choosing instead to embrace a lifestyle that scandalized the very social class she was born into. Her relationship with Kromer, while platonic, served as a convenient vehicle for both their reputations - his as an unwitting hedonist and hers as the rebellious heiress determined to experience life's grittier aspects before her millions could cushion her fall. The irony wasn't lost on either of them that while Greta actively sought to distance herself from her wealthy background, her very ability to choose such a lifestyle was itself a privilege, though this paradox seemed to fuel rather than diminish her determination to live life on her own terms, regardless of the social consequences or raised eyebrows at Manhattan's most exclusive gatherings.

At first, he felt a bit awkward about directing someone older than him, but she proved to be a more cooperative and willing partner than Emmanuel had been. What struck him most was that she actually listened to his responses, her eyes locked onto his as he spoke, unlike the doctors he had encountered who barely seemed to register his presence. Her fierce brow and chapped knuckles gave her a rugged, no-nonsense air, but her genuine interest in his story put him at ease. He told her about his childhood in Brighton, where his father had been a greengrocer, and the way he used to be able to see the sea from his bedroom window. The memory brought a smile to his face, and he felt a sense of connection to this woman that he hadn't felt with anyone in a long time. As they finished sanding, he adjusted the ladder to continue his work on the cornice, feeling a renewed sense of purpose and appreciation for the simple, human connection they had shared. The woman's attentiveness had been a balm to his soul, and he was grateful for the unexpected respite from the usual drudgery of his work.

Paragraph 2:
“Come on,” she said. “I bet you’re paid by the job, not the hour.” At first he was embarrassed telling a woman, older than him by perhaps a decade, what to do, but she turned out to be much more biddable than Emmanuel. As they finished the sanding, he on the ladder, she on foot, she lobbed questions in his direction, and despite her careless manner he sensed that she was, in fact, listening to his answers. Whereas the doctors, to a man and woman, as soon as he opened his mouth, had focussed on pencil sharpeners, radiators, doorknobs. They were paid—not enough, not by him—to barely feign attention, scribble a couple of notes, and, as quickly as possible, write a prescription that would propel him, thank God, out of their offices. But this woman, with her fierce brow, her chapped knuckles, for whatever reason, actually seemed interested. “So,” she said, folding the sandpaper onto the sanding block, “is decorating the family business? Or your heart’s desire?” “Neither.” He was longing to ask about her, so he offered himself up, a pound of apples, a fistful of bananas. “My father was a greengrocer in Brighton. Got up at four every day, except Sunday, to buy the fruit and veg. Then he worked until seven at night, hauling sacks of potatoes and chatting up housewives.” “Did you live near the sea?” she asked. “Not far. If I stood on my bed on tiptoe, there was a tiny triangle of water.” He had done this precisely once, dismayed at what the maneuver had revealed. Now he climbed down the ladder, moved it four feet, climbed back up, and started on the next stretch of cornice.

Paragraph 1:
Gilbert found himself in a predicament he had hoped to avoid, caught in the chaos of a parade that seemed to have taken over his small town. After dropping off his friend Rod at the local video store, he had planned to take a quiet side street to circumvent the main thoroughfare, where the parade was scheduled to pass. However, as luck would have it, he found himself stuck at a stubborn red light, unable to escape the festive commotion. Resigned to his fate, Gilbert watched as the parade unfolded before him, a spectacle of local charm and amateur theatrics. First to pass was a high-school marching band, the energetic cacophony of their instruments somewhat dampened by the sight of its members—sweaty and overweight kids lumbering along in ill-fitting uniforms, their enthusiasm valiantly overcoming their obvious discomfort. Behind them, two teenage boys, their faces painted and adorned in feathers, played the part of Indians, their youthful demeanor betraying the gravity of their chosen characters. The parade continued with an odd pairing of two local car mechanics, dressed in buckskin suits, their attire an attempt at historical accuracy that was undercut by the oil stains on their hands and the cheerfully anachronistic flintlocks they carried. One mechanic, clearly more spirited than the other, took a swig from a demijohn, raising it high and letting out a boisterous "Yee-haw!" that echoed down the street, eliciting laughter and cheers from the gathered crowd. As Gilbert anticipated, the full "hokey Wild West treatment" was in effect, and the parade rolled on with a troop of kids on horses, each dressed as cowboys, their hats askew and toy guns at the ready. They aimed playfully at the crowd, who responded with exaggerated gasps and delighted applause. Gilbert couldn't help but smile at the scene, the parade a testament to the town's quirky charm and the community's enduring spirit.

Paragraph 2:
The marching music, carried by the light wind, seemed nearer. “I better get goin. Don’t want a get tied up in that damn parade.” He got out, threw his chicken box at the trash can. Rod, too, tossed his crumpled box, but it hit the side of the can and sprayed chicken bones. “Forget it,” said Gilbert. “They get paid a pick up.” He dropped Rod back at the video store and headed north, thinking to beat the parade by taking a side street, but he was too late. He stopped for a red light that wouldn’t change and the parade came surging around a corner, passing in front of him, and he had to wait. A section of the high-school band straggled past, sweaty kids, many of them obese, their white marching trousers bunched at the crotch. He remembered schoolmates in his own childhood, skinny, quick ranch kids, no one fat and sweaty, Pete Kitchen looking like he was made of kindling wood and insulation wire, Willis McNitt small enough to shit behind a sagebrush and never be noticed. Behind the band came two teen-age boys dressed as Indians, breechclouts over swim trunks, a load of beads around their necks, black wigs with braids and feathers. One carried a bongo drum, striking it irregularly with his hand. Their skin had been darkened with some streaky substance. Then two men whom he recognized as Sheridan car mechanics slouched along in buckskin suits and fur hats, carrying antique flintlocks. One had a demijohn that he lifted to his lips every thirty seconds, crying “Yee-haw!” The other had a few shiny No. 2 traps over his shoulder. Gilbert could see the hardware-store price tags on them. He knew he was going to get the whole hokey Wild West treatment before he could move. Now came two horses, both bearing kids dressed as cowboys, in heavy woolly chaps, pearl-button Western shirts, limp bandannas, big hats, and boots. Both twirled guns on their fingers, aiming at friends in the crowd.

Martha had adopted Attila five years ago from a local rescue group. The process had involved two phone interviews and a home inspection. She’d also had to sign a contract promising that she would never let the rabbit outdoors; that she would not rename him (his name was Bentley at the time); that she would provide him with a quarter cup of dried food, half a cup of greens, and unlimited timothy hay each day for the rest of his life. If he expired prematurely, she was contractually obligated to inform the rescue organization within twenty-four hours. She’d complied with some but not all of those strictures. She’d renamed him immediately, in light of his relative boldness and his bad habit of biting: Attila the Bun. She had also let Attila hop around the yard, until the neighbor’s tabby had become interested. The tabby’s soft red collar had a bell inside it. It was puffy, sort of like a court jester’s, giving him an Elizabethan air. The bell was to keep him from killing birds, but Attila didn’t know enough to run from a cat. Their one interaction had been a sort of tense standoff, during which the cat’s tail flicked ominously from side to side, like a metronome. Attila hated to be picked up, but he would let you stroke his head. He was a Holland Lop, and the tips of his velvet ears rested on the ground when he was lying down. Once he could no longer go outside, he preferred the living room, where he could stretch his body almost flat on the sisal rug, his long back feet extended behind him. As a prey animal, he did this only when he was very relaxed, absolutely certain that no hawk was circling overhead, ready to lift him into the air and snap his neck.

Understanding the risks, Martha curtailed Attila's outdoor adventures to safeguard him from potential threats. Indoors, Attila developed a preference for the living room, a sanctuary where he could stretch out comfortably and feel secure. Although he had an aversion to being picked up, he was quite fond of gentle head strokes, a ritual that Martha was happy to oblige. In this shared space, Martha found joy in watching Attila's antics, while he, in turn, seemed to appreciate the serene environment she provided. Their bond, forged through mutual understanding and respect, underscored Martha's dedication to fulfilling the promises she made during the adoption process, ensuring Attila lived a life filled with comfort and care.

Paragraph 1:
That correspondence was gestural, bodily, and opened onto an opaque eloquence that had nothing to say, or at least not to me. Once that moment was past, the enthusiasts started talking again and the silence receded; they were all asking Lihn for his opinions on the most disparate issues and events, and at that point my disdain for them evaporated, because I realized that they were just as I had once been: young poets with no support, kids who’d been shut out by the new center-left Chilean government and didn’t have any backing or patronage, all they had was Lihn, a Lihn who looked not like the real Enrique Lihn as he appeared in his author photos but like a much handsomer and more prepossessing Lihn, a Lihn who resembled his poems, who had adopted their age, who lived in a building similar to his poems, and who could vanish in the elegant, resolute way that his poems sometimes had of vanishing. When I realized this, I remember, I felt better. I mean I began to make sense of the situation and find it amusing. I had nothing to fear: I was at home, with friends, with a writer I had always admired. It wasn’t a horror movie. Or not an out-and-out horror movie, but a horror movie leavened with large doses of black humor. And just as I thought of black humor Lihn extracted a little bottle of pills from his pocket. I have to take one every three hours, he said. The enthusiasts fell silent once again. A waiter brought a glass of water. The pill was big. That’s what I thought when I saw it fall into the glass of water. But in fact it wasn’t big. It was dense. Lihn began to break it up with a spoon, and I realized that the pill looked like an onion with countless layers. I leaned forward and peered into the glass. For a moment I was quite sure that it was an infinite pill.

Paragraph 2:
As I sat amidst the gathering of young poets, enveloped in the silent, gestural communication that felt foreign and unintelligible, I initially grappled with a sense of disconnection. It was as though I was observing a secret society from the outside, their interactions elusive and obscure. But as the conversation resumed, the veil of disdain I had initially worn began to lift. I saw myself reflected in these young poets—each of them, like my past self, seeking guidance and support, clinging to the charisma and wisdom of the esteemed Enrique Lihn. Lihn, in his presence, embodied a more vibrant version of himself, the very essence of his poetry emanating from him in waves. This realization brought me an unexpected comfort, transforming my perspective. What initially seemed like a scene from a horror movie morphed into something more akin to black humor, amusing rather than terrifying. The entire situation took on a new light, one of understanding and shared experience. Then came the curious moment when Lihn, with a flourish, produced a pill he was obliged to take every three hours. Its appearance fascinated me; it was dense, layered, almost infinite in its complexity as he dissolved it into water. This small act, seemingly mundane, resonated with a strange profundity. It was as if the pill symbolized the layered wisdom and experiences Lihn imparted, each layer dissolving into the next, shaping the guidance he offered to these eager, searching minds. In that moment, the gathering became not just a meeting of young poets and their mentor but a poignant reflection of the cyclical nature of artistic influence and the continuous passage of knowledge. My earlier feelings of alienation faded, replaced by a deep recognition of the shared journey we were all on, bound by the threads of creativity and the enduring influence of a guide like Lihn.

Paragraph 1:
As she rummaged through the worn suitcase, a treasure trove of memories from her travels, she couldn't help but feel a pang of longing. Her fingers danced across the contents, searching for a specific photograph, one that she had been unable to find for years - a picture of her parents. But it seemed to be nowhere to be found, lost amidst the sea of letters, notebooks, and photographs with friends that she had accumulated over the years. A sense of regret washed over her, and she couldn't shake the feeling that she had been a neglectful daughter, failing to hold onto the one tangible connection to her family's past. Yet, as she closed her eyes, she reassured herself that she could still recall their faces with vivid clarity, a fact that brought her some comfort. Just as she was starting to come to terms with this, a letter arrived toward the end of June, its distinctive envelope and stamp a clear indication of its origin. But despite her curiosity, she found herself unable to bring herself to open it, instead choosing to tuck it behind some Rwandan baskets on her bookshelf. As the days passed, she busied herself with mundane tasks - making dinner, organizing her class notes - all the while aware of the unopened letter, its presence a constant reminder of the past she was struggling to confront.

Paragraph 2:
If only she had at least a photograph of her parents. She rifled through the suitcase that had come with her through all her travels. There were letters, there were notebooks filled with words, useless diplomas, even her Rwandan identity card, with the “Tutsi” stamp that she’d tried to scratch away. There was a handful of photographs of her with her girlfriends in Burundi (which they’d had taken at a photographer’s studio in the Asian district in Bujumbura, before they parted ways, so they wouldn’t forget), there were postcards from her brother in Canada, a few pages of a diary she’d quickly abandoned, but she never did find a photo of her parents. For that, she rebuked herself bitterly. Why hadn’t she thought to ask them to have their picture taken and send her a copy? Was she a neglectful daughter? Had she forgotten them as the years went by? No, they were still there in her memory; she could call up their image anytime she liked. She sat down at her table, took her head in her hands, closed her eyes, focussed her mind, and pictured, one by one, all the faces that death might already have erased. Then, toward the end of June, she got a letter. There was no mistaking where it had come from: the red-and-blue-bordered envelope, the exotic bird on the stamp, the clumsily written address. . . . She couldn’t bring herself to open it. She put it on her bookshelf, behind the Rwandan baskets. She pretended to forget it. There were so many more urgent and more important things to do: make dinner, iron a pair of jeans, organize her class notes. But the letter was still there, behind the baskets.

Paragraph 1:
Fisher, a freelance graphic designer and reporter, lived with his girlfriend Venus and their school friends in a modest flat near a sprawling council estate. Unlike his flatmates, who held steady jobs, Fisher spent his days immersed in the world around him, a keen observer of the subtle shifts in society. Recently, he had noticed a disconcerting change in people's behavior; an eerie compliance had settled over the population. Even the most radical journalists and typically defiant opposition parties had begun to echo the government's extreme directives without question. The Prime Minister had publicly lauded this newfound national consensus, a phenomenon that left Fisher deeply unsettled. As he pondered these strange events, his gaze fell upon the glass of water on the table beside him. It was perplexingly viscid, catching the light in a way that sent an uneasy shiver down his spine. Intrigued and perturbed, Fisher leaned in for a closer examination, swirling the liquid gently and watching the way it clung to the sides of the glass. There was something undeniably unusual about it, a quality that defied his understanding. This discovery sparked a flurry of thoughts and suspicions in Fisher's mind, as he considered the possibility that this oddity in the water might be connected to the peculiar compliance he observed in society. Driven by a growing curiosity, Fisher resolved to delve deeper into this mystery, determined to uncover the truth behind the unnerving changes in both the people and the world around him.

Paragraph 2:
But it seemed to Fisher, who shared a flat on the edge of a council estate with a group of school friends, that people were changing. Fisher lived there with Venus, his girlfriend. She was a carer. Unlike most of his flatmates, he didn’t have a steady job. He did freelance graphic design and reporting. He spent the rest of his time observing, and he’d noticed that the people around him had become docile, amenable to all suggestions from the government. Even radical journalists seemed to be unusually sympathetic to the most extreme government notions. The opposition parties did not oppose anything. The unions capitulated to conditions that the companies they worked for hadn’t even demanded. Firebrand activists and comedians began spewing sentimental statements of alarming conservatism. In the midst of all this, the Prime Minister was often seen smiling. In a recent statement he had said, “It seems we are becoming a nation with a remarkable convergence of views. Dissent has all but disappeared.” No one challenged the complacency of that statement. Fisher was in his room, thinking about the strangeness of these occurrences. He was holding his last glass of water for the day. He had been unconsciously looking into the water as he thought. In that state where the mind wanders but the eye is focussed, he noticed that there was something odd about the water in his glass. It was like water, but at the same time had a viscid quality to it. What’s more, it caught the light in a faintly troubling way. He studied the water closely. Then he saw it.

The wife is like . . .” Dieter thought for a while. “What do you call this piece of material for cleaning the plates? A dishcloth, yes, dishcloth. There is a boy, about eleven, twelve,” he said quickly, eager to pass on to the main topic, “and, of course, this girl, Ruby. She has left the school, she has nothing to do but make trouble. There was a fight between her and the whores up at the brothel. Know where it is? By the G.N.R. The police look out for the girls. This fight—I heard it was really something—the whores said she ruined their business, giving it away for free.” He shifted his knees and bumped the table, then steadied it. “That is the story. Probably it isn’t true. But it is the story.” Stanton pictured the girl, her T-shirt cut off below the breasts, her fuck-you walk, the ludicrous stolen sunglasses encrusted with butterflies. Fifteen, maybe sixteen. Anemic skin and dimpled knees. Unattractive, uneducated, disabled. That hearing aid was prehistoric. “Poor bitch,” he said, and got up. He went outside to the pickup and pressed his hand against the door panel, where the sun glazed the red metal white. He drove out of the village, past the lines of orange trees that bordered the narrow pavements, past the water pump, where a bent old woman was filling plastic containers, past the small square with garish flower beds and a dark-green frog-plagued pond, and turned right after the traffic light, which was there not to control traffic (of which there was a dearth) but to raise a flag to the future. At home, he went straight to the computer, in the bedroom. All his furniture had ended up in that room, except for a couple of chairs and a stool, which were on the terrace. In his mind a correlation had grown between the emptiness of the house and the quality of his work, the sparseness of one guaranteeing the fullness of the other. He read over the last few pages on the screen, making deletions and additions and willing himself into the story. He stood up and sat back down. He set his jaw and willed himself submerged. It was hopeless. It was like deciding to commit suicide, then trying to drown with your face in the washbasin. He closed the computer and resolved to suffer no more interruptions to his mornings.

Dieter's description of Ruby as a disruptive force was evident in his tone, and Stanton couldn't help but feel a pang of pity for the girl, envisioning her as a young, unattractive, and disadvantaged soul, struggling to find her place in the world. As Stanton departed from Dieter's company, he decided to take a drive through the village, taking in the sights and sounds of the quiet streets, the fading light of day casting a warm orange glow over the thatched roofs and the bustling town square. Eventually, he returned home, intent on devoting some time to his writing, but as he sat at his desk, he found it challenging to concentrate, the emptiness of his house, which he had once believed would be conducive to creativity, now feeling like a hollow, unfulfilling space. Despite his best efforts to focus, he found his mind wandering, and the words refusing to flow, the silence and solitude that he had once craved now feeling like a hindrance to his productivity. As the hours ticked by, Stanton came to the realization that it was futile to try and force the creative process, and so, he made the decision to avoid any further interruptions to his routine, hoping that a sense of normalcy would soon be restored, and his writing would once again flourish.

Paragraph 1:
Shirlee's house was a maze of shadows and discord, with the grandmother's shuffling presence downstairs barely audible beneath the violent thumping of the fight raging above. In the bathroom's artificial glow, Shirlee meticulously applied her makeup, seemingly immune to the chaos, while Theo shifted uncomfortably in the doorway, trying not to breathe in the musty air that seemed to cling to everything in the cramped space. The sudden appearance of Shirlee's mother brought a cutting remark that sliced through the air before she disappeared again, prompting Shirlee to suggest they make their escape from the suffocating atmosphere. The summer heat hit them like a wall as they stepped outside, Shirlee already mapping their route to Lane's place for weed, her casual mention of the transaction making Theo's stomach turn. The walk was short but loaded with tension as Theo watched Shirlee approach Lane's house with practiced familiarity, her confident stride suggesting she'd done this many times before. Standing outside the peeling paint of Lane's front door, Theo's discomfort grew exponentially as she pieced together the nature of Shirlee's arrangement with him, the unspoken exchange hanging heavy in the humid air. Unable to bear the weight of her own mounting anxiety and moral conflict, Theo turned away from the house, leaving Shirlee behind without a word. The journey home became a blur of heat waves and exhaustion, her feet dragging against the scorching pavement until she finally reached her own front door. Collapsing onto the couch, her body sank into the cushions as if trying to escape the day's events, only to have Keita's voice pierce through her haze of fatigue, his words about potential pregnancy hanging in the air like storm clouds. Theo's response came as a noncommittal murmur, her mind too overwhelmed with the day's events to process the weight of his concern, while the memory of Shirlee's house, Lane's door, and her own cowardice in walking away swirled together in a nauseating mix of guilt and relief. The afternoon's heat seemed to have followed her inside, pressing down on her chest as she lay there, caught between the urge to sleep and the nagging feeling that she had abandoned her friend to a situation she didn't fully understand but instinctively knew was wrong. The sounds of the neighborhood filtered through the windows – children playing, cars passing, life continuing as normal – while Theo remained frozen on the couch, her body present but her mind still lingering outside Lane's house, wondering if she should have stayed, if she should have said something, if she should have done more than simply walk away. The possibility of pregnancy that Keita had mentioned seemed almost trivial compared to the weight of what she had witnessed and the choices she had made, yet it added another layer to the suffocating blanket of anxiety that had settled over her since leaving Shirlee's chaotic household earlier that day.

Paragraph 2:
Shirlee’s house was a shadowy place choked with listless bodies, a roaring TV, and bold roaches. Upstairs, a fight was happening, composed of what sounded like an army of boys. Shirlee’s grandmother hobbled down the hall without looking up, humming a church song. Shirlee was primping in the bathroom mirror, working patiently with her baby hairs, swirling a dollop of Ampro gel with Vaseline so that the gel wouldn’t crust up. Then, an eternity of cherry roller ball for her lips, eyeliner to make her eyes look tiny, mean, and sexy, and a beauty mark beside her mouth. Theo couldn’t understand how Shirlee could be so calm and cool in there: the room smelled strongly of piss, and the watery light from the bulb made Theo’s eyes ache. Hard-dragging footsteps were getting nearer, and the door of the bathroom swung open, causing the girls to turn. Shirlee’s mother came in with a low umph, staring them up and down. “You think you cute? You ain’t cute, bitch.” When the woman left, Shirlee threw her head back so tears wouldn’t mess up the fresh eyeliner. “Come on, girl. Let’s dip.” Theo grabbed her hand and squeezed it briefly. They walked through the hall and out the front door. The sunshine was a shock after the dim house. “We gone get some green,” she said. Theo stopped in her tracks, heart thump-thumping. “I ain’t never smoked no weed before.” “Trust me. It’s all good. We gone fly high, li’l mama.” But Theo became more and more uncertain as they went. It was getting hot, and Shirlee was walking too damn fast and too damn far; no wonder she was so skinny. Finally, they came to a brick house with green grass and a flower bed in front of a bay window. When Shirlee knocked, a big bear of a man opened the door. “Uh-uh,” Theo said, “I ain’t going in there.” “One second, Lane,” Shirlee said, sounding like she was trying to stay collected. She pulled Theo over to the side of the house. “I been knowing this nigga. He give me tat for tit.” “I ain’t doing that.” “You ain’t got to do it. I’m gone do it,” Shirlee laughed. “You staying up front.” “Girl, that’s a grown man in there.” “That boy ain’t but seventeen. Now, do you want some weed or what?” “Not if you gotta get it like that,” Theo said. “I don’t have to get it like that. I want to get it like that. That’s the difference.” Shirlee disappeared into the house; Theo sat on the couch with her legs pinched together. “This Is How We Do It” was on the stereo. After it had played four times, Theo decided that Shirlee had been gone an unreasonably long while. She began to suspect that, somewhere in that house, bear boy was showing Shirlee’s young body no slack. When Shirlee returned, Theo would remind her about the Wisconsin drifter and the danger of this kind of life style. She hadn’t heard screaming or a thump or anything like that, though, so she figured that whatever was happening was welcome. She decided to leave, but as soon as she’d locked herself outside she regretted it. The heat was suffocating. Her tongue felt like dough in the stove of her mouth. Each step seemed like her last; she fought the urge to give up and lie down in the street. Finally, her house shimmered before her like a mirage. Miraculously, she was under the awning, and her key was turning in the lock. She stumbled onto the couch. Some time passed; she could hear Keita’s voice cutting through to her consciousness. “I hope to God you’re not pregnant.” “I might be a dyke,” Theo mumbled.

She texted while doing crossword puzzles, throwing a Frisbee for their neurotic Weimaraner—even changing diapers. By now, everyone in the family probably knew. Jenny and Claire, the other bridesmaids, lived downstate, and Libby hadn’t met them before the wedding, but she could track them down. Maybe she already had. What would they think? Libby and Jenny and Claire seemed to take the price in stride; they deputized Arden to buy the dresses for them and paid her back without a squeak. And the dresses were beautiful, Thomas had to admit that. In fact, the word that came to him was “stunning.” It seemed a woman’s kind of word, so he didn’t say it, but he thought it when he saw the three women together in the church, excited, weepy, glowing in emerald-green silk that rustled as they danced attendance on their cool ivory queen. He’d been happy to admire what he hadn’t had to pay for, though he knew he’d have found the dresses less appealing if they’d cost him five hundred bills.
